                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               302.
               GLOBAL AIRCRAFT MAINTENANCE SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HE5D52EFCC7EC4687AC65A79D360E0AA2"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  FAA oversight of repair stations located outside the United States
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD76BED900D724179B14C1667CB094103"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Section 44733 of title 49, United States Code, is amended—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H377DAA0E8A014210BD1BEF350814C8D6"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        in the heading by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">
                              Inspection
                            and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">
                              Oversight
                           ;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H9F1291371B47453DAC9CF45A654945BD"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        in subsection (a) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this section, the and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">The; 
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H551F6D7A5116459DB5D0FF77CBD79C38"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        in subsection (e)—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H1D13295D4EC64098A752D37D65C49276"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           by inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                      quote-display-start="auto"
                                      quote-type="text">, without prior notice to such repair stations, after <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                      quote-display-start="auto"
                                      quote-type="text">annually;
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H92815F9686F44328AE182A795E04197B"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           by inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                      quote-display-start="auto"
                                      quote-type="text">and the applicable laws of the country in which the repair station is located after <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                      quote-display-start="auto"
                                      quote-type="text">international agreements; and
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HF64F26BEEF1642FC88B4A550C88F352A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iii)
                           by striking the last sentence and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                      quote-display-start="auto"
                                      quote-type="text">The Administrator may carry out announced or unannounced inspections in addition to the annual unannounced inspection required under this subsection based on identified risks and in a manner consistent with United States obligations under international agreements and the applicable laws of the country in which the part 145 repair station is located.;
                        
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H3A63C0A4E957472197C60A60EF746897"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        by redesignating subsection (g) as subsection (j); and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H11F44B568AF045058D7A929A313C33D4"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (E)
                        by inserting after subsection (f) the following:
                        <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                       display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       display-quotes="yes"
                                       id="HA5AA994A24F24542B88EF60F270BE8F4"
                                       style="OLC">
                           <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                        id="HCB9C8A835DF54E86ACBC900BFCEF6D74"
                                        qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (g)
                              Data analysis
                              <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H5FFC90A569FD4CFDAB932B844F16D2F4"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (1)
                                 In general
                                 Each fiscal year in which a part 121 air carrier has had heavy maintenance work performed on an aircraft owned or operated by such carrier, such carrier shall provide to the Administrator, not later than the end of the following fiscal year, a report containing the information described in paragraph (2). 
                              
                              <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H5FF158DD1DDB44A1807E9F334251AEC6"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (2)
                                 Information required
                                 A report under paragraph (1) shall contain the following:
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="HDDF7C74271474CFAB0B431296BD1B9E4"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (A)
                                    The location where any heavy maintenance work on aircraft was performed outside the United States.
                                 
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="H9211AEFEDE6945B7953D311FDA16329F"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (B)
                                    A description of the work performed at each such location.
                                 
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="HDAAABA4DD4CE4C3084084E399A80C835"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (C)
                                    The date of completion of the work performed at each such location.
                                 
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="H0B2C5D9A0D8C4848BAEE1C09B463AEC5"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (D)
                                    A list of all failures, malfunctions, or defects affecting the safe operation of such aircraft identified by the air carrier not later than 30 days after the date on which an aircraft is returned to service, organized by reference to aircraft registration number, that—
                                    <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H69CE3E67C7D04864854D34FD6AC8F91E"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                       (i)
                                       requires corrective action after the aircraft is approved for return to service; and
                                    
                                    <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H38A5D03A1301403B8860ED4CF7CB3050"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                       (ii)
                                       results from such work performed on such aircraft.
                                    
                                 
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="H91DAFEEE7ABA4512B4F13ED521AB8685"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (E)
                                    The certificate number of the person approving such aircraft or on-wing aircraft engine for return to service following completion of the work performed at each such location.
                                 
                              
                              <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HE64DC2E9A0DD4BCAAD293F725E93487F"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (3)
                                 Analysis
                                 The Administrator shall—
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="H4D5B0DEA8EFA44599564A6BDD376C16E"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (A)
                                    analyze information provided under this subsection and sections 121.703, 121.705, 121.707, and 145.221 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, or any successor provisions of such title, to detect safety issues associated with heavy maintenance work on aircraft performed outside the United States; and
                                 
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="H8A5F0A360E64410C994E7477034B44C7"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (B)
                                    require appropriate actions by an air carrier or repair station in response to any safety issue identified by the analysis conducted under subparagraph (A).
                                 
                              
                              <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H9DEBECE281ED4642843178F2D39D024B"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (4)
                                 Confidentiality
                                 Information provided under this subsection shall be subject to the same protections given to voluntarily provided safety or security related information under section 40123.
                              
                           
                           <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                        id="H75BCBF812753475CAC2A0443225CC55A"
                                        qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (h)
                              Applications and prohibition
                              <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H1B9D691D6D274DF893E9F23DD925AB94"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (1)
                                 In general
                                 The Administrator may not approve any new application under part 145 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, from a person located or headquartered in a country that the Administration, through the International Aviation Safety Assessment program, has classified as Category 2.
                              
                              <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HFADB42D6FC774C5D8E6DA21559063FE5"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (2)
                                 Exception
                                 Paragraph (1) shall not apply to an application for the renewal of a certificate issued under part 145 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
                              
                              <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HC03A040BD1DF47E1986A7D87A747CFA1"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (3)
                                 Maintenance implementation procedures agreement
                                 The Administrator may elect not to enter into a new maintenance implementation procedures agreement with a country classified as Category 2, for as long as the country remains classified as Category 2.
                              
                              <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HA3DB024B606D4CD896F43D18DF9CC131"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (4)
                                 Prohibition on continued heavy maintenance work
                                 No part 121 air carrier may enter into a new contract for heavy maintenance work with a person located or headquartered in a country that the Administrator, through the International Aviation Safety Assessment program, has classified as Category 2, for as long as such country remains classified as Category 2.
                              
                           
                           <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                        id="HDD6AFE182B0446FD95C280DBEA37E86A"
                                        qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (i)
                              Minimum qualifications for mechanics and others working on U.S. registered aircraft
                              <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HCB6D348302F64A4A86A72619BC35BC8A"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (1)
                                 In general
                                 Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this subsection, the Administrator shall require that, at each covered repair station—
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="HD3936974F6444ACA9E74DC951F85C77C"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (A)
                                    all supervisory personnel of such station are appropriately certificated as a mechanic or repairman under part 65 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, or under an equivalent certification or licensing regime, as determined by the Administrator; and
                                 
                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="H4C2411A6F3C94FC1BC66B198EAFA9007"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (B)
                                    all personnel of such station authorized to approve an article for return to service are appropriately certificated as a mechanic or repairman under part 65 of such title, or under an equivalent certification or licensing regime, as determined by the Administrator.
                                 
                              
                              <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HF95F4019669A4B0796C18C899D00D1A8"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (2)
                                 Available for consultation
                                 Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this subsection, the Administrator shall require any individual who is responsible for approving an article for return to service or who is directly in charge of heavy maintenance work performed on aircraft operated by a part 121 air carrier be available for consultation while work is being performed at a covered repair station.
                              
                           
                           .
                        
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3AC6BAF82E924F5897936185AA678EB5"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Definitions
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H0F8DFCD0E1CB456AA2497931B7342CAF"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        In general
                        Section 44733(j) of title 49, United States Code (as redesignated by this section), is amended—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H597A39766F574B43BB653C854A36B71E"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           in paragraph (1) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                      quote-display-start="auto"
                                      quote-type="text">aircraft and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                      quote-display-start="auto"
                                      quote-type="text">aircraft (including on-wing aircraft engines); 
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H7396808030D04F46B83BE3C7206A4269"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           by redesignating paragraphs (1) through (3) as paragraphs (2) through (4), respectively; and
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HCC662F2787EA46AD93A0A0EBC27796E2"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iii)
                           by inserting before paragraph (2), as so redesignated, the following:
                           <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"

                              <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HA0C92AB5C50D488081AB0EDB5A6C0F5B"

                                 Covered repair station
                                 The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                            quote-display-start="auto"

                                 <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"

                              .
                           
                        
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HBF67C04F9DC0472BB4DF6A9CFF054153"

                                   quote-display-start="auto"

                              qb-display-quote="yes">

                     Conforming amendments

                     <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"

                        .
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H584B1468009C4D6FA258F2EF9BA90E3B"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Alcohol and drug testing and background checks
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H971063AD67664BABB67684ADBCFAA304"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall issue a final rule carrying out the requirements of section 2112(b) of the FAA Extension, Safety, and Security Act of 2016 (49 U.S.C. 44733 note).
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA6A2F7AC046F47D89DF18942477BE7E3"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Rulemaking on assessment requirement
                     With respect to any employee not covered under the requirements of section 1554.101 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations, the Administrator shall initiate a rulemaking (or request that the head of another Federal agency initiate a rulemaking) that requires a covered repair station to confirm that any such employee has successfully completed an assessment commensurate with a security threat assessment described in subpart C of part 1540 of such title.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF3243A56241F4C319812C9A462DE0835"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Definition of covered repair station
                     For purposes of this subsection, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">covered repair station means a facility that—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H751E8D41CD7A497883DEC1F5FED2AB06"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        is located outside the United States;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HFB0B2D2CC83643EAB61129FA16D1EB23"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        is certificated under part 145 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE98967A8EAFB4B05B99185D64ADB7A50"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        performs heavy maintenance work on aircraft (including on-wing aircraft engines), operated under part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.

            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H80AE3319012E4564B5A9ED2E875577E9"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               304.
               TRAINING OF ORGANIZATION DELEGATION AUTHORIZATION UNIT MEMBERS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HFEB512C8056C4A06993BE139370A293C"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Unit member annual ethics training
                  Section 44736 of title 49, United States Code, is further amended by adding at the end the following:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="HC01B2272061E412CAB3279ABBD3EE014"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                  id="H5B04D83AF6534B9EB6471B01914DA427"
                                  qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (g)
                        Ethics training requirement for ODA holders
                        <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H93400A65A1904A9685BC74B2E594EE84"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (1)
                           In general
                           Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this subsection, the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration shall review and ensure each ODA holder authorized by the Administrator under section 44702(d) has in effect a recurrent training program for all ODA unit members that covers—
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HB7855D2564EA4079A86C6FD29D40FCBC"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (A)
                              unit member professional obligations and responsibilities;
                           
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HEC92E9371D414CE6BBECD17317B0A71A"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (B)
                              the ODA holder’s code of ethics as required to be established under section 102(f) of the Aircraft Certification, Safety, and Accountability Act (49 U.S.C. 44701 note); 
                           
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H63A98978A8FA4D24AC38782EF70888BF"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (C)
                              procedures for reporting safety concerns, as described in the respective approved procedures manual for the delegation;
                           
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H96D415316E124F208619FF5CD9543A56"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (D)
                              the prohibition against and reporting procedures for interference from a supervisor or other ODA member described in section 44742; and
                           
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H14AC44154BFC4D32A7A2131D46E00EE0"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (E)
                              any additional information the Administrator considers relevant to maintaining ethical and professional standards across all ODA holders and unit members.
                           
                        
                        <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H85509B83A15D4A81B3BC89BA133D4150"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (2)
                           FAA review
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HCB9CFCDB4434497FBB5EF91B9D94425B"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (A)
                              Review of training program
                              The Organization Designation Authorization Office of the Administration established under subsection (b) shall review each ODA holders’ recurrent training program to ensure such program includes—
                              <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H0AE845E41C504A21952535A611D1C64E"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (i)
                                 all elements described in paragraph (1); and
                              
                              <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H45B6F0B59F0F46479EBD5D4BA08826C7"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (ii)
                                 training to instill professionalism and clear understanding among ODA unit members about the purpose of and procedures associated with safety management systems, including the provisions of the third edition of the Safety Management Manual issued by the International Civil Aviation Organization (Doc 9859) (or any successor edition). 
                              
                           
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H06F45F7CD38C476FBF7107D46F1482EC"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (B)
                              Changes to program
                              Such Office may require changes to the training program considered necessary to maintain ethical and professional standards across all ODA holders and unit members.
                           
                        
                        <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE3674F58FC7942DAAB6B9F1E7971F12B"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (3)
                           Training
                           As part of the recurrent training program required under paragraph (1), not later than 60 business days after being designated as an ODA unit member, and annually thereafter, each ODA unit member shall complete the ethics training required by the ODA holder of the respective ODA unit member in order to exercise the functions delegated under the ODA.
                        
                        <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H4DF78433998E4490BA9AEB8812B9442B"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (4)
                           Accountability
                           The Administrator shall establish such processes or requirements as are necessary to ensure compliance with paragraph (3).
                        
                     
                     .
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HA189C123FCA44EECA6789FC68594118B"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Deadline
                  An ODA unit member authorized to perform delegated functions under an ODA prior to the date of completion of an ethics training required under section 44736(g) of title 49, United States Code, shall complete such training not later than 60 days after the training program is approved by the Administrator pursuant to such section.

            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"

               306.
               REAUTHORIZATION OF CERTAIN PROVISIONS OF THE AIRCRAFT CERTIFICATION, SAFETY, AND ACCOUNTABILITY ACT
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H720564FEC6CE4F59A010E7F785772269"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Oversight of organization designation authorization unit members
                  Section 44741 of title 49, United States Code, is amended—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA7A81A027D344948B63CFC516A336579"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     in subsection (f)(2)—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HBB46AC1D5A8F4676A4809FA69A7F6584"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        in the matter preceding subparagraph (A) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">Not later than 90 days and all that follows through <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">the Administrator shall provide a briefing and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">The Administrator shall provide biannual briefings each fiscal year through September 30, 2028; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H1F4CFDB866A749C79A84FD809BE7D8BE"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        in subparagraph (B) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">90-day period and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">6-month period; and
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H71802E206BFD44C28D5A6112708B1225"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)

                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               307.
               CONTINUED OVERSIGHT OF FAA COMPLIANCE PROGRAM
               Section 122 of the Aircraft Certification, Safety, and Accountability Act (Public Law 116–260) is amended—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H669C74FC1A314D39962BA2A71E305D7B"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  in subsection (b) by striking paragraph (2) and inserting the following: 
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="H1B9F9164C1FE4B2191FD4D211A6206D9"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HF1428D4419914C4C8FC6D6811048E895"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (2)
                        conduct an annual agency-wide evaluation of the Compliance Program through fiscal year 2028 to assess the functioning and effectiveness of such program and to assess—
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HFD1B83226CF34007822D41068FD4E32A"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (A)
                           the need for long-term metrics that, to the maximum extent practicable, apply to all program offices, and use such metrics to assess the effectiveness of the program;
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H9601D64242CC4A21A6A970ED9F646202"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (B)
                           if the program ensures the highest level of compliance with safety standards; 
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H12B92B671F9F46EFB357D2D78C92EC43"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (C)
                           if the program has met its stated safety goals and purpose; and
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H570EFEB85A1B42B59EF0083EDAAC33AD"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (D)
                           FAA employee confidence in the program.
                        
                     
                     ;

                  in subsection (d) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"

            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H8FCB9D19268F48EF93A62577892BB293"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               308.
               SCALABILITY OF SAFETY MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS
               In conducting any rulemaking to require, or implementing a regulation requiring, a safety management system, the Administrator shall consider the scalability of such safety management system requirements, to the full range of entities in terms of size or complexity that may be affected by such rulemaking or regulation, including—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H90A8181FB3FA4E30B10A5F76A0308C18"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  how an entity can demonstrate compliance using various documentation, tools, and methods, including, as appropriate, systems with multiple small operators collectively monitoring for and addressing risks;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H70BD14E941DB496CB53EDDD09900A28A"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  a review of traditional safety management techniques and the suitability of such techniques for small entities;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HAFD9F22FB9294FCD8452DB0CE131FECC"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  the applicability of existing safety management system programs implemented by an entity;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HD044957343154FD5B74EAE6D14F7CB8B"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  the suitability of existing requirements under part 5 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, for small entities; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H5099280596034BB6B8826801C6E14170"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (5)
                  other unique challenges relating to small entities the Administrator determines appropriate to consider.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H178D4F98AC424F54A3E755655C1CF3C9"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               309.
               REVIEW OF SAFETY MANAGEMENT SYSTEM RULEMAKING
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H8D7F16B069884AFEAD51C2985E38FA1D"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 60 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall review the final rule of the FAA titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Safety Management Systems and issued on April 26, 2024 (89 Fed. Reg. 33068).
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H6B3F36B17A124980975B07D7DDEF1BAD"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Applicability
                  In reviewing the final rule under subsection (a), the Administrator shall ensure that the safety management system requirement under such final rule described in subsection (a) is applied to all certificate holders operating under the rules for commuter and on-demand operations under part 135 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, commercial air tour operators operating under section 91.147 of such title, production certificate holders that are holders or licensees of a type certificate for the same product, and holders of a type certificate who license out such certificate for production under part 21 of such title.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H6E6D5020A9854819BE3039692F20C289"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Determination
                  If the Administrator determines the final rule does not apply the safety management system requirement in the manner described in subsection (b), the Administrator shall issue such regulation, guidance, or policy as may be necessary to ensure such safety management system requirement is applied in such manner.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HC0FA9A50148E4497987D3EFE52B3FCA3"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               310.
               INDEPENDENT STUDY ON FUTURE STATE OF TYPE CERTIFICATION PROCESSES
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H6F4FE86AF23547AC9068A4BE559F82BD"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Review and study
                  Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall seek to enter into an agreement with an appropriate federally funded research and development center, or other independent nonprofit organization that recommends solutions to aviation policy challenges through objective analysis, to conduct a review and study in accordance with the requirements and elements in this section. 
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H613D749086BE448EA390D6347C302137"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Elements
                  The entity carrying out the review and study pursuant to subsection (a) shall provide analyses, assessments, and recommendations that address the following elements:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H9AA1FDB916AE46C2945CCBB6E3713667"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     A vision for a future state of type certification that reflects the highly complex, highly integrated nature of modern aircraft and improvements in aviation safety.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HFEFA414F2D844A7EA4D228455C9BA114"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     An assessment of digital tools, techniques, and software systems that allow for efficient and virtual evaluation of an applicant design, associated documentation, and software or systems engineering products, including in digital 3-dimensional formats or using model-based systems engineering design techniques. 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE82327C229234A9DBD9587B7CD75B470"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     How the FAA could develop a risk-based model for type certification that improves the safety of aircraft.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H93107C6C67564B05AA43270D3EAAA6DC"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     What changes are needed to ensure that corrective actions for continued operational safety issues, including software modifications, can be approved and implemented in a timely manner while maintaining the integrity of the type certification process.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H84E19885584B4CEC86BC28C686107C8D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     What efficiencies and safety process improvements are needed in the type certification processes of the FAA to facilitate the assessment and integration of innovative technologies and advance aviation safety, such as conducting product familiarization, developing certification requirements, and demonstrating flight test safety readiness.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC85B3261D7C24F83BFB8D25FB9587D33"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     Best practices and tools used by other certification authorities outside of the United States that could be adopted by the FAA, as well as the best practices and tools used by the FAA which can be shared with certification authorities outside of the United States.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H8E470D89CAAD43888E09EE84BFC65170"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Parties to review
                  In conducting the review and study pursuant to subsection (a), the Administrator shall ensure that the entity entering into an agreement under this section shall, throughout the review and study, consult with—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HEFA8261976374B9DAF5A5DE0670B67B9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     the aircraft certification and flight standards offices or services of the Administration; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HCF45401581C94BB7B9CAB5FC9FC8BE9C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     at least 3 industry members representing aircraft and aircraft part manufacturing interests.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H5224657127074E4E8DEA61CCB1F20930"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Considerations
                  In conducting the review and study pursuant to subsection (a), the Administrator shall ensure the entity considers the availability, cost, interoperability, scalability, adaptability, cybersecurity, ease of adoption, and potential safety benefits of the elements described in subsection (b), including any digital tools, techniques, and software systems recommended to address such elements.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HA7DC0BD27E914D8684A0585E6B8F533C"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Report
                  Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the entity conducting the review and study pursuant to subsection (a) shall submit to the Administrator and the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the results of the review and study that includes—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE5B7C99931BB4EBAB4CBA70EDDB055D3"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     the findings and recommendations of the entity; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE46CED9BBA3D4DEBA598229515E5D909"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     an assessment of whether digital tools, techniques, and software systems could improve the coordination, oversight, or safety of the certification and validation activities of the FAA.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H2ACC2868D9484DC99EB3ADB66C2CA7FB"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (f)
                  Congressional briefing
                  Not later than 270 days after the report required under subsection (e) is received by the Administrator, the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H99BFA390B81B4A11935C03A7B0652E23"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     any actions the FAA proposes to take as a result of such findings and recommendations; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1797016AD0C04D4C991CA4EA790DE327"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the rationale of the FAA for not taking action on any specific recommendation, as applicable.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HCDE4301E0F4C44D093A5101C6809D42F"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               311.
               USE OF ADVANCED TOOLS AND HIGH-RISK FLIGHT TESTING IN CERTIFYING AEROSPACE PRODUCTS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H7D0D6465C40443D493B00D74DD8F10F1"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Assessment
                  Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall complete an assessment of the use of advanced tools during the testing, analysis, and verification stages of aerospace certification projects to reduce the risks associated with high-risk flight profiles and performing limit testing.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HDA6787744D8D4B4BAB7B8EB5FF7B289A"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Considerations
                  In carrying out the assessment under subsection (a), the Administrator shall consider—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4C168E3ED82A400D8959C5D4ADD68A44"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     instances in which high-risk flight profiles and limit testing have occurred in the certification process and the applicability of the data produced by such testing for use in other aspects of flight testing;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE0461B4433FA47B1AD416DB8AB8E16A8"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the safety of pilots during such testing;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H48604548B5CD45439006A1600F464A9B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     the value and accuracy of data collected using the advanced tools described in subsection (a);
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H6B9C13DFB7CD4BE1823C1222A2617A2D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     the ability to produce more extensive data sets using such advanced tools;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD21175B4758F44D3998737E0E40F04B6"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     any aspects of such testing for which the use of such advanced tools would not be valuable or applicable; 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H64A64A6D5CA1499D9CCCB4FF562635B3"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     the cost of using such advanced tools; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HBE6C777A0E1C42ADBA4456DA31A332C3"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (7)
                     the best practices of other international civil aviation authorities that permit the use of advanced tools during aerospace certification projects.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H6D7AEB36D6894B1A90C1A21E9F5469A7"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Consultation
                  In carrying out the assessment under subsection (a), the Administrator shall consult with—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD987E6D40C8545AEBDE6305B4B6F9FA5"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     aircraft manufacturers, including manufacturers that have designed and certified aircraft under—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE90E46099FCD46BE953308DD471BC586"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        part 23 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HCCE1878E27B24792935C311556B78DAD"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        part 25 of such title; or
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HCE2432876FA44809BEC57080A94515B4"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        part 27 of such title;
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1A9372A22AA046AABBB22A4CADE42354"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     aircraft manufacturers that have designed and certified, or are in the process of certifying, aircraft with a novel design under part 21.17(b) of such title;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H19246F4312464EB5B9E7C58614B8BAF3"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     associations representing aircraft manufacturers; 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H16B90405BAC9430BB1D3CA495A2E3DCD"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     researchers and academics in related fields; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1448E5CEC393460BBC17A9C0777B5758"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     pilots who are experts in flight testing. 
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H0C066AC08E684AD6AE4F9471E1E0F806"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Congressional report
                  Not later than 60 days after the completion of the assessment under subsection (a), the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the results of the assessment conducted under subsection (a).
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H28779D73055B41B494D5F02239F9E717"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Required updates
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA8B44F5A2195446FB0AD677F85C05A2C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall take necessary actions based on the results of the assessment under subsection (a), including, as appropriate—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HC909783A64474404A32F111D44D8EC31"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        amending part 21 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H45BEA7291E36438FB184CF0E8F17F0F3"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        modifying any associated advisory circulars, guidance, or policy of the FAA.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD4F780A8323942E59F10A5CBE3396138"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Requirements
                     In taking actions under paragraph (1), the Administrator shall consider—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H743E6F6A59F342488F08524EADEF9321"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        developing validation criteria and procedures whereby data produced in high-fidelity engineering laboratories and facilities may be allowed (in conjunction with, or in lieu of) data produced on a flying test article to support an applicant’s showing of compliance required under section 21.35(a)(1) of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H3D6C1B20F4F14D4F91007F9FCB5EB12A"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        developing criteria and procedures whereby an Organization Designation Authorization (as defined in section 44736(c)(5) of title 49, United States Code) may recommend that certain data produced during an applicant’s flight test program may be accepted by the FAA as final compliance data in accordance with section 21.35(b) of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, at the sole discretion of the FAA; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H97CD9D83EB0B4223BA6B5A94234AEEEC"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        working with other international civil aviation authorities representing States of Design to—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HA35BAF0BB0ED45128E3444E5651FD1D7"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           identify their best practices relative to high risk-flight testing; and
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H9431234402094561AAFAF9AD9AE5AA3A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           adopt such practices into the flight-testing requirements of the FAA to the maximum extent practicable.
                        
                     
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H03F835B090E14292B3041175A356669B"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               312.
               TRANSPORT AIRPLANE AND PROPULSION CERTIFICATION MODERNIZATION
               Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall publish a notice of proposed rulemaking for the item titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">Transport Airplane and Propulsion Certification Modernization, published in Fall 2022 in the Unified Agenda of Federal Regulatory and Deregulatory Actions (RIN 2120–AL42).
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H7920FF70811E40AC8EBD6B1001810355"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               313.
               FIRE PROTECTION STANDARDS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H7AEA347CA5D3485E9E6A3DD19D8AE24B"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Internal regulatory review team
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H398B13E82A9A4FC3B80E1ADC3C42EB9C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Establishment
                     Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall establish an internal regulatory review team (in this section referred to as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">Team).
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA096CA9D3E2945038A067A0DD877B0BE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Review
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE5CEC8829025423A9991521177575DA9"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        In general
                        The Team shall conduct a review comparing foreign and domestic airworthiness standards and guidance for aircraft engine firewalls.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H46C1196C4F0746D4A473AC362F27C172"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        Requirements
                        In conducting the review, the Team shall—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H2C0EEB6F783947DE9E6CD15651BF5186"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           identify any significant differences in standards or guidance with respect to test article selection and fire test boundaries and evaluation criteria for burn tests, including the use of certification by analysis for cases in which substantially similar designs have passed burn tests;
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HF2DEAC01D44345EEB76408DB2F47907D"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           assess the safety implications for any products imported into the United States that do not comply with the firewall requirements of the FAA; and
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H1D574E06FA124AC1A8FEB50D2DA2CFFB"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iii)
                           consult with industry stakeholders to the maximum extent practicable.
                        
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HE8C5DB73DEA147E080BB4B4AFD884CF4"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Duties of the Administrator
                  The Administrator shall—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H9F3782D230A349B786E7417E8B3BB50E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     not later than 60 days after the date on which the Team reports the findings of the review to the Administrator, update the Significant Standards List of the FAA based on such findings, as appropriate; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HBE1E8873CD5C4DDC8E2FE7A9964F3645"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     not later than 90 days after such date, submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on such findings and any recommendations for such legislative or administrative action as the Administrator determines appropriate.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HF8D0551ADEE44110AFEDB3903345C353"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               314.
               RISK MODEL FOR PRODUCTION FACILITY INSPECTIONS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H50B5995E319843F9B0850C4A60021571"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 12 months after the date of enactment of this Act, and periodically thereafter, the Administrator shall—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HFBD5E9BD11E84C15A1AEC2503C8914A6"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     conduct a review of the risk-based model used by certification management offices of the FAA to inform the frequency of aircraft manufacturing or production facility inspections; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HBA5C4E96F78A44E892536256D239D770"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     update the model to ensure such model adequately accounts for risk at facilities during periods of increased production.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H334A6EC54BBA445BA1D5FFF205F3D537"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Briefings
                  Not later than 60 days after the date on which the review is completed under subsection (a), the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H6B4BF75EAF7B44CA8282D4B5B26F6647"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     the results of the review;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H2274E7E0374141A4B164AE3ABBEE5CFE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     any changes made to the risk-based model described in subsection (a); and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4D9CB2EF87404BDFAAE4414A11B2724D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     how such changes would help improve the in-plant inspection process.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H969BFB044516462C8E79842E159C2BC3"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               315.
               REVIEW OF FAA USE OF AVIATION SAFETY DATA
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HFE57285FD69444E9B74D64853294B1DB"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall seek to enter into an appropriate arrangement with a qualified third-party organization or consortium to evaluate the collection, collation, analysis, and use of aviation data across the FAA.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H2CB5DE15348042BA9DA573E6C949F667"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Consultation
                  In completing the evaluation under subsection (a), the qualified third-party organization or consortium shall—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H5B21A90821384B7E9787B409D9B83639"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     seek the input of experts in data analytics, including at least 1 expert in the commercial data services or analytics solutions sector; 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE4FA911DF9A240BFA4BCF8669ED7681C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     consult with the National Transportation Safety Board and the Transportation Research Board; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HAD77E70AF9B84E8D94937BBB5B82BE2B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     consult with appropriate federally funded research and development centers, to the extent that such centers are not already involved in the evaluation.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HA5CDD9462DEC43949B07FE1C52350B7A"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Substance of evaluation
                  In completing the evaluation under subsection (a), the qualified third-party organization or consortium shall—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HAA4473B95A1D41B89F06B2332399AFFC"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     compile a list of internal and external sources, databases, and streams of information the FAA receives or has access to that provide the FAA with operational or safety information and data about the national airspace system, its users, and other regulated entities of the FAA;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3EF0787C289A4DD89D8A5E7F4210A367"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     review data sets to determine completeness and accuracy of relevant information;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H7140A2AA76974D099639BFEE02DB6BAC"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     identify gaps in information that the FAA could fill through sharing agreements, partnerships, or other means that would add value during safety trend analysis;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC8B466920FBF4ACEB226EF187AECCBF0"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     assess the capabilities of the FAA, including analysis systems and workforce skillsets, to analyze relevant data and information to make informed decisions;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA27DA374D5414C0CBD850FFAFB0F9AAE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     review data and information for proper storage, identification controls, and data privacy—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HFB92FCB7BAF94F26B6EBC70A68739F5A"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        as required by law; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HB7020E155452493ABF055560F28068B0"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        consistent with best practices for data collection, storage, and use;
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA9D7B6119EB940A7821535C7E64AC93A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     review the format of such data and identify methods to improve the usefulness of such data;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HCD42D8D65C1945ED8D312DFE6F8DB07B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (7)
                     assess internal and external access to data for—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H7CEBCD42EFF241338B12B803D319EA3B"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        appropriateness based on data type and level of detail;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H576187B239CA4E5EA841BAEB3B4E9193"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        proper data access protocols and precautions; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H06EA65CBEBF745608491EC44044359D0"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        maximizing availability of safety-related data that could support the improvement of safety management systems of and trend identification by regulated entities and the FAA;
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8C4910D80283454496D8692D816350BE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (8)
                     examine the collation and dissemination of data within offices and between offices of the FAA;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H87434ED5044A4941AEF1CCEDC12B3555"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (9)
                     review and recommend improvements to the data analysis techniques of the FAA; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
