                              id="H6FE1FFA091994B078A1FB6AD7AADCD3A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (10)
                     recommend investments the Administrator should consider to better collect, manage, and analyze data sets, including within and between offices of the FAA.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HD66C528F005D44A988E294506B4600A2"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Access to information
                  The Administrator shall provide the qualified third-party organization or consortium and the experts described in subsection (b) with adequate access to safety and operational data collected by and held by the agency across all offices of the FAA, except if specific access is otherwise prohibited by law.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H3D82DCFB26184F59894AE27CBAAF8412"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Nondisclosure
                  Prior to participating in the review, the Administrator shall ensure that each person participating in the evaluation under this section enters into an agreement with the Administrator in which the person shall be prohibited from disclosing at any time, except as required by law, to any person, foreign or domestic, any non-public information made accessible to the federally funded research and development center under this section.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HB19F404259CA4024B2FD345074A1046F"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (f)
                  Report
                  The qualified third-party organization or consortium carrying out the evaluation under this section shall provide a report of the findings of the center to the Administrator and include recommendations to improve the FAA’s collection, collation, analysis, and use of aviation data, including recommendations to—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H82C4251D996B49D0A9166F5B8D94770F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     improve data access across offices within the FAA, as necessary, to support efficient execution of safety analysis and programs across such offices;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H631F12BEE19843F8ACB4D05BE15B852A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     improve data storage best practices;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE35A46C6961A41F898999F2494C31F0D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     develop or refine methods for collating data from multiple FAA and industry sources; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H2A6BD082EE4441AE890616F40DD73791"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     procure or use available analytics tools to draw conclusions and identify previously unrecognized trends or miscategorized risks in the aviation system, particularly when identification of such information requires the analysis of multiple sets of data from multiple sources.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HF2AB396454A747D5AC5626091044A75E"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (g)
                  Implementation of recommendations
                  Not later than 6 months after the receipt of the report under subsection (f), the Administrator shall review, develop an implementation plan, and, if appropriate, begin the implementation of the recommendations received in such report.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H27C144CA5A374661884ECDB726CCCA10"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (h)
                  Review of implementation
                  The qualified third-party organization or consortium that conducted the initial evaluation, and any experts who contributed to such evaluation pursuant to subsection (b)(1), shall provide regular feedback and advice to the Administrator on the implementation plan developed under subsection (g) and any implementation activities for at least 2 years beginning on the date of the receipt of the report under subsection (f).
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H05DA22B3EC60459D8119ED184F665112"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (i)
                  Report to Congress
                  The Administrator shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress the report described in subsection (f) and the implementation plan described in subsection (g).
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HE964F35956E84B18B7B96F8E1D4F265D"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (j)
                  Existing reporting systems
                  Consistent with section 132 of the Aircraft Certification, Safety, and Accountability Act (Public Law 116–260), the Executive Director of the Transportation Research Board, in consultation with the Secretary and the Administrator, may further harmonize data and sources following the implementation of recommendations under subsection (g).
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H5B04DF2CA10840E28CD6C351C6F2A192"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (k)
                  Rule of construction
                  Nothing in this section shall be construed to permit the public disclosure of information submitted under a voluntary safety reporting program or that is otherwise protected under section 44735 of title 49, United States Code.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HA65DCB22842F42F1B5A236787AB4A581"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               316.
               WEATHER REPORTING SYSTEMS STUDY
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H4D8E808D4B1149F5B95472173E26FF9F"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall initiate a study to examine how to improve the procurement, functionality, and sustainability of weather reporting systems, including—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB8AFC1B5DF864CD486AFB98556A4AD73"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     automated weather observing systems;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC3587A6BE5804DF4970BC39D5B3FF05E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     automated surface observing systems;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0CBA2EB03D9E40A7B19A2EF404CDA33A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     visual weather observing systems; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H719AC254891041328C884615D919FE78"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     non-Federal weather reporting systems.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H0BDD3957804D4E1A8B33B233FCEFDADA"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Contents
                  In conducting the study required under section (a), the Comptroller General shall address—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD95AB538E247410798534F39E5242BB6"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     the current state of the supply chain related to weather reporting systems and the components of such systems;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H085E3B5D789143C286277DAA5FF7EF99"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the average age of weather reporting systems infrastructure installed in the national airspace system; 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H58D6F83B54494FA2BA2C761D32E40254"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     challenges to maintaining and replacing weather reporting systems, including—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H8C7806DED50848E6AF5D53032F8D9D02"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        root causes of weather reporting system outages, including failures of such systems, and supporting systems such as telecommunications infrastructure; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H774177130A5D4F24995C93BE1D80E06A"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        the degree to which such outages affect weather reporting in the national airspace system; 
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H2F5FC8D9C1FA4D7DB4DE64EED379AC4F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     mitigation measures to maintain aviation safety during such an outage; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H9767F5124DB1485CB42777F3131D3077"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     alternative means of obtaining weather elements at airports, including wind direction, wind speed, barometric pressure setting, and cloud coverage, including visibility.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H54EEB0D015954FC28416F1220B4C7F5F"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Consultation
                  In conducting the study required under subsection (a), the Comptroller General shall consult with the appropriate stakeholders and Federal agencies involved in installing, managing, and supporting weather reporting systems in the national airspace system.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HC768171A53AF44E6B0867F526154E449"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Report
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H471FEE5B69214A098676A7F02D7E566A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress and the Committee on Science, Space, and Technology of the House of Representatives a report describing the results of the study conducted under subsection (a).
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H54980C8A2F434A05BDBAEF59029E498D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Recommendations
                     The Comptroller General shall include in the report submitted under paragraph (1) recommendations for—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H141C35E3C4F741FC8870675FD915E7CA"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        ways to improve the resiliency and redundancy of weather reporting systems; 
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HEAB46F6560A04CA9B59C5C24BACFC64D"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        alternative means of compliance for obtaining weather elements at airports; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HBF916737F4114FADB6920A58DE7ED9E6"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        if necessary, changes to Orders of the Administration, including the following:
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H55667337A7D34222AB19F0EC6A83916C"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           Surface Weather Observing, Joint Order 7900.5.
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HFD850ACC8B3741CFAF4B46F6570178C4"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           Notices to Air Missions, Joint Order 7930.2. 
                        
                     
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H9D27A6B1B6814A8596A01C4462EEF89A"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               317.
               GAO STUDY ON EXPANSION OF THE FAA WEATHER CAMERA PROGRAM
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H17D692CA44894DDDA56156EA1DCF268A"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Study
                  The Comptroller General shall conduct a study on the feasibility and benefits and costs of expanding the Weather Camera Program of the FAA to locations in the United States that lack weather camera services.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HC92C0D3F689247CDA8E51CE998B2271A"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Considerations
                  In conducting the study required under subsection (a), the Comptroller General shall review—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H7E938106F67842E3AF5E07A3B4296310"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     the potential effects of the existing Weather Camera Program on weather-related aviation accidents and flight interruptions;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H20132E0601604326AFA797B1F7B20FF4"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the potential benefits and costs associated with expanding the Weather Camera Program;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA9104BB740FC4D81853DC35B428EA061"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     limitations on the real-time access of weather camera information by pilots and aircraft operators;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H85E2A19A113D49A092CAB3ED7CCFE0C6"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     non-safety related regulatory structures or barriers to the allowable use of weather camera information for the purposes of aircraft operations;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H00A4BD9B066A41EE8F6518338B96C417"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     limitations of existing weather camera systems at the time of the study;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H260817BACAA94493A6A344AF89B784D6"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     alternative sources of viable weather data;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE7BA5E3DBF1E4E9093676919F6D13FF9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (7)
                     funding mechanisms for weather camera installation and operations; and 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H21F3884CA5F74F18B368027519319809"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (8)
                     other considerations the Comptroller General determines appropriate.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HFE629E3495444E0D85F2A63CCC311BD5"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Report to congress
                  Not later than 28 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the results of the study required under subsection (a).
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HC9DFADA9318E45A6811F410611FD8D30"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               318.
               AUDIT ON AVIATION SAFETY IN ERA OF WIRELESS CONNECTIVITY
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HF9EE6A928386468286BF11D6E38C2A5A"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the inspector general of the Department of Transportation shall initiate an audit of the FAA’s internal processes and procedures to communicate the position of civil aviation operators and the safety of the national airspace system to the National Telecommunications and Information Administration regarding proposed spectrum reallocations or auction decisions.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HAD9AE45342124576AAE7E5F46D96147B"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Assessment
                  In conducting the audit described in subsection (a), the inspector general shall assess best practices and policy recommendations for the FAA to—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HBD86A5609B98445393B4D73088C7096B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     improve internal processes by which proposed spectrum reallocations or auctions are thoroughly reviewed in advance to ensure that any comments or technical concerns regarding aviation safety from civil aviation stakeholders are communicated to the National Telecommunications and Information Administration that are to be submitted to the Federal Communications Commission;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE4A5A6F30EE14560BDD09A7D557E045B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     develop internal processes and procedures to assess the effects a proposed spectrum reallocation or auction may have on the national airspace system in a timely manner to ensure safety of the national airspace system;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF2F21EA23D7D4A8BB43106E1546A07E8"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     improve external communication processes to better inform civil aviation stakeholders, including owners and operators of civil aircraft, on any comments or technical concerns of the FAA relating to a proposed spectrum reallocation or auction that may impact the national airspace system; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H43295A7A32514DD0B4F71FC4EB3F62D1"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     better communicate to the National Telecommunications and Information Administration when a proposed spectrum reallocation or auction may pose a potential risk to aviation safety.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H463968C2D16E4448AA3F7F2E5BD89749"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Stakeholder views
                  In conducting the audit pursuant to subsection (a), the inspector general shall consult with relevant stakeholders, including—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB331FAE1ADDF403D8D23239F4F09CCD6"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     air carriers operating under part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H630390B441A34BAEB2E3F44B3647B25E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     manufacturers of aircraft and aircraft components;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB1CF176D1C4B4DE3AECA9A4F119F04DC"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     wireless communication carriers;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H6F436E03F07F4AD59E970F0EBFD1676D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     labor unions representing pilots;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1B9379CA06124073B7AA9FAC80671D6C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     air traffic system safety specialists;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HDE56200D849D4D33AB4F8DA99BFA7A41"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     other representatives of the communications industry;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H143D4DD6D13D44F2B076387AA36F0EE4"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (7)
                     aviation safety experts;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB3D5EFF41D4047CE9FDBACBFA690C742"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (8)
                     the National Telecommunications and Information Administration; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HEC72C9822F4A452DBED4E113DE89AB05"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (9)
                     the Federal Communications Commission.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H243B747EB69D459FBAAF067453A6E328"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Report
                  Not later than 2 years after the date on which the audit is conducted pursuant to subsection (a), the inspector general shall complete and submit a report on findings and recommendations to—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H99FC794618D14290949D0A7D042DBFB8"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     the Administrator;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0B1308DB642A415B9278EF40564DFCA7"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the appropriate committees of Congress; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H58C151A9BFB34B2193F4F20C70C9F0F2"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     the Committee on Energy and Commerce of the House of Representatives.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HFB2218E9C2E5481E96D5C86074172E54"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               319.
               SAFETY DATA ANALYSIS FOR AIRCRAFT WITHOUT TRANSPONDERS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HD549837B8E184B1AB0198ECA069DDAC0"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator, in coordination with the Chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, shall collect and analyze data relating to accidents and incidents involving covered exempt aircraft that occurred within 30 nautical miles of an airport.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HF8E46A45752E4006B8D80AD68CCCD406"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Requirements
                  The analysis required under subsection (a) shall include, with respect to covered exempt aircraft, a review of—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4347549716B44ACD892619AE476C08E3"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     incident and accident data since 2006 involving—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H6BFA50A650F64221A466BAC43C61478C"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        midair events, including collisions;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H97CCA41730CE4995BC2E56E9F3E49047"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        ground proximity warning system alerts;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HB0AC7AE9CB8648CE9B20007C979EA322"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        traffic collision avoidance system alerts; or
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HF14F896166D0426BB7F13E335C187911"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        a loss of separation or near miss; and
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB6B266BB1E82426380BA1C604E39D165"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the causes of the incidents and accidents described in paragraphs (1).
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H94B134AC81BC4476BEAEE531F2FEF6CC"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Briefing to Congress
                  Not later than 30 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the results of the analysis required under subsection (a) and, if applicable, recommendations on how to reduce the number of incidents and accidents associated with such covered exempt aircraft.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H14CF64470C12453EBEC64762C21D98A5"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Covered exempt aircraft defined
                  In this section, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">covered exempt aircraft means aircraft, balloons, and gliders exempt from air traffic control transponder and altitude reporting equipment and use requirements under part 91.215(b)(3) of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H1D9F8153D0F643E4AE403F2B653A9E2F"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               320.
               CRASH-RESISTANT FUEL SYSTEMS IN ROTORCRAFT
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H1319124124AD44ACA7D8DD77155DAECF"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  The Administrator shall task the Aviation Rulemaking Advisory Committee to—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HFDA3A6CE3FE441AD84DC8114F8EFA360"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     review the data analysis conducted and the recommendations developed by the Aviation Rulemaking Advisory Committee Rotorcraft Occupant Protection Working Group of the Administration;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC170094910614F33BB7D66E11DF00792"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     update the 2018 report of such working group on rotorcraft occupant protection by—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HB4339A9C64EE4573B84CFDC1D9CE335E"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        reviewing National Transportation Safety Board data from 2016 through 2023 on post-crash fires in helicopter accidents; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HF36B203D6CD842B482C0C39B67DA1058"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        determining whether and to what extent crash-resistant fuel systems could have prevented fatalities in the accidents covered by the data reviewed under subparagraph (A); and
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H525C8BA2C28948A29490D8358FC7A2A7"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     develop recommendations for either the Administrator or the helicopter industry to encourage helicopter owners and operators to expedite the installation of crash-resistant fuel systems in the aircraft of such owners and operators regardless of original certification and manufacture date.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HEA18D8BBA6B347F695BE743733F1F377"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Schedule
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H9C32A7FA3118499D9ED513F597FC0F1F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Deadline
                     Not later than 18 months after the Administrator tasks the Aviation Rulemaking Advisory Committee under subsection (a), the Committee shall submit the recommendations developed under subsection (a)(2) to the Administrator.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HAAF5ECD693584867AE25052B9AEC76A2"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Implementation
                     If applicable, and not later than 180 days after receiving the recommendations under paragraph (1), the Administrator shall—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H707E610617684EB9B33730EF0A896AEB"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        begin implementing, as appropriate, any safety recommendations the Administrator receives from the Aviation Rulemaking Advisory Committee, and brief the appropriate committees of Congress on any recommendations the Administrator does not implement; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HFE0997308C564DED906651F59A70EB14"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        partner with the United States Helicopter Safety Team, as appropriate, to facilitate implementation of any recommendations for the helicopter industry pursuant to subsection (a)(2).
                     
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H18F2560E7595448184FC8DEE0749C7AB"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               321.
               REDUCING TURBULENCE-RELATED INJURIES ON PART 121 AIRCRAFT OPERATIONS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H9F528360803A4F0E97D71CA6ADAC186F"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall review the recommendations made by the Chair of the National Transportation Safety Board to the Administrator contained in the safety research report titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Preventing Turbulence-Related Injuries in Air Carrier Operations Conducted Under Title 14 Code of Federal Regulations Part 121, issued on August 10, 2021 (NTSB/SS–21/01) and provide a briefing to the appropriate committees of Congress with any planned actions in response to the recommendations of the report.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H3DE5D0A9C81A49DCBF71F86571126CF2"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Implementation
                  Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall implement, as appropriate, the recommendations in the safety research report described in subsection (a). 
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H371BE100063B406B97A85DB93ED7AB85"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Report
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H132AB500CB60445BAE1D260936D18DFC"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Not later than 2 years after completing the review under subsection (a), and every 2 years thereafter, the Administrator shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the implementation status of the recommendations in the safety research report described in subsection (a) until the earlier of—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H0208996FA59F4BFE83A64B9942AFF28B"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        the date on which such recommendations have been adopted or adjudicated as described in paragraph (2); or
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HBD08C0B6523346F6849209854AAB6D95"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        the date that is 10 years after the date of enactment of this Act.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB78B278D107F40BB82D57A17ABA9472B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Contents
                     If the Administrator decides not to implement a recommendation in the safety research report described in subsection (a), the Administrator shall provide, as a part of the report required under paragraph (1), a description of why the Administrator did not implement such recommendation.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H20E8FECDCECB4D71B11385CA0326E0B0"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               322.
               STUDY ON RADIATION EXPOSURE
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H9D0BE4478B3B4D64A81FEB18E713B420"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Study
                  Not later than 120 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall seek to enter into appropriate arrangements with the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine under which the National Research Council of the National Academies shall conduct a study on radiation exposure to crewmembers onboard various aircraft types operated under part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HED6B83AE5D1E48C5B776021D66825383"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Scope of study
                  In conducting the study under subsection (a), the National Research Council shall assess—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB90D1DDE824E4353B53983F6A9149263"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     radiation concentrations in such aircraft at takeoff, in-flight at high altitudes, and upon landing; 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4F809CB2D28C4464A2A60960D5615E48"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the health risks and impact of radiation exposure to crewmembers onboard aircraft operating at high altitudes; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8330B88F999847AE975EFAF600C8B3A4"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     mitigation measures to prevent and reduce the health and safety impacts of radiation exposure to crewmembers.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HD109153D8AE84B2AB86EC2DC0ED3951C"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Report to Congress
                  Not later than 16 months after the initiation of the study required under subsection (a), the Secretary shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress the study conducted by the National Research Council pursuant to this section.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H3A746CC505A44A1A96A019EDF14B2DBF"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               323.
               STUDY ON IMPACTS OF TEMPERATURE IN AIRCRAFT CABINS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HFEB95EE83B774EC692D27A93834A3ADD"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Study
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H987E55A1095B452CAE94C7A72ED1AA80"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall seek to enter into appropriate arrangements with the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine under which the National Academies shall conduct a 1-year study on the health and safety impacts of unsafe cabin temperature with respect to passengers and crewmembers during each season in which the study is conducted.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8E5A3CFFF2444281BD68679498121068"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Considerations
                     In conducting the study required under paragraph (1), the National Academies shall review existing standards produced by recognized industry organizations on safe air temperatures and humidity levels in enclosed environments, including onboard aircraft, and evaluate the validity of such standards as it relates to aircraft cabin temperatures. 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H74033D22B0C24F8B9744F45CC465A709"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Consultation
                     In conducting the study required under paragraph (1), the National Academies shall consult with the Civil Aerospace Medical Institute of the FAA, air carriers operating under part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, relevant Federal agencies, and any applicable aviation labor organizations. 
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H1F5664761233433886BE3E92E762A2D6"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Reports
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H16B7BB5C871D418BA3083ABD993B6DF9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Report to Secretary
                     Not later than 180 days after the date on which the study under subsection (a) is completed, the National Academies shall submit to the Secretary a report on the results of such study, including any recommendations determined appropriate by the National Academies.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE9D4F142F03A4045A5C4244FA1DB5BD7"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Report to Congress
                     Not later than 60 days after the date on which the National Academies submits the report under paragraph (1), the Secretary shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report describing the results of the study required under subsection (a), including any recommendations for further action determined appropriate by the Secretary.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H80859D7EBAE442B09CEC25F00CF7D950"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Covered aircraft defined
                  In this section, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">covered aircraft means an aircraft operated under part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations. 
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H486BC075D7BE4A949D25C3D192376569"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               324.
               LITHIUM–ION POWERED WHEELCHAIRS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H96329FC3CED84F4CAC64A3008697D174"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall task the Air Carrier Access Act Advisory Committee (in this section referred to as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Committee) to conduct a review of regulations related to lithium–ion battery powered wheelchairs and mobility aids on commercial aircraft and provide recommendations to the Secretary to ensure safe transport of such wheelchairs and mobility aids in air transportation.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H6492DE5B994E45798DB6EFFFC0F8E249"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Considerations
                  In conducting the review required under subsection (a), the Committee shall consider the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HDCDBFA2B8CA34D9C8252701944FBD186"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Any existing or necessary standards for lithium–ion batteries, including casings or other similar components, in such wheelchairs and mobility aids.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1EF524B769BB42B3957EB4594340BC91"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     The availability of necessary containment or storage devices, including fire containment covers or fire-resistant storage containers, for such wheelchairs and mobility aids.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD3E9B709A9504F5189E11946EAF9BC06"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     The policies of each air carrier (as such term is defined in part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations) pertaining to lithium–ion battery powered wheelchairs and mobility aids (as in effect on the date of enactment of this Act).
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H2DE1F5FDE70248359AAFB432C5822445"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Any other considerations the Secretary determines appropriate.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HC6471C56FB97440584FD370F4096318D"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Consultation requirement
                  In conducting the review required under subsection (a), the Committee shall consult with the Administrator of the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HE823FB7DDD5C40E5861AB5CF1FE14BFA"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Notification
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H7FD9B080C4A94D6EAFDD7CE4F0AB25E3"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Upon completion of the review conducted under subsection (a), the Committee shall notify the Secretary if an air carrier does not have a policy pertaining to lithium–ion battery powered wheelchairs and mobility aids in effect.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H60ED3FDF90294C76BC5602DFDCE7F875"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Notification
                     The Secretary shall notify an air carrier described in paragraph (1) of the status of such air carrier.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HAC305CAA85DA4D8FBF901F286AF37D23"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Report to congress
                  Not later than 90 days after submission of the recommendations to the Secretary, the Secretary shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress any recommendations under subsection (a), in the form of a report.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HAEB8B80D6B3446E3B6EAE299CFB56384"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (f)
                  Publication
                  The Secretary shall publish the report required under subsection (e) on the public website of the Department of Transportation.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H79097CB0FB6E4A049446C7CB13E8AB09"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               325.
               NATIONAL SIMULATOR PROGRAM POLICIES AND GUIDANCE
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H51B789B508AA47FCA903198D729D8604"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Review
                  Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall review relevant policies and guidance, including all advisory circulars, information bulletins, and directives, pertaining to part 60 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations. 
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HB793F3CAED5B493199E946F91F171C8B"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Updates
                  Upon completion of the review required under subsection (a), the Administrator shall, at a minimum, update relevant policies and guidance, including all advisory circulars, information bulletins, and directives, pertaining to part 60 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H9549C06DA3A5415DB7495E4EE2B7102C"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Consultation
                  In carrying out the review required under subsection (a), the Administrator shall convene and consult with entities required to comply with part 60 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, including representatives of—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H794A1A71A5784B7BA5E3DFBAF3C7A4CD"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     air carriers;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF96EEE886A074DAAB6572ACE43A2A8A1"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     flight schools certificated under part 141 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD0C09478D18340E490A20244731419DD"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     training centers certificated under part 142 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE502EEC96227495BBDAA5F32089C8B2C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     manufacturers and suppliers of flight simulation training devices (as defined in part 1 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, and Appendix F to part 60 of such title).
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H68421889D9134BD287C715B841376F5B"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  GAO study on FAA National Simulator Program
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H6FC17F859CA94D9E84A3BD0BED6397B8"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall conduct a study on the National Simulator Program of the FAA that is part of the Training and Simulation Group of the Air Transportation Division.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H9D413E04C8D44C73828CD3F390A2E016"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Considerations
                     In conducting the study required under paragraph (1), the Comptroller General shall, at a minimum, assess—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H2B11F4FB482B455F868AD58C6E4203B7"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        how the program described in paragraph (1) is maintained to reflect and account for advancement in technologies pertaining to flight simulation training devices (as defined in part 1 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, and appendix F to part 60 of such title);
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H9BD0C665FEB14163A4975F0058B570A9"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        the staffing levels, critical competencies, and skills gaps of FAA personnel responsible for carrying out and supporting the program described in paragraph (1); and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H9022C751F80F436F96A6A4AA556D6B8E"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        how the program described in paragraph (1) engages air carriers and relevant industry stakeholders, including flight schools, to ensure efficient compliance with part 60 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF55608F0322143D2BF4C64CF0AE705CA"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Report
                     Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the findings of the study conducted under paragraph (1).
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HC027C45D734E474F99E9BEEDE0DF31E9"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               326.
               BRIEFING ON AGRICULTURAL APPLICATION APPROVAL TIMING
               Not later than 240 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the amount of time the application approval process takes for agricultural aircraft operations under part 137 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H7AA2CB93F2994F01994B34540527FB69"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               327.
               SENSE OF CONGRESS REGARDING SAFETY AND SECURITY OF AVIATION INFRASTRUCTURE
               It is the sense of Congress that aviation provides essential services critical to the United States economy and that it is important to ensure the safety and security of aviation infrastructure and protect such infrastructure from unlawful breaches with appropriate legal safeguards.
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HD307D05B64E04EB6BC73DB7F9701BF62"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               328.
               RESTRICTED CATEGORY AIRCRAFT MAINTENANCE AND OPERATIONS
               Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Administrator shall have sole regulatory and oversight jurisdiction over the maintenance and operations of aircraft owned by civilian operators and type-certificated in the restricted category under section 21.25 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H17214A995B204BCEB6563D46765A373D"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               329.
               AIRCRAFT INTERCHANGE AGREEMENT LIMITATIONS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H8909A0D26DEB4445AFCAEDCD1B915B88"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Study
                  Not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall conduct a study of foreign interchange agreements.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H653DBAD71F964A288A082E31A9D6A85B"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Contents
                  In carrying out the study required under subsection (a), the Administrator shall address the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H5FC5F725369149D6ADDCF88CC61AC382"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Methods for updating regulations under part 121.569 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, for foreign interchange agreements.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8B9F72CDA1DD4D009CDCDC4EA75AD609"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Time limits for foreign aircraft interchange agreements.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H26154B45A6FD42B98A64B1EEA29EF1BA"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Minimum breaks between foreign aircraft interchange agreements.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H10D99E177ABA46E98E30C75E5617FEE5"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Limits for no more than 1 foreign aircraft interchange agreement between 2 airlines.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H623EFB4073134D8AA6A8EAD86375EA23"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     Limits for no more than 2 foreign aircraft on the interchange agreement.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HD4643E1241944570B3CF8E25AB21AB07"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Briefing
                  Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the results of the study required under subsection (a).
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HDDB17FF5374F4A199D059CA285757222"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Rulemaking
                  Based on the results of the study required under subsection (a), the Administrator may, if appropriate, update the relevant sections of part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HE759E10FF1FB45F0A246E0041F757744"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               330.
               TASK FORCE ON HUMAN FACTORS IN AVIATION SAFETY
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H43B1D8F672DC40409CB40C314744AF9E"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 6 months after the date of enactment of this Act, and notwithstanding section 127 of the Aircraft Certification Safety and Accountability Act (49 U.S.C. 44513 note), the Administrator shall convene a task force on human factors in aviation safety (in this section referred to as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Task Force).
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HFD3BC5CA5A2A4FDCB75FBB0501CC5476"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Composition
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H480122A6D9DF436C885770931F8F7A02"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Members
                     The Administrator shall appoint members of the Task Force—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HF1F4588C9CC94C2C9C5E90CB450E92CE"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        that have expertise in an operational or academic discipline that is relevant to the analysis of human errors in aviation, which may include air carrier operations, line pilot expertise, air traffic control, technical operations, aeronautical information, aircraft maintenance and mechanics psychology, linguistics, human-machine integration, general aviation operations, and organizational behavior and culture;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H98447C0E32A841A684DE1C11DCA55485"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        that sufficiently represent all relevant operational or academic disciplines described in subparagraph (A);
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE67616EDECBC493F9B2BD5FEE9823566"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        with expertise on human factors but whose experience and training are not in aviation and who have not previously been engaged in work related to the FAA or the aviation industry; 
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H67F55399D7E04619825939BA51921958"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        that are representatives of pilot labor organizations and certificated mechanic labor organizations; 
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HB0A4E9A7B60541BBB78C81B7BAE05945"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (E)
                        that are employees of the FAA that have expertise in safety; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HA058ED774060445D986A5DCB1CCAAF7B"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (F)
                        that are employees of other Federal agencies with expertise on human factors.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HCBDD3FAC67D34F71B91C9F69C12DC4A3"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Number of members
                     In appointing members under paragraph (1), the Administrator shall ensure that—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HF97FFE03DF674552B183CEB1CDDF62C6"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        at least half of the members appointed have expertise in aviation;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H453FB547B549425994FE44FC504259D5"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        at least one member appointed represents an exclusive bargaining representative of air traffic controllers certified under section 7111 of title 5, United States Code; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H404E1E3436EA4F448AD892253AE5E91A"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        3 members are employees of the FAA and 1 member is an employee of the National Transportation Safety Board.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HBF6678D70BEE4E2C81D01E6955A73258"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Voting
                     The members described in paragraph (2)(C) shall be non-voting members of the Task Force.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H02434B76E32B4B2E94D51769CF2AE283"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Duration
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8F5FE23FA54E4E118F8068180B85ECBE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Members of the Task Force shall be appointed for the duration of the Task Force.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H934E85E152154ABF8B29A6ACE6A13D6A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Length of existence
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H2E9D026990B6413AAC0F43ED523AC8E1"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        In general
                        The Task Force shall have an initial duration of 2 years.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H49FAE52768F942B29D1AB42CD7030E80"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        Option
                        The Administrator may extend the duration of the Task Force for an additional period of up to 2 years.
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H6AAD58FDA97F4433AF2A89C87EE3F184"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Duties
                  In coordination with the Research, Engineering, and Development Advisory Committee, the Task Force shall—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HEC5922615B6948CDBF8CF29167AE0AAA"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     not later than the date on which the duration of the Task Force expires under subsection (c), produce a written report in which the Task Force—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H4C03ABA5F7C34600A671C0E2B8E25777"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        to the greatest extent possible, identifies the most significant human factors and the relative contribution of such factors to aviation safety risk;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HD9661F3CA30544699683DB3C8E7CF880"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        identifies new research priorities for research in human factors in aviation safety;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HBEC41B0D9783447494652F971AE5F911"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        reviews existing products by other working groups related to human factors in aviation safety including the work of the Commercial Aviation Safety Team pertaining to flight crew responses to abnormal events;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H61C9ACDC26C34D22919A18F4CC640125"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        provides recommendations on potential revisions to any FAA regulations and guidance pertaining to the certification of aircraft under part 25 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, including sections related to presumed pilot response times and assumptions about the reliability of pilot performance during unexpected, stressful events;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H8C55315106EC43B787B7257DD5A1A93D"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (E)
                        reviews rules, regulations, or standards regarding flight crew and maintenance personnel rest and fatigue that are used by a sample of international air carriers, including rules, regulations, or standards determined to be more stringent and less stringent than the current standards pertaining to air carriers (as such term is defined in section 40102 of title 49, United States Code), and identifies risks to the national airspace system from any variation in such rules, regulations, or standards across countries;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HAEF52B98FB0C45EB88193F23BC20347B"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (F)
                        reviews pilot training requirements and recommends any revisions necessary to ensure adequate understanding of automated systems on aircraft; 
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HCB8919C35CE346DBA1D13B2A0ABC0F81"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (G)
                        reviews approach and landing misalignment and makes any recommendations for reducing misalignment events; 
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H3FE7948BF6FB4C94B52DA7BC17848525"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (H)
                        identifies ways to enhance instrument landing system maintenance schedules;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HA4418679BD4C4E81B0CDD427115E789C"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (I)
                        determines how a real-time smart system should be developed to inform the air traffic control system, air carriers, and airports about any changes in the state of runway and taxiway lights and identifies how such real-time smart system could be connected to the maintenance system of the FAA;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H87A58AD55FB24273A5C36ABDB4C9E220"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (J)
                        analyzes, with respect to human errors related to aviation safety of air carriers operating under part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H736609A3142D4ABDB217B302E6852D4C"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           fatigue and distraction during critical phases of work among pilots or other aviation personnel;
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H21406F2275F041DDB82C8B47F67809A8"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           tasks and workload;
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HAFBA82C5FF6249D48C9200A04CFFC359"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iii)
                           organizational culture;
