                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H13544DBCA4D34EEDB6195C6312FD648B"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iv)
                           communication among personnel;
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HFCEE89B923804121A3BA445DEFAAF259"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (v)
                           adherence to safety procedures;
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H44516991F55F4807A9460FE54F69E73E"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (vi)
                           mental state of personnel; and
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HB98FB84AAEAF463090C3D43E56F879EA"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (vii)
                           any other relevant factors that are the cause or potential cause of human error related to aviation safety;
                        
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H4B239F7564E24CDD8C454C88410D7789"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (K)
                        includes a tabulation of the number of accidents, incidents, or aviation safety database entries received in which an item identified under subparagraph (J) was a cause or potential cause of human error related to aviation safety; and 
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H82A7CB22E9EB44F6A385BC71684F1C0D"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (L)
                        includes a list of causes or potential causes of human error related to aviation safety about which the Administrator believes additional information is needed; and
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3BD3D4BF922E408285F49332D322984A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     if the Administrator extends the duration of the Task Force pursuant to subsection (c)(2)(B), not later than the date that is 2 years after the date on which the Task Force is established, produce an interim report containing the information described in paragraph (1).
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HF2D777EBDF584D3DAC1F8CEB54C6B8CF"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Methodology
                  In carrying out the duties under subparagraphs (J) through (L) of subsection (d)(1), the Task Force shall consult with the National Transportation Safety Board and use all available data compiled and analysis conducted on safety incidents and irregularities collected during the relevant fiscal year from the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H644A2E7897EC4670B9F3BBC528DB1995"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Flight Operations Quality Assurance.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HCDB49B016C6A487F91A29DF37430B424"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Aviation Safety Action Program.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H508B888DE44C4E459FC36D2D02EAB3E3"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Aviation Safety Information Analysis and Sharing.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD759B735E9184AF5A12EE66ED4B8FFE0"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     The Aviation Safety Reporting System.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HED5F6FD88DD7468AA9D71040BF880D09"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     Aviation safety recommendations and investigation findings of the National Transportation Safety Board.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HEAAFDF205FDA4F0EB063ADDECFCAD350"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     Other relevant programs or sources.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H749CA2BCC1D1452EB2CB5574832F0619"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (f)
                  Consistency
                  Nothing in this section shall be construed to require changes to, or duplication of, work as required by section 127 of the Aircraft Certification Safety and Accountability Act (49 U.S.C. 44513 note).
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H8864438F8A7D4E2A8A77E89081955975"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               331.
               UPDATE OF FAA STANDARDS TO ALLOW DISTRIBUTION AND USE OF CERTAIN RESTRICTED ROUTES AND TERMINAL PROCEDURES
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HC7F8354F5F4740B7BCE68227E17690A1"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 9 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall update FAA standards to allow for the distribution and use of the Capstone Restricted Routes and Terminal Procedures by Wide Area Augmentation System-capable navigation equipment.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H117C317899E24DDC97D598ADCDF0A458"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Contents
                  In updating standards under subsection (a), the Administrator shall ensure that such standards provide a means for allowing modifications and continued development of new routes and procedures proposed by air carriers operating such routes.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HED5C42BE706B4299BAD843E362C4EA6E"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               332.
               ASOS/AWOS SERVICE REPORT DASHBOARD
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H4CEAA7D4B317479F9B2B11CBC87E863C"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  The applicable Administrators shall work in collaboration to collect the real-time service status of all automated surface observation systems/automated weather observing systems (in this section referred to as <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">ASOS/AWOS).
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HC9DDFAB8D5D3414281025E1F5FFC2A7E"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Availability of results
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H89EB727FBB2D4560BA6448B287623B90"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     In carrying out this section, the applicable Administrators shall make available on a publicly available website the following:
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H0458522FC5634DA2BA75FEC704CB40A8"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        The service status of all ASOS/AWOS.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HC7267B4537E1494C84C1855646703402"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        Information on any actions to repair or replace ASOS/AWOS that are out of service due to technical or weather-related events, including an estimated timeline to return the systems to service.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H30B6D7CDD7FB462C92CB6B87C8A5E1B2"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        A portal on such publicly available website for the public to report ASOS/AWOS outages. 
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H6A8A586297D34843A717A14B57DD8AEC"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Data files
                     The applicable Administrators shall make available the underlying data required under paragraph (1) for each ASOS/AWOS in a machine-readable format. 
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HF252FF15461D4F35B1B45B9A8D375375"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Applicable Administrators
                  In this section, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">applicable Administrators means—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD6FB8AA491A040A0A86B03894608DE71"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     the Administrator of the FAA; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H49C08AC08EBC496C99D40F8D29136E34"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H9133D39061E346B4B61214BBD5004954"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               333.
               HELICOPTER SAFETY
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H363BDDC7F19040978594B37370851EA2"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 270 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall task the Investigative Technologies Aviation Rulemaking Advisory Committee (in this section referred to as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Committee) with reviewing and assessing the need for changes to the safety requirements related to flight data recorders, flight data monitoring, and terrain awareness and warning systems for turbine-powered rotorcraft certificated for 6 or more passenger seats.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H01D30DCECB6241DCA71E7125A47349F4"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Considerations
                  In reviewing and assessing the safety requirements under subsection (a), the Committee shall consider—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB3368FCAA2734224B924D911D3FB2735"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     any applicable safety recommendations of the National Transportation Safety Board; and 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB58A87185F354C0B89B6D5EB26FF31E8"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the operational requirements and safety considerations for operations under parts 121 and 135 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HA9CC15E4A08D4B0383284F4A00659940"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Report and recommendations
                  Not later than 1 year after initiating the review and assessment under this section, the Committee shall submit to the Administrator—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HDAECD9FF9F2640DDAA98FD3499CF7614"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     a report on the findings of the review and assessment under subsection (a); and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H68D1419E2D7C43AD9A2D394103B26285"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     any recommendations for legislative or regulatory action to improve safety that the Committee determines appropriate.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H27F33E6AB2B24055B5D9DF9440FEDEA6"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Briefing
                  Not later than 30 days after the date on which the Committee submits the report under subsection (c), the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H960FA9EF7B5D4AA38C90C09930D55BA1"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     the findings and recommendations included in such report; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H46BF7AA807064EA3A2313C9AA3DC2B05"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     any plan to implement such recommendations. 
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HB7CBF0E8BECB481B97298A0A3DC92683"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               334.
               REVIEW AND INCORPORATION OF HUMAN READINESS LEVELS INTO AGENCY GUIDANCE MATERIAL
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H1FCD2A5E617A4279970D3C0932B24478"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Findings
                  Congress finds that—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H414F772941064313A49099436B0DD3D5"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     proper attention to human factors during the development of technological systems is a significant factor in minimizing or preventing human error;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA5C59BEED6AC4445A1EDFEB710287102"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the evaluation of a new aviation technology or system with respect to human use throughout its design and development may reduce human error when such technologies and systems are used in operational conditions; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H7D70C2667FD34F01BF2CFFE585BB786F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     the technical standard of the Human Factors and Ergonomics Society titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">Human Readiness Level Scale in the System Development Process (ANSI/HFES 400–2021) defines the 9 levels of a Human Readiness Level scale and their application in systems engineering and human systems integration processes.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HB774018954914964B79F02A666A71209"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Review
                  Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall initiate a process to review the technical standard described in subsection (a)(3) and determine whether any materials from such standard should be incorporated or referenced in agency procedures and guidance material in order to enhance safety in relation to human factors.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H64918A1E97F344A39D17E6DEB9B61FE7"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Consultation
                  In carrying out subsection (b), the Administrator may consult with subject matter experts from the Human Factors and Ergonomics Society affiliated with such technical standard or other relevant stakeholders.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HD9DA473DCD0D45AB9B6C15D17AB9EC10"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Briefing
                  Not later than 270 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the progress of the review required under subsection (b).
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HB41097349BA34987AB6E377D82156F7A"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               335.
               SERVICE DIFFICULTY REPORTS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H7A4C50F1ABE9496EA8DECAB5292E8536"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Congressional briefing
                  Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, and annually thereafter through 2027, the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on compliance with requirements relating to service difficulty reports during the preceding year.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H1F6C5D1368A94114ADFD363613DFA3B2"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Scope
                  The Administrator shall include in the briefing required under subsection (a) information relating to—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H39A89C51CE864CB7A608076425AE8499"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     operators required to comply with section 121.703 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H9E4E2A9107144A1BBCAA1B2F8F35A968"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     approval or certificate holders required to comply with section 183.63 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H513458BFC02E45DEA8E50AEB6F20FA20"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     FAA offices that investigate service difficulty reports, as documented in the following FAA Orders (and any subsequent revisions of such orders):
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H2F450AFF19D640B4A5E16752A830EA65"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        FAA Order 8900.1A, titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">Flight Standards Information Management System and issued on October 27, 2022.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE93381FD28554732B6B4EE9921CB253F"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        FAA Order 8120.23A, titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">Certificate Management of Production Approval Holders and issued on March 6, 2017.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H530F8EC0E9EC45539F6C45D8BE3BA4F3"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        FAA Order 8110.107B, titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">Monitor Safety/Analyze Data and issued on October 13, 2023.
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H5BB0631315CC45E0A3C72C07CF1BCD32"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Requirements
                  The Administrator shall include in the briefing required under subsection (a) the following information with respect to the year preceding the year in which the briefing is provided:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1D67DAB72EB747E1A0CF0A5221AD9108"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     An identification of categories of service difficulties reported.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC110D252AAA44961BB71E20C8FA8C6FE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     An identification of service difficulties for which repeated reports are made.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H48B2951053794579BD5872126EFB14BE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     A general description of the causes of all service difficulty reports, as determined by the Administrator.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H01C7BC8E78994A7ABD748DA75818E340"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     A description of actions taken by, or required by, the Administrator to address identified causes of service difficulties.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H01076CE18F454B06BEA055C1BEC6913A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     A description of violations of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, related to service difficulty reports and any actions taken by the Administrator in response to such violations.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HE09E6C6A4B9D4B848EEC4F7FC05FBE4C"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               336.
               CONSISTENT AND TIMELY PILOT CHECKS FOR AIR CARRIERS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H557E9DADA56545E5869E414DC1AB57E0"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Establishment of working group
                  Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, unless the requirements of this section are assigned to working groups under subsection (b)(2), the Administrator shall establish a working group for purposes of reviewing and evaluating all regulations and policies related to check airmen and authorized check airmen for air carrier operations conducted under part 135 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations. 
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H1DB8B96F5BCD467E8653108127424D94"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Membership
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H87F9BEF1641A4E14935169048853E83D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     The working group established under this section shall include, at a minimum—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H735CA56B1CAD4AA48FD606C7AC3300B5"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        employees of the FAA who serve as check airmen;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HD24A69FEA0E949CF8666F9FBB191F323"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        representatives of air carriers operating under part 135 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HC636DEB426BF44DEB74A5648DB6F3518"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        industry associations representing such air carriers.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4011248BF98F4C5DB3E547EE4B46798A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Existing working group
                     The Administrator may assign the duties described in subsection (c) to an existing FAA working group if—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H881DD25B6F034545BA5E4D114E3BA08A"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        such working group includes representatives from the list of required members under paragraph (1); or
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HEF02647E2FCB4831AD0EB7FBFE42143C"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        the membership of such existing working group can be modified to include representatives from the list of required members under paragraph (1).
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H606EE4CE9E154D70B7A8CCE170E393BD"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Duties
                  A working group shall review, evaluate, and make recommendations on the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF194547CBEF142E9837AF982B1814957"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Methods by which authorized check airmen for air carriers operating under part 135 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, are selected, trained, and approved by the Administrator.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H706EEF6B455F479D8F2B3C525E0021C5"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Staffing and utilization rates of authorized check airmen by such air carriers.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1969CD01F6B3492B9763D0BD0F9DDC0C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Differences in qualification standards applied to—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HFA9B1A72728C416C9FB51CECDFEA2DA4"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        employees of the FAA who serve as check airmen; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HD6282EFB3F974819858B59C3CC6FFAE6"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        authorized check airmen of such air carriers.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4C5ABDEEA629444296615BF0F2D88101"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Methods to harmonize the qualification standards between authorized check airmen and employees of the FAA who serve as check airmen.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0F868463549B40638D6719B014D2C76E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     Methods to improve the training and qualification of authorized check airmen.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H90BF3A4999EF492491ED81E9B48BB02B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     Prior recommendations made by FAA advisory committees or working groups regarding check airmen functions.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8FA4CC87DCCE4BC8A8A709DB9CBC222E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (7)
                     Petitions for rulemaking submitted to the FAA regarding check airmen functions.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H8BC6DABE1250427798B1129771DD348F"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Briefing to Congress
                  Not later than 1 year after the date on which the Administrator tasks a working group with the duties described in subsection (c), the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the progress and recommendations of the working group and the efforts of the Administrator to implement such recommendations.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HF2B0E222BF564296B1539D0B8B18960C"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Authorized check airman defined
                  In this section, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">authorized check airman means an individual employed by an air carrier that meets the qualifications and training requirements of sections 135.337 and 135.339 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, and is approved to evaluate and certify the knowledge and skills of pilots employed by such air carrier.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H86459D71B9AF4E5283EEBDE7FC0AB1B0"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               337.
               FLIGHT SERVICE STATIONS
               Section 44514 of title 49, United States Code, and the item relating to such section in the analysis for chapter 445 of such title are repealed.
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H286F99C49CCB470D9FCCD2702971792C"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               338.
               TARMAC OPERATIONS MONITORING STUDY
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HE5A6C4CF628A4930AA17442B1FF2C658"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  The Director of the Bureau of Transportation Statistics, in consultation with relevant offices within the Office of the Secretary and the FAA (as determined by the Secretary), shall conduct a study to explore the capture, storage, analysis, and feasibility of monitoring ground source data at airports.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HADF7F9E9D0FE48C78096E4D463ADAEC9"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Objectives
                  The objectives of the study conducted under subsection (a) shall include the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H401535F28D7948A999711F3A94366CD9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Determining the current state of ground source data coverage at airports.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H9259CB678ACA4F9685A40F894AC917DB"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Understanding the technology requirements for monitoring ground movements at airports through sensors, receivers, or other technologies.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1F5CF436898649F486F5B3711A6464EB"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Conducting data collection through a pilot program established under subsection (c) and collecting ground-based tarmac delay statistics.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H45C65E0617904DF09AB2C22C563F21E9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Performing an evaluation and feasibility analysis of potential system-level tarmac operations monitoring solutions.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H554AEA71CD8F4A9981E1006D1DC063D1"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Pilot program
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE2247A6C3B344CA4B5D8274EA27F6CD9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Director shall establish a pilot program to collect data and develop ground-based tarmac delay statistics or other relevant statistics with respect to airports.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4711BDE3AF5E419394C94B5F0291BD02"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Requirements
                     The pilot program established under paragraph (1) shall—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H239CE1ED8B6E4D31854F7C7F8AC2DEA8"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        include up to 6 airports that the Director determines reflect a diversity of factors, including geography, size, and air traffic; 
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H5B100F0E85764BBF8B18A04A2DE23079"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        terminate not more than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H8C2CC99820F047939624C2A5B6C0A2F8"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        be subject to any guidelines issued by the Director. 
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H1C1A581F218944FB8DEE74EAA8865856"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Report
                  Not later than 4 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Director shall publish the results of the study conducted under subsection (a) and the pilot program established under subsection (c) on a publicly available website.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H5A4C784F794441DB9BFDAF9224E5D98A"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               339.
               IMPROVED SAFETY IN RURAL AREAS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H784230BA70DC4A84853A1E7357E7581F"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Section 322 of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 (49 U.S.C. 44701 note) is amended to read as follows:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="H0FF3C98A585E4E488492EEF5F3D447B5"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                               id="H5E1D41E54DF248FE9BE4764954388A79"
                               qb-display-quote="yes"
                               section-type="subsequent-section">
                        322.
                        IMPROVED SAFETY IN RURAL AREAS
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="HEEB94690073640649A68B12BB5B2F192"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (a)
                           In general
                           The Administrator shall permit an air carrier operating pursuant to part 135 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations—
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H3FD17940EE86456EAB320993D4AC2592"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              to operate under instrument flight rules (in this section referred to as <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                         quote-display-start="auto"
                                         quote-type="text">IFR) to a destination in a noncontiguous State that has a published instrument approach but does not have a Meteorological Aerodrome Report (in this section referred to as <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                         quote-display-start="auto"
                                         quote-type="text">METAR); and 
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HD66D4C6FA98F4074B1519D2A4F49421A"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              to conduct an instrument approach at such destination if—
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H17697F5721E3437E85694016B040ECF2"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 a current Area Forecast, supplemented by noncertified destination weather observations (such as weather cameras and other noncertified observations), is available, and, at the time of departure, the combination of the Area Forecast and noncertified observation indicates that weather is expected to be at or above approach minimums upon arrival;
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H8BA0E1E1D9874D3C9AEF5B4A7BB590EA"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 prior to commencing an approach, the air carrier has a means to communicate to the pilot of the aircraft whether the destination weather observation is either at or above minimums for the approach to be flown; and
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H705A0A3B6FAE4A15A413FAED4208AC20"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (C)
                                 in the event the destination weather observation is below such minimums, a suitable alternate airport that has a METAR is specified in the IFR flight plan.
                              
                           
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H56105074C4C243E688B837260C875D79"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (b)
                           Application template
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HBD08FE73B837491D8EE26C1A43590A3B"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              In general
                              The Administrator shall develop an application template with standardized, specific approval criteria to enable FAA inspectors to objectively evaluate the application of an air carrier to operate in the manner described in subsection (a).
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H3AF8C1216C844755AD7B28B61CB730FB"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              Requirements
                              The template required under paragraph (1) shall include a place in such template for an air carrier to describe—
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H84ADAD8BDAA74CCDB8CA903D10F30BE2"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 how any non-certified human observations will be conducted; and
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HBB6476BF92054C0F99C6A14D64EC81F7"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 how such observations will be communicated—
                                 <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HD147935212D7421EBF62D6289D85B696"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (i)
                                    to air carriers prior to dispatch; and
                                 
                                 <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H93F496186EBC4EB995C3FB800C83E9B0"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (ii)
                                    to pilots prior to approach.
                                 
                              
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H135435379D3F467380AC36A3EAFEE6BD"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (3)
                              Response to application
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H7248023DFB3640BD9DF3649C886A7764"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 Timeline
                                 The Administrator shall ensure—
                                 <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H74E064DF85784979A4DBEB0628A28AAA"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (i)
                                    that the Administrator has the ability to respond to an application of an air carrier not later than 30 days after receipt of such application; and
                                 
                                 <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H607E79D2968E4415B9F37B83304D9A9F"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (ii)
                                    in the event the Administrator cannot respond within 30 days, that the Administrator informs the air carrier of the expected response time with respect to the application of the air carrier.
                                 
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H1177017DF08144239FA35C4F3459DEAC"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 Rejection
                                 In the event that the Administrator rejects an application of an air carrier, the Administrator shall inform the air carrier of the specific criteria that were the cause for rejection.
                              
                           
                        
                     
                     .
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H889EAB9928C34C23AAEF5188A3CEFB7D"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Effective date
                  The amendments made by this section shall take effect on the date that is 12 months after the date of enactment of this Act. 
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H2AD85E4DB24C4C26A717C77C88882621"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               340.
               STUDY ON FAA USE OF MANDATORY EQUAL ACCESS TO JUSTICE ACT WAIVERS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H5E21724DE2FC4313993C5ACE793F6253"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  The Comptroller General shall conduct a study on the use of waivers of rights by the Administrator that may arise under section 504 of title 5, United States Code, or section 2412 of title 28, United States Code, as a condition for the settlement of any proceedings to amend, modify, suspend, or revoke an airman certificate or to impose a civil penalty on a flight engineer, mechanic, pilot, or repairman (or an individual acting in the capacity of such engineer, mechanic, pilot, or repairman). 
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HFFA3B3A1BDFD431780C9E5EF150583C6"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Considerations
                  In conducting the study under subsection (a), the Comptroller General shall consider—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H674D750D0B9947AEB353C6C54151C266"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     the frequency of the use of waivers by the Administrator described in this section;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1152EB1A01854E1B8480CF6744D951D8"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the benefits and consequences of the use of such waivers to both the Administrator and the certificate holder; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H79A980319075414A8BF31F68ECF14F9F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     the effects of a prohibition on using such waivers.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HF5457EB0BC7B4F0FA03FC5AE1BBC6B59"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Cooperation with study
                  The Administrator shall cooperate with any requests for information by Comptroller General to complete the study required under subsection (a).
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H49F02A36255E4B9EAD44FD896B42CAC4"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Report
                  Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report containing the results of the study conducted under subsection (a), including recommendations for any legislation and administrative action as the Comptroller General determines appropriate. 
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HA9BCECD0DE8E400E884A54390933B251"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               341.
               AIRPORT AIR SAFETY
               The Administrator shall seek to enter into appropriate arrangements with a qualified third-party entity to evaluate whether poor air quality inside the Washington Dulles International Airport passenger terminal negatively affects passengers.
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HF52F3FEEFBE848368495437985061CEF"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               342.
               DON YOUNG ALASKA AVIATION SAFETY INITIATIVE
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HA40BC35A672347B7AFE74C7253B9383F"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  
                     Chapter 447 of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="H59269E59B4344545A0F3918899DA2FE2"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                               id="H33D1BD8B7170460795AFC25746A69B34"
                               qb-display-quote="yes"
                               section-type="subsequent-section">
                        44745.
                        DON YOUNG ALASKA AVIATION SAFETY INITIATIVE
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H2EE9EE3BC9FA436684BC0397BCF09539"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (a)
                           In general
                           The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration shall redesignate the FAA Alaska Aviation Safety Initiative of the Administration as the Don Young Alaska Aviation Safety Initiative (in this section referred to as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                      quote-display-start="auto"
                                      quote-type="text">Initiative), under which the Administrator shall carry out the provisions of this section and take such other actions as the Administrator determines appropriate to improve aviation safety in Alaska and covered locations.
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="HEFB78100C9C842EFAAAE901F30DFC542"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (b)
                           Objective
                           The objective of the Initiative shall be to work cooperatively with aviation stakeholders and other stakeholders towards the goal of—
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HC493A26171E3471EB5EF2B77CEF09429"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              reducing the rate of fatal aircraft accidents in Alaska and covered locations by 90 percent from 2019 to 2033; and
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H89E7C9F1DDB1486D9F217F9D683079AA"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              by January 1, 2033, eliminating fatal accidents of aircraft operated by an air carrier that operates under part 135 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
                           
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="HBBB323E792F341BC82ED63315C1E0C12"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (c)
                           Leadership
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H3147374AF1F64944AD5F44742D406323"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              In general
                              The Administrator shall designate the Regional Administrator for the Alaskan Region of the Administration to serve as the Director of the Initiative.
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H5D406CB9C8DA4370954581B00746DD59"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              Covered locations
                              The Administrator shall select a designee within the Aviation Safety Organization to implement relevant requirements of this section in covered locations.
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H1529E4ED56FF4020B587606500B7B9B4"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (3)
                              Reporting chain
                              In all matters relating to the Initiative, the Director of the Initiative shall report directly to the Administrator.
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H22C092704F8244D3AB142B3C9209DD52"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (4)
                              Coordination
                              The Director of the Initiative shall coordinate with the heads of other offices and lines of business of the Administration, including the other regional administrators, to carry out the Initiative.
                           
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H8F7149D433A44F0C9F4D85373A90416C"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (d)
                           Automated weather systems
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HBDF02733F62D42D6AC76008E5ED1F30C"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              Requirement
                              The Administrator shall ensure, to the greatest extent practicable, that a covered automated weather system is installed and operated at each covered airport not later than December 31, 2030. 
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H9036A62E868F4D5DAE5839959DB4581E"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              Waiver
                              In complying with the requirement under paragraph (1), the Administrator may waive any positive benefit-cost ratio requirement for the installation and operation of a covered automated weather system.
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H4C8A1B85D1514A71A28175B9A3740E79"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (3)
                              Prioritization
                              In developing the installation timeline of a covered automated weather system at a covered airport pursuant to this subsection, the Administrator shall—
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HBC15403337A640A982D4E4069C2056DF"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 coordinate and consult with the governments with jurisdiction over Alaska and covered locations, covered airports, air carriers operating in Alaska or covered locations, private pilots based in Alaska or a covered location, and such other members of the aviation community in Alaska or covered locations; and
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H72AD72DCE8CF47DFB470DAB2221C0EEE"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 prioritize early installation at covered airports that would enable the greatest number of instrument flight rule operations by air carriers operating under part 121 or 135 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
                              
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H3F70EC02687E489B8F5FE8D5C5B58CB3"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (4)
                              Reliability
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H167264C5BDB24C8FBF38FEAEE801B2D0"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 In general
                                 Pertaining to both Federal and non-Federal systems in Alaska, the Administrator shall be responsible for ensuring—
                                 <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H5841F099A13B4E9EBEEA2F76D92D26DF"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (i)
                                    the reliability of covered automated weather systems; and
                                 
                                 <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HA11B34736D9C4BE185F510ADF298B4BA"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (ii)
                                    the availability of weather information from such systems.
                                 
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HF50EE88E68B249CDA7E09311282E9D67"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 Specifications
                                 The Administrator shall establish data availability and equipment reliability specifications for covered automated weather systems.
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HD3B1716DCDA7428697A8AF7AEFE4FE25"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (C)
                                 System reliability and restoration plan
                                 Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this section, the Administrator shall establish an automated weather system reliability and restoration plan for Alaska. Such plan shall document the Administrator’s strategy for ensuring covered automated weather system reliability, including the availability of weather information from such system, and for restoring service in as little time as possible.
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H366633C990314DBCA8CFBDE40E505C79"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (D)
                                 Telecommunications or other failures
                                 If a covered automated weather system in Alaska is unable to broadly disseminate weather information due to a telecommunications failure or a failure other than an equipment failure, the Administrator shall take such actions as may be necessary to restore the full functionality and connectivity of the covered automated weather system. The Administrator shall take actions under this subparagraph with the same urgency as the Administrator would take an action to repair a covered automated weather system equipment failure or data fidelity issue.
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HEABD361119264265BE9AB4CCBF6058B6"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (E)
                                 Reliability data
                                 In tabulating data relating to the operational status of covered automated weather systems (including individually or collectively), the Administrator may not consider a covered automated weather system that is functioning nominally but is unable to broadly disseminate weather information telecommunications failure or a failure other than an equipment failure as functioning reliably.
                              
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H85F1EE1BBCBB41D9AE656F4D1EC03114"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (5)
                              Inventory
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HFA4BD1EF4B93405C850F11C5D7B884C4"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 Maintenance improvements
                                 <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HDC23C49E19F9440F9B28F829FD9B3C8C"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (i)
                                    In general
                                    Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2024, the Administrator shall identify and implement reasonable alternative actions to improve maintenance of FAA-owned weather observing systems that experience frequent service outages, including associated surface communication outages, at covered airports.
                                 
                                 <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H09557D4A51D94A3DAF59E818DD85100E"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (ii)
                                    Spare parts availability
                                    The actions identified by the Administrator in clause (i) shall improve spare parts availability, including consideration of storage of more spare parts in the region in which the systems are located.
                                 
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H6A8A47262A434109993A2361ED711A88"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 Notice of outages
                                 Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2024, the Administrator shall update FAA Order 7930.2 Notices to Air Missions, or any successive order, to incorporate weather system outages for automated weather observing systems and automated surface observing systems associated with Service A Outages at covered airports.
                              
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H84E51023EAE144048AEBCF239242F98E"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (6)
                              Visual weather observation system
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H283F3F29FC05429B9FABC914EF68E80B"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 Deployment
                                 Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2024, the Administrator shall take such actions as may be necessary to—
                                 <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HF95EBF715B694494B5E896A50D9CAB82"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (i)
                                    deploy visual weather observation systems; 
                                 
                                 <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H55DB66B84D8E40DABA7068D172BD0193"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (ii)
                                    ensure that such systems are capable of meeting the definition of a covered automated weather system in Alaska; and
                                 
                                 <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H1663FD407E8F45239B3A4E1AB59A7C3F"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (iii)
                                    develop standard operation specifications for visual weather operation systems.
                                 
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HDA0720C7616447CC8FFC237E1BA2AA99"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 Modification of specifications
                                 Upon the request of an aircraft operator, the Administrator shall issue or modify the standard operation specifications for visual weather observation systems developed under subparagraph (A) to allow such systems to be used to satisfy the requirements for supplemental noncertified local weather observations under section 322 of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 (Public Law 115–254).
                              
                           
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H2CDE2B6085074062868ED3FFDF615536"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (e)
                           Weather cameras
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HC49F0236D26A4063A3EBF1238DC8D682"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              In general
                              The Director shall continuously assess the state of the weather camera systems in Alaska and covered locations to ensure the operational sufficiency and reliability of such systems.
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H93370DF991134F55B79251E2F13F8AE3"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              Applications
                              The Director shall—
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HB16ECD05D6A44B60937A7552B81EFD05"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 accept applications from persons to install weather cameras; and
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H1ACF3BE2724F419A99EEE98BBEA566EF"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 consult with the governments with jurisdiction over Alaska and covered locations, covered airports, air carriers operating in Alaska or covered locations, private pilots based in Alaska or covered locations, and such other members of the aviation community in Alaska and covered locations as the Administrator determines appropriate to solicit additional locations at which to install and operate weather cameras.
                              
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HA1108FA5F9904354865E0634C495A894"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (3)
                              Presumption
                              Unless the Director has clear and compelling evidence to the contrary, the Director shall presume that the installation of a weather camera at a covered airport in Alaska, or that is recommended by a government with jurisdiction over a covered location, is cost beneficial and will improve aviation safety.
                           
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H9F17564418D147AD948E7ADB59F8E825"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (f)
                           Cooperation with other agencies
                           In carrying out this section, the Administrator shall cooperate with the heads of other Federal or State agencies with responsibilities affecting aviation safety in Alaska and covered locations, including the collection and dissemination of weather data.
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="HE2FA4EEBB66E4693AAB32C903984EC58"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (g)
                           Surveillance and communication
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H8DE4DD0BC6B84C86971C62D3E9A32ACF"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              In general
                              The Director shall take such actions as may be necessary to—
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H541937FBDC754376B4C04C959C40655B"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 encourage and incentivize the equipage of aircraft that operate under part 135 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, with automatic dependent surveillance and broadcast out equipment; and
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HD8B23735ADF9442CADFD9544C04F1DE5"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 improve aviation surveillance and communications in Alaska and covered locations.
                              
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H61DB44BCDE134B45B6FD9D4137E22C10"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              Requirement
                              Not later than December 31, 2030, the Administrator shall ensure that automatic dependent surveillance and broadcast coverage is available at 5,000 feet above ground level throughout each covered location and Alaska.
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H23ED6091F4AF4E818B4288961C3D6384"
