                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (3)
                              Waiver
                              The Administrator shall waive any positive benefit-cost ratio requirement for—
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H50A54DA7C71842059B57BEECDC10A2F0"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 the installation and operation of equipment and facilities necessary to implement the requirement under paragraph (2); and
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H946E444239294002A563E7D49E70D5B4"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 the provision of additional ground-based transmitters for automatic dependent surveillance-broadcasts to provide a minimum operational network in Alaska along major flight routes.
                              
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H6B1A8B36C44A450EA7E4C191E654F949"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (4)
                              Service areas
                              The Director shall continuously identify additional automatic dependent surveillance–broadcast service areas in which the deployment of automatic dependent surveillance–broadcast receivers and equipment would improve aviation safety.
                           
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H64F1BE86094044A7BCE7ADAA0E3A3D49"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (h)
                           Other projects
                           The Director shall continue to build upon other initiatives recommended in the reports of the FAA Alaska Aviation Safety Initiative of the Administration published before the date of enactment of this section.
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H7B26F17C0B8C4365BE58AB7C112894D1"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           Annual report
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H36B064E45B594376B129B17CC7CC4560"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              In general
                              Beginning on the date that is 1 year after the date of enactment of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2024, and annually thereafter, the Administrator shall submit to the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate a report on the Initiative, including an itemized description of how the Administration budget meets the goals of the Initiative.
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HB4DB6555926545F191B6FA0AB8E253DC"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              Stakeholder comments
                              The Director shall append stakeholder comments, organized by topic, to each report submitted under paragraph (1) in the same manner as appendix 3 of the report titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                         quote-display-start="auto"
                                         quote-type="text">FAA Alaska Aviation Safety Initiative FY21 Final Report, dated September 30, 2021.
                           
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H8710B66FA0D842EEACFF9ED48E84ADBE"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (j)
                           Funding
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H8ED787112A9846D3992A2910A27C4262"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              In general
                              Notwithstanding any other provision of law, for each of fiscal years 2025 through 2028—
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H98239BA1760142E89BE37E0605A5CA20"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 the Administrator may, upon application from the government with jurisdiction over a covered airport and in coordination with the State or territory in which a covered airport is located, use amounts apportioned under subsection (d)(2)(B) or subsection (e) of section 47114 to carry out the Initiative; or
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HC532A75E9D794A83BC65CFDE953BD9BF"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 the sponsor of a covered airport that receives an apportionment under subsection (d)(2)(A) or subsection (e) of section 47114 may use such apportionment for any purpose contained in this section.
                              
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HF3FA1554A4314AA1808EC75E0F6C0077"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              Supplemental funding
                              Out of amounts made available under section 106(k) and section 48101, not more than a total of $25,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2025 through 2028 is authorized to be expended to carry out the Initiative.
                           
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H1C5482671D3A44DDB4809E5ABA1F610C"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (k)
                           Definitions
                           In this section:
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H936DF87F0E9348AA9B3D7D6BF54CE65A"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              Covered airport
                              The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                         quote-display-start="auto"
                                         quote-type="text">covered airport means an airport in Alaska or a covered location that is included in the national plan of integrated airport systems required under section 47103 and that has a status other than unclassified in such plan.
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H3476CD64435F428D89D75557854BE9D5"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              Covered automated weather system
                              The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                         quote-display-start="auto"
                                         quote-type="text">covered automated weather system means an automated or visual weather reporting facility that enables a pilot to begin an instrument procedure approach to an airport under section 91.1039 or 135.225 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H05FF303DFF144FF0AD37482B3F010EAB"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (3)
                              Covered location
                              The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                         quote-display-start="auto"
                                         quote-type="text">covered location means Hawaii, Puerto Rico, American Samoa, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands, and the Virgin Islands.
                           
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="HDF79FEE3D21546E2A759B7C0FEF146DC"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (l)
                           Conformity
                           The Administrator shall conduct all activities required under this section in conformity with section 44720.
                        
                     
                     .
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H10F1217B9D984C55BC82DDF3C8D78326"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Remote positions
                  Section 40122(g) of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="HA7E733FF26BA4446B286D4B190D2042D"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H7C018B8AE7EF47288C48F9C60E0DB3B6"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (7)
                        Remote positions
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H5E42146D3A34495292FC6F56BC184A05"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (A)
                           In general
                           If the Administrator determines that a covered position has not been filled after multiple vacancy announcements and that there are unique circumstances affecting the ability of the Administrator to fill such position, the Administrator may consider, in consultation with the appropriate labor union, applicants for the covered position who apply under a vacancy announcement recruiting from the State or territory in which the position is based.
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H41F6F5C94B19425880201150D27B7055"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (B)
                           Covered position defined
                           In this paragraph, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                      quote-display-start="auto"
                                      quote-type="text">covered position means a safety-critical position, to include personnel located at contract towers, based in Alaska, Hawaii, Puerto Rico, American Samoa, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands, and the Virgin Islands.
                        
                     
                     .
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H5484F83F242746B28FA753969EA6B33C"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  GAO study on Alaska aviation safety
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF06FC6A6219544D6A3E8294B26AAA14F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Study
                     The Comptroller General shall conduct a study to—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HA4CCC1267367442AB3B18E1C437BF78A"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        examine the effectiveness of the Don Young Alaska Aviation Safety Initiative to improve aviation safety, service, and infrastructure; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HDE22A9ABEB6C4D87B07B66824506535D"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        identify challenges within the FAA to accomplishing safety improvements carried out under such Initiative.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD313C26F9F704E1AA01706C83CCBFB46"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Report
                     Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report containing—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE8D243148F2E4EAC972B68EEFAD99C34"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        the findings of the study under paragraph (1); and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HBD1DA571717D457993DF826A8FEDC3C7"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        recommendations for such legislative or administrative action as the Comptroller General determines appropriate.
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H135662C0536B4CA691D82D6D21EBD7FE"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Runway length
                  The Administrator—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8BF2846EE2E449C08C0D5DC3E184DE02"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     may not restrict funding made available under chapter 471 of title 49, United States Code, from being used at an airport in Alaska to rehabilitate, resurface, or reconstruct the full length and width of an existing runway within Alaska based solely on reduced current or forecasted aeronautical activity levels or critical design type standards;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H2EFA9763667741D7A13966834DD01AC5"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     may not reject requests for runway projects at airports in Alaska if such projects address critical community needs, including projects—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HEEA3730CA6454160869452A411F41BCF"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        that support economic development by expanding a runway to meet new demands; or
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H75CFF3518AC24211B95B3B72502BF799"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        that preserve the length of runways used by aircraft to deliver necessary cargo, including heating fuel and gasoline, for the community served by the airport; and
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H7DBFAD8052B14DC28FF5C48C704D7459"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     shall, not later than 60 days after receiving a request for a runway rehabilitation or reconstruction project at an airport in Alaska, review each such request on a case-by-case basis.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H5EB65F3A1D174F87BA9E00E8136FD49E"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Implementation of NTSB recommendations
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H5598A707F0D348B6B86F59E24AECA695"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall take such actions as may be necessary to implement National Transportation Safety Board recommendations A–22–25 and A–22–26 (as contained in Aviation Investigation Report AIR–22–09, adopted November 16, 2022).
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA57068119E114E7586BCCB187C498E64"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Coordination
                     In taking actions under paragraph (1), the Administrator shall coordinate with the State of Alaska, airports in Alaska, air carriers operating in Alaska, private pilots (including tour operators) based in Alaska, and such other members of the Alaska aviation community or other stakeholders as the Administrator determines appropriate.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H133EEE96947840948EE21E496483894B"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (f)
                  Clerical amendment
                  The analysis for chapter 447 of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="HB9D8E9C3BEB4471991929640C237A8FF"
                                 style="OLC">
                     
                        44745. Don Young Alaska Aviation Safety Initiative.
                     
                     .
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HD54919BFB24048F68E68CBFE6DF5487B"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               343.
               ACCOUNTABILITY AND COMPLIANCE
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HECA629E885C94171A901629F0E43C02D"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Section 44704(a) of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="H4EE14552DEB34E75A105CE7344C38D16"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HD82226342E204AA185F61F01BE0D94DF"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (6)
                        Submission of data
                        When an applicant submits design data to the Administrator for a finding of compliance as part of an application for a type certificate, the applicant shall certify to the Administrator that—
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H1DC46AC3D39740C69444B94E711E0E01"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (A)
                           the submitted design data demonstrates compliance with the applicable airworthiness standards; and
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H2ABCBF1FA8B54352B174C00BEF65BA1E"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (B)
                           any airworthiness standards not complied with are compensated for by factors that provide an equivalent level of safety, as agreed upon by the Administrator.
                        
                     
                     .
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H83A376E184CD4F5FAD08AF3CE7574741"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Report to Congress
                  Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall provide to the appropriate committees of Congress a briefing on the implementation of the certification requirement added by the amendment made by subsection (a).
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HF48BA1068B274764A34708714DAB03DF"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               344.
               CHANGED PRODUCT RULE REFORM
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HBCBE413D2B1946059189CE495C2FCCA8"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall issue a notice of proposed rulemaking to revise section 21.101 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, to achieve the following objectives:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H75B6FBCC484F4FDB8C41E0A0498B1424"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     For any significant design change, as determined by the Administrator, to require that the exception related to impracticality under subsection (b)(3) of such section from the requirement to comply with the latest amendments of the applicable airworthiness standards in effect on the date of application for the change be approved only after providing public notice and opportunity to comment on such exception.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC1FAA571B57C426EA1DF8A13E3D9F4AF"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     To ensure appropriate documentation of any exception or exemption from airworthiness requirements in title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, as in effect on the date of application for the change.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H2A52F446687946DEAB2B20B7035D2B0A"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Congressional briefing
                  Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall provide to the appropriate committees of Congress a briefing on the implementation by the FAA of the recommendations of the Changed Product Rule International Authorities Working Group, established for purposes of carrying out the requirements of section 117 of the Aircraft Certification, Safety, and Accountability Act (49 U.S.C. 44704 note), including recommendations on harmonized changes and reforms regarding the impractical exception.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H30AE9E42713B47BABA056C9EAA689EC1"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Final rule
                  Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall issue a final rule based on the notice of proposed rulemaking issued under subsection (a).
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HA89C5FE5C41F4DEDBE71A86764679FB9"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Annual report
                  Beginning in 2025 and annually thereafter through 2028, the Administrator shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress an annual report detailing the number of all significant design change exceptions approved and denied under paragraphs (1) through (3) of section 21.101(b) of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H84168D7FECCA489798A38F89FDEB5D1B"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               345.
               ADMINISTRATIVE AUTHORITY FOR CIVIL PENALTIES
               Section 46301(d) of title 49, United States Code, is amended—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H14246E97CE1F48D0A20A388508131C60"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  in paragraph (4) by striking subparagraph (A) and inserting the following:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="H27DBB538BEB94322B4EFBD4D52C1CAF4"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HB802126FD2F142B091F67485DCF8B4E3"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        the amount in controversy is more than—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HBB9119C170F547F480E3C68688751E72"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           $400,000 if the violation was committed by any person other than an individual or small business concern before the date of enactment of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2024;
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HA91A99EB9EB84C3E99FE4420759B518B"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           $50,000 if the violation was committed by an individual or small business concern before the date of enactment of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2024;
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H7DF9D28F3EDE41D29E53BFD6D506C00B"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iii)
                           $1,200,000 if the violation was committed by a person other than an individual or small business concern on or after the date of enactment of the 
                              FAA Reauthorization Act of 2024; or
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H2B9E229DA5CD4112A0B540A68CFB7AEB"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iv)
                           $100,000 if the violation was committed by an individual on or after the date of enactment of the 
                              FAA Reauthorization Act of 2024;
                        
                     
                     ; and
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HF79AE1DA2F8D4488B29429482765714E"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  by striking paragraph (8) and inserting the following:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="H3C79B5CA2F824B559FD671EFC850D51B"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H6AA9F1CD80D04B778A0E7824E459C382"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (8)
                        The maximum civil penalty the Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration, Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, or Board may impose under this subsection is—
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H352BDFD86D8849FBBD4F7B8825CA744C"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (A)
                           $400,000 if the violation was committed by a person other than an individual or small business concern before the date of enactment of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2024;
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H385C3C7B8A2343DEB2E1E1641B018803"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">

                                       qb-display-quote="yes">

                           $1,200,000 if the violation was committed by a person other than an individual or small business concern on or after the date of enactment of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2024; or
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H3BE9E383163C4E12A2EEF05CBC239525"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (D)
                           $100,000 if the violation was committed by an individual on or after the date of enactment of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2024.
                        
                     
                     .
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HDD11A85A1F6445A688763E3E04A240FF"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               346.
               STUDY ON AIRWORTHINESS STANDARDS COMPLIANCE
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HB58E4D8D87A74305A1D52C517EFB9359"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Study
                  The Administrator shall seek to enter into an agreement with a federally funded research and development center to conduct a study, in consultation with appropriate aviation safety engineers of the FAA, on the occurrences and potential consequences of a transport airplane design found to not comply with applicable airworthiness standards.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HB553C546D6524D67B66F595972619033"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Scope
                  In conducting the study pursuant to subsection (a), the federally funded research and development center shall identify each final airworthiness directive issued by the FAA or another civil aviation authority—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H61F6E3ABB7C74834B48A0E2120293F06"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     applicable to transport airplanes during the 10-year period prior to the date of enactment of this Act; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H00732C35805F4D409013159841DE243C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     to address an unsafe condition resulting from an approved design that was noncompliant with an applicable airworthiness standard.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HD3B073AD35E04BCDB3CF5A6C7B36ED54"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Requirements
                  For each such airworthiness directive identified under subsection (b), the federally funded research and development center shall examine—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H32D24D00DF8D488DBB71DB88FD3B1487"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     the airworthiness standard with which the transport airplane failed to comply;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H5E13569D688248F8BAF80920B34ADD99"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the resulting unsafe condition and whether such condition resulted in an accident;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1D07AC01F9DB40F19A0D5D3653D2AE53"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     the methods by which the noncompliance was discovered and brought to the attention of the FAA or another civil aviation authority, to the extent such methods can be identified;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HFDAB8F7CE7C8482FB6DD06419646DE41"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     an analysis of the method used by the applicant to show compliance during the certification process and whether other compliance methods may have reasonably identified the noncompliance during the certification process;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0AE16ED7044F46E2AAA3137C0D82A559"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     the date of approval of the relevant type design and the date of issuance of the airworthiness directive;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H30DA9F51CB4B406FA5035006EFB3E24C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     any corrective action mandated to address the identified unsafe condition;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA152A3791D774542B3F41DE28BA38A6C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (7)
                     the period of time specified for the incorporation of the corrective action, during which the affected transport airplanes were allowed to operate before the unsafe condition was corrected; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8599E8C24CBA4D6097C16B510FA81559"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (8)
                     the total cost of compliance estimated in the final rule adopting the airworthiness directive.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HE63A6F6A5AA54DBC8780F96D6D9759B3"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Coordination
                  In conducting the study under subsection (a), the federally funded research and development center shall coordinate with, and solicit comments from—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1BB8D22860494901B52277007C2B0FB1"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     transport category aircraft manufacturers; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8A76E9EF2C7D4105884BAC16D3C7B3BA"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     employees of the Administration, including the official bargaining representative of aircraft certification services engineers and of aviation safety engineers under section 7111 of title 5, United States Code, involved in developing airworthiness directives, as necessary.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HA07B1C7F28184626955773E65C378113"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Report to Congress
                  Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report that includes—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4E6B2ECFA4084A4BB3CC5E99E539B95D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     the results of the study conducted under subsection (a);
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC70BA8A2FD6D4F49B195E27B9523BD32"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     actions the Administrator determines necessary to improve safety as a result of the findings under subsection (a) and any root causes of an unsafe condition that were identified;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA5C6B7938CCC4B44B9C4A41462C88F2B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     the comments solicited under subsection (d); and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H12EEB8A9A5C74F62A81FCFE63BD9E1E4"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     any other recommendations for legislative or administrative action determined appropriate by the Administrator.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H97952264EA2743A1AF3BC7947D7BBA1A"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (f)
                  Definitions
                  In this section: 
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H6C3EF21593D642E792386479E85AD958"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Air carrier; foreign air carrier
                     The terms <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">air carrier and <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">foreign air carrier have the meanings given such terms in section 40102 of title 49, United States Code. 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HEA0F16461D5A46119C5FE3907A31B9B9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Transport airplane
                     The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">transport airplane means a transport category airplane designed for operation by an air carrier or foreign air carrier type-certificated with a passenger seating capacity of 30 or more or an all-cargo or combi derivative.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HF923EC57B0D544FD965304F4B8BA66EC"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               347.
               ZERO TOLERANCE FOR NEAR MISSES, RUNWAY INCURSIONS, AND SURFACE SAFETY RISKS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HB2CBF30D707A4ABB9E8BBC3EB04CFDC1"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Policy
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H9BFE4097133C4A0993152CA6F4D1B96F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Section 47101(a) of title 49, United States Code, is amended—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H9236DE80B3E248738454A859263423DD"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        by redesignating paragraphs (2) through (13) as paragraphs (3) through (14), respectively; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HD4340654ED4B477D85230339B4659201"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        by inserting after paragraph (1) the following:
                        <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                       display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       display-quotes="yes"
                                       id="H9454068B5F1D4BCFA328526F88FA9E67"
                                       style="OLC">
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H1F39C94EEE8E4650A869E8C2823DFAD6"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              that projects, activities, and actions that prevent runway incursions serve to—
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HF718CF15510E4BA7A715CEF19903ED9A"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 improve airport surface surveillance; and
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H00DBF8AEF8CA4E17B088BB8EB6B4F859"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 mitigate surface safety risks that are essential to ensuring the safe operation of the airport and airway system;
                              
                           
                           .
                        
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H40B0260DE19443CF827649A901140B84"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Conforming amendments
                     Section 47101 of title 49, United States Code, is amended—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HF6544496217145D6923C7BA2586D0A4B"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        in subsection (g) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">subsection (a)(5) and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">subsection (a)(6); and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HD8D48800AF4E41B2AAB0F922CF6E0C9E"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        in subsection (h) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">subsection (a)(6) and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">subsection (a)(7). 
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE14DC6312A6C48ED914C766E6B6A1D67"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Continuous evaluation
                     In carrying out section 47101(a) of title 49, United States Code, as amended by this subsection, the Administrator shall establish a process to continuously track and evaluate ground traffic and air traffic activity and related incidents at airports.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H2F04F3A9EC2745C9B8DA835AC2454AFF"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Runway safety council
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC08664E3200B439F9E6DE4817992FF0F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Not later than 6 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall establish a council, to be known as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">Runway Safety Council (in this section referred to as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">Council), to develop a systematic management strategy to address airport surface safety risks.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HDE5F53112EE94314B3DA424B315A0CA2"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Duties
                     The duties of the Council shall include, at a minimum, advancing the development of risk-based, data driven, integrated systems solutions and strategies to enhance airport surface safety risk mitigation.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H444C1C124C244C17BB251DD06811A2CB"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Membership
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HD237780F89A448ADB4C1A22DC83407B7"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        In general
                        In establishing the Council, the Administrator shall appoint at least 1 member from each of the following:
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H5356768876C342C5976F4C6D1A6D3B6A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           Airport operators. 
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HB34686A752484439BC8825CCD40DC645"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           Air carriers.
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HE76DA977AFE449029997F0CAA391206E"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iii)
                           Aircraft operators.
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HA903F329A61B4DBDB3C0F4CB5B62C3D0"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iv)
                           Avionics manufacturers. 
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HEFAEDB8F49304F6982DF3A0E022DA428"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (v)
                           Flight schools.
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H7515BCBA3F1D4915AE07B0F331D4608F"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (vi)
                           The exclusive collective bargaining representative of aviation safety professionals for the FAA certified under section 7111 of title 5, United States Code.
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H3CB1E16CCD204DCEA54ECBD577A63771"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (vii)
                           The exclusive bargaining representative of the air traffic controllers certified under section 7111 of title 5, United States Code.
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H8E5314C32B8646D9873483C5A8D97A12"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (viii)
                           Other safety experts the Administrator determines appropriate.
                        
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE62B9437BB9941649EAEA6080DE4FB2E"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        Additional members
                        The Administrator may appoint members representing any other stakeholder organization that the Administrator determines appropriate to the Runway Safety Council.
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HCEC9112DCB9D4B6A8DF9DEF32EAAC6D8"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Airport surface safety technologies
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H00FC7266330E48C981EB21DAE93DC1B4"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Identification
                     Not later than 6 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall, in coordination with the Council, consult with relevant stakeholders to identify technologies, equipment, systems, and process changes, that—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HDD275C90FA204762A62C4D504AD1E602"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        may provide airport surface surveillance capabilities at airports lacking such capabilities;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H48BABEC8CE104A8D8D00C2BF8DBE0975"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        may augment existing airport surface detection and surveillance system; or
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HFB9967E5349D4DA8B257AF21F4273419"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        may improve onboard situational awareness for flight crewmembers, including technologies for use in an aircraft that—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H021BC77E0491498DADE5ADC42E21CFE4"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           reduce the risk of collision on the runway with other aircraft or vehicles;
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H9D0D713FA53C443FB00EADEAE1654507"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           calculate safe landing distances; and
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H89BA33BABB4D4B3B8FEE93B6A48A26FA"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iii)
                           prompt actions to bring the aircraft to a safe stop.
                        
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H762C1A1268E44A93B90AF44EF7D8EEE2"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Criteria
                     Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE2AD01C3DF0E40F78B249F32542002B9"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        based on the information obtained pursuant to paragraph (1)(A) and (1)(B), identify airport surface detection and surveillance systems that meet the standards of the FAA and may be able to—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HD1136D9A1037425597F690CF0385189A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           provide airport surface surveillance capabilities at airports lacking such capabilities; or
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HC7CB7CD6763A4AC79427F1BF29F13D56"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           augment existing airport surface detection and surveillance systems, such as Airport Surface Detection System—Model X or the Airport Surface Surveillance Capability;
                        
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H2F99E6C0957446A3AD32F5817D4B2D3B"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        establish a timeline and action plan for replacing, maintaining, or enhancing the operational capability provided by existing airport surface detection and surveillance systems, and implementing runway safety technologies at airports without airport surface detection and surveillance systems, as needed, to improve runway safety;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HED5D4FB392F34CCCBBDBEF0C1FE64717"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        based on the information obtained pursuant to paragraph (1)(C), identify safety technologies and systems in transport airplanes that meet the standards of the FAA that will—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HBC41D542231F4C40B92C2DA588F0D3A4"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           enhance runway safety for transport airplanes that lack the capabilities of such technologies and systems, as appropriate; or
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HCFD094B556624925A0C958B4C7FAEA63"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           augment existing onboard situational awareness runway traffic alerting and runway landing safety technologies installed on transport airplanes; and
                        
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HA89CC23F9D6F4B409923B78E07672331"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        establish clear and quantifiable criteria relating to operational factors, including ground traffic and air traffic activity and the rate of runway and terminal airspace safety events (including runway incursions), that determine when the installation and deployment of an airport surface detection or surveillance system, or other runway safety system (including runway status lights), at an airport is required.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H5FF4F764795A4B929CD711B8BE318BAB"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Deployment
                     Not later than 5 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall ensure that airport surface detection and surveillance systems are deployed and operational at—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HBFA7EBB7700D477697D988F70D18E50F"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        all airports described in paragraph (2)(A); and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H232CD7420D574D8C8A869236D3EF8393"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        all medium and large hub airports.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA549ABF46F2644F78CE090DFC34ECB81"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Briefing
                     Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the progress of the deployment described in paragraph (3).
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H496F16AA0FAC46ABA8EAA4E686681643"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Foreign object debris detection
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HFE8B99CCDCEA417AA87F80A033D0B891"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall assess, in coordination with the Council, automated foreign object debris monitoring and detection systems at not less than 3 airports that are using such systems.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H929273241D5247FFA5722200A6762A0A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Considerations
                     In conducting the assessment under paragraph (1), the Administrator shall consider the following:
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H4726965E2112445789444662064FE758"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        The categorization of an airport.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H6B71EBC2AF3249DDAB1C074A01DB8E09"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        The potential frequency of foreign object debris incidents on airport runways or adjacent ramp areas.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H1AEAFD285AE44041A019CA60C01E511A"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        The availability of funding for the installation and maintenance of foreign object debris monitoring and detection systems.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HAA11B9001D01429895D6296D41A06BDB"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        The impact of such systems on the airfield operations of an airport.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H8A93CD6DD99643F6B4A10AB3356F9C05"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (E)
                        The effectiveness of available foreign object debris monitoring and detection systems.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H3A0AAC4DD7B04E1D8AFF87B41122A85A"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (F)
                        Any other factors relevant to assessing the return on investment of foreign object debris monitoring and detection systems.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD58A64E181AB4F3CA671EC27FD4C5D87"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Consultation
                     In carrying out this subsection, the Administrator and the Council shall consult with manufacturers and suppliers of foreign object debris detection technology and any other relevant stakeholders.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H88E7FA73DFD44204900F4272070FB220"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Runway safety study
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0751AED1CEB04DCD9EBB937864C53B0C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall seek to enter into appropriate arrangements with a federally funded research and development center to conduct a study of runway incursions, airport surface incidents, operational errors, or losses of standard separation of aircraft in the approach or departure phase of flight to determine how advanced technologies and future airport development projects may be able to reduce the frequency of such events and enhance aviation safety.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD12474875F3C42C7A26650488D264D63"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Considerations
                     In conducting the study under paragraph (1), the federally funded research and development center shall—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HDF5CABD160E04467B70B2A419F5FB2B3"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        examine data relating to recurring runway incursions, surface incidents, operational errors, or losses of standard separation of aircraft in the approach or departure phase of flight at airports to identify the underlying factors that caused such events;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HD4AB098D57FC49A9800367CBBED2B1AD"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        assess metrics used to identify when such events are increasing at an airport;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H2B64F468A5A14E12B85B9305374FD0A3"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        assess available and developmental technologies, including and beyond such technologies considered in subsection (c), that may augment existing air traffic management capabilities of surface surveillance and terminal airspace equipment;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HB7D25B215E4D4DF6B16BDE8534728C5B"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        consider growth trends in airport size, staffing and communication complexities to identify—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H8D4C32CCA9E04DB79EFA9E42D5C800B6"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           future gaps in information exchange between aerospace stakeholders; and
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H315149EEE424431D94246B175E392D0D"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           methods for meeting future near real-time information sharing needs; and
                        
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H5FD8D022B34F48CD8587D0FBD851CA1C"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (E)
                        examine airfield safety training programs used by airport tenants and other stakeholders operating on airfields of airports, including airfield familiarization training programs for employees, to assess scalability to handle future growth in airfield capacity and traffic.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H768847B1E5BA49EF9D30E8C08436CC7F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Recommendations
                     In conducting the study required by paragraph (1), the federally funded research and development center shall develop recommendations for the strategic planning efforts of the Administration to appropriately maintain surface safety considering future increases in air traffic and based on the considerations described in paragraph (2).
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H930FDBFF8C46418BBA341C25AA849BBE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Report to Congress
                     Not later than 90 days after the completion of the study required by paragraph (1), the Administrator shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the findings of such study and any recommendations developed under paragraph (3).
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H273E8318BE1A45899832B73FE4510596"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (f)
                  Definitions
                  In this section:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H6C9F30AF7A854CC8A66E60E8BE6FBAC0"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Air carrier; foreign air carrier
                     The terms <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">air carrier and <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">foreign air carrier have the meanings given such terms in section 40102 of title 49, United States Code. 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H24D2C79C9F734C91AF90448EB58974D6"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Airport surface detection and surveillance system
                     The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">airport surface detection and surveillance system means an airport surveillance system that is—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H39A85A3C09B04526B73E67E3C906A4FC"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        designed to track surface movement of aircraft and vehicles; or
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H402DC0F318B049F0BD3E7D9CFD74BA33"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        capable of alerting air traffic controllers or flight crewmembers of a possible runway incursion, misaligned approach, or other safety event.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HAE0FA8C086604F449B65E25105A1A84B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Transport airplane
                     The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">transport airplane means a transport category airplane designed for operation by an air carrier or foreign air carrier jet type-certificated with a passenger seating capacity of at least 10 seats or a maximum takeoff weight above 12,500 pounds or an all-cargo or combi derivative of such an airplane.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HFC2D1E355A454185B8CD8D6ECB5EA37C"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               348.
               IMPROVEMENTS TO AVIATION SAFETY INFORMATION ANALYSIS AND SHARING PROGRAM
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H0540764AE9B0452D87B0F11AC2371628"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall implement improvements to the Aviation Safety Information Analysis and Sharing Program with respect to safety data sharing and risk mitigation. 
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H5985AB0345AA41528B9FE69DC1E8FD3C"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Requirements
                  In carrying out subsection (a), the Administrator shall—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H6F52F1804B0D4D4FBF54D7CB04594042"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     identify methods to increase the rate at which data is collected, processed, and analyzed to expeditiously share safety intelligence;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H15099C98B8754B9A967F74ECA08B06AB"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     develop predictive capabilities to anticipate emerging safety risks;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H37E519D0FD4841F2B9E8F903A5DF6FB5"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     identify methods to improve shared data environments with external stakeholders;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H7AEE9816C0564F638E486C216E0B1D9F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     establish a robust process for prioritizing requests for safety information;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HFFFAE0FF050F465BB9B271EC829684BD"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     establish guidance to encourage regular safety inspector review of non-confidential aviation safety and performance data;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H97D0DAF048EB438DBA2DAD6561AC569B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     identify industry segments not yet included and conduct outreach to such industry segments to increase the rate of participation, including—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HDE0B919E0A4C4249BFF014EB41DFD997"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        general aviation;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE690630256244DBD939615EA77657496"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        air transportation and commercial aviation;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H3E455F0A758B41B69DA6CF5CC43312B3"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        rotorcraft operations;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H18604144710A44EA8418A03EB60F76E9"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        air ambulance operations; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H54AEA29222C848A8B231A6A662B339F7"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (E)
                        aviation maintenance;
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0ADAF77A904B4D87BACD81C5D07C6305"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (7)
                     establish processes for obtaining and analyzing comprehensive and aggregate data for new and future industry segments; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE2C07AA2A0584E3D9EF9A5C03B29B74B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (8)
