                              Bilateral or multilateral aviation safety agreements entered into under this subsection shall not be construed to diminish or alter any authority of the Administrator under any other provision of law.
                           
                        
                        . 
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H29E47E89A9104B92A1532A14802625AB"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Technical assistance updates
                     Section 40113(e) of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:
                     <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                    display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    display-quotes="yes"
                                    id="HBD6C952D9C9146218AD4EF177ABF58FE"
                                    style="OLC">
                        <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H7F0A5538127F4186867FE962EA4FA3CA"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (6)
                           Technical assistance outside of agreements
                           In the absence of a bilateral or multilateral agreement, the Administrator may provide technical assistance and training under this subsection if the Administrator determines that—
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H6362F89709F44E9DB01F76301CB7DD2D"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (A)
                              a foreign government would benefit from technical assistance pursuant to this subsection to strengthen aviation safety, efficiency, and security; and
                           
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HE94613FF565242639F3CF9296D7E1B6D"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (B)
                              the engagement is to provide inherently governmental technical assistance and training.
                           
                        
                        <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H3E37EE823F1B4BE7A81C362B31337613"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (7)
                           Inherently governmental technical assistance and training defined
                           In this subsection, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                      quote-display-start="auto"
                                      quote-type="text">inherently governmental technical assistance and training means technical assistance and training that—
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H7B69350D94CF4B109180B1965C54F8DF"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (A)
                              relies upon or incorporates Federal Aviation Administration-specific program, system, policy, or procedural matters;
                           
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H28B71118530149E3B56F9C09540CF29C"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (B)
                              must be accomplished using agency expertise and authority; and
                           
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H9A98E5DF4FF444A3B0AF690EF458ED6A"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (C)
                              relates to—
                              <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H2FB37F5144CD45EE95B28A64730A8888"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (i)
                                 international aviation safety assessment technical reviews and technical assistance;
                              
                              <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HAEA842DDCBC34BB49A190D0F908796F5"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (ii)
                                 aerodrome safety and certification;
                              
                              <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H00C6E6B0DFEF4848AF51B29646624380"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (iii)
                                 aviation system certification activities based on Federal Aviation Administration regulations and requirements;
                              
                              <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H3B073E94874B47D4B569C8C54A31E65D"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (iv)
                                 cybersecurity efforts to protect United States aviation ecosystem components and facilities;
                              
                              <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H7A53E1B528CD451EB0E629ADBA25CA8B"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (v)
                                 operation and maintenance of air navigation system equipment, procedures, and personnel; or
                              
                              <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HCFDFD0F39C334337BA0815AF63585CC2"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (vi)
                                 training and exercises in support of aviation safety, efficiency, and security.
                              
                           
                        
                        .
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H34FEA9436F254C35A60FA88FDCAB3C1A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Validation of powered-lift aircraft
                     In carrying out section 40104(d) of title 49, United States Code (as amended by this Act), the Administrator shall ensure coordination with international civil aviation authorities regarding the establishment of mutual processes for efficient validation, acceptance, and working arrangements of certificates and approvals for powered-lift aircraft, products, and articles.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HEF61645EB1924B26AACB8C7907B382D1"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Report on international validation program performance
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HA64498FB0DB5449F8C2433C665049B2C"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        In general
                        Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall initiate a review to evaluate the performance of the type certificate validation program of the FAA under bilateral or multilateral aviation safety agreements, with a focus on agreed to implementation procedures.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HC84C7E1CB48B43F6A49645091B43B86B"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        Contents
                        In conducting the review under subparagraph (A), the Secretary shall consider, at minimum, the following:
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H81C831DF6FB841B08AF39BA43187F318"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           Actions taken for the purposes of carrying out section 243(a) of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 (49 U.S.C. 44701 note).
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H88478D68E0A347C18C4316BC37F31958"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           Metrics from validation programs carried out prior to the initiation of such review, including the number and types of projects, timeline milestones, and trends relating to the repeated use of non-basic criteria.
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H84DCF2057C46417FBE7E1CC4DC476C6A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iii)
                           Training on the minimum standards of established validation work plans, including any guidance on the level of involvement of the validating authority, established justifications for involvement, and procedures for compliance document requests.
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H154653E22338414992AB1C000D01E6C5"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iv)
                           The perspectives of—
                           <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HA6580B80951D42FF9E1F5B2924FF66DB"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (I)
                              FAA employees responsible for type validation projects;
                           
                           <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HCEF57200F8D54C899C7FF6CDCF2695C6"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (II)
                              bilateral civil aviation regulatory partners; and
                           
                           <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HA8BA6D94E9544A5D886F2F9ABC9DE333"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (III)
                              industry applicants seeking validation.
                           
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HCF32074AB21245FFA4ECBEDE456FF74B"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (v)
                           Adequacy of the funding and staffing levels of the International Validation Branch of the Compliance and Airworthiness Division of the Aircraft Certification Service of the FAA.
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H724040C320744DFCA70EF5F0D9C1D898"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (vi)
                           Effectiveness of FAA training for FAA employees.
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HCD37B75683C846658EA07FC17A1D5A34"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (vii)
                           Effectiveness of outreach conducted to improve and enforce validation processes.
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H70BE0C6911284433A999E2D6F3684903"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (viii)
                           Efforts undertaken to strengthen relationships with international certification authorities.
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H723887B0429F4251B3EAE1C17A6D64DB"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ix)
                           Number of approvals issued by other certifying authorities in compliance with applicable bilateral agreements and implementation procedures.
                        
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H62B1447E067241BF85FEBBFE25A596D8"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        Report
                        Not later than 60 days after the completion of the review initiated under this subsection, the Administrator shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report regarding such review.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE9907BE69E8D48E3A7AA355F78660000"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        Definitions
                        In this paragraph, the terms <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">ODA holder and <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">ODA unit have the meanings given such terms in section 44736(c) of title 49, United States Code. 
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HC1858BEF7C8D434BB3B2FC8CF4A71C80"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  International engagement strategy
                  Section 40104(d) of title 49, United States Code, (as redesignated by section 356) is further amended by adding at the end the following:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="H9ACDD707DC584F33BE591DEDDD1043A7"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H2E81C2EA80AC4AC987899DFAE0FAF1B0"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (7)
                        Strategic plan
                        The Administrator shall maintain a strategic plan for the international engagement of the Administration that includes—
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H8D1BBAB5742345B697CE7E42DA7ED43D"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (A)
                           all elements of the report required under section 243(b) of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 (49 U.S.C. 44701 note); 
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HE23C572FF2114A969375FF3EBDD930B4"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (B)
                           measures to fulfill the mission described in paragraph (2);
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H191718F717EA4CAFAC4A864A4D09323C"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (C)
                           initiatives to attain greater expertise among employees of the Federal Aviation Administration in issues related to dispute resolution, intellectual property, and export control laws;
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H5D2966E1139642A8AB17270C4F9931D5"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (D)
                           policy regarding the future direction and strategy of the United States engagement with the International Civil Aviation Organization;
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H53BCAACCF1404E7594B056A53814C831"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (E)
                           procedures for acceptance of mandatory airworthiness information, such as airworthiness directives, and other safety-related regulatory documents, including procedures to implement the requirements of section 44701(e)(5);
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HA39EEBDCB89848FF9FBB049F6FB420C6"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (F)
                           all factors, including funding and resourcing, necessary for the Administration to maintain leadership in the global activities related to aviation safety and air transportation;
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H3C8952545BF64BC5B99B6BDF70E64009"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (G)
                           establishment of, and a process to regularly track and update, metrics to measure the effectiveness of, and foreign civil aviation authority compliance with, bilateral aviation safety agreements; and
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HE8E25EE3A9EC4186903E1B97319017E8"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (H)
                           a strategic methodology to facilitate the ability of the United States aerospace industry to efficiently operate and export new aerospace technologies, products, and articles in key markets globally.
                        
                     
                     .
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HBC6E15B232824D379C76595146C81C05"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Powered-lift aircraft
                  In developing the methodology required under section 40104(d)(7)(H) of title 49, United States Code (as added by subsection (d)), the Administrator shall—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H219232377B0E40359EB6CA487A307432"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     perform an assessment of existing bilateral aviation safety agreements, implementation procedures, and other associated bilateral arrangements to determine how current and future powered-lift products and articles can utilize the most appropriate validation mechanisms and procedures;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H78F9249591154A0ABBCBF5BBC7617457"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     facilitate global acceptance of the approach of the FAA to certification of powered-lift aircraft, products, and articles; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC24772279C2A4BA6B57762C8A165C9F5"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     consider any other information determined appropriated by the Administrator.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HF9C2167CDC924FC58172F054605ADC1A"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               359.
               AVAILABILITY OF PERSONNEL FOR INSPECTIONS, SITE VISITS, AND TRAINING
               Section 40104 of title 49, United States Code, is further amended by adding at the end the following: 
               <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                              display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              display-quotes="yes"
                              id="H2948ABEFB55A4D0C80CC85669977647A"
                              style="OLC">
                  <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                               id="H30F08B7F02844F3E892A65452562703F"
                               qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (f)
                     Travel
                     The Administrator and the Secretary of Transportation shall, in carrying out the responsibilities described in subsection (a), delegate to the appropriate supervisors of offices of the Administration the ability to authorize the domestic and international travel of relevant personnel who are not in the Federal Aviation Administration Executive System, without any additional approvals required, for the purposes of—
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H5A72B39CA7AB461DBF2DBB16A2DF6934"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (1)
                        promoting aviation safety, aircraft operations, air traffic, airport, unmanned aircraft systems, aviation fuels, and other aviation standards, regulations, and initiatives adopted by the United States;
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HF6C85488005942739C9AC8C630ABCC21"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (2)
                        facilitating the adoption of United States approaches on such aviation standards and recommended practices at the International Civil Aviation Organization;
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H505ACFBB957D4954A052FF9D0E49AF5A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (3)
                        supporting the acceptance of Administration design and production approvals by other civil aviation authorities;
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H8C15427C05634A08A788EAF4D5EA2D38"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (4)
                        training Administration personnel and training provided to other persons;
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H0AC2B6E3869F49C4BF07D4ED4B082A75"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (5)
                        engaging with regulated entities, including performing site visits;
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H14DABCA861434B8E869D4353A6E9351F"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (6)
                        activities associated with subsections (c) through (e); and
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H9E7FF2D8558F488584251E06BEF0C1B4"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (7)
                        other activities as determined by the Administrator.
                     
                  
                  .
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H2F411CE134974212A4B9AC0F66D6F753"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               360.
               WILDFIRE SUPPRESSION
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HA563625AC7EB4ADA9EE07F7253BEF7ED"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, to ensure that sufficient firefighting resources are available to suppress wildfires and protect public safety and property, and notwithstanding any other provision of law or agency regulation, the Administrator shall issue a rule under which—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF269F79F4300482CB2ECD29CB6AB4938"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     an operation described in section 21.25(b)(7) of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, shall allow for the transport of firefighters to and from the site of a wildfire to perform ground wildfire suppression and designate the firefighters conducting such an operation as essential crewmembers on board a covered aircraft operated on a mission to suppress wildfire; 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H5AB13301B919485B889A9784EEFDDDA4"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the aircraft maintenance, inspections, and pilot training requirements under part 135 of such title 14 may apply to such an operation, if determined by the Administrator to be necessary to maintain the safety of firefighters carrying out wildfire suppression missions; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H2F92B57FD9DE4131BFC0A772151CA7A3"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     the noise standards described in part 36 of such title 14 shall not apply to such an operation.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H847EAD6B623E414B8BE2D771533400A6"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Surplus military aircraft
                  In issuing a rule under subsection (a), the Administrator may not enable any aircraft of a type that has been—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H75E97200634C4247A889B8C40C374061"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     manufactured in accordance with the requirements of, and accepted for use by, the armed forces (as defined in section 101 of title 10, United States Code); and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC759AC2159A64AB39787AE842DB67072"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     later modified to be used for wildfire suppression operations.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HC92BFC24AC724902B18930EE00B00EC4"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Conforming amendments to FAA documents
                  In issuing a rule under subsection (a), the Administrator shall revise the order of the FAA titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Restricted Category Type Certification, issued on February 27, 2006 (FAA Order 8110.56), as well as any corresponding policy or guidance material, to reflect the requirements of this section.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HE5CA53EE97AC4A13819D48E74A363E32"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Savings provision
                  Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the authority of the Administrator to take action otherwise authorized by law to protect aviation safety or passenger safety.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H449F6764949E4A7D90708D4C9DEA3FCE"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Definitions
                  In this section:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H64EB142CA4534B26930C693FE7591057"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Covered aircraft
                     The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">covered aircraft means an aircraft type-certificated in the restricted category under section 21.25 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, used for transporting firefighters to and from the site of a wildfire in order to perform ground wildfire suppression for the purpose of extinguishing a wildfire on behalf of, or pursuant to a contract with, a Federal, State, or local government agency.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H7F004B55700E4A678233F337C0BDEE09"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Firefighters
                     The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">firefighters means a trained fire suppression professional the transport of whom is necessary to accomplish a wildfire suppression operation. 
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HC6A642CD76904B16B5D1A5EAEF1C5C29"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               361.
               CONTINUOUS AIRCRAFT TRACKING AND TRANSMISSION FOR HIGH ALTITUDE BALLOONS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H4D2BF8F731CC4E79908E9D2A888929AE"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Study on effects of high altitude balloons on aviation safety
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD422C6C44B1A40EFB373D8838F933C32"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator, in coordination with the heads of other relevant Federal agencies, shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the effects of high altitude balloon operations that do not emit electronic or radio signals for identification purposes and are launched within the United States and the territories of the United States on aviation safety. 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H76E92945336C42618319471518109A64"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Considerations
                     In carrying out this subsection, the Administrator shall consider—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H6C4708AC98C0413B93B7E7439507B9D5"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        current technology available and employed to track high altitude balloon operations described under paragraph (1);
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H977922710A184E54914E35929C5DDB66"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        how the flights of such operations have affected, or could affect, aviation safety;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H42022210A6614AC7A821A4EA1178BAE5"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        how such operations have contributed, or could contribute, to misidentified threats to civil or military aviation operations or infrastructure; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H7C81DEF7B66B446B8F2623EA76B8288E"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        how such operations have impacted, or could impact, national security and air traffic control operations.
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H874CEB0BB63D409FBF01038BD8D9A9F7"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  High altitude balloon tracking aviation rulemaking committee
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H00FD82BCBDD44071AA6E0651D3826E45"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Establishment
                     Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall establish an Aviation Rulemaking Committee (in this section referred to as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">Committee) to review and develop findings and recommendations to inform a standard for any high altitude balloon to be equipped with a system for continuous aircraft tracking that transmits, at a minimum, the altitude, location, and identity of the high altitude balloon in a manner that is accessible to air traffic controllers and ensures the safe integration of high altitude balloons into the national airspace system.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4357A58088AE40B59E08B070A14769EE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Composition
                     The Committee shall consist of members appointed by the Administrator, including the following:
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H66EBB72463604197BE18DFBEC8B85373"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        Representatives of industry.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HA5FFE99CB78D4B77B90910847FCB52EF"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        Aviation safety experts, including experts with specific knowledge—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H5CB1BED9D21A4527BDB99C105FC71376"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           of high altitude balloon operations; or
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HDB16F9DBB84046259D09BD72234C7DE0"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           FAA tracking and surveillance systems.
                        
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H6CC91C0C181E463F9DB1A27805235836"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        Non-governmental researchers and educators.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H742660FDFC8143609C8488C7E2F51D97"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        Representatives of the Department of Defense.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H3E63DA80140C4A5EB5B55C9FD188F93A"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (E)
                        Representatives of Federal agencies that conduct high altitude balloon operations.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H210359A86A59487FB1512820E70DF97D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Report
                     Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Committee shall submit to the Administrator a report detailing the findings and recommendations developed under paragraph (1), including recommendations regarding the following:
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H1C4273625EDF4327B28B9A26D4852E0A"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        How to update sections 91.215, 91.225, and 99.13 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, to require all high altitude balloons to have a continuous aircraft tracking and transmission system.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H7A2B36B8B6F747929F3597CF4E69D6A8"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        Any necessary updates to the requirements for high altitude balloons under subpart D of part 101 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H751FCD1628E34CD6A4D2303D41F67357"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        Any necessary updates to other FAA regulations or requirements deemed appropriate and necessary by the Administrator to—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H0BD3B56DEE4E4878AFE02AA98747D98D"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           ensure any high altitude balloon has a continuous aircraft tracking and transmission system;
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H460CF7FF689A459091840053C0738976"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           ensure all data relating to the altitude, location, and identity of any high altitude balloon is made available to air traffic controllers;
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H0F1A87A857884633BFD939B394FC1770"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iii)
                           determine criteria and provide approval guidance for new equipment that provides continuous aircraft tracking and transmission for high altitude balloons and meets the performance requirements described under section 91.225 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, including portable, battery-powered Automatic Dependent Surveillance–Broadcast Out equipage; and
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H337CD27F0B664D20934DC0EF0E8F2A8B"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iv)
                           maintain airspace safety.
                        
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H07A215CB308242F2886D8FE18A06B6DF"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Use of prior work
                     In developing the report under paragraph (3), the Committee may make full use of any research, comments, data, findings, or recommendations made by any prior aviation rulemaking committee.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4CFDA8A83A6B4BCBBABD612FD87A31BE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     New technologies and solutions
                     Nothing in this subsection shall require the Committee to develop recommendations requiring equipage of high altitude balloons with an Automatic Dependent Surveillance–Broadcast Out system or an air traffic control transponder transmission system, or preclude the Committee from making recommendations for the adoption of new systems or solutions that may require that a high altitude balloon be equipped with a system that can transmit, at a minimum, the altitude, location, and identity of the high altitude balloon.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H47794A577FAD4E7B86A878752EED8D89"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     Briefing
                     Not later than 6 months after receiving the report required under paragraph (3), the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the contents of such report and the status of any recommendation received pursuant to such report.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HCBAA7B6FB6864805A237B5A4FF9FE24C"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Definitions
                  In this section, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">high altitude balloon means a manned or unmanned free balloon operating not less than 18,000 feet above mean sea level.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HF343AB02DE334FBC84AEE39D6587191A"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               362.
               CABIN AIR SAFETY
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H49C998716B174EBF87ACDEA207E5BD2A"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Deadline for 2018 study on bleed air
                  Not later than 6 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall complete the requirements of section 326 of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 (49 U.S.C. 40101 note) and submit to the appropriate Congressional committees the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H555C1900B7624123BD648DD3C1E354D9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     The completed study required under subsection (c) of such section.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4002FA33AAD34E61A48B946742E51544"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     The report on the feasibility, efficacy, and cost-effectiveness of certification and installation of systems to evaluate bleed air quality required under subsection (d) of such section.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H46FE33284625414880D920DD06FFF4BB"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Reporting system for smoke or fume events onboard commercial aircraft
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H7D72BB642BE940B1BE3415A2206F12B7"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Not later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall develop a standardized submission system for air carrier employees to voluntarily report fume or smoke events onboard passenger-carrying aircraft operating under part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H975D6053A9E04CDCA3C4743EA086AE10"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Collected information
                     In developing the system under paragraph (1), the Administrator shall ensure that the system includes a method for submitting information about a smoke or fume event that allows for the collection of the following information, if applicable:
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H7AF333DC5F7B48E59C4221ABC18CC1E4"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        Identification of the flight number, type, and registration of the aircraft.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H07D29F3CEA174D528FC1142372C8F44E"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        The date of the reported fume or smoke event onboard the aircraft.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H7FC6AE34B6A64798BB58D69E31EE8023"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        Description of fumes or smoke in the aircraft, including the nature, intensity, and visual consistency or smell (if any).
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE8AAA7CBB12A481DBAAA72D9C3F47E3A"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        The location of the fumes or smoke in the aircraft.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H3307D0BCC7C44A9AA1CBB047150E2DA1"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (E)
                        The source (if discernible) of the fumes or smoke in the aircraft.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HBBFE54DBC1714AE3984EF3B44CDE7BE0"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (F)
                        The phase of flight during which fumes or smoke first became present.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HBC956FBACC0540A3BED7D6DD79613D6D"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (G)
                        The duration of the fume or smoke event.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HEABECAA114D84621B5F9F30A6D031DB2"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (H)
                        Any required onboard medical attention for passengers or crew members.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H2B53BFCFB99A40239CC464B01C25AF45"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (I)
                        Any additional factors as determined appropriate by the Administrator or crew member submitting a report.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H06EF2D47915B432FB5CF2F74A936FDA7"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Guidelines for submission
                     The Administrator shall issue guidelines on how to submit the information described in paragraph (2).
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HCCE75CAB09C54B8D964532C1FF61F386"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Confirmation of submission
                     Upon submitting the information described in paragraph (2), the submitting party shall receive a duplicate record of the submission and confirmation of receipt.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3C487D69BE5B473381AFD70612ACB282"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     Use of information
                     The Administrator—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H2233ECAED3EE45DD9F73CF1F93BCD5D1"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        may not publicly publish any—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HAD5CB2AD5AA14A45AAA5D352B8DE1B40"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           information specific to a fume or smoke event that is submitted pursuant to this section; and
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H61F3BC3647AF4628A4379B3E4B578B9E"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           any information that may be used to identify the party submitting such information;
                        
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HDC005220A2AD4F6B9D741F728C4E3EC4"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        may only publicly publish information submitted pursuant to this section that has been aggregated if—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H3679F2C7CF774E7E9DB40E798214681F"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           such information has been validated; and
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HC1057A5E064F4ABDB4B3B323880BBBCB"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           the availability of such information would improve aviation safety;
                        
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H6D76BCD49F5B4EDB8D9056403C6DF185"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        shall maintain a database of such information;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H66CCF256A3BA4C3F99ECE23CDD185FC4"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        at the request of an air carrier, shall provide to such air carrier any information submitted pursuant to this section that is relevant to such air carrier, except any information that may be used to identify the party submitting such information;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H9D50BFA4D6C54EC6842F6C7BCB3269B5"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (E)
                        may not, without validation, assume that information submitted pursuant to this section is accurate for the purposes of initiating rulemaking or taking an enforcement action;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H3E23EB20712C40A3B2C7769C4C4D7FA4"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (F)
                        may use information submitted pursuant to this section to inform the oversight of the safety management system of an air carrier; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HF269D4F7250B4E97BC59FF39956A4037"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (G)
                        may use information submitted pursuant to this section for the purpose of performing a study or supporting a study sponsored by the Administrator.
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H85BF117CEE8747BCA2D87AB73233BBD9"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  National Academies study on overall cabin air quality
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE1EF7326C25E49DA9DC13F2F3AE1DC0F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall seek to enter into the appropriate arrangements with the National Academies to conduct a study and issue recommendations to be made publicly available pertaining to cabin air quality and any risk of, and potential for, persistent and accidental fume or smoke events onboard a passenger-carrying aircraft operating under part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1AC263C5D3A3417693FECBDD908A3254"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Scope
                     In carrying out a study pursuant to paragraph (1), the National Academies shall examine—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H8DBBE3914C3744F0A5589DCD106B30A2"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        the report issued pursuant to section 326 of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 (49 U.S.C. 40101 note) and any identified assumptions or gaps described in such report;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H45ED78A0296448B8833819F815C86E01"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        the information collected through the system established pursuant to subsection (b);
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H7E56418B14714C1DAB2B6DAE57CA9E0B"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        any health risks or impacts of fume or smoke events on flight crews, including flight attendants and pilots, and passengers onboard aircraft operating under part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H30AF71BF358840C8BE3AE741754534DD"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        instances of persistent or regularly occurring (as determined by the National Academies) fume or smoke events in such aircraft;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H8AA5C9A824874D51AF2A5F14EB4E6DC4"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (E)
                        instances of accidental, unexpected, or irregularly occurring (as determined by the National Academies) fume or smoke events on such aircraft, including whether such accidental events are more frequent during various phases of operations, including ground operations, taxiing, take off, cruise, and landing;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HCF1D536870A94360B12E13B85044E654"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (F)
                        the air contaminants present during the instances described in subparagraphs (D) and (E) and the probable originating materials of such air contaminants;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H5F0A7D3910EC4817BA2ADB57F7603423"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (G)
                        the frequencies, durations, and likely causes of the instances described in subparagraphs (D) and (E); and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H1149E02559F6473588D5F6EBC1B8B337"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (H)
                        any additional data on fume or smoke events, as determined appropriate by the National Academies.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF919EC8FBBA24426BE6E5366F62B581D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Recommendations
                     As a part of the study conducted under paragraph (1), the National Academies shall provide recommendations—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H820680B16A33442AB914928C0C5452AB"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        that, at minimum, address how to—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HCA4DD18DDC7D4EC2867DCDD1D90CAA1F"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           improve overall cabin air quality of passenger-carrying aircraft;
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H8EB594E9ED3049889F12152772086D15"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           improve the detection, accuracy, and reporting of fume or smoke events; and
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HFE61F5DD74794C3C9652D1929017AC1D"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iii)
                           reduce the frequency and impact of fume or smoke events; and
                        
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HBC381CEAC0DA442FB63260300AB59128"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        to establish or update standards, guidelines, or regulations that could help achieve the recommendations described in subparagraph (A).
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4A021710EF7345689ED3E663CE647E6E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Report to Congress
                     Not later than 1 month after the completion of the study conducted under paragraph (1), the Administrator shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a copy of such study and recommendations submitted with such study.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H238CABAFD3D2435A8A993843AD04323B"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Rulemaking
                  Not later than 1 year after the completion of the study conducted under subsection (c), the Administrator may, as appropriate to address the safety risks identified as a result of the actions taken pursuant to this section, issue a notice of proposed rulemaking to establish requirements for scheduled passenger air carrier operations under part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations that may include the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HCAB1B772CE714445ABF23256F6AA2ADD"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Training for flight attendants, pilots, aircraft maintenance technicians, airport first responders, and emergency responders on how to respond to incidents on aircraft involving fume or smoke events.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H6883365D5ECA47C2A99857D4D18C10A2"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Required actions and procedures for air carriers to take after receiving a report of an incident involving a fume or smoke event in which at least 1 passenger or crew member required medical attention as a result of such incident.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD5B2744CD68D4AF1954F273641D8A746"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Installation onboard aircraft of detectors and other air quality monitoring equipment.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HC1EBC35705CC45E194A8EE92D0A41C3C"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Fume or smoke event defined
                  In this section, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">fume or smoke event means an event in which there is an atypical noticeable or persistent presence of fumes or air contaminants in the cabin, including, at a minimum, a smoke event.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HA2EC2F1B786944AABDB7E721072BE164"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               363.
               COMMERCIAL AIR TOUR AND SPORT PARACHUTING SAFETY
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H3CF2F72390E94A6BB180303D01E5A5AE"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Safety requirements for commercial air tour operators
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB1EB11CDC11F4BB1A1C9620F90C41EC2"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Safety reforms
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HA7F810FAF8B045968D95EE027AFC4481"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        Authority to conduct nonstop commercial air tours
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HB3E09FB9958D4F689ACB30F01A05BB0D"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           In general
                           Subject to clause (ii), beginning on the date that is 2 years after the date a final rule is published pursuant to paragraph (3), no person may conduct commercial air tours unless such person either—
                           <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HA8985817E5D442B9A70298D118CD8A84"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (I)
                              holds a certificate identifying the person as an air carrier or commercial operator under part 119 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations and conducts all commercial air tours under the applicable provisions of part 121 or part 135 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations; or
                           
                           <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H070526BBD34942EAB3458F8C9E9B27FF"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (II)
                              conducts all commercial air tours pursuant to the requirements established by the Administrator under the final rule published pursuant to paragraph (3).
                           
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HEEE12F60AEA54530BE9AB54E5DBE23C7"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           Small business exception
                           The provisions of clause (i) shall not apply to a person who conducts 100 or fewer commercial air tours in a calendar year.
                        
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H4DC01750AADB415491BFEE3B3BAA4E26"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        Additional safety requirements
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H531D492894D940DAA92074302D219208"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           In general
                           Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall issue new or revised regulations to require a commercial air tour operator seeking to conduct an operation with a removed or modified door and a person conducting aerial photography operations seeking to conduct an operation with a removed or modified door to receive approval from the Administrator prior to conducting such operation.
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H24329BCD460648E091694D1D971BC8C8"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           Conditions and restrictions
                           In issuing new or revised regulations under clause (i), the Administrator may impose such conditions and restrictions as determined necessary for safety.
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H0BDB2DDEDD3842C88D65044D3CCF8CD6"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iii)
                           Considerations
                           In issuing new or revised regulations under clause (i), the Administrator shall require a commercial air tour operator to demonstrate to any representative of the FAA, upon request, that a pilot authorized to operate such an air tour has received avoidance training for controlled flight into terrain and in-flight loss of control. Such training shall address reducing the risk of accidents involving unintentional flight into instrument meteorological conditions to address day, night, and low-visibility environments with special attention paid to research available as of the date of enactment of this Act on human factors issues involved in such accidents, including, at a minimum—
                           <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H55F6BAE3FBA7495E8B189E32CEB6184E"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (I)
                              specific terrain, weather, and infrastructure challenges relevant in the local operating environment that increase the risk of such accidents;
                           
                           <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H85EBFCF73A354F77A06560C798165A0B"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (II)
                              pilot decision-making relevant to the avoidance of instrument meteorological conditions while operating under visual flight rules;
                           
                           <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HB18652C40584413094F43BDC2DC16399"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (III)
                              use of terrain awareness displays;
                           
                           <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H4CE6A1B3C2734EC190CF1E37821C75BC"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (IV)
                              spatial disorientation risk factors and countermeasures; and
                           
                           <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HFFA89AAE81054D848DD1FDACFF8C5A33"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (V)
                              strategies for maintaining control, including the use of automated systems.
                           
                        
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H96BB9876018E47CFBCD471A8E07D22AB"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Aviation rulemaking committee
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H62A53A55205D4C03BFF69E64F09992B5"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        In general
                        The Administrator shall convene an aviation rulemaking committee to review and develop findings and recommendations to increase the safety of commercial air tours.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H03506448DB6F460E8394116003A5B16C"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        Considerations
                        The aviation rulemaking committee convened under subparagraph (A) shall consider, at a minimum—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HE0F1E17DF18047A5B0E75F42FE591F2F"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           potential changes to operations regulations or requirements for commercial air tours, including requiring—
                           <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H5B60363876074C6388189894EF096755"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (I)
                              the adoption of pilot training standards that are comparable, as applicable, to the standards under subpart H of part 135 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations; and
                           
                           <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H42E72D8D0C214E629703DC2876D24461"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (II)
                              the adoption of maintenance standards that are comparable, as applicable, to the standards under subpart J of part 135 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations;
                           
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H41F15C58AB0B4695A1195A6AC28165DE"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           establishing a performance-based standard for flight data monitoring for all commercial air tour operators that reviews all available data sources to identify deviations from established areas of operation and potential safety issues;
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H1FBBC8FAB16542F8A7D3D3E7F4C72A4C"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iii)
                           requiring all commercial air tour operators to install flight data recording devices capable of supporting collection and dissemination of the data incorporated in the Flight Operational Quality Assurance Program under section 13.401 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations (or, if an aircraft cannot be retrofitted with such equipment, requiring the commercial air tour operator for such aircraft to collect and maintain flight data through alternative methods);
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H611B7E34EF024F24B16F169138613C5E"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iv)
                           requiring all commercial air tour operators to implement a flight data monitoring program, such as a Flight Operational Quality Assurance Program;
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HC6C37700B7304F208A904212590A5C7C"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (v)
                           establishing methods to provide effective terrain awareness and warning; and
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H9C7BEA536D6A4B0BA5464AA245988480"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (vi)
                           establishing methods to provide effective traffic avoidance in identified high-traffic tour areas, such as requiring commercial air tour operators that operate within such areas be equipped with an automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast out- and in-supported traffic advisory system that—
                           <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H498E75A71F024E7E86FF3BCCFE040B8E"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (I)
                              includes both visual and aural alerts;
                           
                           <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
