                                 not later than 90 days after transmission of such notification, request and initiate final discussions with the foreign country to recommend actions by which the foreign country can mitigate the noncompliance; and
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HBD790AE4DBB14FB7BA30C5C052B7C52B"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (C)
                                 after the discussions described in subparagraph (B) have concluded, determine whether or not the noncompliance finding has been corrected;
                              
                           
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H80BF2A5A45A74D31AC58ECF99E182ED2"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (b)
                           Uncorrected non-compliance
                           If the Administrator finds that such foreign country has not corrected the non-compliance by the close of such final discussions—
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H6A6AA2D62B5E4CC8A763565F7A545A78"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              the Administrator shall notify the Secretary of Transportation and the Secretary of State that the condition of noncompliance remains;
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HA54C39526E734C41820AD2022072555C"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              the Administrator, after consulting with informing the Secretary of Transportation and the Secretary of State, shall notify the foreign country of such finding; and
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HBE7E9D0D728A4F62AA00272740D3BEB4"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (3)
                              notwithstanding section 40105(b), the Administrator, after consulting with the appropriate civil aviation authority of such foreign country and notifying the Secretary of Transportation and the Secretary of State, may withhold, revoke, or prescribe conditions on the operating authority of a foreign air carrier that—
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H267710E5F17749ED8E1EE9C2B81B9387"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 provides or seeks to provide foreign air transportation to and from the United States; or
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HA11E7ACDBF7D4F46B1205D0F43F66AEB"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 carries or seeks to carry the code of an air carrier.
                              
                           
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H4DFBB83671274843BB47DAFD86B42BE2"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (c)
                           Authority
                           Notwithstanding subsections (a) and (b), the Administrator retains the ability to take immediate safety oversight actions if the Administrator, in consultation with the Secretary of Transportation and the Secretary of State, as needed, determines that a condition exists that threatens the safety of passengers, aircraft, or crew traveling to or from such foreign country. In this event that the Administrator makes a determination under this subsection, the Administrator shall immediately notify the Secretary of State of such determination so that the Secretary of State may issue a travel advisory with respect to such foreign country.
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H1DE79030C7B5417AA7BCE822EFA721CE"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (d)
                           Public notification
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HD037EA53450F4D8FA035B8F9417966E1"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              In general
                              In any case in which the Administrator provides notification to a foreign country under subsection (b)(2), the Administrator shall—
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HD30216EE723B491A9FA296C76D4941FE"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 recommend the actions necessary to bring such foreign country into compliance with the international standards contained in the Chicago Convention;
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HB79CDECA4A9B4191B29AB94B68D7C018"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 publish the identity of such foreign country on the website of the Federal Aviation Administration, in the Federal Register, and through other mediums appropriate to provide notice to the public; and
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HF16C02A9689E4A58904402D488F0D582"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (C)
                                 brief the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate on the identity of such foreign country and a summary of any critical safety information resulting from an assessment described in subsection (a)(1).
                              
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H4E7D86F217774BCEAD66AC52D27429DD"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              Compliance
                              If the Administrator finds that a foreign country subsequently corrects all outstanding noncompliances, the Administrator, after consulting with the appropriate civil aviation authority of such foreign country and notifying the Secretary of Transportation and the Secretary of State, shall take actions as necessary to ensure the updated compliance status is reflected, including in the mediums invoked in paragraph (1)(B).
                           
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H88EBCFDD6934477E9D7BF52766E678AD"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (e)
                           Accuracy of the IASA list
                           A foreign country that does not have foreign air carrier activity, as described in subsection (a)(1), for an extended period of time, as determined by the Administrator, shall be removed for inactivity from the public listings described in subsection (d)(1)(B), after informing the Secretary of Transportation and the Secretary of State.
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="HD083D982BF20411A9B151A07C922CD43"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (f)
                           Consistency
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H6667A767CDF046639E0534A3BB1CC76D"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              In general
                              The Administration shall use data, tools, and methods that ensure transparency and repeatability of assessments conducted under this section.
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H690DE8F744774D8BAAAD9EC2A51BE97E"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              Training
                              The Administrator shall ensure that Administration personnel are properly and adequately trained to carry out the assessments set forth in this section, including with respect to the standards, methodology, and material used to make determinations under this section.
                           
                        
                     
                     .
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HE3D98F8DF6724271A1DD9E589DE500E9"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Report to congress
                  Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, and annually thereafter through 2028, the Administrator shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the assessments conducted under the amendments made by this section, including the results of any corrective actions taken by noncompliant foreign countries.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H80522E4D012A46F79A95F8C2F0D1698E"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Clerical amendment
                  The analysis for chapter 447 of title 49, United States Code, is further amended by adding at the end the following:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="H21FF3EFB17AE46849924DA60B2BA22C0"
                                 style="OLC">
                     
                        44747. Aviation safety oversight measures carried out by foreign countries.
                     
                     .
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H4929F274185D4BC8865A83EDF7783CAC"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               370.
               WHISTLEBLOWER PROTECTION ENFORCEMENT
               Section 42121(b) of title 49, United States Code, is amended—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HCADEC76FB0054BB6A60C4827557E44C6"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  in the subsection heading by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">
                        Department of Labor complaint procedure
                      and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">
                        Department of Labor and Federal Aviation Administration complaint procedure
                     ; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HF9305DE2901C4BEEBB610D240D1FEA6C"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  by striking paragraph (5) and inserting the following: 
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="H20D8966BC2F44D00847DF56EDDBFADB9"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H0E9C7C545605411D9CDC7580582D6725"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (5)
                        Enforcement of order
                        Whenever any person has failed to comply with an order issued under paragraph (3), the Secretary of Labor and the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration shall consult with each other to determine the most appropriate action to be taken, in which—
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H0CBA85CC5D694BCF95916F47A57CC65B"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (A)
                           the Secretary of Labor may file a civil action in the United States district court for the district in which the violation was found to occur to enforce such order, for which, in actions brought under this paragraph, the district courts shall have jurisdiction to grant all appropriate relief including, injunctive relief and compensatory damages; and
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HFC7A05E681744445A50F5CFF42686013"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (B)
                           the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration may assess a civil penalty pursuant to section 46301.
                        
                     
                     .
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H9DD7A7CBEAF54B5EB21037BDEA80551D"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               371.
               CIVIL PENALTIES FOR WHISTLEBLOWER PROTECTION PROGRAM VIOLATIONS
               Section 46301(d)(2) of title 49, United States Code, is amended by inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">section 42121, before <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">chapter 441.
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H501B79FDF5C94A429347D414A9965B7F"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               372.
               ENHANCED QUALIFICATION PROGRAM FOR RESTRICTED AIRLINE TRANSPORT PILOT CERTIFICATE
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HC38205D8E0784AFD9D173EC92DBD3996"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Program
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1B9D35651FBF46BE9E14B74C9DEDADB0"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Not later than 6 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall establish the requirements for a program to be known as the Enhanced Qualification Program (in this section referred to as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">Program) under which—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HCD60FC49272E436DA60AF37EEF3A1188"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        qualified air carriers are certified by the Administrator to provide enhanced training for eligible pilots seeking to obtain restricted airline transport certificates, either directly by the air carrier or by a certified training institution under part 141 or part 142 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, that is under contract with the qualified air carrier; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H56EF86E24FF447989E4B4B9B0CC1568F"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        qualified instructors and evaluators provide enhanced training to eligible pilots pursuant to the curriculum requirements under paragraph (4).
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD49DC1166634408E8E678DE339ADA2EF"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Qualified instructors and evaluators
                     Under the Program—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HC2AFB456A39F421DBA3A02612DB21E90"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        all testing and training shall be performed by qualified instructors; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE509BEFE54CD431E8F626BC04C2A9E58"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        all evaluations shall be performed by qualified evaluators.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HAF4486F36F2C4B9A93AF2FDFE7700C93"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Pilot assessment
                     Under the Program, the Administrator shall establish guidelines for an assessment that prospective pilots are required to pass in order to participate in the training under the Program. Such assessment shall include an evaluation of the pilot’s aptitude, ability, and readiness for operation of transport category aircraft.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF3522A37673947B4A58A264AE95F9221"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Program curriculum
                     Under the Program, the Administrator shall establish requirements for the curriculum to be provided under the Program. Such curriculum shall include—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H2DB51C1325B94D2CBAB6F0141B927F89"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        a nationally standardized, non-air carrier or aircraft-specific training curriculum which shall—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HCDAF1292ACF04CC385A8865EA8D899F5"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           ensure prospective pilots have appropriate knowledge at the commercial pilot certificate, multi-engine rating, and instrument rating level;
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H94FFDFD79C3843B4A343F0509ADC2A7D"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           introduce the pilots to concepts associated with air carrier operations;
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HB18F1231096C4A24B481638AEB4F1810"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iii)
                           meet all requirements for an ATP Certification Training Program under part 61.156 or part 142 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations; and
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H0531082D888640F4BD68A9CAA295F84F"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iv)
                           include a course of instruction designed to prepare the prospective pilot to take the ATP Multiengine Airplane Knowledge Test;
                        
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HF0933EB694A4401AA9DD26E2ECF50E26"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        an aircraft-specific training curriculum, developed by the air carrier using objectives and learning standards developed by the Administrator, which shall—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H327F37325DF64CEB9162153B840809D7"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           only be administered to prospective pilots who have completed the requirements under subparagraph (A);
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H5667AE110D8740BBA24588BE2B5A1EFA"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           resemble a type rating training curriculum that includes aircraft ground and flight training that culminates in—
                           <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H741C56CA3B424354B8007DC5AB21707D"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (I)
                              the completion of a maneuvers evaluation that incorporates elements of a type rating practical test; or
                           
                           <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HA927617CA261489FAADF93C7525E27EE"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (II)
                              at the discretion of the air carrier, an actual type rating practical test resulting in the issuance of a type rating for the specific aircraft; and
                           
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H1C7249ADB31D4FC5BA9A32F4BE86034A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iii)
                           ensure the prospective pilot has an adequate understanding and working knowledge of transport category aircraft automation and autoflight systems; and
                        
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HB4E3C488C3954F3C8BF474AA79D75C62"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        air carrier-specific procedures using objectives and learning standards developed by the Administrator to further expand on the concepts described in subparagraphs (A) and (B), which shall—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HA5604A0D2E9E4898860270668DA876E1"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           only be administered to prospective pilots who have completed requirements under subparagraphs (A) and (B) and an ATP Multiengine Airplane Knowledge Test;
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H378AE76EAD214C8DB9284241CDC6499C"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           include instructions on air carrier checklist usage and standard operating procedures; and
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H6C50A0D75584495C931BB17D401BCC1F"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iii)
                           integrate aircraft-specific training in appropriate flight simulation training devices representing the specific aircraft type, including complete crew resource management and scenario-based training.
                        
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF0D5A4CA3002435198798394D27040AC"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     Application and certification
                     Under the Program, the Administrator shall establish a process for air carriers to apply for training program certification. Such process shall include a review to ensure that the training provided by the air carrier will meet the requirements of this section, including—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H4EE534DF8B314959BCC048615B132DDD"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        the assessment requirements under paragraph (3);
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HBF0B401D07694149AB5E0E909C85981E"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        the curriculum requirements under paragraph (4);
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H996EFDD91E7C4927A067A4085EC45C69"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        the requirements for qualified instructors under subsection (d)(5); and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H757B540B1FE44215A880C33BE72D121C"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        the requirements for eligible pilots under subsection (d)(2).
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HCD4369FB9F9E465D9C6E642646CD4497"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     Data
                     Under the Program, the Administrator shall require that each qualified air carrier participating in the Program collect and submit to the Administrator such data from the Program that the Administrator determines is appropriate for the Administrator to provide for oversight of the Program.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HAFA35D0B7252421B9894CC835C0A11F0"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (7)
                     Regular inspection
                     Under the Program, the Administrator shall provide for the regular inspection of qualified air carriers certified under paragraph (5) to ensure that the air carrier continues to meet the requirements under the Program.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H2FB43DDE132E41CB99059015E4A1F118"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Regulations
                  The Administrator may issue regulations or guidance as determined necessary to carry out the Program.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HF7B4EE867F024A92B633328F8246648D"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Clarification regarding required flight hours
                  The provisions of this section shall have no effect on the total flight hours required under part 61.159 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, to receive an airline transport pilot certificate, or the Administrator’s authority under section 217(d) of the Airline Safety and Federal Aviation Administration Extension Act of 2010 (49 U.S.C. 44701 note) (as in effect on the date of enactment of this section).
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HDDF08A45223444EE88980BC006F7EF0D"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Definitions
                  In this section:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB3E08B34AEC84C228462DEAF013FFF16"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Air carrier
                     The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">air carrier has the meaning given that term in section 40102 of title 49, United States Code.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC10794BBD66244A0B3B777D11AA7339E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Eligible pilot
                     The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">eligible pilot means a pilot that—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H49C183B626C741208BE4AF1C58CFAD82"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        has—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H986A23C91A894A1CB3D85DB56282C3A3"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           graduated from a United States Armed Forces undergraduate pilot training school;
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HBEA3242EE6CF45F7AF9AD216358A1E9A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           obtained a degree with an aviation major from an institution of higher education (as defined in part 61.1 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations) that has been issued a letter of authorization by the Administrator under part 61.169 of such title 14; or
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H50C92E3215904F2EB913A7CDE07B04F0"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iii)
                           completed flight and ground training for a commercial pilot certificate in the airplane category and an airplane instrument rating at a certified training institution under part 141 of such title 14;
                        
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H5F01DEE0090D452FB5C02D5821CBF3C1"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        has a current commercial pilot certificate under part 61.123 of such title 14, with airplane category multi-engine and instrument ratings under part 61.129 of such title 14; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HF9F67A87E79C4A71866545824B021191"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        meets the pilot assessment requirements under subsection (a)(3).
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H5BE646ACAAAE4BB7AE4B5E4C43050020"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Qualified air carrier
                     The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">qualified air carrier means an air carrier that has been issued a part 119 operating certificate for conducting operations under part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H27796F9756674CE083332440E5F49B54"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Qualified evaluator
                     The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">qualified evaluator means an individual that meets the requirements for a training center evaluator under part 142.55 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, or for check airmen under part 121.411 of such title.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H155104C5E72845A8997782922A29B8F5"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     Qualified instructor
                     The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">qualified instructor means an individual that—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H6AA76F05BEB5429D8A1F165AD3216732"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        is qualified in accordance with the minimum training requirements for an ATP Certification Training Program under paragraphs (1) through (3) of part 121.410(b) of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H7C2B721731D74DD8904F5ECB6440199D"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        if the instructor is a flight instructor, is qualified in accordance with part 121.410(b)(4) of such title;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HDDD31F5B94CE4DDE9924376725374FBB"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        if the instructor is administering type rating practical tests, is qualified as an appropriate examiner for such rating;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HABD6DB3DE47F412B9E580B9A17CFF134"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        received training in threat and error management, facilitation, and risk mitigation determined appropriate by the Administrator; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HEE518B99071F49388007EBD082036E1D"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (E)
                        meets any other requirement determined appropriate by the Administrator.
                     
                  
               
            
         
         <subtitle id="HF40C3F729F8C489595451FC1DFA2542F"
                    qb-display-quote="yes"
                    style="OLC">
            B
            Aviation Cybersecurity
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H8D242A1CF8CF4038A6EB999EC25B9614"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               391.
               FINDINGS
               Congress finds the following:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H9A268F7ADD934B01A215BD978F23DA51"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Congress has tasked the FAA with responsibility for securing the national airspace system, including the air traffic control system and other air navigation services, civil aircraft, and aeronautical products and articles through safety regulation and oversight. These mandates have included protecting against cyber threats affecting aviation safety or the Administration’s provision of safe, secure, and efficient air navigation services and airspace management.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H64737581207B46459F7888FD4BB9C829"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  In 2016, Congress passed the FAA Extension, Safety, and Security Act of 2016, pursuant to which the FAA enhanced the cybersecurity of the national airspace system by—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H57A1B162FEB84BC1A2EBE18751498535"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     developing a cybersecurity strategic plan;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H6F5AA233478D42888900962A3B7174FF"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     coordinating with other Federal agencies to identify cyber vulnerabilities;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H86DA87E4D20C4DE689BFB0CA15CA0306"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     developing a cyber threat model; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H999841F53F134140A212F1157AE68001"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (D)
                     completing a comprehensive, strategic policy framework to identify and mitigate cybersecurity risks to the air traffic control system.
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H045501F275634661A883BBD1B9B8C97D"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  In 2018, Congress passed the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 which—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HD2483FAC3CC34E0AB9AAA85E2F70BF66"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     authorized funding for the construction of FAA facilities dedicated to improving the cybersecurity of the national airspace system;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H2CAFDA98D3834A3591A591ABAD859D97"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     required the FAA to review and update its comprehensive, strategic policy framework for cybersecurity to assess the degree to which the framework identifies and addresses known cybersecurity risks associated with the aviation system, and evaluate existing short- and long-term objectives for addressing cybersecurity risks to the national airspace system;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HDF61A83003FD424FB691A009909A338B"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     created a Chief Technology Officer position within the FAA to be responsible for, among other things, coordinating the implementation, operation, maintenance, and cybersecurity of technology programs relating to the air traffic control system with the aviation industry and other Federal agencies; and 
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HE437C2B84E8445F5AF9A4613762B695B"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (D)
                     directed the National Academy of Sciences to study the cybersecurity workforce of the FAA in order to develop recommendations to increase the size, quality, and diversity of such workforce. 
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H78360470882746579FB436047E19C462"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  Congress has declared that the FAA is the primary Federal agency to assess and address the threats posed from cyber incidents relating to FAA-provided air traffic control and air navigation services and the threats posed from cyber incidents relating to civil aircraft, aeronautical products and articles, aviation networks, aviation systems, services, and operations, and the aerospace industry affecting aviation safety or the provision of safe, secure, and efficient air navigation services and airspace management by the Administration.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H687276ECB7F743A49AB8283DB80431C9"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               392.
               AEROSPACE PRODUCT SAFETY
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HD1C4CB855E624523A30F1E6411AE210E"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Cybersecurity standards
                  Section 44701(a) of title 49, United States Code, is amended—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HBE5D619D634E4095917D308F0538A375"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     in paragraph (1) by inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">cybersecurity, after <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">quality of work,; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HFA0335E1D1AD48A1B03213A647E8ECC0"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     in paragraph (5)—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H495B60593DC44E3A8E530647DC724167"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        by inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">cybersecurity and after <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">standards for; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HC2967614283446428D52FC388F0770F4"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">procedure and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">procedures.
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H9B39D8714ACA4B8399A38EDFCAA326F9"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Exclusive rulemaking authority
                  Section 44701 of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following: 
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="H47E6A5A7B0024D45B7B90119E88294B8"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                  id="HB2ABD757FB264BEFB23070C40E498984"
                                  qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (g)
                        Exclusive rulemaking authority
                        Notwithstanding any other provision of law and except as provided in section 40131, the Administrator, in consultation with the heads of such other agencies as the Administrator determines necessary, shall have exclusive authority to prescribe regulations for purposes of assuring the cybersecurity of civil aircraft, aircraft engines, propellers, and appliances. 
                     
                     .
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H4C33969625A6489F8789B18FE8074755"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               393.
               FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINISTRATION REGULATIONS, POLICY, AND GUIDANCE
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HDEF34B25AC604463A57E310DA3E013BE"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  
                     Chapter 401 of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="H0E83188FBDC443C99FF9BEB9B5CF3803"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                               id="H47E976D472824E4EAC876AD910B6DC9C"
                               qb-display-quote="yes"
                               section-type="subsequent-section">
                        40131.
                        NATIONAL AIRSPACE SYSTEM CYBER THREAT MANAGEMENT PROCESS
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H82BAAAEA6A044859A009DEFF155D15B7"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (a)
                           Establishment
                           The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, in consultation with the heads of other agencies as the Administrator determines necessary, shall establish a national airspace system cyber threat management process to protect the national airspace system cyber environment, including the safety, security, and efficiency of air navigation services provided by the Administration.
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H5190CC26A7B64A55AC2529D2E49AE108"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (b)
                           Issues To be addressed
                           In establishing the national airspace system cyber threat management process under subsection (a), the Administrator shall, at a minimum—
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HED1047E30DFA4D69ACED4A74D8CB0188"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              monitor the national airspace system for significant cybersecurity incidents;
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HFF36FB5D5F294F0E84F15B80E1EEF427"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              in consultation with appropriate Federal agencies, evaluate the cyber threat landscape for the national airspace system, including updating such evaluation on both annual and threat-based timelines;
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HB4AF9CB9285B471D81B4B91C7FF3916B"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (3)
                              conduct national airspace system cyber incident analyses;
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H7B67095F91CF43D2827CF9573649A38E"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (4)
                              create a cyber common operating picture for the national airspace system cyber environment;
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H44269406154E4F2381F940818499D290"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (5)
                              coordinate national airspace system significant cyber incident responses with other appropriate Federal agencies;
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H3CD2C6F0D59E43DF84603D48D4D91ABC"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (6)
                              track significant cyber incident detection, response, mitigation implementation, recovery, and closure;
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H0BAD77DBE8804FD8A83E0878BCC4B33C"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (7)
                              establish a process, or utilize existing processes, to share relevant significant cyber incident data related to the national airspace system; 
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H6C203B9D39F24FC998D0EDD2289ACE95"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (8)
                              facilitate significant cybersecurity reporting, including through the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Agency; and
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H3C05108471124674BCA177E569E53408"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (9)
                              consider any other matter the Administrator determines appropriate.
                           
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H74A2904C21974435972FE09CE2B96D1C"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (c)
                           Definitions
                           In this section:
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H7C90B98D3EBE4535916D9DFB9E272A8A"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              Cyber common operating picture
                              The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                         quote-display-start="auto"
                                         quote-type="text">cyber common operating picture means the correlation of a detected cyber incident or cyber threat in the national airspace system and other operational anomalies to provide a holistic view of potential cause and impact.
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HABC5994EDE1C46DEA9EE0860D3CEDEE2"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              Cyber environment
                              The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                         quote-display-start="auto"
                                         quote-type="text">cyber environment means the information environment consisting of the interdependent networks of information technology infrastructures and resident data, including the internet, telecommunications networks, computer systems, and embedded processors and controllers.
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H499B932A245F4F04AEC03230159E3328"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (3)
                              Cyber incident
                              The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                         quote-display-start="auto"
                                         quote-type="text">cyber incident means an action that creates noticeable degradation, disruption, or destruction to the cyber environment and causes a safety or other negative impact on operations of—
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H0CDFB2A10E404881BC11613FB43DA6E2"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 the national airspace system;
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H53CCF041BB274EB5BD8C813FAE9C978E"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 civil aircraft; or
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H1FF63FF4F6E444C4B9472FBD549FD915"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (C)
                                 aeronautical products and articles.
                              
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HF97834C621134C0EA18AFB8F41EC36DE"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (4)
                              Cyber threat
                              The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                         quote-display-start="auto"
                                         quote-type="text">cyber threat means the threat of an action that, if carried out, would constitute a cyber incident or an electronic attack.
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HB6A3F7FB1BC24E139A539EAA7D426F51"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (5)
                              Electronic attack
                              The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                         quote-display-start="auto"
                                         quote-type="text">electronic attack means the use of electromagnetic spectrum energy to impede operations in the cyber environment, including through techniques such as jamming or spoofing.
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HBBB8630E43E54DB3A532D0338E779CFB"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (6)
                              Significant cyber incident
                              The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                         quote-display-start="auto"
                                         quote-type="text">significant cyber incident means a cyber incident, or a group of related cyber incidents, that the Administrator determines is likely to result in demonstrable harm to the national airspace system of the United States.
                           
                        
                     
                     .
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HABCF7F607E1F4428B556D07A8683EE28"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Clerical amendment
                  The analysis for chapter 401 of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="H08364BBE16044A998E8286AA7034A13B"
                                 style="OLC">
                     
                        40131. National airspace system cyber threat management process.
                     
                     .
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HCE6FF35920AE4A2099EBC40A97B1E4F5"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               394.
               SECURING AIRCRAFT AVIONICS SYSTEMS
               Section 506(a) of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 (49 U.S.C. 44704 note) is amended—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HF9AEC802AC56497986648D41EE3A6EEC"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  in the matter preceding paragraph (1) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">consider, where appropriate, revising and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">revise, as appropriate, existing;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HAA784DAD62B846A185E1A7BE466F219A"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  in paragraph (1) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">and at the end;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H9AE3A082D93343EA873D1271E158ACBC"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  in paragraph (2) by striking the period at the end and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">; and; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H746D328E85AF463BA3C18D2C0771BCAF"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  by adding at the end the following:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="H5ACEEAA0A6E540A4A077A1BB14611739"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H8D0656FDEF274EFDA2DF31415C949015"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (3)
                        to establish a process and timeline by which software-based systems and equipment, including aircraft flight critical systems of aircraft operated under part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, can be regularly screened to attempt to determine whether the software-based systems and equipment have been compromised by unauthorized external or internal access.
                     
                     .
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HA0858D567F0A43A6AB762648C5EAE948"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               395.
               CIVIL AVIATION CYBERSECURITY RULEMAKING COMMITTEE
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H08D8C9E4956E4C72B5BC03A38EE8EA48"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall convene an aviation rulemaking committee on civil aircraft cybersecurity to conduct reviews (as segmented under subsection (c)) and develop findings and recommendations on cybersecurity standards for civil aircraft, aircraft ground support information systems, airports, air traffic control mission systems, and aeronautical products and articles.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HB35F63E8BFAD423CAC6D98560177E211"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Duties
                  The Administrator shall—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H80A4DEFC209A4C538F77C2EB0DBE7B20"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     for each segmented review conducted by the committee convened under subsection (a), submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report based on the findings of such review; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8C9C7045FC924F75B0B8F7333C3B35C8"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     not later than 180 days after the date of submission of a report under paragraph (1) and, in consultation with other agencies as the Administrator determines necessary, for consensus recommendations reached by such aviation rulemaking committee—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H935A527B47E440948868F7FF67BA7BAE"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        undertake a rulemaking, if appropriate, based on such recommendations; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H6B44EF0200F54E2EB4261A9016F8B049"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a supplemental report with explanations for each consensus recommendation not addressed, if applicable, by a rulemaking under subparagraph (A).
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H0430CC6710B243558CCF7B020C722FA9"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Segmentation
                  In tasking the aviation rulemaking committee with developing findings and recommendations relating to aviation cybersecurity, the Administrator shall direct such committee to segment and sequence work by the topic or subject matter of regulation, including by directing the committee to establish subgroups to consider different topics and subject matters.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H2EAD88364A8B4FB69CB366C97A5ECB94"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Composition
                  The aviation rulemaking committee convened under subsection (a) shall consist of members appointed by the Administrator, including representatives of—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H17C2A4A9D6164A4D9F51AA0C8FC00031"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     aircraft manufacturers, to include at least 1 manufacturer of transport category aircraft;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H59965550F865493C9B195D6D8655F706"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     air carriers;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H571712B9C7274E4890A5547BA7DBA46B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     unmanned aircraft system stakeholders, including operators, service suppliers, and manufacturers of hardware components and software applications;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H28E5BFEE57F84960AA84E0521D51C037"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     manufacturers of powered-lift aircraft; 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE861FE681D4342199B9B4FB11C6B668F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     airports;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H251DDBBEF3604D118B95A9AAAAC3E8F3"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     original equipment manufacturers of ground and space-based aviation infrastructure; 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H848FA593CAA748A890D4FD110A713C91"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (7)
                     aviation safety experts with specific knowledge of aircraft cybersecurity; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0383CC7FAD0B43CDAB23C06FEC769E4F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (8)
                     a nonprofit which operates 1 or more federally funded research and development centers with specific knowledge of aviation and cybersecurity. 
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H1309B28F6B954B0499B5C848F47C4461"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Member eligibility
                  Prior to a member’s appointment under subsection (c), the Administrator shall establish appropriate requirements related to nondisclosure, background investigations, security clearances, or other screening mechanisms for applicable members of the aviation rulemaking committee who require access to sensitive security information or other protected information relevant to the member’s duties on the rulemaking committee. Members shall protect the sensitive security information in accordance with part 1520 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H2B9D883197A4434DB51E1B3D4EBA7BE0"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (f)
                  Prohibition on compensation
                  The members of the aviation rulemaking committee convened under subsection (a) shall not receive pay, allowances, or benefits from the Government by reason of their service on such committee.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H772425ADA18B4F088717A43D4159FB2C"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (g)
                  Considerations
                  The Administrator may direct such committee to consider—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE06F6D5AA3B242A9A1B5499307745585"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     existing aviation cybersecurity standards, regulations, policies, and guidance, including those from other Federal agencies, and the need to harmonize or deconflict proposed and existing standards, regulations, policies, and guidance;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H37B3552CB22C400BA6BC144B3795F0FD"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     threat- and risk-based security approaches used by the aviation industry, including the assessment of the potential costs and benefits of cybersecurity actions;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC7D6178BE3A44292A35619F54B23A4A8"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     data gathered from cybersecurity or safety reporting;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HDB855F939FE74C7E9643F0C2FDFDAB70"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     the diversity of operations and systems on aircraft and amongst air carriers;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0BEA8BDE0E8543038B60CEE95F653FCE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     design approval holder aircraft network security guidance for operators;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H2D322765BEF0418ABCC353C603D714C7"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     FAA services, aviation industry services, and aircraft use of positioning, navigation, and timing data in the context of Executive Order No. 13905, as in effect on the date of enactment of this Act;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE704CAE191DD46CEB06386E14E1A3B3C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (7)
                     updates needed to airworthiness regulations and systems safety assessment methods used to show compliance with airworthiness requirements for design, function, installation, and certification of civil aircraft, aeronautical products and articles, and aircraft networks;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA7067CEDA854474498716765CAD9B2A1"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (8)
                     updates needed to air carrier operating and maintenance regulations to ensure continued adherence with processes and procedures established in airworthiness regulations to provide cybersecurity protections for aircraft systems, including for continued airworthiness;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE94918BB5A8D4140BC13047947102806"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (9)
                     policies and procedures to coordinate with other Federal agencies, including intelligence agencies, and the aviation industry in sharing information and analyses related to cyber threats to civil aircraft information, data, networks, systems, services, operations, and technology and aeronautical products and articles;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H17DF8068DE9643CD8401DD1A5947D3C1"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (10)
                     the response of the Administrator and aviation industry to, and recovery from, cyber incidents, including by coordinating with other Federal agencies, including intelligence agencies;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4A38CFEBBE094C6BA4260E27BAED6436"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (11)
                     processes for members of the aviation industry to voluntarily report to the FAA cyber incidents that may affect aviation safety in a manner that protects trade secrets and confidential business information;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H6DE7495C1A5F46A68ED8FBFB9FDB779F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (12)
                     appropriate cybersecurity controls for aircraft networks, aircraft systems, and aeronautical products and articles to protect aviation safety, including airworthiness;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0E2539D7A88B44C689EF040112A5EC7A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (13)
                     appropriate cybersecurity controls for airports relative to the size and nature of airside operations of such airports to ensure aviation safety; 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H35D599ABF4944062A031B361C67F5264"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (14)
                     minimum standards for protecting civil aircraft, aeronautical products and articles, aviation networks, aviation systems, services, and operations from cyber threats and cyber incidents;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC94213AD91DB4609BF9F3343162EB246"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (15)
                     international collaboration, where appropriate and consistent with the interests of aviation safety in air commerce and national security, with other civil aviation authorities, international aviation and standards organizations, and any other appropriate entities to protect civil aviation from cyber incidents and cyber threats;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1E717A9A687048BBB03317E5471B18D6"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (16)
                     activities of the Administrator under section 506 of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 (49 U.S.C. 44704 note) (as amended by section 394); and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H70D79C8B767B41F39EF8F7613325D461"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (17)
                     any other matter the Administrator determines appropriate.
