                  Report
                  Not later than 2 years after the date of the establishment of the task group, the task group shall submit to the Secretary and the appropriate committees of Congress a report detailing—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H7348AA0703E940CEBC6DD8EE1AF784B5"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     the results of the review under paragraph (3)(A); and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HF17F327BC57449C7B67CC50FFD5C45A8"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     progress on the implementation of recommendations pursuant to subparagraphs (D) and (E) of paragraph (3); and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H2BE19DEDCDF24F848FDBFB32631C6E0D"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     the activities carried out pursuant to fulfilling the duties described in subparagraphs (F) and (G) of paragraph (3).
                  
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H9F85DA7FDA7D45A9962128EAE104CE53"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (e)
               Support
               The Administrator shall seek to enter into 1 or more agreements with the National Academies to support the activities of the working group described in subsection (c).
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H36E2DB0C948F4C25AF6830392AFAD681"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (f)
               Findings and recommendations
               Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, and annually thereafter, the working group shall submit to the Administrator and the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the findings and recommendations resulting from the activities carried out under subsection (c).
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H95AC449C25BD440192EDEF3B1F72E1F8"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (g)
               Implementation
               Not later than 1 year after receiving recommendations outlined in the report under subsection (f), the Administrator may take such action, as appropriate, to implement such recommendations.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H72F2C564792F4FBF98E28D1A7A20E7ED"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (h)
               Sunset
               The working group shall terminate on October 1, 2028.
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HC8E356B2617040EFA81C191FDFD4E1FB"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            412.
            FRONTLINE MANAGER WORKLOAD STUDY
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H78FCDB4512994FDAA5F3152D25DEBC5E"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall conduct a study on frontline manager workload challenges in air traffic control facilities.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H75F41FA95C08463D881494F3C38D62A8"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Considerations
               In conducting the study required under subsection (a), the Administrator may—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H255CDD65337E4105AC21E48B288E3298"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  consider—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HEE3C003B5F314DF0852F3C684707FAE1"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     workload challenges including—
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HDA64BB1C7C974B9993238CEC05E47672"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (i)
                        the tasks expected to be performed by frontline managers, including employee development, management, and counseling;
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H77B2C4CAABAD4662A293561BEEC886EC"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (ii)
                        the number of supervisory positions of operations requiring watch coverage in each air traffic control facility;
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H2406D3C0A26E4F12959E8EBD7EFEE15B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (iii)
                        the complexity of traffic and managerial responsibilities; and
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HFAD92446C396407DB617CE4AD0E95663"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (iv)
                        proficiency and training requirements;
                     
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HF6A8887A8F894387A82A3E3EF7D09828"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     facility type;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HF08C888621354CC3A1A13651066B8738"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     facility staffing levels; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H17184587FEBE422F9256556CBA78AD0B"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (D)
                     any other factors as the Administrator considers appropriate; and
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H89890E1ACC0C4CAFB87F8CC4D3556592"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  describe recommendations for updates to the Frontline Manager’s Quick Reference Guide that reflect current operational standards.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HF899AE92D85C4673BFADA7F2C9BC53AD"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Briefing
               Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the results of the study conducted under subsection (a).
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HC27F91D3F1E446C7B4B006C89FF4D241"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            413.
            MEDICAL PORTAL MODERNIZATION TASK GROUP
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HC3127F7AEBF74307B8326B2BDBC8D850"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Establishment
               Not later than 120 days after the working group pursuant to section 411 is established, the co-chairs of such working group shall establish a medical portal modernization task group (in this section referred to as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">task group) to evaluate the user interface and information sharing capabilities of an online medical portal administered by the FAA.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HAB816A1B09234293BC16E1A8AB572094"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Composition
               The co-chairs of the working group provided for in section 411 shall appoint—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H759E8257C4A14389BC9D93A5C3A7FD45"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  a Chair of the task group; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H9283DF258BE8457FB34303CDDE133ABC"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  members of the task group from among the members of the working group appointed by the Administrator under section 411(b).
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H5CDD8A2DB26543388670723F4147E394"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Assessment; recommendations
               The task group shall, at a minimum, assess and evaluate the capabilities of any such medical portal and provide recommendations to improve the following:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H246AB6DBC98448E19CDA0B158FE3A9F4"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  The cybersecurity protections and protocols of any such medical portal, including the secure exchange of health information and records between Aviation Medical Examiners and pilots, or their designee, including the ability for airmen to submit additional information requested by the Administrator. 
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H11E7E1A38B9A492697C2C2C7E6067012"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  The status of an airman’s medical application and the disclosure of how long an airman can expect to wait for a final determination to be issued by the Administrator.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HF4F7910BD6364A96A4A6629562CD64A3"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  The disclosure of the name and contact information of the Administrator’s representative managing an airman’s case so that an Aviation Medical Examiner has a point of contact within the Administration who is familiar with an airman’s application.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HA50BE5622FDF44ABA615B0902FA44742"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (d)
               Consultation
               In carrying out the duties described in subsection (c), the task group may consult with cybersecurity experts and individuals with a knowledge of securing electronic health care transactions.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H9F1B8EE1909A46B4A3F74872BA6704E4"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (e)
               Report
               Not later than 1 year after the date of the establishment of the task group, the task group shall submit to the Administrator and the appropriate committees of Congress a report detailing activities and recommendations of the task group.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H42D0D9F648C54B2FBDF4C6AF9341E86B"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (f)
               Implementation
               Not later than 1 year after receiving the report described in subsection (e), the Administrator may take such action as may be necessary to implement recommendations of the task group to improve any such medical portal.
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H61E2ADE8375541459BE9708C03189968"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            414.
            STUDY OF HIGH SCHOOL AVIATION MAINTENANCE TRAINING PROGRAMS
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H1A16F7FFD10042EF9B5DE6B4549B45FA"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall initiate a study to assess high school aviation maintenance technician programs and identify any barriers for graduates of such programs with respect to—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HB1AA4865761F4E26A4B6763AB9D936AB"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  pursuing post-secondary or vocational academic training at an FAA-approved aviation maintenance technician school; or
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HF4674C1C93944755B1DF2EFB3CBF4FC7"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  obtaining the training and experience necessary to become an FAA-certificated mechanic through on-the-job training or alternative pathways.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H2B19A5E62842484CB68649B6C3721C83"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Contents
               The study required under subsection (a) shall assess the following:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HBD2F655667CB4977843D931AE23389B3"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  The number of high school aviation maintenance programs in the United States and the typical career outcomes for graduates of such programs.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H3B02FE2CB3A946EEA39F7572B96B4F38"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  The extent to which such programs offer curricula that align with FAA mechanic Airman Certification Standards.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H9206B9F3B7C44CB5845901C9B75FADE9"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  The number of such programs that partner with FAA-approved aviation maintenance technician schools (as described in part 147 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations).
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H39F6689EB5C7429D819C61AC874C48C4"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  The level of engagement between the FAA and high school aviation maintenance programs with respect to developing curricula to build the foundational knowledge and skills necessary for a student to attain FAA mechanic certification and associated ratings.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HA37CD72140A44B81A2C117276BE6BC97"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (5)
                  Barriers to accessing the general knowledge test described in section 65.71(a)(3) of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H8C9E1AA6C5BB4482BDDE1C3F395DDF2A"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (6)
                  The applicability of all FAA regulations and policies in effect on the day before the date of enactment of this Act as such regulations and policies apply to student enrollees of high school aviation maintenance programs and whether such regulations or policies pose any barriers to students interested in pursuing a career in the field of aviation maintenance. 
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H4D6919BF6B9544228298EC2CE6418BB5"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Report
               Not later than 2 years after the completion of the study required under this section, the Comptroller General shall provide to the Administrator and the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the findings of such study, including recommendations for any legislative and administrative actions as the Comptroller General determines appropriate. 
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HD4972BAC9FAA46FAA7360B18769E4752"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            415.
            IMPROVED ACCESS TO AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL SIMULATION TRAINING
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HAC80CB72F2CE4CC69968BC9F7782C081"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               The Administrator shall continue making tower simulator systems (in this section referred to as <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">TSS) more accessible to all air traffic controller specialists assigned to an air traffic control tower of the FAA (in this section referred to as an <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">ATCT), regardless of facility assignment.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HE7024BD213F8458495D7B0980BEC5020"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Cloud-based visual database and software system
               Not later than 30 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall develop and implement a cloud-based visual database and software system that is compatible with existing and future TSS that, at a minimum, includes—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H5951D2C3271240C8AAEB14ADAA0F5A47"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  the unique runway layout, approach paths, and lines of sight of every ATCT; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H31CD0E742F1A4AD18F1C4FF2CD9FECF7"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  specifications that meet all applicable data security requirements.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H29BF6BE3924346F7BD9F8A9FACBA1569"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               TSS upgrades
               Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall upgrade existing, permanent TSS so that the TSS is, at a minimum, capable of—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HD82D63C790B246BA8F0BF05ACCEE5D8C"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  securely and quickly downloading data from the cloud-based visual database and software system described in subsection (b); and 
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HF2DC45330350493AB444A27B8C174232"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  running scenarios for each ATCT involving differing levels of air traffic volume and varying complexities, including, aircraft emergencies, rapidly changing weather, issuance of safety alerts, special air traffic procedures for events of national or international significance, and recovering from unforeseen events or losses of separation.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H8FF36F4EF3E84F198BF416DA0448ABBF"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (d)
               Mobile TSS
               Not later than 4 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall acquire and implement mobile TSS at each ATCT that is without an existing, permanent TSS so that the mobile TSS is capable of, at a minimum, the capabilities described in paragraphs (1) and (2) of subsection (c).
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H105C4C678C78472CA84913E09F5184A9"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (e)
               Collaboration
               In carrying out this section, the Administrator may collaborate with the exclusive bargaining representative of air traffic controllers certified under section 7111 of title 5, United States Code. 
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H234B8E553C904E68BA449A925A4CC6D3"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            416.
            AIR TRAFFIC CONTROLLER INSTRUCTOR RECRUITMENT, HIRING, AND RETENTION
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H64E52D11E72F48BCBB875775E4BB7137"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               No later than 270 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall initiate a study examining the recruitment, hiring, and retention of air traffic controller instructors and the projected number of instructors needed to maintain the safety of the national airspace system over a 5-year period beginning with fiscal year 2025.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H37643A8A64B8477ABA9942090C390391"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Contents
               The Administrator shall include in the study required under subsection (a) the following:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HDA81E538DD38447393AC9390497524D2"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  An examination of projected instructor staffing targets, including the number of on-the-job instructors needed for the instruction and training of Certified Professional Controllers (in this section referred to as <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">CPCs) in training.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HBA0C4BC502454DAD9EADF20F62CF23BE"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  An analysis on whether involving additional retired CPCs as instructors, including for classroom training, would produce improvements in air traffic controller instruction and training.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H7F15605D1BED4F5D99240A4A46F74565"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  Recommendations on how and where to utilize retired CPCs.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H4F94963E2D2D4FD1837F28A1FFD064BD"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  The effect on the ability of active CPCs to carry out on-the-job duties, other than instruction, and any related efficiencies if additional retired CPCs were involved as instructors.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H227E95167F2C4F8A8EE9D7DB73422E0E"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (5)
                  The known vulnerabilities, as categorized by FAA Air Traffic Organization regions, in cases in which the FAA requires CPCs to provide instruction and training to CPCs in training is a significant burden on FAA air traffic controller staffing levels.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HE9372E50822346BBB309CC38A4F04C46"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Deadline
               Not later than 2 years after the date on which the Administrator initiates the study required under subsection (a), the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the results of the study and any actions that may be taken by the Administrator based on such results. 
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H914EC77A861645B0B0C8CD3A3C918386"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            417.
            ENSURING HIRING OF AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL SPECIALISTS IS BASED ON ASSESSMENT OF JOB-RELEVANT APTITUDES
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HE74C1D20DDEF42708BA16C4A155EC4C3"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Review of the air traffic skills assessment
               Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall review and revise, if necessary, the Air Traffic Skills Assessment (in this section referred to as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">AT–SA) administered to air traffic controller applicants described in clauses (ii) and (iii) of section 44506(f)(1)(B) of title 49, United States Code, in accordance with the following requirements, the Administrator shall:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HF0A1D7A6354F4F60BA4A8D603F1242FC"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Evaluate all questions on the AT–SA and determine whether a peer-reviewed job analysis that ensures all questions test job-relevant aptitudes would result in improvements in the air traffic control specialist workforce training and hiring process.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HEC8CB502B9E44F468BD9E051F79A9B5C"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Assess the assumptions and methodologies used to develop the AT–SA, the job-relevant aptitudes measured, and the scoring process for the assessment.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H2EA2F65A249042268B8CF5026E140A83"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  Assess whether any other revisions to the AT–SA are necessary to enhance the air traffic control specialist workforce training and hiring process. 
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HD81D76BAEF3346ECB1418FB245299401"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               DOT inspector general report
               Not later than 180 days after the completion of the review and any necessary revision of the AT–SA required under subsection (a), the inspector general of the Department of Transportation shall submit to the Administrator, the appropriate committees of Congress, and, upon request, to any member of Congress, a report that assesses the AT–SA and any applicable revisions, a description of any associated actions taken by the Administrator, and any other recommendations to address the results of the report. 
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HBA0338386FD24BFBB9E5D0F7CC9D6A43"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            418.
            PILOT PROGRAM TO PROVIDE VETERANS WITH PILOT TRAINING SERVICES
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HE9D1CE2F4A344DEEAE358E950C39548F"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Education and the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, shall establish a pilot program to provide grants to eligible entities to provide pilot training activities and related education to support a pathway for veterans to become commercial aviators.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H64D0A9967F5E415EB7B9447C4944F5BF"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Eligible entity
               In this section, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">eligible entity means a pilot school or provisional pilot school that—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H26262C765A8343E7A72DB836B4182045"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  holds an Air Agency Certificate under part 141 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H38A5D168B31840068E58710D376A1F97"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  has an established employment pathway with at least 1 air carrier operating under part 121 or 135 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H1ABC36CA13BB4D98A49EE46D98854894"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Priority application
               In selecting eligible entities under this section, the Secretary shall prioritize eligible entities that meet the following criteria:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H609B1551EE2A4E92BDB70E00065913AD"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  An eligible entity accredited (as defined in section 61.1 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations) by an accrediting agency recognized by the Secretary of Education.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HAD2CF72CADBD4284A25ABCAFD95FB644"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  An eligible entity that holds a letter of authorization issued in accordance with section 61.169 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HDE3215F34EBF4DA9BF50A539ECE8A79C"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (d)
               Use of funds
               Amounts from a grant received by an eligible entity under the pilot program established under subsection (a) shall be used for the following:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H7E6F39BE9E23475F884116978E215D46"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Administrative costs related to implementation of the program described in subsection (a) not to exceed 5 percent of the amount awarded.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H1C8D3C6F43B449028949FEAB981C3830"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  To provide guidance and pilot training services, including tuition and flight training fees for veterans enrolled with an eligible entity, to support such veterans in obtaining any of the following pilot certificates and ratings: 
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H9E6F925614E24623B4203408226ECEE8"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     Private pilot certificate with airplane single-engine or multi-engine ratings.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H659851EBBC964A04AC60616E9BB1EEBF"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     Instrument rating.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HC0D29A091597430C8627C69F9F285981"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     Commercial pilot certificate with airplane single-engine or multi-engine ratings.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H34DF9D2C64F743E1A4383DC24E5B6835"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (D)
                     Multi-engine rating.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H9DD987BE496C446A943EAF3FE5560562"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (E)
                     Certificated flight instructor single-engine certificate, if applicable to the degree sought.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HF19FB9A7CC094C34B0D52E5F5A42B19F"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (F)
                     Certificated flight instructor multi-engine certificate, if applicable to the degree sought.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H3D4B787C5FCB407DB7DFEB28F5D9DB41"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (G)
                     Certificated flight instructor instrument certificate, if applicable to the degree sought.
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HD0EABBD6A3CB44E1A177A4C78209DF4A"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  To provide educational materials, training materials, and equipment to support pilot training activities and related education for veterans enrolled with the eligible entity.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H3BF1A1FCF5E34E1B802BC5090AA7E7D2"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  To provide periodic reports to the Secretary on use of the grant funds, including documentation of training completion of the certificates and ratings described in subparagraphs (A) through (G) of paragraph (2).
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H6EA4654234374155AD54C53124D997A4"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (e)
               Award amount limit
               An award granted to an eligible entity shall not exceed more than $750,000 in any given fiscal year.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H638B1960E8414E24B0493312420877AE"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (f)
               Appropriations
               To carry out this section, there is authorized to be appropriated $5,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2025 through 2028. 
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H54098D9DD02948CA98EFD547FE416530"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            419.
            PROVIDING NON-FEDERAL WEATHER OBSERVER TRAINING TO AIRPORT PERSONNEL
            The Administrator may take such actions as are necessary to provide training that is easily accessible and streamlined for airport personnel to become certified as non-Federal weather observers so that such personnel can manually provide weather observations in any case in which automated surface observing systems and automated weather observing systems experience outages and errors to ensure operational safety at airports.
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HFB7B92491A724A6AAD8DF49A6F7EFB39"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            420.
            PROHIBITION OF REMOTE DISPATCHING
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HF4530691D0A14A7CA31EC3F9A066B887"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Amendments to prohibition
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H05BF88CA5B434D05BBBDDDC168EE2952"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  In general
                  Section 44711(a) of title 49, United States Code, is amended—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HF508D33BB9C54FD99BDFA26B86D18674"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     in paragraph (9) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">or after the semicolon;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H76140E89995D425689B8737CA47079CD"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     by redesignating paragraph (10) as paragraph (11); and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H776FDCE43E21439886CC6FB4FC9E7120"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     by inserting after paragraph (9) the following:
                     <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                    display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    display-quotes="yes"
                                    id="HA9EF6F3E3F634508BFE90C795CB1D246"
                                    style="OLC">
                        <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HBB8035C85390494F87DE8BCAB364D0F2"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (10)
                           work as an aircraft dispatcher outside of a physical location designated as a dispatching center or flight following center of an air carrier, except as provided under section 44747; or
                        
                        .
                     
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HF87E81DBCD6A4FDFA36D1F8568FB1B79"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Regulations
                  Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall issue regulations requiring persons to comply with section 44711(a)(10) of title 49, United States Code (as added by paragraph (1)).
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HB6A3EEA50EE147328201CE49A5E65F23"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Aircraft dispatching
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H7CD413A7115A45F18542EBD319F200F3"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  In general
                  
                     Chapter 447 of title 49, United States Code, is further amended by adding at the end the following:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="HED9B892CF92040AF8C83A17DA263AE8D"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                               id="H2B61C909066C4DBD8DF80DDAE6CB2289"
                               qb-display-quote="yes"
                               section-type="subsequent-section">
                        44748.
                        AIRCRAFT DISPATCHING
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H63F61C30C07E4901BCA421007F72BAE0"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (a)
                           Aircraft dispatching certificate
                           No person may serve as an aircraft dispatcher for an air carrier unless such person holds the appropriate aircraft dispatcher certificate issued by the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration.
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H18B115C8BB9C41C4AD8E67C7DE461530"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (b)
                           Proof of certification
                           Upon the request of the Administrator or an authorized representative of the National Transportation Safety Board, or other appropriate Federal agency, a person who holds such a certificate, and is performing dispatching, shall present the certificate for inspection.
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H108F2A99B1EA41249541DE8A1876C1CD"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (c)
                           Dispatch centers and flight following centers
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HD084F88A628C4AF7A6F1E0AB0BC11F74"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              Establishment
                              Each air carrier shall establish and maintain sufficient dispatch centers and flight following centers necessary to maintain operational control of each flight of the air carrier at all times.
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H50067D23997543F8BFB52C0A2FE0B8E4"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              Requirements
                              An air carrier shall ensure that each dispatch center and flight following center of the air carrier—
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HBF99396A1F2746FD83355D48BD140F85"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 has a sufficient number of aircraft dispatchers on duty at the dispatch center or flight following center to ensure proper operational control of each flight of the air carrier at all times;
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HBA721510F1BD47C3A4C19A46F17E587F"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 has the necessary equipment, in good repair, to maintain proper operational control of each flight of the air carrier at all times; and
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HB27E8734A8BF47479CDE47C94D5BF1E0"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (C)
                                 includes the presence of physical security and cybersecurity protections to prevent unauthorized access to the dispatch center or flight following center or to the operations of either such center.
                              
                           
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H6004818D0FFF48CEB01FE4F5134288D6"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (d)
                           Prohibition
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HF756FF11A21F48F2B1DB69CC91B7EC0B"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              In general
                              Except as provided in paragraph (2), an air carrier may not dispatch aircraft from any location other than the dispatch center or flight following center of the air carrier.
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HC64516C0EE9D49CBBE45384B02C3A9D1"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              Emergency authority
                              In the event of an emergency or other event that renders a dispatch center or a flight following center inoperable, an air carrier may dispatch aircraft from a location other than the dispatch center or flight following center of the air carrier for a period of time not to exceed 14 consecutive days per location without approval of the Administrator.
                           
                        
                     
                     .
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H4745D86EEF07459E9C913FEC6437ECB7"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Clerical amendment
                  The analysis for chapter 447 of such title is further amended by adding at the end the following:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="H7CF80B50B9464148961E5477184CD159"
                                 style="OLC">
                     
                        44748. Aircraft dispatching.
                     
                     .
                  
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H4F87E40C7CCC41E3A12563A8B0F6FF92"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            421.
            CREWMEMBER PUMPING GUIDANCE
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HF92D20B351B84BB0BB6863BFC78E4696"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall issue guidance to part 121 air carriers relating to the expression of milk by crewmembers on an aircraft during noncritical phases of flight, consistent with the performance of the crewmember's duties aboard the aircraft. The guidance shall be equally applicable to any lactating crewmember. In developing the guidance, the Administrator shall—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H0D0592BECC5045CA983E140672A4905E"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  consider multiple methods of expressing breast milk that could be used by crewmembers, including the use of wearable lactation technology; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HF2631D6C973247D09392DEBBF45F605F"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  ensure the guidance will not require an air carrier or foreign air carrier to incur significant expense, such as through—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HCB14718E792242A8BC2F04EA30FFE452"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     the addition of an extra crewmember in response to providing a break;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HF2FFD68023AA49E4A0CA332BA9D548F6"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     removal or retrofitting of seats on the aircraft; or
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H7C7DA550DE0549B2AF546E6A4D83399D"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     modification or retrofitting of an aircraft.
                  
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H8358087DAAFC45FA8D4F5B01F341EB40"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Definitions
               In this section:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H58F8F60BE67E41BA8D68D9B90993AD56"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Crewmember
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">crewmember has the meaning given such term in section 1.1 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H5E5E899C798E47A3847E58C39B849F9D"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Critical phases of flight
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">critical phases of flight has the meaning given such term in section 121.542 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H999C63A04E264BEAAA5EEEEA96DFEF42"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  Part 121
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">part 121 means part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H0D0A5393C83F43BF95AFD1761A0CCE21"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Aviation safety
               Nothing in this section shall limit the authority of the Administrator relating to aviation safety under subtitle VII of title 49, United States Code. 
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H1FA7F811DDDE40F99DD567C4A09DB53A"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            422.
            GAO STUDY AND REPORT ON EXTENT AND EFFECTS OF COMMERCIAL AVIATION PILOT SHORTAGE ON REGIONAL/COMMUTER CARRIERS
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H3D15073D591D4526A59CEF84E4CD3169"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Study
               The Comptroller General shall conduct a study to identify the extent and effects of the commercial aviation pilot shortage on regional/commuter carriers (as such term is defined in section 41719(d) of title 49, United States Code). 
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HF83C4D78C2FD400CAF456FDF5EF87B0E"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Report
               Not later than 12 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report containing the results of the study conducted under subsection (a), including recommendations for such legislation and administrative action as the Comptroller General determines appropriate. 
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H5A55032F120E460DA6632F907DA3495A"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            423.
            REPORT ON IMPLEMENTATION OF RECOMMENDATIONS OF FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINISTRATION YOUTH ACCESS TO AMERICAN JOBS IN AVIATION TASK FORCE
            Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary, acting through the Administrator, shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the implementation of the following recommendations of the Youth Access to American Jobs in Aviation Task Force of the FAA established under section 602 of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 (Public Law 115–254):
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                        id="H219D68092FEC42C19D95059DB9F1E6F8"
                        qb-display-quote="yes">
               (1)
               Improve information access about careers in aviation and aerospace.
            
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                        id="H24AFF7DDFA474CA18A8329A89437B3E0"
                        qb-display-quote="yes">
               (2)
               Collaboration across regions of the FAA on outreach and workforce development programs.
            
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                        id="H08A07AB14BDD448E8BACC5CE75B166D2"
                        qb-display-quote="yes">
               (3)
               Increase opportunities for mentoring, pre-apprenticeships, and apprenticeships in aviation.
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HDFE54DB7334348429A7B74D3C89DDE38"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            424.
            SENSE OF CONGRESS ON IMPROVING UNMANNED AIRCRAFT SYSTEM STAFFING AT FAA
            It is the sense of Congress that the Administrator should leverage the Unmanned Aircraft System Collegiate Training Initiative to address any staffing challenges and skills gaps within the FAA to support efforts to facilitate the safe integration of unmanned aircraft systems and other new airspace entrants into the national airspace system.
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H753A0A8132A744D98CAF42C0DA080953"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            425.
            JOINT AVIATION EMPLOYMENT TRAINING WORKING GROUP
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H75969E7FEAEA4CE5A34F0581975DAAA9"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Establishment
               Not later than 120 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall establish an interagency working group (in this section referred to as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">working group) to advise the Secretary and the Secretary of Defense on matters and policies related to increasing awareness of the eligibility, training, and experience requirements needed to become an FAA-certified or a military-covered aviation professional in order to improve career transitions between the military and civilian workforces.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HB2C5A49F743E4D4693E068F04EBC3F29"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Membership
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H554B8C74BC6C4D0DA84AC66738BC5B92"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  In general
                  The working group shall consist of—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H64E466F958A34260AFE0B0D35CB49C82"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     2 co-chairs described in paragraph (2);
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H673138854FFC4C80BC6599B8118D1A43"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     not less than 6 representatives of the FAA, to be appointed by the co-chair described in paragraph (2)(A); and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H41C298686D7440E082ED07CA9EC93DBA"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     not less than 1 representative of each component of the armed forces (as such term is defined in section 101 of title 10, United States Code), to be appointed by the co-chair described in paragraph (2)(B).
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HB69CD07510D24E0A8B8E5AD65F675043"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Co-Chairs
                  The working group shall be co-chaired by—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H0DF28FCBA3604A93A4FEC84B2ADAF53F"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     a representative of the Department of Transportation, to be appointed by the Secretary; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H92B859D8977048EC99D3FF58D043E0D1"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     a representative of the Department of Defense, to be appointed by the Secretary of Defense.
                  
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HBDAFD2E53F37458897E44D581BEC5532"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Activities
               The working group shall—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HE54E2335EF194100874F8F926EC38C79"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  evaluate and compare all eligibility, training, and experience requirements for individuals interested in becoming FAA-certified, or serving in the armed forces, as covered aviation professionals, including agency policies, guidance, and orders affecting covered aviation professionals;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H98267CC0C99848E3BB702D45BF420D83"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  identify challenges that inhibit recruitment, training, and retention within the respective workforces of such professionals;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H2B73F328C7A4416DA859A86EECCD0BC4"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  assess methods to improve outreach, engagement, and awareness of eligibility, training, and experience requirements needed to enter careers of covered aviation professionals;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HE45A654513AB42FAB9CEB9F5B4EACFB9"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  consult with representatives from nonprofit organizations supporting veterans and representatives from aviation industry organizations representing covered aviation professionals in the development of recommendations required pursuant to subsection (d)(2)(B); and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HE6C58D165A1B47CD8DBFAFF5DDA784FB"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (5)
                  identify opportunities for increased interagency information sharing across workforces on matters related to certification pathways, including knowledge testing, affecting covered aviation professionals.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H27C6FCA052E346D1A34822331ACE5881"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (d)
               Initial report to Congress
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H1B7BE3DE27A6449FB474AD5BF67DBADC"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  In general
                  Not later than 1 year after the date on which the Secretary establishes the working group, the working group shall submit to the covered committees of Congress an initial report on the activities of the working group.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H0538D56661CE447DACBF0EE64C6C7358"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Contents
                  The report required under paragraph (1) shall include—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H7ACFE75FCF86431E8AA44618870F5AFC"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     a detailed description of the findings of the working group pursuant to the activities required under subsection (c), including feedback offered by representatives described in subsection (c)(4); and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H20A718A32E2546F8BE918112E4F10D02"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     recommendations for regulatory, policy, or legislative action to improve awareness of the eligibility, training, and experience requirements needed to become FAA-certified or military-covered aviation professionals across the civilian and military workforces.
                  
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H81F1D6951E6A456595798B927B2491C2"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (e)
               Annual reporting
               Not later than 1 year after the date on which the working group submits the initial report under subsection (d), and annually thereafter, the working group shall submit to the covered committees of Congress a report—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HF73689037A4E49A9968FFE19F0A73CCD"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  describing the continued activities of the working group;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HA1CDD7F8FA9F4A06B38172EC3BA5CB25"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  describing any progress made by the Secretary or Secretary of Defense in implementing the recommendations described in subsection (d)(2)(B); and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H449CE009A1664281A117BD1BFDD6F433"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  containing any other recommendations the working group may have with respect to efforts to improve the employment and training of covered aviation professionals in the civilian and military workforces.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HE2E65D46929C4400BCA7ADDB5C4DC7AE"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (f)
               Sunset
               The working group shall terminate on the date that is 4 years after the date on which the working group submits the initial report to Congress pursuant to subsection (d).
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H5F4AE7E2A9E44374B50C18DE125499E3"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (g)
               Definitions
               In this section:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H3F76FBAE81B84D6F964948ED4288C282"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Covered committees of Congress
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">covered committees of Congress means—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H2848DF48E3F24299B26C07193A011DAB"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     the Committee on Armed Services of the House of Representatives;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H86052C010A59481896DD0713360401A9"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     the Committee on Armed Services of the Senate;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H485AA2C237044902A0FE9916FD4B31D0"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HC426704A8DC64756B29430AFDEE36F60"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (D)
                     the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate.
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HC27C37036A924EEBB09F4253591B6218"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Covered aviation professional
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">covered aviation professional means—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HFC6BDCC5BEB143B5AD3E7DA90F37F9BB"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     an airman;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HEDFE6F6434714C44B74B79BB9F1A34D7"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     an aircraft maintenance and repair technician; 
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H79534666ECB24C03893B9E799EEECD3E"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     an air traffic controller; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H130AB09E4C6E43F58D3395476F911EF7"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (D)
                     any other aviation-related professional that has comparable tasks and duties across the civilian and military workforces, as determined jointly by the co-chairs of the working group.
                  
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H324EECC4D4C243AA9CB3BA82204AB215"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            426.
            MILITARY AVIATION MAINTENANCE TECHNICIANS RULE
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H642C7F418FBF49FBBBE40A128B16AEC6"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Streamlined certification for eligible military maintenance technicians
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H24097092E5D8421C96721CB35D0C0795"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Rulemaking
                  Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall issue a notice of proposed rulemaking to revise part 65 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, to—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HC1A6B2B0FA664B8CB51AB0DCAA9329D1"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     create a military mechanic written competency test that addresses gaps between military and civilian experience; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H5648DB40B6964AF09F651ED7AAAC9194"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     develop, as necessary, a relevant Airman Certification Standard to qualify eligible military maintenance technicians for a civilian mechanic certificate with airframe or powerplant ratings.
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H1DA4EE2D9D164DCBA6DB29B4BB43E950"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Consideration
                  In carrying out paragraph (1), the Administrator shall evaluate and consider—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HBC819D33A8A742408D2F56D538369C6B"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     whether to allow a certificate of eligibility from the Joint Services Aviation Maintenance Technician Certification Council (in this section referred to as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">JSAMTCC) evidencing completion of a training curriculum for any rating sought to serve as a substitute to fulfill the requirement under such part 65 for oral and practical tests administered by a designated mechanic examiner for eligible military maintenance technicians;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H88B5924F83FE4D638DAD4327D98FD80A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     aeronautical knowledge subject areas contained in the Aviation Mechanic General, Airframe, and Powerplant Airman Certification Standards as described in section 65.75 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, as appropriate, to the rating sought; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HB44C61A33D91410BB8F7E58454EB8DAB"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     any applicable recommendations by the Aviation Rulemaking Advisory Committee Airman Certification System Working Group.
                  
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H75E1770A7AF24CB8930867DFE8D59097"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Expansion of testing locations
               Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of Homeland Security, shall determine—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H7E9B6A943C164DE9AC629F3C777D5BD5"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  whether an expansion of the number of active testing locations operated within military installation testing centers would increase access to testing; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H35BEC1AD184D4309AD3CAE0A932DDBD5"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  how to implement such expansion, if appropriate.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H0C3A845D120E4D0CA43E16022EA0FF03"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Outreach and awareness
               Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator, in coordination with the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, and the Secretary of Homeland Security, shall develop a plan to increase outreach and awareness regarding services made available by the JSAMTCC and how such services can assist in facilitating the transition between military and civilian aviation maintenance careers.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H62F8F2FCB69B466DAB62D87AF58BD468"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (d)
               Briefings
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HF37C65F9F2714B4E80B7D8853334C861"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Initial briefing
                  Not later than 180 days after the date on which the Administrator develops the outreach and awareness plan pursuant to subsection (c), the Administrator shall provide to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation and the Committee on Veterans’ Affairs of the Senate and the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure and the Committee on Veterans’ Affairs of the House of Representatives a briefing on the activities planned to implement the outreach and awareness plan.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HB89BD283E3854D20A50502FFF5954FDC"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Periodic briefing
                  Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, and 2 years thereafter, the Administrator shall provide to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation and the Committee on Veterans’ Affairs of the Senate and the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure and the Committee on Veterans’ Affairs of the House of Representatives a briefing on any rulemaking activities carried out pursuant to subsection (a), including a timeline for the issuance of a final rule.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H461D545BBD57453784053F3AA297E818"
