                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (e)
               Eligible military maintenance technician defined
               For purposes of this section, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">eligible military maintenance technician means an individual who—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HA1A2BD9C25154304AF172CC4B102DBD9"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  has been a maintenance technician during service in the armed forces who was honorably discharged or has retired from the armed forces (as defined in section 101 of title 10, United States Code);
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H335DD186320642108DE2A4960BD8C915"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  presents an official record of service in the armed forces confirming that the individual has been a military aviation maintenance technician, holding an appropriate Military Occupational Specialty Code, as determined by the Administrator, in coordination with the Secretary of Defense; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HE0E0790B92E8430A9FA5216F9B4481EE"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  presents documentary evidence of experience in accordance with the requirements under section 65.77 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations. 
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H7EA8550D86D24944A4D9AAD1240E143A"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            427.
            CREWMEMBER SELF-DEFENSE TRAINING
            Section 44918 of title 49, United States Code, is amended—
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                        id="HA8C5A12D2DBD47F3A0E43D98DD8E9D72"
                        qb-display-quote="yes">
               (1)
               in subsection (a) by—
               <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB23703AFA0014BEFB555D1384E9AB395"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (A)
                  in paragraph (1) by inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">and unruly passenger behavior before the period at the end;
               
               <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H828473814E8D4D4EA0D0E0515732EA7E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (B)
                  in paragraph (2)—
                  <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H632FE3B157E4435AB687F9D94F753591"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (i)
                     by striking subparagraph (A) and inserting the following:
                     <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                    display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    display-quotes="yes"
                                    id="H3B923EFD1450400FA6AAE4368DB8A966"
                                    style="OLC">
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H19400323977B4EF1A21E54E5C37F3878"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (A)
                           Recognize suspicious behavior and activities and determine the seriousness of any occurrence of such behavior and activities. 
                        
                        ;
                     
                  
                  <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H97F44555C594492E8E5D9858AFFA9EF3"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (ii)
                     by striking subparagraph (H) and inserting the following:
                     <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                    display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    display-quotes="yes"
                                    id="HD23BCB59953F48F3BD7CF3FD591D8B69"
                                    style="OLC">
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HC02888252D194FA2A92CC17A4953B23A"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">

                           De-escalation training based on recommendations issued by the Air Carrier Training Aviation Rulemaking Committee. 
                        
                        ;
                     
                  
                  <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H4CF6A9E161EB47069C40BA64ADB39A52"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (iii)
                     by redesignating subparagraphs (I) and (J) as subparagraphs (J) and (K), respectively; and
                  
                  <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HB8C0B43AF17C4BD48247ABABFE8477E9"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (iv)
                     by inserting after subparagraph (H) the following:
                     <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                    display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    display-quotes="yes"
                                    id="H804107E6F5D44D6C8F6792F661C53B91"
                                    style="OLC">
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HB7F7FFDB925D4639BAEBEF1CFAB469A7"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (I)
                           Methods to subdue and restrain an active attacker. 
                        
                        ;
                     
                  
               
               <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8D1AB2B187A44090A752C54D59490AD8"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (C)
                  by striking paragraph (4) and inserting the following:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="H385BC51D4A954D22957AC4DA0F5156AF"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H7312E50962D645D69394DB74FF695379"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (4)
                        Minimum standards
                        Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2024, the Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration, in consultation with the Federal Air Marshal Service and the Aviation Security Advisory Committee, shall establish minimum standards for—
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H17B800FF8417455C8C9C97A3E60A4112"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (A)
                           the training provided under this subsection and any for recurrent training; and
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HAE9ECA46671E43B8AE4021D95AFCDEC2"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (B)
                           the individuals or entities providing such training.
                        
                     
                     ; and
                  
               
               <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HFB5B39FD36E247FB83F7818F4EA0A9E5"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (D)
                  in paragraph (6)—
                  <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H728B084828B740B4BB3C594EC4A157D8"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (i)
                     in the first sentence—
                     <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HDDC8E46F8E844258ACBBD6EFC5152849"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (I)
                        by inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">and the Federal Air Marshal Service after <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">consultation with the Administrator;
                     
                     <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H87AE6EA1B75E486BB0A28E59D436C215"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (II)
                        by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">and periodically shall and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">and shall periodically; and
                     
                     <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HB1E81D71B5F6473C9648E843B75ADAB7"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (III)
                        by inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">based on changes in the potential or actual threat conditions before the period at the end; and
                     
                  
                  <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H2F09E5A471E8485CBA9546D0CF98F15F"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (ii)
                     in the third sentence by inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">, including self-defense training expertise and experience before the period at the end; and
                  
               
            
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                        id="H5848E58CE1E9402183F163455987C1E2"
                        qb-display-quote="yes">
               (2)
               in subsection (b)—
               <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H55038900A2704F8C83C163F79C32D0FA"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (A)
                  in paragraph (4) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Neither and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Except as provided in paragraph (8), neither; and
               
               <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H88BC1764063D45009D963F94EF3C4F4D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (B)
                  by adding at the end the following:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="H20241A8F389947FA8488B61E498AA6C1"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H1B03342770DA4CC89DEDC4226261B8B4"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (8)
                        Air carrier accommodation
                        An air carrier with a crew member participating in the training program under this subsection shall provide a process through which each such crew member may obtain reasonable accommodations.
                     
                     .
                  
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HFD2846CD928645F888D2B1E5EAB9B616"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            428.
            DIRECT-HIRE AUTHORITY UTILIZATION
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HE6F10AEDE33441729FD9DD07D716E2F3"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               The Administrator shall utilize direct hire authorities (as such authorities existed on the day before the date of enactment of this Act) to hire individuals on a non-competitive basis for positions related to aircraft certification and aviation safety. In utilizing such authorities, the Administrator shall take into consideration any staffing gaps in the safety workforce of the FAA, including in positions supporting the safe integration of unmanned aircraft systems and other new airspace entrants.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H11D27538404449C7A7912ED3CB5AE629"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Congressional briefing
               Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, and annually thereafter through 2028, the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HE94394F2F3B14C54A473C45B73054F79"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  utilization of the Administrator's direct-hire authorities described in subsection (a);
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HFFAF06CDD83F4B0EBD7E3B45C1422310"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  utilization of the Administrator's direct-hire authorities with respect to the Unmanned Aircraft System Collegiate Training Initiative of the FAA; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H6F2A5811864A4C3EBA88F487BB0D8601"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  number of employees hired as a result of the utilization of such authorities by the Administrator, the relevant lines of business or offices in which such employees were hired, and the occupational series of the positions filled.
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H933547E3650B487C9A48D85884DBBDB2"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            429.
            FAA WORKFORCE REVIEW AUDIT
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H8E85349237F14EB297FE77D0FBE3ACD6"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               Not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the inspector general of the Department of Transportation shall initiate an audit of any FAA workforce plans completed during the 5 fiscal years preceding the fiscal year in which such audit is initiated related to occupations the agency relies on to accomplish its aviation safety mission.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HF3B470E72C994595B46726BCFABDC6C3"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Contents
               In conducting the audit under subsection (a), the inspector general shall—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HBA250654F6F54166A618EDEF17A94295"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  identify whether any safety-critical positions have not been reviewed within the period specified in subsection (a);
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H4F539C80A0FD424391322B695D5F2948"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  assess staffing levels and workforce retention trends relating to safety-critical occupations within all offices of the FAA that support such services;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H4D8A2A2BA6AD4C5CB056F24718F83322"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  review FAA workforce gaps in safety-critical and senior positions, including the average vacancy period of such positions during the most recent fiscal year in the period specified in subsection (a);
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H2A46FAC916AF4466927154C7D2627E56"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  evaluate any applicable assessments of the historic workload of safety-critical positions and changes in workload demands over time;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HB173E0C57928441AB4113B49693546C6"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (5)
                  analyze any applicable assessments of critical competencies and skills gaps among safety-critical positions conducted by the FAA and any relevant agency actions in response;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HECD1A6F01CC2419992510E21F4175944"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (6)
                  review whether existing FAA workforce development programs are producing intended results, especially in rural communities, such as increased recruitment and retention of agency personnel; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H6F8DFD6A0C4E45D2A548BC70FEE4F87B"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (7)
                  review opportunities (as such opportunities exist on the date of enactment of this Act) for employees of the FAA to gain or enhance expertise, knowledge, skills, and abilities through cooperative training with appropriate aerospace companies and organizations, including—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H2B43267D54374D04A4871378C094B03F"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     assessing the appropriateness of existing cooperative training programs and any conflicts of interest or the appearance of such conflicts with FAA policies and obligations relating to FAA employee interactions with aviation industry;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HA757ED11614E4575BB81185181C48D84"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     identifying a means by which to leverage such programs to support credentialing and recurrent training activities for FAA employees, as appropriate;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H763069D47236433C9EAC73E8F7292DF4"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     assessing the policies and procedures the FAA has established to avoid both conflicts of interest and the appearance of such conflicts for employees participating in such opportunities, which may include requirements under—
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H320FC9040DDB41039BAD985650CA0165"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (i)
                        
                           chapter 131 of title 5, United States Code;
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8C866E25F0774ED693712541993D16F6"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (ii)
                        
                           chapter 11 of title 18, United States Code;
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H5FB02DD3C4ED47A4B0825C753E0B93D0"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (iii)
                        subchapter B of chapter XVI of title 5, Code of Federal Regulations; and
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HFB83A7610C42412F8008C555B15D2925"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (iv)
                        sections 2635.101 and 2635.502 of title 5, Code of Federal Regulations; and
                     
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H07C3A4AC944D4AAB9BE50FD710EFACC9"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (D)
                     evaluating whether the conflict of interest policies and procedures of the FAA for such opportunities provide for the appropriate means by which employees return to work at the FAA after having engaged in such opportunities.
                  
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H422887E6358A448CA1F9A3FA6487B67B"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Inspector general report
               Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the inspector general shall submit to the Administrator and the appropriate committees of Congress—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H5287EACB4C7F43F9A40A0086B37947F8"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  a report on the results of the audit conducted under subsection (a); and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H4D390F00165F4A2F9E8FDCE1F8E72C52"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  recommendations for such legislative and administrative action as the inspector general determines appropriate.
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HB6FBCB9EF7AC4377B32847E33CEE0304"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            430.
            STAFFING MODEL FOR AVIATION SAFETY INSPECTORS
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HAD853016D14840FFA27FF66DA08CCD9F"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall review and, as necessary, revise the staffing model for aviation safety inspectors.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H059EE8620AA94DC5B7932BEEF75D2A66"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Requirements
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H20117EF9CBC74EE4A59F53881F2D7A24"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Consideration of prior studies and reports
                  In reviewing and revising the model, the Administrator shall take into consideration the contents and recommendations contained in the following:
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H00A1C3F46365471EA5E20E5A0B35D8F6"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     The 2006 report released by the National Research Council titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">Staffing Standards for Aviation Safety Inspectors.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HCF590F22820E453C8F5A91BACDD312BC"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     The 2007 study released by the National Academy of Sciences titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">Staffing Standards for Aviation Safety Inspectors.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H0F729D1F6C37445BA989E31377F4A62F"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     The 2013 report released by Grant Thornton LLP, titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">ASTARS Gap Analysis Study: Comparison of the AVS Staffing Model for Aviation Safety Inspectors to the National Academy of Sciences’ Recommendations Final Report.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HB59654B4A43B43C582EC015E73243386"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (D)
                     The 2021 report released by the inspector general of the Department of Transportation titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">FAA Can Increase Its Inspector Staffing Model’s Effectiveness by Implementing System Improvements and Maximizing Its Capabilities.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HDBCCB391B9D7455DB8F99FCE1AEBB86A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (E)
                     The FAA Fiscal Year 2023 Aviation Safety Workforce Plan conducted to satisfy the requirements of section 104 of the Aircraft Certification, Safety, and Accountability Act, as enacted in the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2021 (49 U.S.C. 44701 note). 
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HC9A0F292AD64469990B48729F605B334"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Assessments
                  In carrying out this section, the Administrator shall assess the following:
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H11E61CE4B84C45A8AC79A62576E2DF48"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     Projected staffing needs at the service and office level.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HB0FC13C61F794E168C094AE87537DCEC"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     Forecasted attrition of the aviation safety inspector workforce.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H79AD30B6F6FF43A894F4287CB20C609C"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     Forecasted workload of aviation safety inspectors, including responsibilities associated with overseeing aviation manufacturers and new airspace entrants.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H646277C7F56B4A5D871D06FBD0A0EDC7"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (D)
                     Means by which field managers use the model to assess aviation safety inspector staffing and provide feedback on resources needed at the office level.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HA275FCF2B4954D79B26D58A0FFC4E6B4"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (E)
                     Work performed by aviation safety inspectors in comparison to designees acting on behalf of the Administrator.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HDBE54C4B036445C59093F0AC53386DC9"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (F)
                     Any associated performance metrics to inform periodic comparisons to actual aviation safety inspector staffing level results.
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H74CBD5DEA232463D850F8C0B873CC66E"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  Consultation
                  In carrying out this section, the Administrator shall consult with interested persons, including the exclusive collective bargaining representative for aviation safety inspectors certified under section 7111 of title 5, United States Code. 
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H37FED46859E449E9B56B244415C9AA85"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            431.
            SAFETY-CRITICAL STAFFING
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H7154510D4B48425B99185D3D72CF5F43"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Implementation of staffing standards for safety inspectors
               Upon completion of the revised staffing model for aviation safety inspectors under section 430, and validation of the model by the Administrator, the Administrator shall take all appropriate actions in response to the number of aviation safety inspectors, aviation safety technicians, and operation support positions that are identified in such model to meet the responsibilities of the Flight Standards Service and Aircraft Certification Service, including potentially increasing the number of safety critical positions in the Flight Standards Service and Aircraft Certification Service each fiscal year, as appropriate, so long as such staffing increases are measured relative to the number of individuals serving in safety-critical positions as of September 30, 2023.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H7320ECEAA1C54B88ADDB242D723B9C7D"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Availability of appropriations
               Any increase in safety critical staffing pursuant to this subsection shall be subject to the availability of appropriations.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H7FADEE420F3243BF8F2C040129C1DE8C"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Safety-critical positions defined
               In this section, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">safety-critical positions means—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H262A82BA595A4F8C937375973C442D32"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  aviation safety inspectors, aviation safety specialists (1801 job series), aviation safety technicians, and operations support positions in the Flight Standards Service; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HFD530119873D4C5385A1C507E6CC8865"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  manufacturing safety inspectors, pilots, engineers, Chief Scientist Technical Advisors, aviation safety specialists (1801 job series), safety technical specialists, and operational support positions in the Aircraft Certification Service. 
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H629FACDBA6A6454FA95C861D60F5526F"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            432.
            DETERRING CREWMEMBER INTERFERENCE
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H03CFAC4E807A4FCC93C9E96396B211B2"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Task force
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H862F226140074F39A0CD1648A3A8DEBD"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  In general
                  Not later than 120 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall convene a task force to develop voluntary standards and best practices relating to suspected violations of sections 46318, 46503, and 46504 of title 49, United States Code, including—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HEDF7EEC7199446A4928D5C6B301FD048"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     proper and consistent incident documentation and reporting techniques;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H40CAD9A37DEB4AA29F7F9913ED3FC27C"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     best practices for flight crew and cabin crew response, including de-escalation;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H21C17B47C5A94A62B3C05E8973EC209C"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     improved coordination between stakeholders, including flight crew and cabin crew, airport staff, other Federal agencies as appropriate, and law enforcement; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H2BD538556BC34AC1968A5F4092970EA3"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (D)
                     appropriate enforcement actions.
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HC0F295CFD3F74A9FA61DFE789A99C1A1"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Membership
                  The task force convened under paragraph (1) shall be comprised of representatives of—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HEFF5FBA359034E34BA152E32C6525087"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     air carriers;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H16AB1633C55546EEB1F922C2AFDA27B7"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     airport sponsors and airport law enforcement agencies;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HCE6CAF1C3A3845AAB136A8D1E1442C5A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     other Federal agencies determined necessary by the Administrator; 
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H04EC7EABA59B477AAA34ECA3CBB0C35D"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (D)
                     labor organizations representing air carrier pilots; 
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H8AFC609C1CA84A29A5C1911208F66BB0"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (E)
                     labor organizations representing flight attendants; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HE6558702664048C9A97E8B6884FF74B7"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (F)
                     labor organizations representing ticketing, check-in, or other customer service representatives employed by air carriers.
                  
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HF3EE7915D2DA483098158A2CCCF3E2B2"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Announcements
               Not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall initiate such actions as may be necessary to include in the briefing of passengers before takeoff required under section 121.571 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, a statement informing passengers that it is against Federal law to assault or threaten to assault any individual on an aircraft or interfere with the duties of a crewmember.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HE53CEF0D98914CAA84B9AC3FAE1D2E5A"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Definitions
               For purposes of this section, the definitions in section 40102(a) of title 49, United States Code, shall apply to terms in this section.
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H5011C6F455CD49DBBA748AA913D28A7A"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            433.
            USE OF BIOGRAPHICAL ASSESSMENTS
            Section 44506(f)(2)(A) of title 49, United States Code, is amended by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                       quote-display-start="auto"
                       quote-type="text">paragraph (1)(B)(ii) and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                       quote-display-start="auto"
                       quote-type="text">paragraph (1)(B).
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HAA5F502777ED45C8889ECAE77D691FE1"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            434.
            EMPLOYEE ASSAULT PREVENTION AND RESPONSE PLAN STANDARDS AND BEST PRACTICES
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H005E1E31FFD84D3BACA8E2B0AC588CB0"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Sense of Congress
               It is the sense of Congress that—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H1183C86B7D864DF9B2FE1D179F9B72DE"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  each air carrier operating under part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, shall submit to the Administrator an Employee Assault Prevention and Response Plan pursuant to section 551 of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 (49 U.S.C. 44903 note);
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HF33113EB35B54CF486D72F5C002FA869"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  each such air carrier should have in place and deploy an Employee Assault Prevention and Response Plan to facilitate appropriate protocols, standards, and training to equip employees with best practices and the experience necessary to respond effectively to hostile situations and disruptive behavior and maintain a safe traveling experience; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H4D81E5D5DB584EED96F169BB90AF61D6"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  any air carrier formed after the date of enactment of this Act should develop and implement an Employee Assault Prevention and Response Plan. 
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H5B59564A4D8D44579E7A364141E106FF"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Required briefing
               Section 551 of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 (49 U.S.C. 44903 note) is amended by adding at the end the following:
               <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                              display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              display-quotes="yes"
                              id="HB2642F430CCF4618BCE9FCCE774FEA49"
                              style="OLC">
                  <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                               id="H08FB901132A04A3DBE86E1B08F40A0A1"
                               qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (f)
                     Briefing to Congress
                     Not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this subsection, the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration shall provide to the appropriate committees of Congress a briefing on the Employee Assault Prevention and Response Plan submitted by each air carrier pursuant to this section.
                  
                  .
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HE4AED417585D494FBA70EFA86C9F92F0"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            435.
            FORMAL POLICY ON SEXUAL ASSAULT AND HARASSMENT ON AIR CARRIERS
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HDDCA87C3C8DC41D785014B405DB68A93"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, passenger air carriers operating under part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, shall issue, in consultation with labor unions representing personnel, a formal policy with respect to sexual assault or harassment incidents.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H5B1784E212FD483E896F729674F0BEE7"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Contents
               Each policy required under subsection (a) shall include—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HAB6CE60EA6D54810A472FDFE49589DBF"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  a statement indicating that no sexual assault or harassment incident is acceptable under any circumstance;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H0AA9DB1D2E08498C99DF19A07E5E8B58"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  procedures that facilitate the reporting of a sexual assault or harassment incident, including—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H61930BE5C42E4BFB9184B1951CB47D46"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     appropriate public outreach activities; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H27ED91ECEBCE41539C36412A51C6293A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     confidential phone and internet-based opportunities for reporting;
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H017A1EAC27AC428D95635B7F679FE13E"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  procedures that personnel should follow upon the reporting of a sexual assault or harassment incident, including actions to protect affected individuals from continued sexual assault or harassment and to notify law enforcement, including the Federal Bureau of Investigation, when appropriate;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H6563A8CD733B497594721A919CF40FEE"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  procedures that may limit or prohibit, to the extent practicable, future travel with the air carrier by any passenger who commits a sexual assault or harassment incident; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H4AB0E492801F4C4DA781F373ACDA89F3"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (5)
                  training that is required for all appropriate personnel with respect to each such policy, including specific training for personnel who may receive reports of sexual assault or harassment incidents.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H68D83F389CB444EB9FDABDE2EFEAFA9A"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Passenger information
               An air carrier described in subsection (a) shall display, on the website of the air carrier and through the use of appropriate signage, a written statement that informs passengers and personnel of the procedure for reporting a sexual assault or harassment incident.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H656C3C8FFF924A7D8EE23F0C5D94A7FA"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (d)
               Standard of care
               Compliance with the requirements of this section, and any policy issued thereunder, shall not determine whether the air carrier described in subsection (a) has acted with any requisite standard of care.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H7D6E499D0234437393944FC6D0983D4B"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (e)
               Rules of construction
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H4817FD505D044406941F90BCB13860AB"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Effect on authorities
                  Nothing in this section shall be construed as granting the Secretary any additional authorities beyond ensuring that a passenger air carrier operating under part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations issues a formal policy and displays required information in compliance with this section.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H70A532DC5BFF4AC99BAFA310CD0311DA"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Effect on other laws
                  Nothing in this section shall be construed to alter existing authorities of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, the Department of Labor, or the Department of Justice to enforce applicable employment and sexual assault and sexual harassment laws.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H01DA45525E294E39AB0089070FC58BA1"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (f)
               Definitions
               In this section:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HF85881788A104A888BEC3B4F7EDD731F"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Personnel
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">personnel means an employee or contractor of passenger air carrier operating under part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H8C5F24C2655A4E0AB509497C1A0B7025"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Sexual assault
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">sexual assault means the occurrence of an act that constitutes any nonconsensual sexual act proscribed by Federal, tribal, or State law, including when the victim lacks capacity to consent.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HA98076E11C694595AE4895EF1CF40441"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  Sexual assault or harassment incident
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">sexual assault or harassment incident means the occurrence, or reasonably suspected occurrence, of an act that—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H35A8336EDA044372AB67D9C31AC3A14B"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     constitutes sexual assault or sexual harassment; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H5DBE33C6F61C49248D7BEF4C8FF7AF57"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     is committed—
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB160179754F84C7EA90D46D691476525"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (i)
                        by a passenger or personnel against another passenger or personnel; and
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD2287F7523964D29B09EDFB5266CEC32"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (ii)
                        within an aircraft or in an area in which passengers are entering or exiting an aircraft.
                     
                  
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H2C32314DA2EA47EA8C95963C43BEBDEB"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            436.
            INTERFERENCE WITH SECURITY SCREENING PERSONNEL
            Section 46503 of title 49, United States Code, is amended—
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                        id="H5F495B744CEE46A189978AF3F9E890A7"
                        qb-display-quote="yes">
               (1)
               by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">An individual and inserting the following:
               <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                              display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              display-quotes="yes"
                              id="H2C871C61C1A1497386850C4D3F4ED7A9"
                              style="OLC">
                  <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                               id="H2C786484039D40A0BB91649EE830A271"
                               qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (a)
                     In general
                     An individual
                  
                  ; and
               
            
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                        id="HE61ACE36D626402BAE1E0E1E36B9BEE3"
                        qb-display-quote="yes">
               (2)
               by adding at the end the following:
               <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                              display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              display-quotes="yes"
                              id="H24D610ABCC3F4B4881AAAFFD61A06888"
                              style="OLC">
                  <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                               id="H68FBF94D6F704BD1A1A4F56C3AA50F91"
                               qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (b)
                     Airport and air carrier employees
                     For purposes of this section, an airport or air carrier employee who has security duties within the airport includes an airport or air carrier employee performing ticketing, check-in, baggage claim, or boarding functions.
                  
                  .
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H164345092AFD4B9E9DF982047E93A582"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            437.
            AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL WORKFORCE STAFFING
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H9CCFD7BBA1DD4C8A8F1E8CF03FFE4D17"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Maximum hiring
               Subject to the availability of appropriations, for each of fiscal years 2024 through 2028, the Administrator shall set as the minimum hiring target for new air traffic controllers (excluding individuals described in section 44506(f)(1)(A) of title 49, United States Code) the maximum number of individuals able to be trained at the Federal Aviation Administration Academy.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H8B2A3EDE2C9E4D5887D9BEEAD1A0BC66"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Transportation research board assessment
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HA8E39804A7C242D69FCA0ABCE674B5A1"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Review
                  Not later than 30 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall submit an attestation to the appropriate committees of Congress demonstrating an agreement entered into with the with the National Academies Transportation Research Board to—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H23C6AB8381B6407FA23E579ED1A0F7F7"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     compare the Certified Professional Controller (in this section referred to as <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">CPC) operational staffing models and methodologies in determining the FAA Controller Staffing Standard included in the 2023 Air Traffic Controller Workforce Plan of the FAA, with such models and methodologies developed by the Collaborative Resource Workgroup of the FAA (in this subsection referred to as <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">CRWG) to determine CPC operational staffing targets necessary to meet facility operational, statutory, contractual and safety requirements, including—
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H84AADC99A8D44130AB6001D72132DC56"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (i)
                        the availability factor multiplier and other formula components;
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H00AA731EBBD74036B4D99979F2C4FD59"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (ii)
                        the independent facility staffing targets of CPCs able to control traffic;
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3F2E288FF4254F57AD391B098F0BDB62"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (iii)
                        air traffic controller position utilization;
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H98A31677947C45A0931F142EC6CE28F4"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (iv)
                        attrition rates at each air traffic control facility operated by the Administration; and
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1E447E1A2D714B519F25F67B608135C6"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (v)
                        the time needed to meet facility operational, statutory, and contractual requirements, including relevant resources to develop, evaluate, and implement processes and initiatives affecting the national airspace system;
                     
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H8EAE4B5D58274A658E73B0E14EDC974D"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     examine the current and estimated budgets of the FAA to implement the FAA Controller Staffing Standard included in the 2023 Controller Workforce Plan in comparison to the funding needed to implement the CRWG CPC operational staffing targets;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H229E572DCA2D4E35861962F0152451E5"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     assess future needs of the air traffic control system and potential impacts on staffing standards, including projected air traffic in the airspace of each air traffic control facility operated by the Administration; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H2C5AF197B31540A3B6A15FE27A9EA434"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (D)
                     determine which staffing models and methodologies evaluated pursuant to this subsection best accounts for the operational staffing needs of the air traffic control system and provide a justification for such determination.
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HC59CAB4E2BA549C7AA6ABA32669493C0"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Report
                  Not later than 180 days after the agreement entered into pursuant to paragraph (b)(1), the Transportation Research Board of the National Academies shall submit a report to the Administrator and appropriate committees of Congress on the findings and recommendations under this subsection, including the determination pursuant to subparagraph (D).
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HB44A3C85983F4F33BA9C8864C9A6088E"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  Consultation
                  In conducting the assessment under this subsection, the Transportation Research Board shall consult with—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H7688897659B548CC9ABD9B9839C04771"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     the exclusive bargaining representatives of air traffic control specialists of the Administration certified under section 7111 of title 5, United States Code;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HE7D6EA0EE84E4BBF925962B7DD8526AE"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     front line managers of the air traffic control system;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H3DCD4A5B0F844C87AAF6AAC0A62D5586"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     managers and employees responsible for training air traffic controllers;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H0AE26B79B4DD4976BDFC5447CF7A09F0"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (D)
                     the MITRE Corporation;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H125C5BFB19784AC79B88690CF6EE4196"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (E)
                     the Chief Operating Officer of the Air Traffic Organization of the FAA, and other Federal Government representatives;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H0BE6A6FDD43B481DAED40173EB488051"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (F)
                     users and operators in the air traffic control system;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HB9A711E1FF0D4ABEB0B2F826039EA1FD"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (G)
                     relevant industry representatives; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HA13D15CB2CBD4CBDBED7A4939B257F23"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (H)
                     other parties determined appropriate by the Transportation Research Board of the National Academies.
                  
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H55A775CA05EC402A9523439A72D47FF8"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Required implementation of identified staffing model
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H7A504ACBAFD64A458974B062AEB2A3BE"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Use of staffing model
                  The Administrator shall, as appropriate, take such action that may be necessary to implement and use the staffing model identified by the Transportation Research Board pursuant to subsection (b)(1)(D), including any recommendations for improving such model, not later than one year after enactment of this Act.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H9B46EE73BE164D188A70DFAC17112A56"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Briefing
                  Not later than 90 days after taking such actions to implement and use the staffing model identified by the Transportation Research Board pursuant to subsection (b)(1)(D), the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress regarding the reasons for why any recommendation by the Transportation Research Board study was not incorporated into the implemented staffing model.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H6E1AAB9EE96E4ABE874613BD9D5C2365"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (d)
               Revised staffing standards
               The Administration shall revise the FAA CPC operational staffing standards of the Administration implemented under subsection (c) to—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HAF41B963A6804DB98A8C09C5C0F6B472"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  provide that the controller and management workforce is sufficiently staffed to safely and efficiently manage and oversee the air traffic control system;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H91FEA632434F4063A0B097BCD1F4B624"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  account for the target number of CPCs able to control traffic at each independent facility; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H0CDE8D1607A745738F5229ED90E5C1A0"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  avoid any required or requested reduction of national airspace system capacity or aircraft operations as a result of inadequate air traffic control system staffing.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HA19C71DDD5F3441BAFFA2DC11304966D"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (e)
               Interim adoption of collaborative resource workgroup models
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H0FF82F870EC04D6DA1A79D618EE4767B"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  In general
                  In submitting a Controller Workforce Plan of the FAA to Congress published after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall adopt and use the staffing models and methodologies developed by the Collaborative Resource Workgroup that were recommended in the 2023 Controller Workforce Plan.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HC69FF10951C747BE953F8AEE994442AE"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Revisions to the controller workforce plan
                  Section 44506(e) of title 49, United States Code is amended—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HED709A5C39CC49FD85196B76A3EBA117"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     in paragraph (1) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">the number of air traffic controllers needed and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">the number of fully certified air traffic controllers needed; 
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H298CC0FBD2F5496B8B3E46B7FF16BC52"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     by redesignating paragraphs (2) and (3) as paragraphs (3) and (4), respectively; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H40A77FDD5EF044A8ABF702BCB1D7C7D7"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     by inserting after paragraph (1) the following:
                     <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                    display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    display-quotes="yes"
                                    id="H498396CC0CED4A53AC4D4F2D35F6B9E9"
                                    style="OLC">
                        <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H5C495C620B9C4FD88BE60D0D12A62D7B"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (2)
                           for each air traffic control facility operated by the Federal Aviation Administration—
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H42F64FDDA66046838C16B6614E695191"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (A)
                              the current certified professional controller staffing levels;
                           
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HA6D36D781203469181E9E13DD34088D3"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (B)
                              the operational staffing targets for certified professional controllers;
                           
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H6A3BB8111C5242B7BB04E997FDEFDC19"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (C)
                              the anticipated certified professional controller attrition for each of the next 3 years; and
                           
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HF3EBABEEDF0A455990C41FACEE18CDBA"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (D)
                              the number of certified professional controller trainees;
                           
                        
                        .
                     
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H3D60FD9F85D747B7B87AB63EC179AAD1"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  Effective date
                  The requirements of paragraph (1) shall cease to be effective upon the adoption and implementation of a revised staffing model by the Administrator as required under subsection (c).
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HDAD952B3C18441208275418A7687F4B1"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (f)
               Controller training
               In any Controller Workforce Plan of the FAA published after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HC6A6AB38612C4A80995D4439DCE3E7E5"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  identify all limiting factors on the ability of the Administrator to hire and train controllers in line with the staffing standards target set out in such Plan; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H48180140F88A4541B2E54F1F2A8F8AC9"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  describe what actions the Administrator intends to take to rectify any impediments to meeting staffing standards targets and identify contributing factors that are outside the control of the Administrator.
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H79715A1C956143EFAE6FEED3A63CAE1F"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            438.
            AIRPORT SERVICE WORKFORCE ANALYSIS
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H0EABB60CE2FE447AB9CC446BDF7DADD3"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall complete a comprehensive review of the domestic airport service workforce and examine the role of, impact on, and importance of such workforce to the aviation economy.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H1294AF2BC4034542B98C38F9DC90D6A9"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Working group
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HDA17CC9078624EDB81528EA5A429D457"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Report
                  Upon completion of the review required under subsection (a), the Comptroller General shall submit to the Secretary a report containing such review.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H093DF55DB7C54674B6E1C6D6A80CDBD5"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Public working group
                  The Secretary may convene a public working group to evaluate and discuss the report under paragraph (1) containing—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H380AB0D38757476B807EF4FE81D0559A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     the entities the Comptroller General consulted with in carrying out the review under subsection (a);
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H6DEB6D6A2EAB4448AFFDC3383C460FB2"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     representatives of other relevant Federal agencies; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HB06E938CE82B40689C4D525203767B5C"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     any other appropriate stakeholder.
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HC8437B00157F477E883E09C90AD02185"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  Termination
                  If the Secretary convenes a working group under paragraph (2), such working group shall terminate on the date that is 1 year after the date on which the working group is convened.
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H05F6A56ECD374392AD9E750E49AA3427"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            439.
            FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINISTRATION ACADEMY AND FACILITY EXPANSION PLAN
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H823B51A2AB12482CB58B9920ADF028BA"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Plan
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H10CC19966B5C44A9B6288D29CA9E1927"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  In general
                  No later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall initiate the development of a plan to expand overall FAA capacity relating to facilities, instruction, equipment, and training resources to grow the number of developmental air traffic controllers enrolled per fiscal year and support increases in FAA air controller staffing to advance the safety of the national airspace system.
