                  (e)
                  Sense of Congress
                  It is the sense of Congress that route structures to rural airports serve a critical function to the Nation by connecting many military installations to major regional airline hubs.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HD773318DADB04BDD94473648B39D56D1"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (f)
                  Ending, suspending, and reducing basic essential air service
                  Section 41734 of title 49, United States Code, is amended—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H033A35101BE046FAA78433DFD872B91F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     in subsection (a)—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE8F4AE70A61D44CB8033A58C58D524B5"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">An air carrier and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">Subject to subsection (d), an air carrier; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H5D36B4E3B0C04B6BAAD1FED6C383C5B1"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">90 and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">140;
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE9A59593D9CA4B448B0467596E983E49"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     by striking subsection (d) and inserting the following:
                     <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                    display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    display-quotes="yes"
                                    id="HEDF7F088A3584109B708B9233647E731"
                                    style="OLC">
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="HCE7F7F1257D14CF799596EF53AE5DECB"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (d)
                           Continuation of compensation after notice period
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H8AAA670FE35E4913A8109D53CB336F66"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              In general
                              If an air carrier receiving compensation under section 41733 for providing basic essential air service to an eligible place is required to continue to provide service to such place under this section after the 140-day notice period under subsection (a), the Secretary—
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HE3C3C771241A49648CE5D181B98BB362"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 shall provide the carrier with compensation sufficient to pay to the carrier the amount required by the then existing contract for performing the basic essential air service that was being provided when the 140-day notice was given under subsection (a);
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H30E78156727D4E3EB41B068FDA0E26DD"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 may pay an additional amount that represents a reasonable return on investment; and
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HCCD573F8A16A4A64A026226C38BC6838"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (C)
                                 may pay an additional return that recognizes the demonstrated additional lost profits from opportunities foregone and the likelihood that those lost profits increase as the period during which the carrier or provider is required to provide the service continues.
                              
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H0C9A028858D241DD8D82E8D16DFC6F4C"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              Authority
                              The Secretary may incorporate contract termination penalties or conditions on compensation into a contract for an air carrier to provide service to an eligible place that take effect in the event an air carrier provides notice that it is ending, suspending, or reducing basic essential air service.
                           
                        
                        ;
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H5AAE43CB80E7403E86A7B496C06DFF7D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     in subsection (e) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">providing that service after the 90-day notice period and all that follows through the period at the end of paragraph (2) and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">providing that service after the 140-day notice period required by subsection (a), the Secretary may provide the air carrier with compensation after the end of the 140-day notice period to pay for the fully allocated actual cost to the air carrier of performing the basic essential air service that was being provided when the 140-day notice was given under subsection (a) plus a reasonable return on investment that is at least 5 percent of operating costs.; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H350D46459E2B4EACB890300F441E1D92"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     in subsection (f) by inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">air after <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">find another.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HF122A7D467144227813A384B6211C6DD"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">

                  Section 41735 of title 49, United States Code, and the item relating to such section in the analysis for subchapter II of chapter 417 of such title, are repealed.

                  (k)
                  Community and regional choice programs
                  Section 41745 of title 49, United States Code, is amended—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H515BF592435D4DE9A84D70E1CD5BE452"

            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H1844EC10629F41F498350F304AD1AEA9"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               563.
               GAO STUDY AND REPORT ON THE ALTERNATE ESSENTIAL AIR SERVICE PILOT PROGRAM
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H2DEC1F9ACD3C4B2EA4AB9210CA07B3E7"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Study
                  The Comptroller General shall study the effectiveness of the alternate essential air service pilot program established under section 41745 of title 49, United States Code, (in this section referred to as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Alternate EAS program), including challenges, if any, that have impeded robust community participation in the Alternate EAS program.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HDE8552FC277C434A970DBCB3B54D3862"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Contents
                  The study required under subsection (a) shall include an assessment of potential changes to the Alternate EAS program and the basic essential air service programs under subchapter II of chapter 417 of title 49, United States Code, including changes in which Governors of States or territories containing essential air service communities would be given block grants in lieu of essential air service subsidies.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H23C6EFC5F842484EADD07F343F82C095"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Briefing
                  Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the study required under subsection (a), including any recommendations for legislation and administrative action as the Comptroller General determines appropriate. 
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H062F9C5D31B04FC1A2A7F1F931E44FE4"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               564.
               ESSENTIAL AIR SERVICE IN PARTS OF ALASKA
               Not later than September 1, 2024, the Secretary, in consultation with the appropriate State authority of Alaska, shall review all domestic points in the State of Alaska that were deleted from carrier certificates between July 1, 1968, and October 24, 1978, and that were not subsequently determined to be an eligible place prior to January 1, 1982, as a result of being unpopulated at that time due to destruction during the 1964 earthquake and its resultant tidal wave, to determine whether such points have been resettled or relocated and should be designated as an eligible place entitled to receive a determination of the level of essential air service supported, if necessary, with Federal funds.
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H10E664B368B744EEA8A4FF9A800F4AFC"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               565.
               ESSENTIAL AIR SERVICE COMMUNITY PETITION FOR REVIEW
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H22A9F5A8D4F04E1987BB559C38E7AA8F"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Section 41733 of title 49, United States Code, is amended—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE78E51F3A6B543C09DAB1C657DE29F9D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     in subsection (b)(2) by inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">, as defined by the Secretary after <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">appropriate representative of the place; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H568098C864E34D0EBC84DD1A18091C19"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     by adding at the end the following:
                     <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                    display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    display-quotes="yes"
                                    id="H6657953F01DF45E5A130F9BE8BC76831"
                                    style="OLC">
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H063132A51975461BB69E2DB9A6A0201D"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           Community petition for review
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H92E32E18A48948E29F653040D5E0E5AE"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              Petition
                              An appropriate representative of an eligible place, as defined by the Secretary, may submit to the Secretary a petition expressing no confidence in the air carrier providing basic essential air service under this section and requesting a review by the Secretary. A petition submitted under this subsection shall demonstrate that the air carrier—
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H3B071493088E42D592D968AF9504953E"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 is unwilling or unable to meet the operational specifications outlined in the order issued by the Secretary specifying the terms of basic essential air service to such place;
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HD12AAD323971469499F0BA2C9D4FEF09"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 is experiencing reliability challenges with the potential to adversely affect air service to such place; or
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HDC3CAF8BBB144E51A412C18DA6B4E94B"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (C)
                                 is no longer able to provide service to such place at the rate of compensation specified by the Secretary.
                              
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H0A3A983189884D13AE1E0B49F609D80A"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              Review
                              Not later than 2 months after the date on which the Secretary receives a petition under paragraph (1), the Secretary shall review the operational performance of the air carrier providing basic essential air service to such place that submitted such petition and determine whether such air carrier is fully complying with the obligations specified in the order issued by the Secretary specifying the terms of basic essential air service to such place.
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HBEB6057008F0458CBC978B3A96809982"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (3)
                              Termination
                              If based on a review under paragraph (2), the Secretary determines noncompliance by an air carrier with an order specifying the terms for basic essential air service to the community, the Secretary may—
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H4E32100602384602B49A942BB909968B"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 terminate the order issued to the air carrier; and
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H241D235BDD62472782427512A828CCD7"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 issue a notice pursuant to subsection (c) that an air carrier may apply to provide basic essential air service to such place for compensation under this section and select an applicant pursuant to such subsection.
                              
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H279F9E2A51BF4DE88BECFD89E41DE4C3"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (4)
                              Continuation of service
                              If the Secretary makes a determination under paragraph (3) to terminate an order issued to an air carrier under this section, the Secretary shall ensure continuity in air service to the affected place.
                           
                        
                        .
                     
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HA8EF6ABD252C44F2BDA4EDA9056384F0"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"

               566.
               ESSENTIAL AIR SERVICE AUTHORIZATION
               Section 41742(a)(2) of title 49, United States Code, is amended by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">$155,000,000 for fiscal year 2018 and all that follows through <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">May 10, 2024, and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">$348,544,000 for fiscal year 2024, $340,000,000 for fiscal year 2025, $342,000,000 for fiscal year 2026, $342,000,000 for fiscal year 2027, and $350,000,000 for fiscal year 2028.
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HC52FB1025DAC450AA8B1EB58303DB6C1"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               567.
               GAO STUDY ON COSTS OF ESSENTIAL AIR SERVICE
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HB6D35B8E9E084651B7F6234F626BCBE9"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Study
                  The Comptroller General shall conduct a study of the change in costs of the essential air service program under sections 41731 through 41742 of title 49, United States Code.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H3A170EE6A5004CAFA9A569965B182C12"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Contents
                  In conducting the study required under subsection (a), the Comptroller General shall—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H14F3696C6BAC4302A03D77971E4F2B08"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     assess trends in costs of the essential air service program under sections 41731 through 41742 of title 49, United States Code, over the 10-year period ending on the date of enactment of this Act; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H67C71601CD894541A94D023D3E81E397"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     review potential causes for the increased cost of the essential air service program, including—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H1ECA3701AB0849379C3CCAF23060B2B2"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        labor costs;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE0E2FDA52F444DAF823B62056DB6E577"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        fuel costs;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H6F0F0286E2F449B3BF280A52949EAFBA"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        aging aircraft costs; 
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HA1EF405CD93943B9AF456ACC392B9728"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        air carrier opportunity costs;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HC5087747A0E04F7A9C8EE3764A43C089"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (E)
                        airport costs; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HA963F1325B974D35ACEF8012BB62F811"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (F)
                        the effects of the COVID–19 pandemic.
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H2ACC9CB475834789921FB69667618F59"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Report
                  Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the results of the study conducted under subsection (a).
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HE1C8CEBF7DDE4B05BBF003C3017AFEEE"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               568.
               RESPONSE TIME FOR APPLICATIONS TO PROVIDE ESSENTIAL AIR SERVICE
               The Secretary shall take such actions as are necessary to respond with an approval or denial of any application filed by an applicant to provide essential air service under subchapter II of chapter 417 of title 49, United States Code, to the greatest extent practicable not later than 6 months after receiving such application. The Assistant General Counsel for International and Aviation Economic Law shall ensure the timely review of all orders proposed by the Essential Air Service Office, and such timeliness shall be analyzed annually by the General Counsel of the Department of Transportation. 
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H64A3A96B3534473CB2745CDD3919B885"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               569.
               GAO STUDY ON CERTAIN AIRPORT DELAYS
               The Comptroller General shall conduct a study on flight delays in the States of New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut and the possible causes of such delays.
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H5E673899C6AA471B80766CD408E0FBFA"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               570.
               REPORT ON RESTORATION OF SMALL COMMUNITY AIR SERVICE
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H57404B659F854ADEA2EBD6555E72B261"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall seek to enter into an agreement with the National Academies to conduct a study on the loss of commercial air service in small communities in the United States and options to restore such service.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H810BB9FB87AD43ECBB2F898393690137"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Contents
                  In conducting the study required under subsection (a), that National Academies shall—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H9FA5D49CFAB440BBA4015D3764B64FDB"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     assess the reduction of scheduled commercial air service to small communities over a 5-year period ending on the date of enactment of this Act, to include small communities that have lost all scheduled commercial air service;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC912609528924838BF4DB4EEA0F4FF31"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     review economic trends that have resulted in reduction or loss of scheduled commercial air service to such communities;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HFBE95F7C3CC04F178481CA774DEEE9F1"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     review the economic losses of such communities who have suffered a reduction or loss of scheduled commercial air service;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H79EDE94F2B0B49C9AA6ECABBED8A0C8D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     identify the causes that prompted air carriers to reduce or eliminate scheduled commercial air service to such communities;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H7ADDDC5206664E0E968889C9E04AC56D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     assess the impact of changing aircraft economics; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4EA90F7E6273476AB3C594D57A72EF29"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     identify recommendations that can be implemented by such communities or Federal, State, or local agencies to aid in the restoration or replacement of scheduled commercial air service.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H199BA5C9BED04DF5B5D82780498E80EA"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Case studies
                  In conducting the study required under subsection (a), the National Academies shall assess not fewer than 7 communities that have lost commercial air service or have had commercial air service significantly reduced in the past 15 years, including—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4D89B20E78EF419BADCF08EF7D452219"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Williamsport Regional Airport;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H933718579C144DA488C30949375BF5F1"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Alamogordo-White Sands Regional Airport; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H9F63A23E1F9044528F0A6971AB64E166"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Chautauqua County Jamestown Airport.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HD47CB83E06C140C3BD46F0F2F16F9A10"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Report
                  Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the National Academies shall submit to the Secretary and the appropriate committees of Congress a report containing—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3AD11F333D144F06B55CAF699CBE4912"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     the results of the study described in subsection (a); and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0B28484707964AB38B5884BCB2095E4B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     recommendations to Congress and communities on action that can be taken to improve or restore scheduled commercial service to small communities.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H6BDABE879F1E435A98DD15189A2C4988"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Funding
                  No funding made available to carry out subchapter II of chapter 417 of title 49, United States Code, may be used to carry out this section.
               
            
         
      
      <title id="HA6A176DBDEB8448C8CC4131D2F73B6E0"
              qb-display-quote="yes"
              style="OLC">
         VI
         MODERNIZING THE NATIONAL AIRSPACE SYSTEM
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H425F55ECA45D48898266A670A2AFFB87"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            601.
            INSTRUMENT LANDING SYSTEM INSTALLATION
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H40F4C1DDCD7145D6B5E3CB292E6FB5B9"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               Not later than January 1, 2025, the Administrator shall expedite the installation of at least 15 instrument landing systems (in this section referred to as <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">ILS) in the national airspace system by utilizing the existing ILS contract vehicle and the employees of the FAA.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H34EAEB85A2DA4A51BDE42270FD213C0C"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Requirements
               In carrying out subsection (a), the Administrator shall—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HEDB4A384478E4FD899B9CE671DB8B148"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  incorporate lessons learned from installations under section 44502(a)(4) of title 49, United States Code; 
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HE6A1C727D862437E95F3A40B1423A488"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  record metrics of cost and time savings of expedited installations; 
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HD63B36BA583D4F22BD27A27079AED78D"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  consider opportunities to further develop ILS technical expertise among the employees of the FAA; and 
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HC99C71C56E454C56A1B331CCC8FA5464"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  consider the cost-benefit analysis of utilizing the existing ILS contract vehicle, the employees of the FAA, or both, to accelerate the installation and deployment of procured equipment.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H0A71C2F2E91041BE9994233BD137A259"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Briefing to Congress
               Not later than June 30, 2025, the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H4E15B02EE0BA4814905C19157C590043"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  on the installation of ILS under this section;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HF57C2DA50F6D405B8626BEC71FF3FAD1"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  describing any planned near-term ILS installations; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H0D4716CB07C44195942AB9913DB77904"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  outlining the approach of the FAA to accelerate future procurement and installation of ILS throughout the national airspace system in a manner consistent with the requirements of title VIII of division J of the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (Public Law 117–58).
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H85D369DE9F8A4E60B044E8E1430EF85F"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            602.
            NAVIGATION AIDS STUDY
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HD62A721903CE4D72A839D86E67163ABA"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the inspector general of the Department of Transportation shall initiate a study examining the effects of reclassifying navigation aids to Design Assurance Level–A from Design Assurance Level–B, including the following navigation aids:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H37BDDA7BC52445C2A75283D882EDF77B"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Distance measuring equipment.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HD8E4ED6A22B549B18E6506BF44E0E004"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Very high frequency omni-directional range.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HBA56B4BE6B42421CBB8F984711ED6E50"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  Tactical air navigation.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H9B24D3F7D40B4D8899DC262BC453744E"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  Wide area augmentation system.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H27A4AC514011479B979BE7F3F2C902D7"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Contents
               In conducting the study required under subsection (a), the inspector general shall address—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H697ADF660DEB4F43B339060416BCC709"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  the cost-benefit analyses associated with the reclassification described in such subsection;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H9DB1ABBE25F34DE7A5C71D2998339F38"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  the findings from the operational safety assessments and preliminary hazard analyses of the navigation aids listed in such subsection;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HBE3CA6C5F52D47CD84012AD70FD7C750"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  the risks of such reclassification on navigation aid equipment currently in use;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H496569D895C943AD913BDAD546D5BC91"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  the potential impacts on global interoperability of navigational aids; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HED837EDA25F04E0F970BABAD7F722727"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (5)
                  what additional actions should be taken based on the findings of this subsection.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HF5C8623F06B445E3AE6CC24249861207"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Report
               Not later than 24 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the inspector general shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report describing the results of the study conducted under subsection (a).
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H89C2C166A00240AF8D009507FB3ADD1A"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            603.
            NEXTGEN ACCOUNTABILITY REVIEW
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H63873EA410AB4E8B9B0F37630694F9F5"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               Not later than December 31, 2026, the Administrator shall seek to enter into an agreement with the National Academy of Public Administration to initiate a review to assess the performance of the FAA in delivering and implementing quantifiable operational benefits to the national airspace system within the NextGen program.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H37D5463C56A94CBDAE1D375C931759F5"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Review requirements
               In conducting the review required under subsection (a), the National Academy of Public Administration shall—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H821A68A3B621485998D08C1CB74BF772"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  leverage metrics used by the FAA to quantify the benefits of NextGen technology and investments;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HC9FB4D5068FD4913A64F700877ED46D7"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  validate metrics and identify additional metrics the FAA can use to track national airspace system throughput and savings as a result of NextGen investments—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HCE8B81C132E24EAF88DBF19102AE1B2C"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     by calculating a per flight average, weighted by distance, of the—
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H9935E8FE0E8F43AFB48EEBE80FDCDCB5"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (i)
                        reduction and cumulative savings of track miles and time savings;
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H5A6B2C026B864E0E81269FD3D39F14F4"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (ii)
                        reduction and cumulative savings of emissions and fuel burn; and
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA357CFBDD82F4A7294D7BB8E499C3E94"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (iii)
                        reduction of aircraft operation time; and
                     
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HFFFC214E8F2C4DADB30E986A7567E143"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     by using any other metrics that the National Academy determines may provide insights into the quantifiable benefits for operators in the national airspace system; and
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HA50EB5E230FB4C4380AEFF34761D1961"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  validate current metrics and identify additional metrics the FAA can use to track and assess fleet equipage across operators in the national airspace system, including identifying—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HEA025EE19F11441E89209B3E03B6F9AA"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     the percentage of aircraft equipped with NextGen avionics equipment as recommended in the report of the NextGen Advisory Committee titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">Minimum Capabilities List (MCL) Ad Hoc Team NAC Task 19–1 Report, issued on November 17, 2020;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H8E0BD12A59FA4ECBADCE009E4C68C64A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     quantified costs and benefits for an operator to properly equip an aircraft with baseline NextGen avionics equipment over the lifecycle of such aircraft; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HDE02DF851F1A4EEBABCD0326EFE647CA"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     cumulative unrealized NextGen benefits associated with rates of mixed equipage across operators.
                  
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HDD82FAE4C6234AFA885E08200689429D"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Industry consultation
               In conducting the review required under subsection (a), the National Academy of Public Administration may consult with aviation industry stakeholders.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H1B3866BEAAFF468DA2F34246CB10407B"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (d)
               Report
               Not later than 270 days after the initiation of the review under subsection (a), the National Academy shall submit to the Administrator and the appropriate committees of Congress a report containing any findings and recommendations under such review.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H74C51988E7694D9BB5A2DBE90EE23AF1"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (e)
               Publication
               Not later than 180 days after receiving the report required under subsection (d), the Administrator shall establish a website of the FAA that can be used to monitor and update—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H5DE71D12303D4D178E1B8EEB4FB38255"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  the metrics identified by the review conducted under subsection (a) on a quarterly and annual basis through 2030, as appropriate; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H4D8B479228ED420CAEFFEF3E657C1C6E"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  the total amount invested in NextGen technologies and resulting quantifiable benefits on a quarterly basis until the Administrator announces the completion of NextGen implementation.
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HE1BE15584B0E4FAEB25192F13A2207F8"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            604.
            AIRSPACE ACCESS
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H78BACBD185C14AFC8B661DF3DCFADA29"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Coalescing airspace
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H6D1A7E6803C742289CEA872B43549EA0"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Review of national airspace system
                  Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator, in coordination with the Secretary of Defense, shall conduct a comprehensive review of the airspace of the national airspace system, including special use airspace.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H0488F225DFF64D97B7EE53D3E2C794EA"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Streamlining and expediting access
                  In carrying out paragraph (1), the Administrator shall identify methods to streamline, expedite, and provide greater flexibility of access to certain categories of airspace for users of the national airspace system who may not regularly have such access.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H4EB5CC0C86D04D78A8521E4ED559C894"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Briefing
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H62AD168AD9654F00A4E8BE8F3433B173"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  In general
                  Not later than 3 months after the completion of review the under subsection (a), the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the findings of such review and a proposed action plan to improve access to airspace for users of the national airspace system.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H43700C07768C478EB2DE2E1561D75482"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Contents
                  In the briefing under paragraph (1), the Administrator shall include, at a minimum, the following:
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HBB2C415C241D4F7BB604A34C072455A5"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     An identification of current challenges and barriers faced by airspace users in accessing certain categories of airspace, including special use airspace.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H588242419E244AF0B527749CD14E8F5F"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     An evaluation of existing procedures, regulations, and requirements that may impede or delay access to certain categories of airspace for certain users of the national airspace system.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HF1D3E3A6AB7F4D31A2BD1DA1D3B65F25"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     Actions for streamlining and expediting the airspace access process, including potential regulatory changes, technological advancements, and enhanced coordination among relevant stakeholders and Federal agencies.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HC4C5C441FF1542568CCBBA7FA6C3F171"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (D)
                     If determined appropriate, an implementation plan for a framework that allows for temporary access to certain categories of airspace, including special use airspace, by users of the national airspace system who do not have regular access to such airspace.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H7C591D3788F8467AA67C71F8F85554F5"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (E)
                     An assessment of the impact of airspace access improvements described in paragraph (1) on the safety of, efficiency of, and economic opportunities for airspace users, including—
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H2119861D7ADB47DF8850D14C789CF12B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (i)
                        military operators;
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H89E1F5CC3C6545F9815003DCBD5D5E4E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (ii)
                        commercial operators; and
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H6C0D724F9A434429BCEF3F4A1F94DE20"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (iii)
                        general aviation operators.
                     
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H856D16ED94C34724A5B43576A3BA3EF4"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  Implementation and follow-up
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H341DBCF5ABF249BC8012626D39A30577"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     Action plan
                     The Administrator shall take such actions as are necessary to implement the action plan developed pursuant to this section.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H012874D777934F2AA72C37F32039982C"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     Coordination
                     In implementing the action plan under subparagraph (A), the Administrator shall coordinate with relevant stakeholders, including airspace users and the Secretary of Defense, to ensure effective implementation of such action plan, and ongoing collaboration in addressing airspace access challenges.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H6EFBC1B0B2FB4A77ADA8B360598D0ACF"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     Progress reports
                     The Administrator shall provide to the appropriate committees of Congress periodic briefings on the implementation of the action plan developed under this subparagraph (A), including updates on—
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA41A321303CF4CC29577660B9C9A7005"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (i)
                        the adoption of streamlined procedures;
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB5EB3FAF7085481FBD4CC82E11DA2857"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (ii)
                        technological enhancements; and
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H137B1A689DBC4E95BCE4E1D331F8B5B1"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (iii)
                        any regulatory changes necessary to improve airspace access and flexibility.
                     
                  
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H4F472D2EA23545259C9006EDFE39CE96"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            605.
            FAA CONTRACT TOWER WORKFORCE AUDIT
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HED27BE4BEF8A4F20B2E3112D964DCE10"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               Not later than 120 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the inspector general of the Department of Transportation shall initiate an audit of the workforce needs of the Contract Tower Program, as established under section 47124 of title 49, United States Code.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H5947643A7D934D45B41BDBCCE6B80381"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Contents
               In conducting the audit required under subsection (a), the inspector general shall, at a minimum—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H7686BC3D6A4840EDB0B682D04932A5E8"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  review the assumptions and methodologies used in assessing FAA contract towers staffing levels and determine the adequacy of staffing levels at such towers;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H0C99BFE25B894467A372F6416954CD3B"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  evaluate the supply and demand of trained and certificated personnel prepared for work and such towers;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HB43CECF2F2424867871A3D49961FF390"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  examine efforts to establish an air traffic controller training program or curriculum to allow contract tower contractors to conduct—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HED3FF1A7F18645FEBC07B2B813F2CCD1"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     initial training of controller candidates employed or soon to be employed by such contractors who do not have a Control Tower Operator certificate or a FAA tower credential;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HDE209ED690734E50A0DD126647C4E16F"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     any initial training for controller candidates who have completed an approved Air Traffic Collegiate Training Initiative program from an accredited school that has a demonstrated successful curriculum; or
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H027B23B2DFBF42B4AE7952F1E99A4A32"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     on-the-job training of such candidates described in subparagraphs (A) or (B);
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HCEBE4C0FF4F54DBA814808EAC5F3223F"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  assess whether establishing pathways to allow contract tower contractors to use the air traffic technical training academy of the FAA, or other means such as higher educational institutions, to provide initial technical training for air traffic controllers employed by such contractors could improve the workforce needs of the contract tower program and any related impact such training may have on air traffic controller staffing more broadly; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H405AC7B0A046445288697AC7C30CCC69"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (5)
                  consult with the exclusive bargaining representative of the air traffic controllers certified under section 7111 of title 5, United States Code. 
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H1626D215C8A5467FB9B1DBF969937B2F"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Report
               Not later than 90 days after the completion of the audit under subsection (a), the inspector general shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the findings of such audit and any recommendations as a result of such audit.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HCF7CA8F03BE54BED9ED27909FB20C34B"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (d)
               Implementation
               The Administrator shall take such actions as are necessary to implement any recommendations included in the report required under subsection (c) with which the Administrator concurs.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H959049BDA2C24A15A34C6640FA6131F9"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (e)
               Rule of construction
               Nothing in this subsection shall be construed as a delegation of authority by the Administrator to air traffic control contractors for the purposes of issuing initial certifications to air traffic controllers.
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H53182D79BAE24902A64EA6EC48C95449"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            606.
            AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL TOWER SAFETY
            In designing, adopting a design, or constructing an air traffic control tower based on a previously adopted design, the Administrator shall prioritize the safety of the national airspace system, the safety of employees of the Administration, the operational reliability of such air traffic control tower, and the costs of such tower. 
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H0E6720602A694CC493079909B1C7E96E"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            607.
            AIR TRAFFIC SERVICES DATA REPORTS
            Section 45303(g)(2)(A) of title 49, United States Code, is amended by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                       quote-display-start="auto"
                       quote-type="text">8 years and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                       quote-display-start="auto"
                       quote-type="text">14 years.
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H6E9B416425E34E6F891843E9BE4F2F5F"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            608.
            CONSIDERATION OF SMALL HUB CONTROL TOWERS
            In selecting projects for the replacement of federally owned air traffic control towers from funds made available under the heading <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                       quote-display-start="auto"
                       quote-type="text">Federal Aviation Administration—Facilities and Equipment in title VIII of division J of the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (Public Law 117–58), the Administrator shall consider selecting projects at small hub commercial service airports with control towers that are at least 50 years old.
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H18A83820DF744AD3BB34ED5733238DCF"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            609.
            FLIGHT PROFILE OPTIMIZATION
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H218DE34851594C2B86F6079852A258BB"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Pilot program
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H8F2032C5E9494E59AA58D50692A0C673"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Establishment
                  The Administrator shall establish a pilot program to award grants to air traffic flow management technology providers to develop prototype capabilities to incorporate flight profile optimization (in this section referred to as <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">FPO) into the trajectory based-operations air traffic flow management system of the FAA.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H1001556B9328433BB09C3C60D21CF294"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Considerations
                  In establishing the pilot program under paragraph (1), the Administrator shall consider the following:
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H0927FF19C3F04882921A20442A9138A1"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     The extent to which developed FPO capabilities may reduce strain on the national airspace system infrastructure while facilitating safe and efficient flow of future air traffic volumes and diverse range of aircraft and advanced aviation aircraft.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H51F9B51C2D154FF4A54C0ED046607E99"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     The extent to which developed FPO capabilities may achieve environmental benefits and time savings.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HF2F414FBF83E4E62B1C7C85AF037329D"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     The perspectives of FAA employees responsible for air traffic flow management development projects, bilateral civil aviation regulatory partners, and industry applicants on the performance of the FAA in carrying out air traffic flow management system development projects.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H3C762F0ACA634D8EA8832C6AB6A77218"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (D)
                     Any other information the Administrator determines appropriate.
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HE9CE8CE831584C05A44E0C094D9D5847"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  Application
                  To be eligible to receive a grant under the program, an air traffic flow management technology provider shall submit an application to the Administrator at such time, in such manner, and containing such information as the Administrator may require.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H61B83898785B4F9FA062A884A4B54163"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  Maximum amount
                  A grant awarded under the program may not exceed $2,000,000 to a single air traffic flow management technology provider.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H57437D16FE404F77955DF5A0D671870F"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Briefing to Congress
               Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, and annually thereafter until the termination of the pilot program under subsection (d) established under this section, the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the progress of such pilot program, including any implementation challenges of the program, detailed metrics of the program, and any recommendations to achieve the adoption of FPO.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H019F132F0249470B96876EA487E57A12"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Trajectory-based operations defined
               In this section, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">trajectory-based operations means an air traffic flow management method for strategically planning, managing, and optimizing flights that uses time-based management, performance-based navigation, and other capabilities and processes to achieve air traffic flow management operational objectives and improvements.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HE505A16DE7AB4E649F5A3154C12C5F02"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (d)
               Sunset
               The pilot program under this section shall terminate on October 1, 2028. 
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HB3D18B4761AF49098011C307319661F9"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            610.
            EXTENSION OF ENHANCED AIR TRAFFIC SERVICES PILOT PROGRAM
            Section 547 of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 (49 U.S.C. 40103 note) is amended—
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                        id="H1018F6133E154327A852A77D6D8126B3"
                        qb-display-quote="yes">
               (1)
               by striking subsection (d) and inserting the following:
               <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                              display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              display-quotes="yes"
                              id="H6C5CCE4D76AF467BA41F310624EDBF10"
                              style="OLC">
                  <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                               id="H2BCC2B4080AC4382849276C051E08CA9"
                               qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (d)
                     Definitions
                     In this section:
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H68719196A17942D098719C8774B4AF6C"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (1)
                        Certain NextGen avionics
                        The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">certain NextGen avionics means those avionics and baseline capabilities as recommended in the report of the NextGen Advisory Committee titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">Minimum Capabilities List (MCL) Ad Hoc Team NAC Task 19–1 Report, issued on November 17, 2020.
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H7FF7D0E58A414CC587A194A40DBB9798"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (2)
                        Preferential basis
                        The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">preferential basis means prioritizing aircraft equipped with certain NextGen avionics by providing them more efficient service, shorter queuing, or priority clearances to the maximum extent possible without reducing overall capacity or safety of the national airspace system.
                     
                  
                  ; and
               
            
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                        id="H354704F6A5E84718B314A8AEA38AFFB0"
                        qb-display-quote="yes">
               (2)
               in subsection (e) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">May 10, 2024 and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">September 30, 2028.
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H73E9DFD5C10C404F9D86074A23190402"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            611.
            FEDERAL CONTACT TOWER WAGE DETERMINATIONS AND POSITIONS
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HC3A359389BBA4F8AB4E733CB041C9ABD"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               The Secretary shall request that the Secretary of Labor—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HD5D845DBCC1A43E587618339EF8FB416"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  review and update, as necessary, including to account for cost-of-living adjustments, the basis for the wage determination for air traffic controllers who are employed at air traffic control towers operated under the Contract Tower Program established under section 47124 of title 49, United States Code;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HDE2B910B817741319D8E5A69D9C00A6A"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  reassess the basis for air traffic controller occupation codes;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HEC0AFD09101D4AA5B2DF38E0C96A5261"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  create a new wage determination category or occupation code for managers of air traffic controllers who are employed at air traffic control towers operated under the Contract Tower Program; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H9AA490652BF1489A920C352398C81F17"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  consult with the Administrator in carrying out the requirements of paragraphs (1) through (3).
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H13F735C0E625495390AD1F78C93D8DF6"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Report
               Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Labor, shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report that includes—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H7A716A14EC4643F0A11329CD2AA8D709"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  a description of the findings and conclusions of the review and reassessment made under subsection (a);
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H2E657C80D10C4998BB2B97E3A19F95F9"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  an explanation of and justification for the basis for the wage determination; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HADD14CACA61742A3B7C0A456DB4EC2D9"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  a description of the actions taken by the Department of Transportation and the Department of Labor to ensure that contract tower air traffic controller wages are adjusted for inflation and are assigned the appropriate occupation codes.
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H8245EEF49C4B46ADA912BA183A295265"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            612.
            BRIEFING ON RADIO COMMUNICATIONS COVERAGE AROUND MOUNTAINOUS TERRAIN
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H3546E7B20CDE48FCA09697412FA856C2"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Briefing requirement
               Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the radio communications coverage within the airspace surrounding the Mena Intermountain Municipal Airport in Mena, Arkansas.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H8D68F70682344F738CB9A77C6E8DEA9E"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Briefing contents
               The briefing required under subsection (a) shall include the following:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H1A214FC1DFD94647A909E2BBEAA140AA"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  The radio communications coverage within the airspace surrounding the Mena Intermountain Municipal Airport with the applicable Air Route Traffic Control Center. 
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H87200CDE17E24B0198967452EC84F3CC"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  The altitudes at which radio communications capabilities are lost within such airspace.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
