                  an assessment of the operational condition of the legacy systems in use, including the interoperability of such systems;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H8746E15DB2FC457B853B88026D8F3C52"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  the average age of such legacy systems and, for each such legacy system, the intended design life of the system, by type; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HF1CB205974B94DDFBCCE6297FDD32EC2"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  the availability of replacement parts, equipment, or technology to maintain such legacy systems.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HD58F151EF830443CAB521602087017D0"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (e)
               Plan to accelerate drawdown, replacement, or enhancement of identified legacy systems
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H390E13772F684B63A6833D8A8449AF07"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  In general
                  Not later than 120 days after the date on which the Administrator provides the report under subsection (d), the Administrator shall develop and implement a plan, in consultation with industry representatives, to accelerate the drawdown, replacement, or enhancement of any legacy systems that are identified in the audit required under subsection (a) as outdated, insufficient, unsafe, or unstable legacy systems.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H24BD760B72304E67A4F922214901146B"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Priorities
                  In developing the plan under paragraph (1), the Administrator shall prioritize the drawdown, replacement, or enhancement of such legacy systems based on the operational risks such legacy systems pose to aviation safety and the costs associated with the replacement or enhancement of such legacy systems.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H035B1BD5DEDD4697832D17234A1FBD10"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  Collaboration with external experts
                  In carrying out this subsection, the Administrator shall—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H8FA14454A4DB407EA5DA455B3336CDB9"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     collaborate with industry representatives and other external experts in information technology to develop the plan under paragraph (1) within a reasonable timeframe; 
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HF53DDC69A2854B4AA81D258D5BCBC679"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     identify technologies in existence or in development that, with or without adaptation, are expected to be suitable to meet the technical information technology needs of the FAA; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H40DCF6C1EB7F4CF99F0EE10190455B5C"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     maintain consistency with the acquisition management system established and updated pursuant to section 40110(d) of title 49, United States Code.
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HCFEA8311BD504A919D6EBDD407688C8C"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  Progress updates
                  The Administrator shall provide the appropriate committees of Congress with semiannual updates through September 30, 2028 on the progress made in carrying out the plan under paragraph (1).
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HCB2CA228BD2247949EA6A3A91E2AC777"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (5)
                  Inspector general review
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H2F9BCB9365CE4143975468E71B7E89DE"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     In general
                     Not later than 3 years after the Administrator develops the plan required under paragraph (1), the inspector general of the Department of Transportation shall assess such efforts of the Administration to drawdown, replace, or enhance any legacy systems identified under subsection (a).
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HAEF3D665EFFB4A8FAD2D11C94E718D8A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     Report
                     The inspector general shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the results of the review carried out under subparagraph (A).
                  
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H6F922A8B5FBA498D97B4E8F2A6E168BC"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (f)
               Definitions
               In this section:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HBBCFC6849730475B866C0AA5C00FAF10"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Industry
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">industry means aviation industry organizations with expertise in aviation-dedicated network systems, systems engineering platforms, aviation software services, air traffic management, flight operations, and International Civil Aviation Organization standards.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HFEEE3FD85A4842B989E9195234DF8102"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Legacy system
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">legacy system means any communication, navigation, surveillance, or automation or network applications or ground-based aviation infrastructure, or other critical software and hardware systems owned by the FAA, that were deployed prior to the year 2000, including the Notice to Air Missions system.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HA6E15EC9295A40AEB750922FC3E51F8C"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  Outdated, insufficient, unsafe, or unstable legacy system
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">outdated, insufficient, unsafe, or unstable legacy system means a legacy system for which the likelihood of failure of such system creates a risk to air safety or security due to the age, ability to be maintained in a cost-effective manner, vulnerability to degradation, errors, or malicious attacks of such system, or any other factors that may compromise the performance or security of such system, including a legacy system—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H22DBFF7E784640D0927D76A649A89870"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     that is vulnerable or susceptible to mechanical failure; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HD9135DA45DA84EA3BCA9F45AA2752165"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     with a risk of a single point of failure or that lacks sufficient contingencies in the event of such failure.
                  
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H096FC72709E546F689EF3D04275C10CA"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            623.
            AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL FACILITY REALIGNMENT STUDY
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HB70B29E18D5D4E849642F4308A391048"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Examination
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H969480D1C8CC4E278840D7A8CA50D3CA"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  In general
                  Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall seek to enter into an agreement with a federally funded research and development center to conduct an Air Traffic Control Facility Realignment study to examine consolidating or otherwise reorganizing air traffic control facilities and the management of airspace controlled by such facilities.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H28798DD4882B440199518EAAA754F017"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Contents
                  In the study required under paragraph (1), the federally funded research and development center shall—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H652A0D7796904F90BDB9A9E84D81D3A3"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     evaluate the potential efficiencies that may result from a reorganization;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HF96E95DBCAF64E439DBFDB23416E37A5"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     identify whether certain areas prone to airspace congestion or facility staff shortages would benefit from any enhanced flexibilities or operational changes; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H1EFABE189CA94BCC8201D254B0A45448"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     recommend opportunities for integration of separate facilities to create a more collaborative and efficient traffic control environment.
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H2E1BD5442627487B903A9D553FB9AAEF"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  Consultation
                  In carrying out this subsection, the federally funded research and development center shall consult with the exclusive representatives of air traffic controllers certified under section 7111 of title 5, United States Code.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HD8B34411CAA140BE86423CC638F670E8"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Report
               Not later than 15 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the federally funded research and development center shall submit to the Administrator a report detailing the findings of the study required under subsection (a) and recommendations related to consolidation or reorganization of air traffic control work facilities and locations.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H03BBC38773044DEDAA414AA6C98C254D"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Congressional briefing
               Not later than 18 months after receiving the report under subsection (b), the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the results of the study under subsection (a) and any recommendations under subsection (b) related to consolidation or reorganization of air traffic control work facilities and locations.
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H8CECC6C0FADC4278A1481303EA774451"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            624.
            AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL TOWER REPLACEMENT PROCESS REPORT
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H36CED86FA07A44A89D92D79726E9519C"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Report required
               Not later than 120 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall submit to Congress a report on the process by which air traffic control tower facilities are chosen for replacement.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HFE5A43B5B55245D1B315CEF384F5C8C4"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Contents
               The report required under subsection (a) shall contain—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HE05205F7B6C64E2E8D49071A2377EC39"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  the process by which air traffic control tower facilities are chosen for replacement, including which divisions of the Administration control or are involved in the replacement decision making process;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H91C3B2781F6544CFA13F1F08AADCC2A7"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  the criteria the Administrator uses to determine which air traffic control tower facilities to replace, including—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H806867C72D5A40A8BAB3E43E9787C704"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     the relative importance of each such criteria;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H5767D0F6445646F9B1DADFC06940925D"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     why the Administrator uses each such criteria; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H017A947866E54C12BE2D2965F4F1D345"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     the reasons for the relative importance of each such criteria;
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H3C2B78D4903C4DCA9D73A2811E603003"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  what types of investigation the Administrator carries out to determine if an air traffic control tower facility should be replaced;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HF99B12D5A25445C8BD83C747BC9BB455"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  a timeline of the replacement process for an individual air traffic control tower facility replacement;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H3DF3EEADFF5E4E8FBD9FD4393B4E2F20"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (5)
                  the list of facilities established under subsection (c), including the reason for selecting each such facility; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H04F7E6B78DAF422B9DD753E9ECA90973"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (6)
                  any other information the Administrator considers relevant.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H0D19756249714D699871BB9F0685B0BA"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               List of replaced air traffic control tower facilities
               The Administrator shall establish, maintain, and publish on the website of the FAA a list of the following:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H2FDD16CCBF704E128C3275C8205ACD1F"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  All air traffic control tower facilities replaced within the 10-year period preceding the date of enactment of this Act.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H07A35B62C97A47E0B825C10EE3D7EA48"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Any air traffic control tower facilities for which the Administrator has made a determination requiring replacement, but for which such replacement has not yet been completed.
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H1C70681ABBD7405BBA7D1CFFA952AC16"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            625.
            CONTRACT TOWER PROGRAM SAFETY ENHANCEMENTS
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HC4FA56B6342F434DB759AC341F84CADA"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Pilot program for transitioning to FAA Towers
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H83AF7D1F735446FC9B8D47E0619A5735"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  In general
                  Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall establish a pilot program to convert high-activity air traffic control towers operating under the Contract Tower Program as established under section 47124 of title 49, United States Code, (in this section referred to as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Contract Tower Program) to a level I (Visual Flight Rules) tower staffed by the FAA.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HABE506C8010948899A8C753E24CB7203"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Priority
                  In selecting air traffic control towers to participate in the pilot program established under paragraph (1), the Administrator shall prioritize air traffic control towers operating under the Contract Tower Program that—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H78F423A005FF4195A813043C608AFF5F"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     either—
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H567D4B5133C14C47BA49E0B83BA8D951"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (i)
                        had over 200,000 annual tower operations in calendar year 2022; or
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HCE0CDD845A3D4B5991F158FC76F90BDA"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (ii)
                        served a small hub airport with more than 900,000 passenger enplanements in calendar year 2021;
                     
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H100FFB9EDD5449499F6B155A871B2BF6"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     are either currently owned by the FAA or are constructed to FAA standards; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H09C7C00965BF47EAA749AEE8253DCE17"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     operate within complex airspace, including airspace that serves air carrier, general aviation, and military aircraft.
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H49DBF403DE0D41C48A861B845A1851E6"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  Tower selection
                  The number of air traffic control towers selected to participate in the pilot program established under paragraph (1) shall be determined based on the availability of funds for the pilot program and the interest of the airport sponsor related to such facility. 
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H60F5AD813FF04EC78EF7BD3302F7FC12"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  Controller retention
                  With respect to any high-activity air traffic control tower selected to be converted under the pilot program established under paragraph (1), the Administrator shall appoint to the position of air traffic controller any air traffic controller who—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HA17D70B0A28748E0AA7AC9B2D7CE46DF"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     is employed at such air traffic control tower as of the date on which the Administrator selects such tower to be converted;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H44D0DB90C3864C28BFC603C3AF2EF35B"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     meets the qualifications contained in section 44506(f)(1)(A) of title 49, United States Code; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H0DFAA0F4F4AD4DB2B9E2B6B4FACD0F24"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     has all other pre-employment qualifications required by law to be a certified controller of the FAA.
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H593799CA238B4C7CA0CDB7D4C6C4D31C"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (5)
                  Safety analysis
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HA3A1A1818B4A41DB8EE59263E93BDAB7"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     In general
                     The Administrator shall conduct a safety analysis to determine whether the conversion of any air traffic control tower described in paragraph (1) negatively impacts aviation safety at such air traffic control tower and take such actions needed to address any negative impact.
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H511D4ED0F473453FBE722073DB5A2E96"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     Report
                     Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report describing the results of the safety analysis under subparagraph (A), any actions taken to address any negative impacts to safety, and the overall results of the pilot program established under this subsection.
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H95CDC8BD12774D9697C4878043F8F3AA"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (6)
                  Authorization of appropriations
                  Out of amounts made available under section 106(k) of title 49, United States Code, there is authorized to be appropriated to carry out this subsection $30,000,000 to remain available for 5 fiscal years.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H285E93EBEA60422982952BF1FF532594"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Air traffic controller staffing levels at small and medium hub airports
               Section 47124(b)(2) of title 49, United States Code, is amended—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H7F82DF995A83453880A7B4AF973CFD73"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">The Secretary may and inserting the following:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="HB2CEAE6A9AA2473B96D6945CA72A4FAE"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H8EFC337C24DD4D9DA4730DEC860081E7"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        In general
                        The Secretary may
                     
                     ; and
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H08E606A57AA941648A0F68967719A632"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  by adding at the end the following:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="H1BECC042BC26425FA9DA778B8A0CEB4D"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HBF3C7698CFF144F99321B6C49B6CC819"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        Small or medium hub airports
                        In the case of a contract entered into on or after the date of enactment of this subparagraph to operate an airport traffic control tower at a small or medium hub airport, the contract shall require the Secretary, after coordination with the airport sponsor and the entity, State, or subdivision, and not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2024, to provide funding sufficient for the cost of wages and benefits of at least 2 air traffic controllers for each tower operating shift. 
                     
                     .
                  
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H65C8537F02FC466984A963DF158B34D2"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Priorities for facility selection
               Section 47124(b)(3)(C) of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:
               <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                              display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              display-quotes="yes"
                              id="H7B5D18BB3E30472A866E189F5D171118"
                              style="OLC">
                  <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HA7B4296E1EFF41B2955B4A5DDB112CEB"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (viii)
                     Air traffic control towers at airports with safety or operational problems related to the lack of an existing tower.
                  
                  <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H59543F056EB04D768570480AA86E0A42"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (ix)
                     Air traffic control towers at airports with projected commercial and military increases in aircraft or flight operations.
                  
                  <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H6E1E29DDCF294901B4A6C6615338833A"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (x)
                     Air traffic control towers at airports with a variety of aircraft operations, including a variety of commercial and military flight operations.
                  
                  .
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HAC87F05796274772B45F2AF377DEDFD4"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            626.
            SENSE OF CONGRESS ON USE OF ADVANCED SURVEILLANCE IN OCEANIC AIRSPACE
            It is the sense of Congress the FAA shall continue to evaluate the potential uses for space-based automatic dependent surveillance broadcast to improve surveillance coverage of domestic airspace including improving surveillance coverage over remote terrain and in oceanic airspace. If determined appropriate by the Administrator, the FAA shall consider whether additional testing would meaningfully contribute to the FAA’s processes for developing separation standards and more efficient routes.
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HD289833EB345477F857F34C7D6B0081E"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            627.
            LOW-ALTITUDE ROUTES FOR VERTICAL FLIGHT
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H35C7311832B649558219490ED32D1FD3"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Sense of Congress
               It is the sense of Congress that the national airspace system requires additional rotorcraft, powered-lift aircraft, and low-altitude instrument flight rules, routes leveraging advances in performance based navigation in order to provide direct, safe, and reliable routes that ensure sufficient separation from higher altitude fixed wing aircraft traffic.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H84E5A57B031C4A8EA513D10D94C5E3DC"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Low-altitude rotorcraft and powered-lift aircraft instrument flight routes
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HD94EF4DF15C24C7AA9F29CEEB6A1D415"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  In general
                  Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall initiate a rulemaking process to establish or update, as appropriate, low altitude routes and flight procedures to ensure safe rotorcraft and powered-lift aircraft operations in the national airspace system.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H8D4098C5814742F7B4C8E03A89658B61"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Requirements
                  In carrying out this subsection, the Administrator shall—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HEF73ED4663064DAB99CC692362EECD5B"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     incorporate instrument flight rules rotorcraft operations into the low-altitude performance based navigation procedure infrastructure;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H1EE93C9F8DE14FCA8D4EAAD93884C901"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     prioritize the development of new helicopter area navigation instrument flight rules routes as part of the United States air traffic service route structure that utilize performance based navigation, such as Global Positioning System and Global Navigation Satellite System equipment; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H675CC5A9A5514FBFB53DAFC85B3572F3"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     consider the impact of such low altitude flight routes on other airspace users and impacted communities to ensure that such routes are designed to minimize—
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HCBBFDC92BB4843DAB03814771688F2D8"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (i)
                        the potential for conflict with existing national airspace system operations;
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA91BDE66A31142AAA59B59128DB62ACA"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (ii)
                        the workload of air traffic controllers; and
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA70BA045E9894F67877EB4BFDEB547B7"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (iii)
                        negative effects to impacted communities.
                     
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H4205EDF1AC1F4489A79ECED4EC5F1AA3"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  Consultation
                  In carrying out the rulemaking process under paragraph (1), the Administrator shall consult with—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H6B0BA25DBAB34D2F98E5D3662DA24E75"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     stakeholders in the airport, heliport, rotorcraft manufacturer and operator, general aviation operator, powered-lift operator, air carrier, and performance based navigation technology manufacturer sectors; 
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H90BDB08EE4664352A7645D3B521F8008"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     the United States Helicopter Safety Team;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HA5D48078F9B94B6CA3CB9C2C334095FA"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     exclusive bargaining representatives of air traffic controllers certified under section 7111 of title 5, United States Code; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HA3BB44C3FC464C5CAB98448AECD2E5F5"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (D)
                     other stakeholders determined appropriate by the Administrator.
                  
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HEE369CC01E46462E8FAA8BBFCFC0E000"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            628.

            Section 40128(b)(4) of title 49, United States Code, is amended—
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"

               <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"

         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H896A3FB5C7D64E7EA67614A36DEE00F1"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            629.
            UPGRADING AND REPLACING AGING AIR TRAFFIC SYSTEMS
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H234FD9527BA6420D98BF2701B13A7F19"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Study
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HD82444CF802943FBB4DDA0BF5BAD9E9D"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  In general
                  Not later than 60 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall seek to enter into an agreement with a qualified organization to conduct a study to assess the need for upgrades to or replacement of existing automated surface observation systems/automated weather observing systems (in this section referred to as <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">ASOS/AWOS) located in non-contiguous States.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HD8A6A1BF15AC4E0AAE350BE6D73D269A"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Contents
                  The study conducted under paragraph (1) shall include an analysis of—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H15E87EABCF124A2DA4FFCF78EB9C4A6E"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     the age of each ASOS/AWOS located in non-contiguous States;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HE54867F176934CD8AB76089770FD1AA4"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     the number of days in the calendar year preceding the date on which the study is conducted that each such ASOS/AWOS was not able to accurately communicate or disseminate data for any period of time;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HC1983162E9A24DE3871EA8CE4415A1D6"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     impacts of extreme severe weather on ASOS/AWOS outages;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H1CD458F40C3648A29CAF72BA4E0510B6"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (D)
                     the effective coverage of the existing ASOS/AWOS;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H99DB4368674743F1B330FF29B4351E92"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (E)
                     detailed upgrade requirements for each existing ASOS/AWOS, including an assessment of whether replacement would be the most cost-effective recommendation;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H03CD653B67AF4215ABC5B51D3338A08E"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (F)
                     prior maintenance expenditures for each existing ASOS/AWOS;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HE5C0A73AD120483C8039D58B2763D852"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (G)
                     a description of all upgrades or replacements made by the FAA to ASOS/AWOS prior to the date of enactment of this Act; 
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HF09BEC8FD9F5423C9E4570A5B410FE13"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (H)
                     impacts of an outage or break in service in the FAA Telecommunications Infrastructure on such ASOS/AWOS; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HC4384B9D10DA4530B26CB8E7D8A85C11"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (I)
                     any other matter determined appropriate by the Administrator.
                  
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H39D3118BEEFB49AFAA8D01867D7F9A9B"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Report
               Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the findings of the study conducted under subsection (a), and include in such report—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H5A67F9ACEFA8476589E41EC50EF9FE1C"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  a plan for executing upgrades to or replacements of existing ASOS/AWOS located in non-contiguous States;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H8C47FCE8BE67439F98D680BE4217596B"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  a plan for converting and upgrading such ASOS/AWOS communications to the FAA Telecommunications Infrastructure;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H2D047C3930604C8C9AEC002DE1EAD63D"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  an assessment of the use of unmonitored navigational aids to allow for alternate airport planning for commercial and cargo aviation to limit ASOS/AWOS service disruptions; 
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H07462023676D4661A3691A0531074069"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  an evaluation of additional alternative methods of compliance for obtaining weather elements that would be as sufficient as current data received through ASOS/AWOS; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HDCDC2E1D5090483D9B4CAAA014422967"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (5)
                  any other recommendation determined appropriate by the Administrator.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HC419615B05F24502AC472385AED473A1"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Funding
               To carry out the study under this section, the Administrator may use amounts made available pursuant to section 48101(c)(1) of title 49, United States Code. 
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HB614AAD813A24F5FA0231869E3427F83"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            630.
            AIRSPACE INTEGRATION FOR SPACE LAUNCH AND REENTRY
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H096FAE78133C4E1E8D7894453D0C1A9A"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Sense of Congress
               It is the Sense of Congress that—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H2527DDB060364FF094ED492C99FDF788"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  a safe and efficient national airspace system that successfully supports existing users and integrates new entrants is of the utmost importance;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H20ED457DCA30468D8905B50E533C3702"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  both commercial aviation and space launch and reentry operations are vital to United States global leadership, national security, and economic opportunity;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HBB4787BD1DE047E98D01512FEC216E45"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  aircraft hazard areas are necessary during space launch and reentry operations to ensure public safety; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H895413D7D7D7479CA1F202AD61E62AA5"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  the Administrator should prioritize the development and deployment of technologies to improve visibility of space launch and reentry operations within FAA computer systems and minimize operational workload to air traffic controllers associated with routing traffic during spaceflight launch and reentry operations.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H8E3B1533E76440E8B497353B07C616F4"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Space launch and reentry airspace integration technology
               Out of amounts made available under section 48101 of title 49, United States Code, $10,000,000 for each of the fiscal years 2025 through 2028 (or until such time as the Administrator determines that the project meeting the requirements of this section has reached an operational status) is available for the Administrator to carry out a project to expedite the development, acquisition, and deployment of technologies or capabilities to aid in space launch and reentry integration with the objective of operational readiness not later than December 31, 2026, which may include—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H500486F286294FED81F7EF48A26C0B99"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  technologies recommended by the Airspace Access Priorities aviation rulemaking committee in the final report titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">ARC Recommendations Final Report, issued on August 21, 2019;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H72B0823602224B8A95C094445EAB7886"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  systems to enable the integration of launch and reentry data directly onto air traffic controller displays; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H7A4CF145F90146EC8A788D4A6362BA44"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  automated systems to enable near real-time planning and dynamic rerouting of commercial aircraft during and following commercial space launch and reentry operations.
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HAD742CA533A2465085135CD282BAFCBD"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            631.
            UPDATE TO FAA ORDER ON AIRWAY PLANNING STANDARD
            Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall take such actions as may be necessary to update ,the order of the FAA titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                       quote-display-start="auto"
                       quote-type="text">Airway Planning Standard Number One–Terminal Air Navigation Facilities and Air Traffic Control Services (FAA Order 7031.2c), to lower the remote radar bright display scope installation requirement from 30,000 annual itinerant operations to 15,000 annual itinerant operations.
         
      
      <title id="HF7CD5B337F4241118C3C38CA293C7C95"
              qb-display-quote="yes"

                                    display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    display-quotes="yes"
                                    id="HC33177B194284947921ED061D1C9541D"
                                    style="OLC">
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H84CA82DFE577456BAB522841D8D7F111"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (S)
                           acquisition of advanced digital construction management systems and related technology used in the planning, design and engineering, construction, and maintenance of airport facilities when such systems or technologies are acquired to carry out a project approved by the Secretary under this subchapter.
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H1BA8F2E5EE664231983414882689EE3D"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (T)
                           improvements, or planning for improvements (including monitoring equipment or services), that would be necessary to sustain commercial service flight operations or permit the resumption of such flight operations following a natural disaster (including an earthquake, flooding, high water, wildfires, hurricane, storm surge, tidal wave, tornado, tsunami, wind driven water, sea level rise, tropical storm, cyclone, land instability, or winter storm) at—
                           <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H9DE0D4D74B2C4637B9BFC6910A064A05"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (i)
                              a primary airport; or
                           
                           <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H9AAF15155F704FDEAFAD71195EEA5330"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (ii)
                              a nonprimary airport that is designated as a Federal staging area or incident support base by the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency.
                           
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H84CB9F5EF17E4BF9A8FAE132B3393069"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (U)
                           a project to comply with rulemakings and recommendations on airport cybersecurity standards from the aviation rulemaking committee convened under section 395 of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2024. 
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HDA964F75A17C4D0BBCFEBA7431E2A764"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (V)
                           reconstructing or rehabilitating an existing crosswind runway (regardless of the wind coverage of the primary runway) if the reconstruction or rehabilitation of such crosswind runway is in the most recently approved airport layout plan of the sponsor.
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H8F2CEB58F6844C2DBCAEFE15EC6DCA5A"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (W)
                           constructing or acquiring such airport-owned infrastructure or equipment, notwithstanding revenue producing capability of such infrastructure or equipment, as may be required for—
                           <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HFBA0FC69997D4349914D3B8BA4AF956B"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (i)
                              the on-airport distribution or storage of unleaded aviation gasoline for piston-driven aircraft, including on-airport construction or expansion of pipelines, storage tanks, low-emission fuel systems, and airport-owned fuel trucks providing exclusively unleaded aviation fuels (unless the Secretary determines that an alternative fuel may be safely used in such fuel truck for a limited time); or
                           
                           <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HA2FC2974D60B40EA856F5DAC3B13B9E9"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (ii)
                              fueling systems for type certificated hydrogen-powered aircraft.
                           
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H6162B4C8ED2542398A9AF5667A10BACB"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (X)
                           constructing, reconstructing, or rehabilitating a taxiway or taxilane that serves non-exclusive use aeronautical facilities, including aircraft storage facilities, except for the 50 feet of pavement immediately in front of an ineligible building.
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H66846C1F593140B59425780A1759C9A5"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (Y)
                           any other activity (excluding terminal development) that the Secretary concludes will reasonably improve the safety of the airport.
                        
                        ;
                     
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H8CEAC03BDB124210ADA76C14897B5010"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">

            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HA83FFDD1E98645BEB17CC5B93ECE17C9"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               703.
               REVENUE DIVERSION PENALTY ENHANCEMENT
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HE7135170FE6F4644887DC70C654B0740"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Section 47107 of title 49, United States Code, is amended—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H031289D0266245BEBD19E3AF760EA795"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     in subsection (m)(4) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">an amount equal to and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">an amount equal to double; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4401F3F64CB0441E85BFC323236E25E9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     in subsection (n)(1) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">an amount equal to and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">an amount equal to double.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H1FA80030E25149058B6B2CF0B89810A4"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Applicability
                  The amendments made by subsection (a) shall not apply to any illegal diversion of airport revenues (as described in section 47107(m) of title 49, United States Code) that occurred prior to the date of enactment of this Act.

               705.
               RENEWAL OF CERTAIN LEASES
               Section 47107(t)(2) of title 49, United States Code, is amended—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H972B950413FD45B3BCFB4577400B6C96"

               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H9B0FA3EF94D24E8DB7A72F065E6BE34F"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  by striking subparagraph (D) and inserting the following:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
