            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H2F042DD7BEA343DA82F6F9B1B7DC74F3"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               729.
               NATIONAL PRIORITY SYSTEM FORMULAS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H705993D2C3BE4D3AB40CBF8490BCAB34"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall review and update the National Priority System prioritization formulas contained in FAA Order 5090.5 to account for the amendments to chapter 471 of title 49, United States Code, made by this Act.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H47BE692128384C9D82725B7E65480B66"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Required consultation
                  In revising the formulas under subsection (a), the Secretary shall consult with representatives of the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8444E3847C7D4C738697DC42D9449BDB"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Primary airports, including large, medium, small, and nonhub airports.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA2D848748BF842C7BF38E29A68808EAF"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Non-primary airports, including general aviation airports.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3FA496957F344281B3CF05D7C26F6C0F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Airport trade associations, including trade associations representing airport executives.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H6D23B741E5BD4107A8CF6067B3370B5B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     State aviation officials, including associations representing such officials.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HFEB177EFBB474E448C820B482AC28986"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     Air carriers, including mainline, regional, and low-cost air carriers.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3BF1156B958441A48A1936553A8A9D59"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     Associations representing air carriers.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HD83C5D1C5BEC40FA99ADF8B80FD5A947"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Priority projects
                  In revising the formulas under subsection (a), the Secretary shall assign the highest priority to projects that increase or maintain the safety, efficiency, and capacity of the aviation system.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H7C919D9BB87D44E2BEF7BB46FBA10429"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               730.
               MINORITY AND DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS PARTICIPATION
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H95D5C0B19B3A41398B98152C05195346"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Findings
                  Congress finds the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H733A39EA6A4D4AC9BDC89CEC525BFC1E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     While significant progress has occurred due to the establishment of the airport disadvantaged business enterprise program and the airport concessions disadvantaged business enterprise program under sections 47113 and 47107(e) of title 49, United States Code, respectively, discrimination and related barriers continue to pose significant obstacles for minority- and women-owned businesses seeking to do business in airport-related markets across the Nation.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA95C71E17CED4042BF7B96C6766AA75D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Congress has received and reviewed testimony and documentation of race and gender discrimination from numerous sources, including congressional hearings and roundtables, scientific reports, reports issued by public and private agencies, news stories, reports of discrimination by organizations and individuals, and discrimination lawsuits. Such testimony and documentation show that race- and gender-neutral efforts alone are insufficient to address the problem.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H53AAFCC823714E0392AB4B0AA2937DF0"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     The testimony and documentation described in paragraph (2) demonstrate that race and gender discrimination pose a barrier to full and fair participation in airport-related businesses of women business owners and minority business owners in the racial groups detailed in parts 23 and 26 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations, and has impacted firm development and other aspects of airport-related business in the public and private markets.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H9146980318E34C4BB556ED0734E85503"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     The testimony and documentation described in paragraph (2) provide a strong basis that there is a compelling need for the continuation of the airport disadvantaged business enterprise program and the airport concessions disadvantaged business enterprise program to address race and gender discrimination in airport-related business.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H8DF13A9C667E402CBB8EDD4D783AC670"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Supportive services
                  Section 47113 of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="H48E4F30E2B6E49D299E11E4DA8B81251"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                  id="HF6EB53E818A14C98891A2087F191EB33"
                                  qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (f)
                        Supportive services
                        <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H7BD4724EFD9B4379B3644DD4E94A0B26"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (1)
                           In general
                           The Secretary, in coordination with the Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, may, at the request of an airport sponsor, provide assistance under a grant issued under this subchapter to develop, conduct, and administer training programs and assistance programs in connection with any airport improvement project subject to part 26 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations, for small business concerns referred to in subsection (b) to achieve proficiency to compete, on an equal basis for contracts and subcontracts related to such projects. 
                        
                        <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H319DA994FB2C4684B95389F0E4BE57B6"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (2)
                           Eligible entities
                           An entity eligible to receive assistance under this section is—
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H20D5CCF0379546B7A68D24AB948DCD2D"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (A)
                              a State;
                           
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H75CE68A5F16D4369BE9E4371E76079BF"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (B)
                              a political subdivision of a State or local government;
                           
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HED94B894E9A84D43A882B200FEB9B85B"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (C)
                              a Tribal government;
                           
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H587BF8AF52CF4FE386B2CB2F0BE1FF5D"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (D)
                              an airport sponsor;
                           
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H8F49C2B54ACA450096627D3A01073494"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (E)
                              a metropolitan planning organization;
                           
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H7D21A6A54E4F4044B6502C310AAC0444"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (F)
                              a group of entities described in subparagraphs (A) through (E); or
                           
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H546E634C1A27406E860598D42FADBD64"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (G)
                              any other organization considered appropriate by the Secretary.
                           
                        
                     
                     .
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HC8E609D808A4433CB9E7DB2A581524E1"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               731.
               EXTENSION OF PROVISION RELATING TO AIRPORT ACCESS ROADS IN REMOTE LOCATIONS
               Section 162 of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 (49 U.S.C. 47102 note) is amended, in the matter preceding paragraph (1), by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">2018 and all that follows through <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">2024 and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">2024 through 2028.
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HAB3D3D85CB374946BB3E5230F8E2ED34"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               732.
               POPULOUS COUNTIES WITHOUT AIRPORTS
               Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Secretary may not deny inclusion in the national plan of integrated airport systems maintained under section 47103 of title 49, United States Code, to an airport or proposed airport if the airport or proposed airport—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H975EBD21E23C4800B27238B13DC64C08"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  is located in the most populous county (as such term is defined in section 2 of title 1, United States Code) of a State that does not have an airport listed in the national plan;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H41FD11D1998E4448A22308A00D37A26F"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  has an airport sponsor that was established before January 1, 2017;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HFD08BD6CC48747EE8D756271201A984F"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  is located more than 15 miles away from another airport listed in the national plan;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H5F12E6C12411468F9464808CDD5C5DC6"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  demonstrates how the airport will meet the operational activity required, through a forecast validated by the Secretary, within the first 10 years of operation;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H9983D8FC94294E69B5FAB699EB60CFCB"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (5)
                  meets FAA airport design standards;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HB7E3D3A3DB1F45F996D93806A966A08C"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (6)
                  submits a benefit-cost analysis;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H94F52069894B41C6BD01E0D4C74B5FFA"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (7)
                  presents a detailed financial plan to accomplish construction and ongoing maintenance; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H33580DB1E0B54DFA8F48E030B07B1E54"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (8)
                  has the documented support of the State government for the entry of the airport or proposed airport into the national plan.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H8CFA0ECA03844FBFA1757F81619429A1"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               733.
               AIP HANDBOOK UPDATE
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HE4D9C0EE97BD4938BE920C497B52F513"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall revise the Airport Improvement Program Handbook (FAA Order 5100.38D) (in this section referred to as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">AIP Handbook) to account for legislative changes to the airport improvement program under subchapter I of chapter 471 and chapter 475 of title 49, United States Code, and to make such other changes as the Administrator determines necessary.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HD43A6482804B457686C8FC388E00C7E6"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Requirements relating to Alaska
                  In revising the AIP Handbook under subsection (a) (and in any subsequent revision), the Administrator, in consultation with the Governor of Alaska, shall identify and incorporate reasonable exceptions to the general requirements of the AIP Handbook to meet the unique circumstances, and advance the safety needs, of airports in Alaska, including with respect to the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1A4660C80471494E96B1982C11EE74E0"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Snow Removal Equipment Building size and configuration.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H686382298A05496195E9FEAAF59235C4"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Expansion of lease areas.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H7D39A22F787F4090B6AA8E6C354B0CEC"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Shared governmental use of airport equipment and facilities in remote locations.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HEBDE2BD271224416A2F99F510DDE03D0"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Ensuring the resurfacing or reconstruction of legacy runways to support—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H666E0022A12D4EA8A68FF0029038D2A0"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        aircraft necessary to support critical health needs of a community;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H00C085EADBC14B3DBBF72430AA12F127"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        remote fuel deliveries; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H1AC038DDC23B49628E7913BB1E1E6C0C"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        firefighting response.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H17F36709E8944580900A1535BD17A7DA"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     The use of runway end identifier lights at airports in Alaska.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HA8DD0C8EE8424FB98C7C8971F0599AC6"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Additional requirement
                  In revising the AIP Handbook under subsection (a), the Administrator shall include updates to reflect whether a light emitting diode system is an appropriate replacement for any existing halogen system.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H98249685160E4E82AFE3ACC724248368"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Public comment
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HEB9D8ECF67734B80BA9142B1ACB40E2E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall publish a draft revision of the AIP Handbook and make such draft available for public comment for a period of not less than 90 days. 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H556C7A24C17C47D8ABA516BED0DD879C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Review
                     The Administrator shall—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HDF030DFF97EC414499B1C9AE6301AAE9"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        review all comments submitted during the public comment period described under paragraph (1);
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H337EF8782F404AF1B84F93D8C1A33CC1"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        as the Administrator considers appropriate, incorporate changes based on such comments into the final revision of the Handbook; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H5FFA04DF5A984DCE80EE6DBF22433D7D"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        provide a response to all significant comments.
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H7882841C96484E7C8A64A69F5061CD15"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Interim implementation of changes
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE0FF8541DF1F4A61B6C8B5C75091F141"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Except as provided in paragraph (2), not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall issue program guidance letters to provide for the interim implementation of amendments made by this Act to the Airport Improvement Program.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0DDBCE1136F34913BB887CDB967F92C4"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Alaska exceptions
                     Not later than 60 days after the date on which the Administrator identified reasonable exceptions under subsection (b), the Administrator, in consultation with the Regional Administrator of the FAA Alaskan Region, shall issue program guidance letters to provide for the interim application of such exceptions.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HFA0CE199C7824CC38159EFB08662415E"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               734.
               GAO AUDIT OF AIRPORT FINANCIAL REPORTING PROGRAM
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H58E4D089AEFE4AA4BD9390FF07332BCB"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Audit
                  Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall initiate an audit of the airport financial reporting program of the FAA and provide recommendations to the Administrator on improvements to such program.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H28FD1F4A61B249CF809289AABA0F877D"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Requirements
                  In conducting the audit required under subsection (a), the Comptroller General shall, at a minimum—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H52FB9716A0394029B0E6AEECA08CBF45"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     review relevant FAA guidance to airports, including the version of Advisory Circular 150/5100–19, titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">Operating and Financial Summary, that is in effect on the date of enactment of this Act;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H543ACCD6F31B4C2FB11E15ECB60B0170"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     evaluate the information requested or required by the Administrator from airports for completeness and usefulness by the FAA and the public;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H74235347D6B547EFBB41F17610A399AA"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     assess the costs associated with collecting, reporting, and maintaining such information for airports and the FAA;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H08B58110E83A498A8F2A4F9E385D7E4C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     determine if such information provided is—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE430E7885BEA4867AE395002CA544AEF"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        updated on a regular basis to make such information useful; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H2AEC5CF1A65344FC8A504C2FAED20A5E"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        audited and verified in an appropriate manner;
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H5E7526AF7B164C74B18094C475E62E9B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     assess if the Administrator has addressed the issues the Administrator discovered during the apportionment and disbursement of relief funds to airports under the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (Public Law 116–136) using inaccurate and aged airport financial data; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H6DFE52CEF0A4452FB52B0919ADC90A15"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     determine whether the airport financial reporting program as structured as of the date of enactment of this Act provides value to the FAA, the aviation industry, or the public.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H1FACE21B370349809F4725D28257C43E"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Report to Congress
                  Not later than 3 months after the completion of the audit required under subsection (a), the Comptroller General shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report containing the findings of such audit and any recommendations provided to the Administrator to improve or alter the airport financial reporting program.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HDC6F5DCB120F4CEFBC7C6ADE8A9322BB"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               735.
               GAO STUDY OF ONSITE AIRPORT GENERATION
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H6479171F2022477AAF1C4FDC0651730D"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Study
                  Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall initiate a study on the feasibility of installation and adoption of certain power generation property at airports which receive funding from the Federal Government.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HFAABCAF110A54349924EEFE803B1F534"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Content
                  In carrying out the study required under subsection (a), the Comptroller General shall examine—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H96FCAF660BC7469C9461F8EED7485515"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     any safety impacts of the installation and operation of such power generation property, either in aggregate or around certain locations or structures at the airport;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB0913C9246944127A5A3953339832AA7"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     regulatory barriers to adoption;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H95DE2C9297FF49538E3A57812CC65617"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     benefits to adoption;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF8E56B0BDBA84B54AA18B59FB6764AA9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     previous examples of adoptions;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA5D2E05E7DA44AC4A2415FE60712B7ED"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     impacts on other entities; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0EC926E6A21F4B57A5514766DB174812"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     previous examples of adoption and factors pertaining to previous examples of adoption, including—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE660563BC5B7451C9F5E6A370B715BA5"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        novel uses beyond supplemental power generation, such as expanding nonresidential property around airports to minimize noise, power generation resilience, and market forces;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H13B4E881CBBD4D6899DEFE84DBC26355"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        challenges identified in the installation process;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H68EED17720944462A7EC6396BEC665F5"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        upfront and long-term costs, both foreseen and unforeseen;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H02694BC502144AE09A46A4263704D50F"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        funding sources used to pay for upfront costs; and 
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H93BCC55D55BD4170AE563EEB25898EBD"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (E)
                        long-term savings.
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HFEA67ACB50F04155B97E099677EB4313"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Report
                  Not later than 2 years after the initiation of the study under subsection (a), the Comptroller General shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report containing the results of the study and any recommendations based on such results.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HEF6ABAC6B2324309B77656A23A89B5BB"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Power generation property defined
                  In this section, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">power generation property means equipment defined in section 48(a)(3)(A) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H78DA4F3BE44149A0B7B79601280C1FA2"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               736.
               TRANSPORTATION DEMAND MANAGEMENT AT AIRPORTS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H154C2DBBBC6F43358C28A3EFCE33FF97"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall conduct a study to examine the efficacy of transportation demand management strategies at United States airports.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H2C9475160CD04EE88FD8AAD24AB209A2"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Considerations
                  In conducting the study under subsection (a), the Comptroller General shall examine, at a minimum—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8FB92EB9C8774CD5BD4CEF8FC56EAD0A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     whether transportation demand management strategies should be considered by airports when making infrastructure planning and construction decisions; 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HFBFBA4CBD1B74E79BA2E812BB0D82A2C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the impact of transportation demand management strategies on existing multimodal options to and from airports in the United States; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H24A6D9E60CC1447B8302291FDAD7697A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     best practices for developing transportation demand management strategies that can be used to improve access to airports for passengers and airport and airline personnel.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H379E74804C3A4512AE717F436FCBA79C"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Report
                  Upon completion of the study conducted under subsection (a), the Comptroller General shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on such study.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H095689CD82D0419C821B98703DAD745E"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Transportation demand management strategy defined
                  In this section, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">transportation demand management strategy means the use of planning, programs, policy, marketing, communications, incentives, pricing, data, and technology to optimize travel modes, routes used, departure times, and number of trips.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H6C314928B3F1466DAF4ACDA8B286065B"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               737.
               COASTAL AIRPORTS ASSESSMENT
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HA55D771FB66244C1BFAC439D08B9B79A"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator, in coordination with the Chief of Engineers and Commanding General of the United States Army Corps of Engineers, and the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, shall initiate an assessment on the resiliency of airports in coastal or flood-prone areas of the United States.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H1A48FF8752544885AAC4D7A6EB04A87E"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Contents
                  The assessment required under subsection (a) shall—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HED820A0CF4E44E96BC4205A3073F9420"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     examine the impact of hazardous weather and other environmental factors that pose risks to airports in coastal or flood-prone areas; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8E807868817C45FBAF1289EB6369AEC0"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     identify and evaluate initiatives and best practices to prevent and mitigate the impacts of factors described in paragraph (1) on airports in coastal or flood-prone areas.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H022E2DC14B724235A353B2590E83B0DA"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Report
                  Upon completion of the assessment, the Administrator shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress and the Committee on Science, Space, and Technology of the House of Representatives a report on—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8A7E8EB6E7B943CDB1617027D4C0AFC2"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     the results of the assessment required under subsection (a); and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H9EA16000698B429DA6EF44084E5A922D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     recommendations for legislative or administrative action to improve the resiliency of airports in coastal or flood-prone areas in the United States.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HBB6EF5A6AB22484EA091DC4F4FEC765E"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               738.
               AIRPORT INVESTMENT PARTNERSHIP PROGRAM
               Section 47134(b) of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:
               <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                              display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              display-quotes="yes"
                              id="H70E98337B93A4796B7D07D4B289E43DC"
                              style="OLC">
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HAB4AD78D665649ECB53774FBE9977229"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Benefit-cost analysis
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HFBB7918BF39E4D64AE16A7943A8C7B59"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        In general
                        Prior to approving an application submitted under subsection (a), the Secretary may require a benefit-cost analysis.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HCA22622BCA3D4066A75DFB0D07464B0B"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        Finding
                        If a benefit-cost analysis is required, the Secretary shall issue a preliminary and conditional finding, which shall—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H613D3AE6088D4BD88595BC89B3C564DA"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           be issued not later than 60 days after the date on which the sponsor submits all information required by the Secretary;
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H2953C4BC842E41859F94F5709318F188"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           be based upon a collaborative review process that includes the sponsor or a representative of the sponsor;
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H7ACC516F81D240A89D42980E61A9E874"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iii)
                           not constitute the issuance of a Federal grant or obligation to issue a grant under this chapter or other provision of law; and
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H77CB2906EE5847FB9627C49EB786BECE"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (iv)
                           not constitute any other obligation on the part of the Federal Government until the conditions specified in the final benefit-cost analysis are met.
                        
                     
                  
                  .
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H87EDFCA73EE7460B8048ACBA6A83CF31"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               739.
               SPECIAL RULE FOR RECLASSIFICATION OF CERTAIN UNCLASSIFIED AIRPORTS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H0E60455585064221A40C2C3583F88B11"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Request for reclassification
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1926CE42122A4E999D72CF2431FDD87A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Not later than September 30, 2024, a privately owned reliever airport (as such term is defined in section 47102 of title 49, United States Code) that is identified as unclassified in the National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems of the FAA titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems (NPIAS) 2023–2027, published on September 30, 2022 may submit to the Secretary a request to reclassify the airport according to the criteria used to classify a publicly owned airport.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HFF2DA5CE92114F4E930866E5E7772386"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Required information
                     In submitting a request under paragraph (1), a privately owned reliever airport shall include the following information:
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HD4564EF916F2407AB1F8C093437D8530"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        A sworn statement and accompanying documentation that demonstrates how the airport would satisfy the requirements of FAA Order 5090.5, titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">Formulation of the NPIAS and ACIP (or any successor guidance), to be classified as <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">Local or <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">Basic if the airport was publicly owned.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE0BA8D2224A9492A9947E5F9F3FC52F1"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        A report that—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H645720E8E8C14B4CBA70D72C42F19D9A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           identifies the role of the airport to the aviation system; and
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H02F2C3F78D4A41CDA58DD970322E0D7C"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           describes the long-term fiscal viability of the airport based on demonstrated aeronautical activity and associated revenues relative to ongoing operating and maintenance costs.
                        
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H845A082E3E364A9496803711C0B4C868"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Eligibility review
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA051F0BB46044483B7833C1D83D03895"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Not later than 60 days after receiving a request from a privately owned reliever airport under subsection (a), the Secretary shall perform an eligibility review with respect to the airport, including an assessment of the safety, security, capacity, access, compliance with Federal grant assurances, and protection of natural resources of the airport and the quality of the environment, as prescribed by the Secretary.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3779E7F4E4484D51900BD94D8304584C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Public sponsor
                     In performing the eligibility review under paragraph (1), the Secretary—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H036F9987CA9E4EEBB2A7BFA23191E20F"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        may require the airport requesting reclassification to provide information regarding the outlook (whether positive or negative) for obtaining a public sponsor; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HDC04DCCA0DF343B9BFB1703F0DAC2B8F"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        may not require the airport to obtain a public sponsor.
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H9323C83EB92A4D8981FF53CB4C39DA87"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Reclassification by Secretary
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HAB784F84BB754CDA90533668EEB93D57"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Not later than 60 days after receiving a request from a privately owned reliever airport under subsection (a)(1), the Secretary shall grant such request if the following criteria are met:
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H64D86F66C94F4BCB8FCBA3C88A55F5F8"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        The request includes the required information under subsection (a)(2).
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HD54BE8AA3E3A448986D2B2B018A6959F"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        The privately owned reliever airport, to the satisfaction of the Secretary—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H6A9DB2D110104B4A9AF2B3F68C4AB3DE"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           passes the eligibility review performed under subsection (b); or
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H4DB2ACD98D33417F815E79CC7561694F"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           submits a corrective action plan in accordance with paragraph (2).
                        
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF2A976C2DA7542DD876045A1FC41E90A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Corrective action plan
                     With respect to a privately owned reliever airport that does not, to the satisfaction of the Secretary, pass the eligibility review performed under subsection (b), the Secretary shall provide notice of disapproval to such airport not later than 60 days after receiving the request under subsection (a)(1), and such airport may resubmit to the Secretary a reclassification request along with a corrective action plan that—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HA08794EB7EE24E0F9673EAB724ED4F1E"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        resolves any shortcomings identified in such eligibility review; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HFF53D01C1E7F4FB0A53F81DFD052521E"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        proves that any necessary corrective action has been completed by the airport.
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HFACA0AEF721F4C868D094F9037FAC8E7"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Effective date
                  The reclassification of any privately owned reliever airport under this section shall take effect not later than—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H78B1F569696A490AA728D41AF38DAEC0"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     October 1, 2025, for any request granted under subsection (c)(1); and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H20B85CE48B3E4537926422B37BC97F20"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     October 1, 2026, for any request granted after the submission of a corrective action plan under subsection (c)(2).
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H57959291C17040D594B353DB2D476DD5"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               740.
               PERMANENT SOLAR POWERED TAXIWAY EDGE LIGHTING SYSTEMS
               Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall produce an engineering brief that describes the acceptable use of permanent solar powered taxiway edge lighting systems at regional, local, and basic general aviation airports (as categorized in the most recent National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems of the FAA titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems (NPIAS) 2023–2027, published on September 30, 2022).
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HC90F68D74A4541BBA5698EFA2E071A62"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               741.
               SECONDARY RUNWAYS
               In approving grants for projects with funds made available pursuant to title VIII of division J of the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (Public Law 117–58) under the heading <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">Federal Aviation Administration—Airport Infrastructure Grants, the Administrator shall consider permitting a nonhub or small hub airport to use such funds to extend secondary runways, notwithstanding the level of operational activity at such airport.
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HCBA80DBCDE9841ED8ABA4D5D4CA25403"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               742.
               INCREASING ENERGY EFFICIENCY OF AIRPORTS AND MEETING CURRENT AND FUTURE ENERGY POWER DEMANDS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H2BA61DF56368428185309E3F9050EF42"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Section 47140 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to read as follows: 
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="H755AC70CD7B34D8691E864187A3E8F24"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                               id="H1E1F40F83F66473BBE6891026ED49642"
                               qb-display-quote="yes"
                               section-type="subsequent-section">
                        47140.
                        MEETING CURRENT AND FUTURE ENERGY POWER DEMAND
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H847384CF371C4E228B5E27BC1CE070C5"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (a)
                           In general
                           The Secretary of Transportation shall establish a program under which the Secretary shall—
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H40AB016C1FB94B7891C8D9EF23EB75D6"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              encourage the sponsor of each public-use airport to—
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HD81580DEFE1D438E8D91F8DB7420AEEF"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 conduct airport planning that assesses the airport’s—
                                 <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H12F0F1EEAECD42FC865D006FDFD4908A"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (i)
                                    current and future energy power requirements, including—
                                    <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="H12894FD979794A39BA1E61CD31F4FE1F"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                       (I)
                                       heating and cooling;
                                    
                                    <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="H900B85E3D93E4648B01A7988043A6F4E"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                       (II)
                                       on-road airport vehicles and ground support equipment;
                                    
                                    <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="H6A903C711F014B0C88D02B937ECE57E9"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                       (III)
                                       gate electrification; 
                                    
                                    <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="HF8EAB80D81464C3B9D127D76FFB3367D"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                       (IV)
                                       electric aircraft charging; and
                                    
                                    <subclause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                                id="H874E981A302440F198D6676B7B6C4327"
                                                qb-display-quote="yes">
                                       (V)
                                       vehicles and equipment used to transport passengers and employees between the airport and—
                                       <item display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                              id="H829644029C614945BF56723C4B441603"
                                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                                          (aa)
                                          nearby facilities owned or controlled by the airport or which otherwise directly support the functions or services provided by the airport; or
                                       
                                       <item display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                              id="HF1531C73BF5E43D88C9B2CF53B4E39DF"
                                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                                          (bb)
                                          an intermodal surface transportation facility adjacent to the airport; and
                                       
                                    
                                 
                                 <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="HEEA5BDB6521D488192C253ABF0E2F22F"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                                    (ii)
                                    existing energy infrastructure condition, location, and capacity, including base load and backup power, to meet the current and future electrical power demand as identified in this subparagraph; and 
                                 
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HC69A8C06C9C04B2EBB2AC74C594FD071"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 conduct airport development to improve energy efficiency, increase peak load savings at the airport, and meet future electrical power demands as identified in subparagraph (A); and
                              
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H5D02444DE51E40CCB6BFAA9D0069BF08"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              reimburse the airport sponsor for the costs incurred in conducting the assessment under paragraph (1)(A).
                           
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H85FA3B880EB9424E9CE5871BC563C2DB"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (b)
                           Grants
                           The Secretary shall make grants to airport sponsors from amounts made available under section 48103 to assist such sponsors that have completed the assessment described in subsection (a)(1)—
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HB8A0F4EBC19D4936B8294EF43C6041AA"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              to acquire or construct equipment that will improve energy efficiency at the airport; and
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H6D621E6BC6E94DF5809BD5474D3B011D"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              to pursue an airport development project described in subsection (a)(1)(B).
                           
                        
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H8F15C8B35BFD41ECA4B3A8B7D36D6D76"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (c)
                           Application
                           To be eligible for a grant under paragraph (1), the sponsor of a public-use airport shall submit an application, including a certification that no safety projects are being deferred by requesting a grant under this section, to the Secretary at such time, in such manner, and containing such information as the Secretary may require.
                        
                     
                     .
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HF1110C4687944A8298579BE371A6C1AE"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">

                  Clerical amendment
                  The analysis for chapter 471 of title 49, United States Code, is amended by striking the item relating to section 47140 and inserting the following:

                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"

                        47140. Meeting current and future energy power demand. 
                     
                     .
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H5D0E7ADC13B040799D022B6A8E1E1B3B"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               743.
               REVIEW OF AIRPORT LAYOUT PLANS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H9E5705CB98F64D8EB8DCE6BC38E0CDF9"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Section 163 of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 (49 U.S.C. 47107 note) is amended—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H5281BCDBC1AE49E6A8AEC12FFACD4630"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     by striking subsection (a) and inserting the following:
                     <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                    display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    display-quotes="yes"
                                    id="H90840FBE04444E5484E148B7FD8F25AD"

                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"

                           (a)
                           [Reserved].

                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3AF166800E734B2AB281F9CD9165EA75"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     by striking subsection (b) and inserting the following:
                     <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                    display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    display-quotes="yes"
                                    id="HDA83D2C371EE489297902CCDD5632877"
                                    style="OLC">
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H1579E02CAFD946F595EDA3421DF0974E"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (b)
                           [Reserved].
                        
                        .
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H7287B9840AFF48D1B0B35BBDA64A5A17"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Airport layout plan approval authority
                  Section 47107 of title 49, United States Code, is amended—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB0EF0DF425C6449589FF779208AD523F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     in subsection (a)(16)—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HBCA029FA8820463597868D46AEEF78A3"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        by striking subparagraph (B) and inserting the following:
                        <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                       display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       display-quotes="yes"
                                       id="H4398CAE2DD9642B0B4F7108891410EA0"
                                       style="OLC">
                           <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                          id="H04A30F18F68E44FF886333EE31B91B22"
                                          qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (B)
                              subject to subsection (x), the Secretary will review and approve or disapprove the plan and any revision or modification of the plan before the plan, revision, or modification takes effect;
                           
                           ; and
                        
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HC4C58408532C407698043A4B3CF4C19F"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        in subparagraph (C)(i) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">subparagraph (B) and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                   quote-display-start="auto"
                                   quote-type="text">subsection (x); and
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD287C57AE63441F2B5353D7DBCB4B400"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     by adding at the end the following:
                     <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                    display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    display-quotes="yes"
                                    id="H682756123EE54B84869FD818FD41D20F"
                                    style="OLC">
                        <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                     id="H1B457AF0BD7F48FA982CFE2F3EF4543B"
                                     qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (x)
                           Scope of airport layout plan review and approval authority of Secretary
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HBA218DC651D6486797C406AE92A95C6F"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (1)
                              Authority over projects on land acquired without Federal assistance
                              For purposes of subsection (a)(16)(B), with respect to any project proposed on land acquired by an airport owner or operator without Federal assistance, the Secretary may review and approve or disapprove only the portions of the plan (or any subsequent revision to the plan) that—
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H301A15F109034031BF088F3F023BDFA8"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 materially impact the safe and efficient operation of aircraft at, to, or from the airport;
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H832E72A1159F411C99E783A163C056F3"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 adversely affect the safety of people or property on the ground as a result of aircraft operations; or
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H2834380356674A12B05704138007130C"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (C)
                                 adversely affect the value of prior Federal investments to a significant extent.
                              
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HFFEC9A4715EB48BAB0BCD4AE73D64AA2"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (2)
                              Limitation on non-aeronautical review
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="HA1DE2AE3674E4713941990138472AB21"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 In general
                                 The Secretary may not require an airport to seek approval for (including in the submission of an airport layout plan), or directly or indirectly regulate or place conditions on (including through any grant assurance), any project that is not subject to paragraph (1).
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H83B25F49FDFC48249A78C908812577F8"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 Review and approval authority
                                 If only a portion of a project proposed by an airport owner or operator is subject to the review and approval of the Secretary under subsection (a)(16)(B), the Secretary shall not extend review and approval authority to other non-aeronautical portions of the project.
                              
                           
                           <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HAF796EAD7E314EE58F8D9F26AED10747"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (3)
                              Notice
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H9F6F8FB66AFA4887ACD4408C756D0CF5"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (A)
                                 In general
                                 An airport owner or operator shall submit to the Secretary a notice of intent to proceed with a proposed project (or a portion thereof) that is outside of the review and approval authority of the Secretary, as described in this subsection, if the project was not on the most recently submitted airport layout plan of the airport.
                              
                              <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                             id="H5ED314C623C147DFBC4838F78BADFCA3"
                                             qb-display-quote="yes">
                                 (B)
                                 Failure to object
                                 If not later than 45 days after receiving the notice of intent described in subparagraph (A), the Secretary fails to object to such notice, the proposed project (or portion thereof) shall be deemed as being outside the scope of the review and approval authority of the Secretary under subsection (a)(16)(B).
                              
                           
                        
                        .
                     
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H4F760594DA644056B4B0CEE80ABEBDA2"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               744.
               PROTECTION OF SAFE AND EFFICIENT USE OF AIRSPACE AT AIRPORTS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H99ADA409CD114282A396B67913CE9BDC"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Airspace review process requirements
