                  The Administrator shall consider the following additional factors in the evaluation of cumulative impacts when making a determination of hazard or no hazard, or objection or no objection, as applicable, under part 77 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, regarding proposed construction or alteration within 3 miles of the runway ends and runway centerlines (as depicted in the FAA-approved Airport Layout Plan of the airport) on any land not owned by any such airport:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H2082464265134DE2993098BC30C073B5"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     The accumulation and spacing of structures or other obstructions that might constrain radar or communication capabilities, thereby reducing the capacity of an airport, flight procedure minimums or availability, or aircraft takeoff or landing capabilities. 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H77CAFAEA850E486CA7CA574068F1C428"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Safety risks of lasers, lights, or light sources, inclusive of lighted billboards and screens, affixed to structures, that may pose hazards to air navigation. 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0A10450622EF42F09B2553E365BBC0B6"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Water features or hazardous wildlife attractants, as defined by the Administrator. 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB9F1A5FCB79B4A9098DF92BF81971613"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Impacts to visual flight rule traffic patterns for both fixed and rotary wing aircraft, inclusive of special visual flight rule procedures established by Letters of Agreement between air traffic facilities, the airport, and flight operators. 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H636F6D7D09864BC8A54D60837FC479F3"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     Impacts to FAA-funded airport improvement projects, improvements depicted on or described in FAA-approved Airport Layout Plans and master plans, and preservation of the navigable airspace necessary for achieving the objectives and utilization of the projects and plans. 
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HF2B4F53FAD104AC8A7BB8B1FA1CA2243"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Required information
                  A notice submitted under part 77 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, shall include the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA14EF058DD254F679A8204D48EED8CFB"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Actual designs of an entire project and property, without regard to whether a proposed construction or alteration within 3 miles of the end of a runway of an airport and runway centerlines as depicted in the FAA-approved Airport Layout Plan of the airport is limited to a singular location on a property.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HBC6FCF2ABFEF43DE842643C57B7F41A8"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     If there are any changes to such designs or addition of equipment, such as cranes used to construct a building, after submission of such a notice, all information included with the notice submitted before such change or addition shall be resubmitted, along with information regarding the change or addition. 
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HECFE30FD34B8402292B2666C61EA8E97"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Expiration
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H162C8AD67B03417F929CD72ECB51A3C0"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Unless extended, revised, or terminated, each determination of no hazard issued by the Administrator under part 77 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, shall expire 18 months after the effective date of the determination, or on the date the proposed construction or alteration is abandoned, whichever is earlier.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H67C78D66260D411189FDA3650D5F0CFD"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     After expiration
                     Determinations under paragraph (1) are no longer valid with regard to whether a proposed construction or alteration would be a hazard to air navigation after such determination has expired.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H98FBC7A16D964E268BD1132D6EFD3200"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Authority to consolidate OEI surface criteria
                  The Administrator may develop a single set of One Engine Inoperative surface criteria that is specific to an airport. The Administrator shall consult with the airport operator and flight operators that use such airport, on the development of such surface criteria.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H9F2F16858E134F35ABE904437CAC8F95"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Development of policies to protect OEI surfaces
                  Not later than 6 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress regarding the status of the efforts of the FAA to protect One Engine Inoperative surfaces from encroachment at United States certificated and federally obligated airports, including the current status of efforts to incorporate such protections into FAA Obstruction Evaluation/Airport Airspace Analysis processes. 
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H6E72C9E29F6D4A0392DDD3B03616712C"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (f)
                  Authority to consult with other agencies
                  The Administrator may consult with other Federal, State, or local agencies as necessary to carry out the requirements of this section.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H15499E139D494375B0B9C6996FF01C34"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (g)
                  Applicability
                  This section shall only apply to an airport in a county adjacent to 2 States with converging intersecting cross runway operations within 12 nautical miles of an Air Force base.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H8C2765E119CD46DEAD445FD93B234087"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               745.
               ELECTRIC AIRCRAFT INFRASTRUCTURE PILOT PROGRAM
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H68D028EB59D04161B680F09B33FCF907"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  The Secretary may establish a pilot program under which airport sponsors may use funds made available under chapter 471 or section 48103 of title 49, United States Code, for use at up to 10 airports to carry out—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H329091B12D0A45A6AE6156C307E6585A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     activities associated with the acquisition, by purchase or lease, operation, and installation of equipment to support the operations of electric aircraft, including interoperable electric vehicle charging equipment; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF99F46DEF11C4B988774E492252D2AE9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the construction or modification of infrastructure to facilitate the delivery of power or services necessary for the use of electric aircraft, including—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HAF19735D94694CAF8FA6C2DC2C3881D9"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        on airport utility upgrades; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H7AC85DEC3524410FBF8B22FDD93ADAC7"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        associated design costs.
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HE5C0DFE8FB6E4A02855F7B32713E529F"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Eligibility
                  A public-use airport is eligible for participation in the pilot program under this section if the Secretary finds that funds made available under subsection (a) would support—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC79B74F2EA304D13A86CBD673891E91C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     electric aircraft operators at such airport, or using such airport; or
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H5C36DEDD51A94D8EA936AE248220784B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     electric aircraft operators planning to operate at such airport with an associated agreement in place.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HFC03A10A44DC4605AB3C3C915374505E"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Sunset
                  The pilot program established under subsection (a) shall terminate on October 1, 2028.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H80CEE71D6CB14642A582EBBF75FF98BB"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               746.
               CURB MANAGEMENT PRACTICES
               Nothing in this Act shall be construed to prevent airports from—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H99C2740140254402A72211833E13F75F"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  engaging in curb management practices, including determining and assigning curb designations and regulations;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H8C36652C09CD4DCB8BEE727BE55AAB06"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  installing and maintaining upon any of the roadways or parts of roadways as many curb zones as necessary to aid in the regulation, control, and inspection of passenger loading and unloading; or
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H6EA398BFEE9C4C9D8C0E9A1C73394C6A"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  enforcing curb zones using sensor, camera, automated license plate recognition, and software technologies and issuing citations by mail to the registered owner of the vehicle.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HBCA1AA8CAD854718810CEEC16F4366BA"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               747.
               NOTICE OF FUNDING OPPORTUNITY
               Notwithstanding part 200 of title 2, Code of Federal Regulations, or any other provision of law, funds made available as part of the Airport Improvement Program under subchapter I of chapter 471 or chapter 475 of title 49, United States Code, shall not be subject to any public notice of funding opportunity requirement.
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HFAD99F4F872B43AC9EF69E2FD3F71D27"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               748.
               RUNWAY SAFETY PROJECTS
               In awarding grants under section 47115 of title 49, United States Code, for runway safety projects, the Administrator shall, to the maximum extent practicable—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HCB16E11A2F784DF5A088A997A30C2FEB"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  reduce unnecessary or undesirable project segmentation; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H456A6F30D42246E882606123B588AC4F"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  complete the entire project in an expeditious manner.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HA562A3BA4D4542B8AE73A0C83B390392"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               749.
               AIRPORT DIAGRAM TERMINOLOGY
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HDC474DF7C2534D01BB5F05A5880B62F4"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  The Administrator shall update Airport Diagram Order JO 7910.4 and any related advisory circulars, policy, and guidance to ensure the clear and consistent use of terms to delineate the types of parking available to general aviation pilots.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H3DC44AE86D8444F480DE113F8F45DDBF"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Collaboration
                  In carrying out subsection (a), the Administrator shall collaborate with industry stakeholders, commercial service airports, and general aviation airports in—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H7AA2A977D9064EB98C2345DE2CCDC548"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     facilitating basic standardization of general aviation parking terms;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H6FD58885CDB84562AE275A6C61E43F5F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     accounting for the majority of uses of general aviation parking terms; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H349AAAC407C54BBCADB48EA18B9D9424"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     providing clarity for chart users.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H2F8D0045637E445EB1D0D6A5F96622B6"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  IAC specifications
                  The Administrator shall encourage the Interagency Air Committee to incorporate the terms developed pursuant to subsection (a) in publications produced by the Committee.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HB5E4BCEE30094C0CB164903BB1896B68"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               750.
               GAO STUDY ON FEE TRANSPARENCY BY FIXED BASED OPERATORS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HFBCBDD1A2B574AAEAC4FA3AF9F0F7DB8"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  The Comptroller General shall conduct a study reviewing the efforts of fixed based operators to meet their commitments to improve the online transparency of prices and fees for all aircraft and enhancing the customer experience for general and business aviation users.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H8928206AA729413490049ADBCD6A7F47"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Contents
                  In conducting the study described in subsection (a), the Comptroller General, at a minimum, should evaluate the fixed based operator industry commitment to <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Know Before You Go best business practices including—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3532D678DCDD4136AEB2286C459E79FE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     fixed based operators provisions for all general aviation and business aircraft types regarding a description of available services and a listing of applicable retail fuel prices, fees, and charges;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HBDB625D3BDD44C53A2CE0BA464E6B042"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the accessibility of fees and charges described in paragraph (1) to aircraft operators on-line and in a user-friendly manner and with sufficient clarity that a pilot operating a particular aircraft type can determine what will be charged;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD195E2F26FC44EED91FAB8BD393F2469"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     efforts by fixed based operators to invite and encourage customers to contact them so that operators can ask questions, know any options, and make informed decisions; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H117D38E03A6445369FE7A864BFD74EBC"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     any practices imposed by an airport operator that prevent fixed based operators from fully disclosing fees and charges. 
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HC155DA5A5159498EBA794CF06ACF36C7"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Report required
                  Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report containing the results of the review required under this section. 
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H8FC0D43B95FB4457AC23F681D2C529C0"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               751.
               MINORITY AND DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS PARTICIPATION
               Section 157(b)(2) of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 (49 U.S.C. 47113 note) is amended by adding at the end the following: 
               <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                              display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              display-quotes="yes"
                              id="HE0D5FFE5A767476C9FE1E594CCCB205E"
                              style="OLC">
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H000C400502EC467BBEE7CE150669BDC1"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (D)
                     Publishing data
                     The Secretary of Transportation shall report on a publicly accessible website the uniform report of DBE awards/commitments and payments specified in part 26 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations, and the uniform report of ACDBE Participation for non-car rental and car rental concessions, for each airport sponsor beginning with fiscal year 2025. 
                  
                  .
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H1F5214E3209A4749AC75A37342D64D9D"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               752.
               PROHIBITION ON CERTAIN RUNWAY LENGTH REQUIREMENTS
               Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Secretary may not require an airport to shorten the length or width of the runway, apron, or taxiway of the airport as a condition for the receipt of federal financial assistance if the airport directly supports a base of the United States Air Force or the Air National Guard at the airport, regardless of the stationing of military aircraft.
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H93BC86F564F1450D8099B1ED6420860D"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               753.
               REPORT ON INDO-PACIFIC AIRPORTS
               The Administrator, in consultation with the Secretary of State, shall submit to Congress a report on airports of strategic importance in the Indo-Pacific region that includes each of the following:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H14830C3169044C618A14A8CA1C7AE91F"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  An identification of airports and air routes critical to national security, defense operations, emergency response, and continuity of government activities.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HBECEED3CB3CF4DB8A846A5AD5D36873C"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  An assessment of the economic impact and contribution of airports and air routes to national and regional economies.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HACE6D63FED394D4EAD97B1547CAD88C8"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  An evaluation of the connectivity and accessibility of airports and air routes, including their importance in supporting domestic and international travel, trade, and tourism.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H26E2A32526504CD1A18BA5130ECEADD7"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  An analysis of infrastructure and technological requirements necessary to maintain and enhance the strategic importance of identified airports and air routes.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H04121321507F4C53B5184660A995A5BA"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (5)
                  An identification of potential vulnerabilities, risks, and challenges faced by airports and air routes of strategic importance, including cybersecurity threats and physical infrastructure vulnerabilities.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H8583A1DDEC2F4591AD4F393D4A265FE9"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (6)
                  Any recommendations for improving the security, resilience, and efficiency of the identified airports and air routes, including potential infrastructure investments and policy changes.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H0ACAA1BE88574BCBACE835BCE57A33EC"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               754.
               GAO STUDY ON IMPLEMENTATION OF GRANTS AT CERTAIN AIRPORTS
               The Comptroller General shall conduct a study on the implementation of grants provided to airports located in the Republic of the Marshall Islands, Federated States of Micronesia, and Republic of Palau under section 47115(i) of title 49, United States Code and submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the results of such study.
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H3AD1E8AD65174BE4A93FF8E96045EBFD"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               755.
               GAO STUDY ON TRANSIT ACCESS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H6C38AF342DE74C63B971B49B36508057"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall conduct a study on transit access to airports and submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the results of such study.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H4F8B32D72F904846BC5F4907717BC9C1"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Contents
                  In carrying out the study under subsection (a), the Comptroller General shall review public transportation access to commercial service airports throughout the United States, including accessibility and other potential barriers for individuals. 
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H1466B7A54DAA4689B7E859793EC65892"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               756.
               BANNING MUNICIPAL AIRPORT
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H60880FF36BA84F31BBAF51516652FFAF"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  The United States, acting through the Administrator, shall release the City of Banning, California, from all restrictions, conditions, and limitations on the use, encumbrance, conveyance, and closure of the Banning Municipal Airport, as described in the most recent airport layout plan approved by the FAA, to the extent such restrictions, conditions, and limitations are enforceable by the Administrator. 
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H8AC41A598C3344EBA5A44B7B9D3C6CD6"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Conditions
                  The release under subsection (a) shall not be executed before the City of Banning, California, or its designee, transfers to the United States Government the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8F25927742B946029E11571B3C5A2F40"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     A reimbursement for 1983 grant the City of Banning, California received from the FAA for the purchase of 20 acres of land, at an amount equal to the fair market value for the highest and best use of the Banning Municipal Airport property determined in good faith by 2 independent and qualified real estate appraisers and an independent review appraiser on or after the date of the enactment of this Act.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H326BF5DE098248CBBF56485A4D8CEB04"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     An amount equal to the unamortized portion of any Federal development grants other than land paid to the City of Banning for use at the Banning Municipal Airport, which may be paid with, and shall be an allowable use of, airport revenue notwithstanding section 47107 or 47133 of title 49, United States Code.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H333F61DD5F28434B8741E71711248405"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     For no consideration, all airport and aviation-related equipment of the Banning Municipal Airport owned by the City of Banning and determined by the FAA or the Department of Transportation of the State of California to be salvageable for use at other airports. 
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H1C0789A54A5845D391C9AB2B7584BBC1"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Rule of construction
                  Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the applicability of—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC2DE04E790534C82ABDC67189B9228DF"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     the requirements and processes under section 46319 of title 49, United States Code;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA6F035AD59C543148DF3CF0012817773"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the requirements under the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (42 U.S.C. 4321 et seq.);
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB01FCA91F69842AE92639C72737A7CB2"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     the requirements and processes under part 157 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations; or
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H6A5CCB6FF0354514B4CF2A04BBC77C34"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     the public notice requirements under section 47107(h)(2) of title 49, United States Code. 
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H0ECEAE8764994C8CBD391B80C6F504EB"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               757.
               DISPUTED CHANGES OF SPONSORSHIP AT FEDERALLY OBLIGATED, PUBLICLY OWNED AIRPORT
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HFC978724F87745C89EDD193E32D301F5"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Approval authority
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HBED9B31BC11047E08A9CEE92AAC69D50"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Subject to paragraph (2), in the case of a disputed change of airport sponsorship, the Administrator shall have the sole legal authority to approve any change in the sponsorship of, or operational responsibility for, the airport from the airport sponsor of record to another public or private entity.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA2E554CE0E8A4E0DB98639DFA27A0179"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Exclusion
                     This section shall not apply to a change of sponsorship or ownership of a privately-owned airport, a transfer under the Airport Investment Partnership Program, a change when the Federal Government exercises a right of reverter, or a change that is not disputed.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H2F672FA1C8574E029E072CDADDC904CD"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Conditions for approval
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0D23653AC9CB4F9D99465B5C084C6F17"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Subject to paragraphs (2) and (3), the Administrator shall not approve any disputed change of airport sponsorship unless the Administrator receives—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H888A731B55D744EBB9B2D7193001B829"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        written documentation from the airport sponsor of record consenting to the change in sponsorship or operation;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HF87F90CA916E4AE98AF8D9607C0A6E37"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        notice of a final, non-reviewable judicial decision requiring such change; or
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H03CB6CF7CFAE4B8D866797D816F1AC3B"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        notice of a legally-binding agreement between the parties involved. 
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8CACACF7490F444DAD6887AFD5170B01"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Pending judicial review
                     The Administrator may not evaluate or approve a disputed change of airport sponsorship where a legal dispute is pending before a court of competent jurisdiction.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4D9A87F873AB47BAB00164573830F7CF"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Technical assistance
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H6AB8277148324D5EAF47B135F94287B2"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        In general
                        Any State or local legislative body or public agency considering whether to take an action (including by drafting legislation) that would impact the ownership, sponsorship, governance, or operations of a federally obligated, publicly owned airport may request from the Administrator, at any point in the deliberative process—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H41260FF5274B4E42813291846E650F3F"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           technical assistance regarding the interrelationship between Federal and State or local requirements applicable to any such action; and
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HBDA6641690F248599426C12823C38CB6"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           review and comment on such action.
                        
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H66DEE7FE59854AE085212277935F9B5D"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        Failure to seek technical assistance
                        The Administrator may deny a change in the ownership, sponsorship, or governance of, or operational responsibility for, a federally obligated, publicly owned airport if a State or local legislative body or public agency does not seek technical assistance under subparagraph (A) with respect to such change.
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HA818D9281E2C48F3A6E6F4E679055881"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Final decision authority
                  In addition to the conditions outlined in subsection (b), the Administrator shall independently determine whether the proposed sponsor or operator is able to satisfy Federal requirements for airport sponsorship or operation and shall ensure, by requiring whatever terms and conditions the Administrator determines necessary, that any change in the ownership, sponsorship, or governance of, or operational responsibility for, a federally obligated, publicly owned airport is consistent with existing Federal law, regulations, existing grant assurances, and Federal land conveyance obligations.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H2A2261A1DE8443568CCE827C64387353"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Definition of disputed change of airport sponsorship
                  In this section, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">disputed change of airport sponsorship means any action that seeks to change the ownership, sponsorship, or governance of, or operational responsibility for, a federally obligated, publicly owned airport, including any such change directed by judicial action or State or local legislative action, where the airport sponsor of record initially does not consent to such change.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H5D29305A0CA941409665864F06EFF564"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               758.
               PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS APPLICABLE TO FAA MULTIMODAL PROJECTS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H99EF3CFDE5624B349EE7FA7871044EB3"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Any multimodal airport development project that uses grant funding from funds made available to the Administrator to carry out subchapter I of chapter 471 of title 49, United States Code, or airport infrastructure projects under the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (Public Law 117–58) shall abide by the procurement regulations applicable to— 
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA13F3A2E33CF42CDACB6CBB3A9BD66A6"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     the FAA; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0FA5040D6428490ABBF2FE103B624BF8"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     subject to subsection (b), the component of the project relating to transit, highway, or rail, respectively.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H77CED934B9BD4D9B8253A01BB329D7DB"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Multiple component projects
                  In the case of a multimodal airport development project described in subsection (a) that involves more than 1 component described in paragraph (2) of such subsection, such project shall only be required to apply the procurement regulations applicable to the component where the greatest amount of Federal financial assistance will be expended. 
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H192A68C0F1EA4FF1B5685825DCAC5D3B"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               759.
               BUCKEYE 940 RELEASE OF DEED RESTRICTIONS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H6C29DD1A9C4342AEA05E9689B228AC81"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Purpose
                  The purpose of this section is to authorize the Secretary to issue a Deed of Release from all terms, conditions, reservations, restrictions, and obligations contained in the Quitclaim Deed and to permit the State of Arizona to deposit all proceeds of the disposition of Buckeye 940 in the appropriate fund for the benefit of the beneficiaries of the Arizona State Land Trust. 
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HD3E5D57DDD674B20B00961BC5C516182"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Release of any and all interest in Buckeye 940
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HCE211D026CEA434B8B1D55812E9D471F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the United States, acting through the Secretary, shall issue to the State of Arizona a Deed of Release to release all terms, conditions, reservations, restrictions, and obligations contained in the Quitclaim Deed, including any and all reversionary interest of the United States in Buckeye 940.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H52B8EF57BCB346B9883B5709CAF7C329"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Terms and conditions
                     The Deed of Release described in paragraph (1) shall be subject to such additional terms and conditions, consistent with such paragraph, as the Secretary considers appropriate to protect the interests of the United States.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H25C2D5EE13CF4992B37ADB6673FEF614"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     No restriction on use of proceeds
                     Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the State of Arizona may dispose of Buckeye 940 and any proceeds thereof, including proceeds already collected by the State and held in a suspense account, without regard to any restriction imposed by the Quitclaim Deed or by section 155.7 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H90624AAC599D4187A0C714EF65767401"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Mineral reservation
                     The Deed of Release described in paragraph (1) shall include the release of all interests of the United States to the mineral rights on Buckeye 940 included in the Quitclaim Deed. 
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HDB3F93D371624FDB865E4BE38E302C3E"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Definitions
                  In this section:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H32CDF6E87845419ABD2D028814D5CB53"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Buckeye 940
                     The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">Buckeye 940 means all of section 12, T.1 N., R.3 W. and all of adjoining fractional section 7, T.1 N., R.2 W., Gila and Salt River Meridian, Arizona, which property was the subject of the Quitclaim Deed between the United States and the State of Arizona, dated July 11, 1949, and which is currently owned by the State of Arizona and held in trust for the beneficiaries of the Arizona State Land Trust.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HCCA2B3DDE15A4016848B77043A7B94A9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Quitclaim Deed
                     The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">Quitclaim Deed means the Quitclaim Deed between the United States and the State of Arizona, dated July 11, 1949.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H4A23C23FEF4B486EA5A5324D8CA5DF4D"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               760.
               WASHINGTON, DC METROPOLITAN AREA SPECIAL FLIGHT RULES AREA
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HBEAB8B7520B149ACA13D8D4CE8463FB8"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Submission of study to Congress
                  Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security and the Secretary of Defense, shall submit to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation and the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs of the Senate and the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure and the Committee on Homeland Security of the House of Representatives a study on the Special Flight Rules Area and the Flight Restricted Zone under subpart V of part 93 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H15679FFC311D42F38CA2089361993346"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Contents of study
                  In carrying out the study under subsection (a), the Administrator shall assess specific proposed changes to the Special Flight Rules Area and the Flight Restricted Zone that will decrease operational impacts and improve general aviation access to airports in the National Capital Region that are currently impacted by the Special Flight Rules Area and the Flight Restricted Zone.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HDE9E84CBA9524087BEBE9E6E86A9144D"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Briefing
                  Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall provide to the committees of Congress described in subsection (a) a briefing on the feasibility (including any associated costs) of—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE3B9F6C897524DD794333C4B2A5E3830"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     installing equipment that allows a pilot to communicate with air traffic control using a very high frequency radio for the purposes of receiving an instrument flight rules clearance, activating a DC FRZ flight plan, or activating a DC SFRA flight plan (as applicable) at—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HBAB2FE37D833470EB505E00128D4C15C"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        non-towered airports in the Flight Restricted Zone; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HEA38F4F4F39140E489E2DE676890129C"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        airports in the Special Flight Rules Area that do not have the communications equipment described in this paragraph;
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H09C1A3C4A25B4770B95495B3646C90AA"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     allowing a pilot approved by the Transportation Security Administration in accordance with section 1562.3 of title 49, Code of Federal Regulations, to electronically file a DC FRZ flight plan or instrument flight rules flight plan that departs from, or arrives at, an airport in the Flight Restricted Zone; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB16DAA3766D740619CF7AC91F792971C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     allowing a pilot to electronically file a standard very high frequency radio flight plan that departs from, or arrives at, an airport in the Special Flight Rules Area or Flight Restricted Zone.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HBD99FF2E92A44F27A3EB9A13B2AFE2D9"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Definitions
                  In this section:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD800AD7A90144BD380B6E7FFC560DA91"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     DC FRZ flight plan; DC SFRA flight plan
                     The terms <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">DC FRZ flight plan and <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">DC SFRA flight plan have the meanings given such terms in section 93.335 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4356B5741821488C90ACD53908D28EBE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Standard VFR flight plan
                     The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">standard VFR flight plan means a VFR flight plan (as such term is described in section 91.153 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations) that includes search and rescue services. 
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H023832C8F2434C949AF11D4BB26B1B71"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               761.
               STUDY ON AIR CARGO OPERATIONS IN PUERTO RICO
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HD62946E37E6B4ED49492A6F03694AABC"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  No later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall conduct a study on air cargo operations in Puerto Rico.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H8A88402B58044CBFBDB434ECE86EAE09"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Contents
                  In conducting the study required under subsection (a), the Comptroller General shall address the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD3DB20736D6F4CC795C039EE41C3ACBB"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     The economic impact of waivers authorized by the Secretary related to air cargo operations in Puerto Rico.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H20C166E5CD8F49BCB8AA5A9855D1D271"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Recommendations for security measures that may be necessary to support increased air cargo operations in Puerto Rico.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H88C8C1D0BA1B43ACBDF9F0D82C39926B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Potential need for additional staff to safely accommodate additional air cargo operations. 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF72F3B2337EE4F5CB17680CD5CD49939"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Airport infrastructure improvements that may be needed in the 3 international airports located in Puerto Rico to support increased air cargo operations.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H55A79996DB2B4060B407ADE2EA2F85C2"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     Alternatives to increase private stakeholder engagement and use of the 3 international airports in Puerto Rico to attract increased air cargo operations.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8145EFB6CE564E47A9E152ED0A9C10EC"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     Possible national benefits of increasing air cargo operations in Puerto Rico.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HEBA3B9A52E9D4BCEB652CC07F75FE82D"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Report
                  Not later than 12 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the results of the study described in subsection (a).
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HF5131224DFCD4B6A848402B8F0C54110"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               762.
               PROGRESS REPORTS ON THE NATIONAL TRANSITION PLAN RELATED TO A FLUORINE-FREE FIREFIGHTING FOAM
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H81F7F4CC2F274172942DE2B27E2E1F4E"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, and every 180 days thereafter until the progress report termination date described in subsection (c), the Administrator, in consultation with the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency and the Secretary of Defense, shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a progress report on the development and implementation of a national transition plan related to a fluorine-free firefighting foam that meets the performance standards referenced in chapter 6 of the advisory circular of the FAA titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Aircraft Fire Extinguishing Agents, issued on July 8, 2004 (Advisory Circular 150/5210–6D) and is acceptable under section 139.319(l) of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, for use at part 139 airports. 
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H4FB0A47BAC3C429A966E46B6665ECBBF"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Required information
                  Each progress report under subsection (a) shall include the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H516BB988554947BC86D0AA922F131959"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     An assessment of the progress made by the FAA with respect to providing part 139 airports with—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H50468094AB75486C9F1C9FF138F0E81E"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        guidance from the Environmental Protection Agency on acceptable environmental limits relating to fluorine-free firefighting foam;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H77C065AA6C4B443A9C9E3B8C75112290"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        guidance from the Department of Defense on the transition of the Department of Defense to a fluorine-free firefighting foam; 
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HD2B5E5C078234B5B843B96103652AAB0"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        best practices for the decontamination of existing aircraft rescue and firefighting vehicles, systems, and other equipment used to deploy firefighting foam at part 139 airports; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HF28A10DE87204D828AAA8F09988ADF91"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        timelines for the release of policy and guidance relating to the development of implementation plans for part 139 airports to obtain approved military specification products and firefighting personnel training.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H28E5A8DBE7F44444804E0CF01AE76D46"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     A comprehensive list of the amount of aqueous film-forming firefighting foam at each part 139 airport as of the date of the submission of the progress report, including the amount of such firefighting foam held in firefighting equipment and the number of gallons regularly kept in reserve at each such airport. 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC16898D8FB8F4F3896EBD64C796CC655"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     An assessment of the progress made by the FAA with respect to providing airports that are not part 139 airports and local authorities with responsibility for inspection and oversight with guidance described in subparagraphs (A) and (B) of paragraph (1) as such guidance relates to the use of fluorine-free firefighting foam at such airports.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H02CE6F2E16184739AE3EDEC76ADCB5A1"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Any other information that the Administrator determines is appropriate.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H5CE25E91EAC64BE29A810FCDC3E892E9"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Progress report termination date
                  The progress report termination date described in this subsection is the date on which the Administrator notifies the appropriate committees of Congress that development and implementation of the national transition plan described in subsection (a) is complete.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H3BB10FA7156B48409005D0ACD860C236"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Part 139 airport defined
                  In this section, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">part 139 airport means an airport certified under part 139 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations. 
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HF768629AC2E141A19079966510BD4BA7"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               763.
               REPORT ON AIRPORT NOTIFICATIONS
               Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the activities of the FAA with respect to—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H7FAF7A6C11944529B448C597502466AA"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  collecting more accurate data in notices of construction, alteration, activation, and deactivation of airports as required under part 157 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H014B315F0CE14FFCA669DD30B1CFE3F3"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  making the database under part 157 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, more accurate and useful for aircraft operators, particularly for helicopter and rotary wing type aircraft operators. 
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HBE0CF726FF9A4519BF43388C37A6631B"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               764.
               STUDY ON COMPETITION AND AIRPORT ACCESS
               Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HD3F77F21D5A14B9EBFEAB2F126187857"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  specific actions the Secretary and the Administrator, using existing legal authority, can take to expand access for lower cost passenger air carriers to capacity constrained airports in the United States, including New York John F. Kennedy International Airport, LaGuardia Airport, and Newark Liberty International Airport; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HC25905459A2648BB9C6117FC7E729CDA"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  any additional legal authority the Secretary and the Administrator require in order to make additional slots at New York John F. Kennedy International Airport and LaGuardia Airport and runway timings at Newark Liberty International Airport available to lower cost passenger air carriers. 
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HF4DB6155113D4C65823F7CA16D87432C"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               765.
               REGIONAL AIRPORT CAPACITY STUDY
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H1E02C81B3BC0474C9B618531C4690CCA"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall initiate a study on the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H7E11CD4D16BC4950942A6BD3D9E5BCD0"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Existing FAA policy and guidance that govern the siting of new airports or the transition of general aviation airports to commercial service.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H856E82C9739E459EBF55F393007D1F63"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Ways that existing regulations and policies could be streamlined to facilitate the development of new airport capacity, particularly in high-demand air travel regions looking to invest in new airport capacity.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H54ED6694885D4ECAB3D145D2465CD35D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Whether Federal funding sources (existing as of the date of enactment of this Act) that are authorized by the Secretary could be used for such purposes.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF0EEBAD9F30446D28258C971E717A189"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Whether such Federal funding sources meet the needs of the national airspace system for adding new airport capacity outside of the commercial service airports in operation as of the date of enactment of this Act.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H012A8F605E0D47E3AE17EEFC6BAB9D01"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     If such Federal funding sources are determined by the Administrator to be insufficient for the purposes described in this subsection, an estimate of the funding gap.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H349E31EFAE144B1999FD2067E5395457"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Report
                  Not later than 30 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the results of the study conducted under subsection (a), together with recommendations for such legislative or administrative action as the Administrator determines appropriate.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HB1327FCA90EC4EE3BF3D8DF631B80D8F"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Guidance
                  Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall, if appropriate, revise FAA guidance to incorporate the findings of the study conducted under subsection (a) to assist airports and State and local departments of transportation in increasing airport capacity to meet regional air travel demand. 
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HB941ADA5A0DB42F8830C75A94B9F27A9"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               766.
               STUDY ON AUTONOMOUS AND ELECTRIC-POWERED TRACK SYSTEMS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H1381BD95381A405B9965F3AC850DE90B"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Study
                  The Administrator may conduct a study to determine the feasibility and economic viability of autonomous or electric-powered track systems that—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H5BB62B1DDEA9455DAAE23509078D45BD"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     are located underneath the pavement at an airport; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H6C1319473EBC44B0845BB545AF49B4C3"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     allow a transport category aircraft to taxi without the use of the main engines of the aircraft.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H0D07EC0186214BA284630E4972BE6972"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Briefing
                  If the Administrator conducts a study under subsection (a), the Administrator shall provide a briefing to the appropriate committees of Congress on the results of such study.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H02616D976FB547C9B884DC541E1F7E40"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               767.
               PFAS-RELATED RESOURCES FOR AIRPORTS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H34B4E710DE3A414F948329FE9835DCA9"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  PFAS replacement program for airports
                  Not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary, in consultation with the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, shall establish a program to reimburse sponsors of eligible airports for the reasonable and appropriate costs incurred after September 12, 2023, and associated with any of the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H9F0F246E60644A9CAD439F54827C3C0A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     The one-time initial acquisition by the sponsor of an eligible airport of an approved fluorine-free firefighting agent under Military Specification MIL–PRE–32725, dated January 12, 2023, in a quantity of—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H7C2AAADBBF06492FA2C82B77C0F7A4E2"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        the capacity of all required aircraft rescue and firefighting equipment listed in the most recent FAA-approved Airport Certification Manual, regardless of how the equipment was initially acquired; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HFBEC0F3C30EF400F82740F682007B486"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        twice the quantity carried onboard each required truck available in the fire station for the eligible airport.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H846C4C59A1094708932F8A6BF3F4B70E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     The disposal of perfluoroalkyl or polyfluoroalkyl products, including fluorinated aqueous film-forming agents, to the extent such disposal is necessary to facilitate the transition to such approved fluorine-free firefighting agent, including aqueous film-forming agents currently in firefighting equipment and vehicles and any wastewater generated during the cleaning of firefighting equipment and vehicles. 
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HEE24E526726148F199B2A6027B1D4626"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     The cleaning or disposal of existing equipment or components thereof, to the extent such cleaning or disposal is necessary to facilitate the transition to such approved fluorine-free firefighting agent.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB1EEAB3C6E50459CA13E09493D1E727A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     The acquisition of any equipment, or components thereof, necessary to facilitate the transition to such approved fluorine-free firefighting agent.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H2A4553FA4067403B84CE50325DEC090C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     The replacement of any aircraft rescue and firefighting equipment determined necessary to be replaced by the Secretary.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HE77CFC66899047F6AEA47A888124C787"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Distribution of funds
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H10E13D97A7EE41B6BF2E991193463960"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Grants to replace aircraft rescue and firefighting vehicles
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H7895E2EB90994DC9AC23CC9FF3952D99"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        In general
                        Of the amounts made available to carry out the PFAS replacement program, the Secretary shall reserve up to $30,000,000 to make grants to each eligible airport that is designated under part 139 as an Index A airport and does not have existing capabilities to produce fluorine-free firefighting foam for the replacement of aircraft rescue and firefighting vehicles.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H76509244C8A144FEBA5152AD87978F99"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        Amount
                        The maximum amount of a grant made under subparagraph (A) may not exceed $2,000,000.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB3A708A2A5B74274AE51BC15684470ED"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Remaining amounts
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HBC8EAD16C8D0482CB5E4041AB0B57772"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
