                  Not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall initiate a study to determine—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H50B9EB24E03841A8879755DBC9AA3050"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     the number of aircraft registered in the United States, and any other aerial vehicles operating in the airspace of the United States, that are not equipped with Automatic Dependent Surveillance–Broadcast out equipment (in this section referred to as <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">ADS–B out);
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HD0BBD7ABA6E44042A8B185450D2C5F82"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     the requirements for, and impact of, expanding the dual-link architecture that is used below an altitude of flight level 180;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HCB8F6B9997DF4797BCEAE9F91F05F54A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     the costs and benefits of equipage of ADS–B out; 
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HEFF988FEF038463F95F1E3B4D34DA1D5"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (D)
                     the costs and benefits of any accommodation made for aircraft with inoperable ADS–B out;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HA5470A321B814832ABF46A5F6E905685"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (E)
                     reasons why aircraft owners choose not to equip or use an aircraft with ADS–B out; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H53145A3AF4994FC18E46DB9122810238"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (F)
                     ways to further incentivize aircraft owners to equip and use aircraft with ADS–B out.
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H78BDD28165314F889909C9000BC08C4F"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Briefing
                  Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the results of the study conducted under paragraph (1).
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H629B44C9AA184FD59B7DEBAB45CABBA9"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Vehicle-to-vehicle link program
               Not later than 270 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator, in coordination with the Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Chair of the Federal Communications Commission, shall establish an interagency coordination program to advance vehicle-to-vehicle link initiatives that—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H6921FF93C0B54311BCA32FE7FB278D24"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  enable the real-time digital exchange of key information between nearby aircraft; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HE109952379E8432AB9BE6BB053F6CAE7"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  are not reliant on ground infrastructure or air-to-ground communication links.
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HEBC39CC1E8894857940788F9BED1A261"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            809.
            ENSURING SAFE LANDINGS DURING OFF-AIRPORT OPERATIONS
            The Administrator shall not apply section 91.119 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, in any manner that requires a pilot to continue a landing that is unsafe.
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H43F740B60346479F8196C444B0F61E5C"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            810.
            DEVELOPMENT OF LOW-COST VOLUNTARY ADS–B
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HA2FDC89B1CFE4A32A03F4A6A4846F350"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall prepare a report on the development of a suitable position reporting system for voluntary use in covered airspace to facilitate traffic awareness.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H097FB3034498467B8761D0A4ACD01837"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Technical advice
               In preparing the report under subsection (a), the Administrator shall solicit technical advice from representatives from—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H778C5F24E13248CBA62B190DB97D70C1"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  industry groups, including pilots, aircraft owners, avionics manufacturers; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HDF39A39EAEDA42F8ABA5EB18F6F01D52"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  any others determined necessary by the Administrator.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H40AE90A24C374F05A73D943807FDFDDA"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Requirements
               In preparing the report under subsection (a), the Administrator shall—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H2EE103D1DE784A7290B0EF74EFD570A6"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  research and catalog domestic and international equipment, standards, and systems analogous to ADS–B available as of the date on which the report is completed;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H6127872751004B369C9A9FD55BCDB8A4"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  address strengths and weaknesses of such equipment, standards, and systems, including with respect to cost;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H1640CB6686184FBFB003E17FAF9A8C8B"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  to enable the development and voluntary use of portable, installed, low-cost position reporting systems for use in covered airspace—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H0E36D23499EC4AAB930EC638F744A116"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     provide recommendations on any regulatory and procedural changes to be taken by the Administrator or other Federal entities; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H98CCD00E7FF44CB7B2FB8E2D2C23A5EF"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     describe any equipment, standards, and systems that may need to be developed with respect to such reporting systems;
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HF3B5CCD1AFB747DA8C651FBBD2BA2B4C"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  determine market size, development costs, and barriers that may need to be overcome for the development of technology that enables such position reporting systems in covered airspace; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H24D9075AC4D54225932D5A2E3C7B5B27"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (5)
                  include a communication strategy that—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H85BC492E5A0B41DEAA2CF5C7420EB69B"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     targets potential users of such position reporting systems as soon as such technology is available for commercial use; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HFF99C9CD719B4B629679C07BA5D6F091"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     promotes the benefits of the voluntary use in covered airspace of position reporting systems to enhance traffic awareness.
                  
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H43B8ECFC9A4B4926AB46E74ECDB776BC"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (d)
               Report to Congress
               Not later than 30 days after the date on which the report prepared under subsection (a) is finalized, the Administrator shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress the report prepared under subsection (a).
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H8AAF49AB585E4E768F5CD87D7BB25007"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (e)
               Definitions
               In this section:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H6E8B625C08014BE4A1093589BC2D5CF0"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Covered airspace
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">covered airspace means airspace for which the use of ADS–B out equipment on an aircraft is not required under section 91.225 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, 
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H48227A11CB5B48DAABA7FC34A6422834"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  ADS–B
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">ADS–B means Automatic Dependent Surveillance–Broadcast. 
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H4B47BACC4DC340C89264BD090D7BF32D"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            811.
            AIRSHOW SAFETY TEAM
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H45A9A490B2B04D2BB27568040798EF20"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator may, as determined necessary by the Administration, coordinate with the General Aviation Joint Safety Committee to establish an Airshow Safety Team focused on airshow and aerial event safety.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H7E1DCFD389594AAA844D566BFD13939C"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Objective
               The objective of the Airshow Safety Team described in subsection (a) shall be to—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H61045E232BDB4A46B58DBE36A8A925A3"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  serve as a mechanism for Federal Government and industry cooperation, communication, and coordination on airshow and aerial event safety; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H8BEF8C55AA644930AEFA906AFE935BAF"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  reduce airshow and aerial event accidents and incidents through non-regulatory, proactive safety strategies.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HE60B054922C44EC5B64021D3217EC305"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Activities
               In carrying out the objectives pursuant to subsection (b), the Airshow Safety Team shall, at a minimum—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H51575630D04D4939B74299258C1A5A4A"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  perform an analysis of airshow and aerial event accidents and incidents in conjunction with the Safety Analysis Team;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H6ADC3EB3B8F843C0AE83D0ED46C27DEF"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  publish and update every 2 years after initial publication an Airshow Safety Plan that incorporates consensus based and data driven mitigation measures and non-regulatory safety strategies to improve and promote safety of the public, performers, and airport personnel; and 
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H78B6B8780E5648CEBBBB5B366F681F35"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  engage the airshow and aerial event community to—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H21C50273020B4C168B596FDA91B58027"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     communicate non-regulatory, proactive safety strategies identified by the Airshow Safety Plan to mitigate incidents; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H2B06AA517A7F4288AEA3979DC0A655D6"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     discuss best practices to uphold and maintain safety at events.
                  
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HA93388B4EE9147D7970DDF4A84046879"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (d)
               Membership
               The Administrator may request the Airshow Safety Team be comprised of at least 10 individuals, each of whom shall have knowledge or a background in the planning, execution, operation, or management of an airshow or aerial event.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HB3AB67F5075E48B2BB0CEE30C0603272"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (e)
               Meetings
               The Airshow Safety Team shall meet at least twice a year at the direction of the co-chairs of the General Aviation Joint Safety Committee.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H29AEC074F7E043F7A35BEA3DB0E5FF2C"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (f)
               Construction
               Nothing in this section shall be construed to require an amendment to the charter of the General Aviation Joint Safety Committee.
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H307DFB752B1C4CB3B6AE6BE06AD53B6E"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            812.
            AIRCRAFT REGISTRATION VALIDITY DURING RENEWAL
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H433DBA1DDE6A460881A58454D18072B0"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               Section 44103 of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:
               <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                              display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              display-quotes="yes"
                              id="H060CE03BDB884F26B49E6195AFE9C5AF"
                              style="OLC">
                  <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                               id="H21B28DE26B4544E1AFDE3CFB02296FBF"
                               qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (e)
                     Validity of aircraft registration during renewal
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H073BE33CA93F4BCEB8ABEB44F24117F7"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (1)
                        In general
                        An aircraft may be operated on or after the expiration date found on the certificate of registration issued for such aircraft under this section as if it were not expired if the operator of such aircraft has aboard the aircraft—
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H7B33D752BF844C898003121830FEC8DD"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (A)
                           documentation validating that—
                           <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H489C41C688114026A6FF734EE73C5FAF"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (i)
                              an aircraft registration renewal application form (AC Form 8050–1B, or a succeeding form) has been submitted to the Administrator for such aircraft but not yet approved or denied; and
                           
                           <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H87B39678117240AABFA67245D8CB567A"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                              (ii)
                              such aircraft is compliant with maintenance, inspections, and any other requirements for the aircraft’s airworthiness certificate issued under section 44704(d); and
                           
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HDCC3CA71ADB94CAFAD5663B9C2818AB2"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (B)
                           the most recent aircraft registration.
                        
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H17653CCDB4AC4B91886DD9E0D6FBAF88"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (2)
                        Proof of pending renewal application
                        The Administrator shall provide an applicant for renewal of registration under this section with documentation described in paragraph (1)(A). Such documentation shall—
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HF4AD60B3FCD9496BA40B1C72BD94D238"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (A)
                           be made electronically available to the applicant immediately upon submitting an aircraft registration renewal application to the Civil Aviation Registry for an aircraft;
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H0F950A62B17A41078C08F362E8946732"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (B)
                           notify the applicant of the operational allowance described in paragraph (1);
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HE4E43CB2A2084EDA9678788505D415D6"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (C)
                           deem an aircraft’s airworthiness certificate issued under section 44704(d) as valid provided that the applicant confirms acknowledgment of the requirements of paragraph (1)(A)(ii);
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H108F0A8C0EC943E18464ABDD98A593E1"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (D)
                           confirm the applicant acknowledged the limitations described in paragraph (3)(A) and (3)(B); and
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HA780AFCE76904382B5A2181E9828A812"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (E)
                           include identifying information pertaining to such aircraft and to the registered owner.
                        
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HE8D868E82A44453D8B823515271DE558"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (3)
                        Rule of construction
                        Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to permit any person to operate an aircraft—
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HAA33B06D36AD41988B27CCB7B9B8E48E"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (A)
                           with an expired registration, except as specifically provided for under this subsection; or
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H24878849380F4D99847B7D811EC0AF98"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (B)
                           if the Administrator has denied an application to renew the registration of such aircraft.
                        
                     
                  
                  .
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H99B795DBD1A64070BCE7D8411737C2F8"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Rulemaking; guidance
               Not later than 36 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall issue a final rule, if necessary, and update all applicable guidance and policies to reflect the amendment made by this section.
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HC82193FA2F6E467BB2F6B03152C17499"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            813.
            TEMPORARY AIRMAN CERTIFICATES
            Section 44703 of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:
            <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                           display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           display-quotes="yes"
                           id="H318CE94DD92F4AEF920F5DC600C795DA"
                           style="OLC">
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HDBBD2B3D8E074E2393BB6A5432AD0527"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (l)
                  Temporary airman certificate
                  An individual may obtain a temporary airman certificate from the Administrator after requesting a permanent replacement airman certificate issued under this section. A temporary airman certificate shall be—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H55B0F401C432494B905359E37FB2722B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     made available—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H1F21BC430A5F40C1BBD3A95ACF6D780E"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        electronically to the individual immediately upon submitting an online application for a replacement certificate to the Administrator; or
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H0775D4815D114AF19628D9F4F9B01BAF"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        physically to the individual at a flight standards district office—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HCC4BBC4B3769491CB675CA8E30546F65"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           if the individual submits an online application for a replacement certificate; or
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HB8492A9D28D9461083876DC6585AA745"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           if the individual applies for a permanent replacement certificate other than by online application and such application has been received by the Federal Aviation Administration; and
                        
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC7A5862D715B4C549B467EC4FFDF7924"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     destroyed upon receipt of the permanent replacement airman certificate from the Administrator. 
                  
               
               .
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HCBDE8741C0524592A1EFD415322B8D50"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            814.
            LETTER OF DEVIATION AUTHORITY
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HFBF3B77B0F614E61B208DD5A2F128BBF"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               A flight instructor, registered owner, lessor, or lessee of a covered aircraft shall not be required to obtain a letter of deviation authority from the Administrator to allow, conduct, or receive flight training, checking, and testing in such aircraft if—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H47845E9FB51F4E4198A2B5BE0D910952"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  the flight instructor is not providing both the training and the aircraft;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HA34630C7DCDE4CA892497E6A83238E11"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  no person advertises or broadly offers the aircraft as available for flight training, checking, or testing; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HDEF14E367FE34D589DB68A0972949D89"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  no person receives compensation for use of the aircraft for a specific flight during which flight training, checking, or testing was received, other than expenses for owning, operating, and maintaining the aircraft.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H0DABB5CBB1744E5A9CF16F9EA392DA62"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Covered aircraft defined
               In this section, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">covered aircraft means—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HC14F4215FD5C48049D02192149156653"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  an experimental category aircraft;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H6A0D8CA6651E4574957C707C0C95F17E"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  a limited category aircraft; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HFDB5DC3B22D74B11A1E89C729E979FEC"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  a primary category aircraft.
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HABA08F1E63A74536BAF1B46BCE76E6AE"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            815.
            BASICMED FOR EXAMINERS ADMINISTERING TESTS OR PROFICIENCY CHECKS
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H74023B5DD12145ED8DBEC60DBB789402"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Equivalent pilot-in-command medical requirements
               Notwithstanding section 61.23(a)(3)(iv) of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, an examiner may administer a practical test or proficiency check if such examiner meets the medical qualification requirements under part 68 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, if the operation being conducted is in a covered aircraft, as such term is defined in section 2307(j) of the FAA Extension, Safety, and Security Act of 2016 (49 U.S.C. 44703 note).
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HE0A6C560CF004214BC2425689A033266"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Rulemaking
               Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall issue a final rule to update part 61 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, to implement the requirements under subsection (a), in addition to any related requirements the Administrator finds are in the interest of aviation safety.
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H7DF5FB558F194360A6B8458FE77147F6"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            816.
            DESIGNEE LOCATOR TOOL IMPROVEMENTS
            Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall ensure that the designee locator search function of the public website of the Designee Management System of the Administration has the functionality to—
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                        id="H980D944AD8AA4F009BB3BF0A5FC10E25"
                        qb-display-quote="yes">
               (1)
               filter a search for an Aviation Medical Examiner (as described in section 183.21 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations) by sex, if such information is available;
            
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                        id="H125EBD857ECA49D5B3FEBA6698194C3F"
                        qb-display-quote="yes">
               (2)
               display credentials and aircraft qualifications of a designated pilot examiner (as described in section 183.23 of such title); and
            
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                        id="H95B64AAD7E324DC8BE66F527A3819237"
                        qb-display-quote="yes">
               (3)
               display the scheduling availability of a designated pilot examiner (as described in section 183.23 of such title) to administer a test or proficiency check to an airman.
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H0A6B2A38D5534937AB50CC09C9DD4290"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            817.
            DEADLINE TO ELIMINATE AIRCRAFT REGISTRATION BACKLOG
            Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall take such actions as may be necessary to reduce and maintain the aircraft registration and recordation backlog at the Civil Aviation Registry so that, on average, applications are processed not later than 10 business days after receipt.
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H2DC7A08ABBF345A9ABA9F2F000E6309C"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            818.
            PART 135 AIR CARRIER CERTIFICATE BACKLOG
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H4FB5D403245748F0A4E1457CDF60BB89"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               The Administrator shall take such actions as may be necessary to achieve the goal of reducing the backlog of air carrier certificate applications under part 135 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, to—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HDD532B440F2B4E9F913098FD640F973C"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, maintain an average application acceptance or rejection time of less than 60 days; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H980F549E49594025B7286ACAE656F429"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, maintain an average application acceptance or rejection time of less than 30 days.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H37E712B5DC174ADF8376C2ED705EF3C2"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Measures
               In meeting the goal under subsection (a), the Administrator may—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H4846A92382854D00A94BD624B051423B"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  assign, as appropriate, additional personnel or support staff, including on a temporary basis, to review, adjudicate, and approve applications;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H45121536F6E3462895DF1FC1BD80FFD4"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  improve and expand promotion of existing applicant resources which could improve the quality of applications submitted to decrease the need for Administration applicant coordination and communications; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H612BD25F274C4B49A3096D0913A7C95E"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  take into consideration any third-party entity that assisted in the preparation of an application for an air carrier certificate under part 135 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H8A8CA0F2168A4D4EA174632115B01A27"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Congressional briefing
               Beginning 6 months after the date of enactment of this Act, and not less than every 6 months thereafter until the Administrator complies with the requirements under subsection (a)(2), the Administrator shall provide a briefing to appropriate committees of Congress on the status of the backlog of air carrier certificate applications under part 135 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, any measures the Administrator has put in place under subsection (b).
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H9002DF5DF7D54484AF6F8F89F766B391"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            819.
            ENHANCING PROCESSES FOR AUTHORIZING AIRCRAFT FOR SERVICE IN COMMUTER AND ON-DEMAND OPERATIONS
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HC94CEE1987EB4EC799EDFEE052932E88"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Establishment of working group
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H34C10E6137604B42884081311C473DC3"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  In general
                  Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall establish a part 135 aircraft conformity working group (in this section referred to as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Working Group).
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HCC005E5B5CF242969C50B1D80B0ADBFF"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Requirements
                  The Working Group shall study methods and make recommendations to clarify requirements and standardize the process for conducting and completing aircraft conformity processes in a timely manner for existing operators and air carriers operating aircraft under part 135 and entering such aircraft into service.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H8A99F9E14601479F94FB9BDD4AE2BA73"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Membership
               The Working Group shall be comprised of representatives of the FAA, existing operators and air carriers operating aircraft under part 135, associations or trade groups representing such operators or air carriers, and, as appropriate, labor groups representing employees of air carriers operating under part 135.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H14886E4D8DCB4075BE11670FE8C7E774"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Duties
               The Working Group shall consider all aspects of the FAA processes as of the date of enactment of this Act for ensuring aircraft conformity and make recommendations to enhance such processes, including with respect to— 
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H274A3708668C4436B6E9089ED0763C2A"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  methodologies for air carriers and operators to document and attest to aircraft conformity in accordance with the requirements of part 135;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HB34A58E20DE948D3A39390EC157ED3D1"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  streamlined protocols for operators and air carriers operating aircraft under part 135 to add an aircraft that was listed on another part 135 certificate immediately prior to moving to a new air carrier or operator; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H88E0E54ADD5A415582961D6580EC665B"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  changes to FAA policy and documentation necessary to implement the recommendations of the Working Group.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HEB1E63FE2C89487B9D63F285EDB4E952"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (d)
               Congressional briefing
               Not later than 1 year after the date on which the Administrator establishes the Working Group, the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the progress made by the Working Group in carrying out the duties specified in subsection (c), recommendations of the Working Group, and the efforts of the Administrator to implement such recommendations. 
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H1F5E8F5558D14FC9B9F91B048F3CC3F7"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (e)
               Definition of part 135
               In this section, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">part 135 means part 135 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HB1AB54805E6344F0A4DFCE5C4D8A87E7"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            820.
            FLIGHT INSTRUCTOR CERTIFICATES
            Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall issue a final rule for the rulemaking activity titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                       quote-display-start="auto"
                       quote-type="text">Removal of the Expiration Date on a Flight Instructor Certificate, published in Fall 2022 in the Unified Agenda of Federal Regulatory and Deregulatory Actions (RIN 2120–AL25) to, at a minimum, update part 61 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, to—
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                        id="H6D05973E20554E03910B2535D1E347E5"
                        qb-display-quote="yes">
               (1)
               remove the expiration date on a flight instructor certificate; and 
            
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                        id="H47CC751AC0A14545AB75AF8F84169526"
                        qb-display-quote="yes">
               (2)
               replace the requirement that a flight instructor renews their flight instructor certificate with appropriate recent experience requirements for the holder of a flight instructor certificate to exercise the privileges of such certificate.
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HC384A1B0A8854EE791EF08377AA121EB"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            821.
            CONSISTENCY OF POLICY APPLICATION IN FLIGHT STANDARDS AND AIRCRAFT CERTIFICATION
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H0725C594548E48ACBE71D68B266E9014"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               The inspector general of the Department of Transportation shall initiate audits, as described in subsection (d), of the Flight Standards and Aircraft Certification Services of the FAA, and the personnel of such offices, on the consistency of—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HB5A191416A5E46E38567C1528266BCA3"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  the interpretation of policies, orders, guidance, and regulations; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HA4A1E573E31D477F873C581F402F41B9"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  the application of policies, orders, guidance, and regulations.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H9F72FC1F4EC547E0B40CE848BAF046D0"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Components
               In completing the audits required under this section, the inspector general shall interview stakeholders, including at a minimum, individuals or entities that—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HC26C44671FD74B43B531A8BC0859B5E7"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  hold a certificate or authorization related to the issue being audited under subsection (d);
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H95B570C38AE94A069D1CD683B386B4B4"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  are from different regions of the country with matters before different flight standards district offices or before different FAA Flight Standards Service and Aircraft Certification Service offices;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H8C096B975AF14B06A3315EA9C4BFE2A4"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  work with multiple flight standards district offices or aircraft certification offices of the Administration; or
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HAE3B44BE0D084720A998414024985BFE"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  hold a single or multiple relevant certificates or authorizations.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HDCF22E92CFD84910928514C599F17CF1"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Reports
               The inspector general of the Department of Transportation shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress, the Secretary, and the Administrator a report for each audit required in this section, containing the results of the audit, including findings and necessary recommendations to the Administrator to improve the consistency of decision-making by Flight Standards and Aircraft Certification Services offices of the Administration.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H770802359F9C4638BE1ACB192F7AEA9D"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (d)
               Audits
               The inspector general shall complete an audit and issue the associated report required under subsection (c) not later than—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HE05CB4AFDBED4F118DD5DD49FC49BBE2"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, with regard to supplemental type certificates;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HDCC76A24AFFB4ABC83217BA5394B7920"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  34 months after the date of enactment of this Act, with regard to repair stations certificated under part 145 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H0AD13DB0F01E45C9BE3AE028A9E75835"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  50 months after the date of enactment of this Act, with regard to technical standards orders.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HF3B187618DEC410FA720C892542689AA"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (e)
               Implementation
               In addressing any recommendations from the inspector general contained in the reports required under subsection (c), the Administrator may—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H26CFF059F100444A9BDF3B23F3C6DE48"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  maintain an implementation plan; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H7C5143CC54264363B968599A7E12CBA0"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  broadly adopt any best practices to improve the consistency of interpretation and application of policies, orders, guidance, and regulations by other offices of the Administration and with regard to other activities of the Administration.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H729C5D13DD484CA186F23E820F406880"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (f)
               Briefing
               Not later than 6 months after receiving a report required under subsection (c), the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the implementation plan required under subsection (d), the status of any recommendation received pursuant to this section, and any best practices that are being implemented more broadly.
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H84B42EBC30774999B660B7116A4099F0"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            822.
            APPLICATION OF POLICIES, ORDERS, AND GUIDANCE
            Section 44701 of title 49, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following:
            <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                           display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           display-quotes="yes"
                           id="H6271F9F4F001485EAE38B76B3D7F294D"
                           style="OLC">
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H67BACA43B8AF44AC80C8E5684FFE2285"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (h)
                  Policies, orders, and guidance
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1F5FB5E5D94E46EEAA107FB22765E57D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Consistency of application
                     The Administrator shall ensure consistency in the application of policies, orders, and guidance of the Administration by—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HC11547E5455A4AFF957B34948508C50F"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        audits of the application and interpretation of such material by Administration personnel from person to person and office to office;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H624A19252B9B4E1ABBDDB2444CEA59C8"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        updating policies, orders, and guidance to resolve inconsistencies and clarify demonstrated ambiguities, such as through repeated inconsistent interpretation; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H9FD4C155F74D49169D7FDF31848B5612"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        ensuring officials are properly documenting findings and decisions throughout a project to decrease the occurrence of duplicative work and inconsistent findings by subsequent officials assigned to the same project.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC649E5F5F5264FDC8C1E8FDAF3487952"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Alterations
                     The Administrator shall consult as appropriate with regulated entities who will be impacted by proposed changes to the content or application of policies, orders, and guidance before making such changes.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H6182080A12624B41903E505332C317E8"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Authorities and regulations
                     The Administrator shall issue policies, orders, and guidance documents that are related to a law or regulation or clarify the intent of or compliance with specific laws and regulations.
                  
               
               .
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H044ABB7CDDE84404891218E356E477C7"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
