                     (2)
                     Format
                     In carrying out paragraph (1), the Administrator may not require the use of open-ended descriptive prompts that are required to be filled out by an applicant, except to provide applicants the ability to provide the FAA with information for an unusual or irregular operation.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H90683F7A908E468A92F244F30C0B1F95"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Data
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H684AB2C28FD743CE84DD1B86AC109088"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        In general
                        In carrying out paragraph (1), the Administrator shall leverage data gathered from previous requests for certificates of waivers.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H6BC9C18BB7A149AC8D6D7E819E32A91A"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        Considerations
                        In carrying out subparagraph (A), the Administrator shall safely use—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HD259BF5BD29042BF80A7692A63F16DC8"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           big data analytics; and
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H88279A8F20BF45DDB2A26B18767BD530"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           machine learning. 
                        
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HF8B77411F31D4C3596161D1804D03612"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Consideration of property access
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4C4AA2CEEC394A1282F80DC5DFC74478"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     In determining whether to issue a certificate of waiver under section 107.200 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, the Administrator shall—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H60AEE4BD73CE412897793B1EF88ED9CA"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        consider whether the waiver applicant has control over access to all real property on the ground within the area of operation; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H2DE79B9560EF4844986CA42E0C6E6DEC"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        recognize and account for the safety enhancements of such controlled access.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H78376495436D438E99557D6D7630E46D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Rule of construction
                     Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to influence the extent to which the Administrator considers a lack of control over access to all real property on the ground within an area of operation as affecting the safety of an operation intended to be conducted under such certificate of waiver.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H3A63A58C371D4BB394D893FB88076805"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Public availability of waivers
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H97F2010212674E758CA317CD8B858260"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     The Administrator shall publish all certificates of waiver issued under section 107.200 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, on the website of the FAA, including, with respect to each issued certificate of waiver—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HFAF917B3518540DB8AF36806303F3F83"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        the terms, conditions, and limitations; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H52F1CEE5020D4EB882977AD30AAF181A"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        the class of airspace and any restrictions related to operating near airports or heliports.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H95D58C7164C24B048E6FC26DBD86F240"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Publication
                     In carrying out paragraph (1), the Administrator shall ensure that published information is made available in a manner that prevents inappropriate disclosure of proprietary information.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H660912050325458FB591AF011BE2291B"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Precedential use of previously approved waivers
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H90C1A0E50D2449D38302F7590FF683EE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Waiver approval precedent
                     If the Administrator determines, using criteria for a particular waiver, that an application for a certificate of waiver issued under section 107.200 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, is substantially similar (or is comprised of elements that are substantially similar) to an application for a certificate of waiver that the Administrator has previously approved, the Administrator may streamline, as appropriate, the approval of applications for such a particular waiver.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HFC946A8D82734D07BB39C8A79A4DD131"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Rule of construction
                     Nothing in paragraph (1) shall be construed to preclude an applicant for a certificate of waiver from applying to modify a condition or remove a limitation of such certificate.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H130D616C42B7432FB023BEFF1359FC91"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (f)
                  Modification of waivers
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H31C4B424E2F24EDB99E64333D3B41BF8"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     The Administrator shall establish an expedited review process for a request to modify or renew certificates of waiver previously issued under section 107.200 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, as appropriate.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3CE3D56E7C8C42EA9E452C9E14604221"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Use of review process
                     The review process established under paragraph (1) shall be used to modify or renew certificates of waiver that cover operations that are substantially similar in all material facts to operations covered under a previously issued certificate of waiver.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H1227B7C1A5B449559BCA9057156AD65E"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               909.
               ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW AND NOISE CERTIFICATION
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H491818531CD64D3EA20D3C9DB83CA2E9"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  National Environmental Policy Act guidance
                  Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall publish unmanned aircraft system-specific environmental review guidance and implementation procedures and, thereafter, revise such guidance and procedures as appropriate to carry out the requirements of this section.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H45B915CEFBCE405BA6B2B1F5ED8949E0"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Prioritization
                  The guidance and procedures established by the Administrator under subsection (a) shall include processes that allow for the prioritization of project applications and activities that—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD986F3F2B7C9414A8730C5703A3A44E6"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     offset or limit the impacts of non-zero emission activities;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H2DBEC5C21A2E4E0AA774638DE4190291"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     offset or limit the release of environmental pollutants to soil or water; or
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF2293DCD05CD4EFF8F2E971D9B9C2BA5"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     demonstrate other factors that benefit human safety or the environment, as determined by the Administrator.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H2C30B56122314A29ADEA6BBE471C00AB"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Programmatic level approach to NEPA review
                  Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall examine and integrate programmatic-level approaches to the requirements of the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (42 U.S.C. 4321 et seq.) by which the Administrator can—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H93129682CE6444E1AC15B217F15F1454"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     leverage an environmental review for unmanned aircraft operations within a defined geographic region, including within and over commercial sites, industrial sites, or other sites closed or restricted to the public; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8F772C36C3884DAB9F9972D35CB4068E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     leverage an environmental assessment or environmental impact statement for nationwide programmatic approaches for large scale distributed unmanned aircraft operations.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HA33830E5720143CAB8C5359686250617"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Developing 1 or more categorical exclusions
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H62D47F6CE51E46559AC28E0F6B7FC57E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     The Administrator shall engage in periodic consultations with the Council on Environmental Quality to identify actions that are appropriate for a new categorical exclusion and shall incorporate such actions in FAA Order 1050.1F (or successor order) as considered appropriate by the Administrator to more easily allow for safe commercial operations of unmanned aircraft.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H28C8CFF4CA594B7D82DDEC0106AE2E99"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Prior operations
                     The Administrator shall review existing categorical exclusions for applicability to unmanned aircraft operations in accordance with the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (42 U.S.C. 4321 et seq.) and subchapter A of chapter V of title 40, Code of Federal Regulations.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HEACF0262BAF74153A0A24745219BE59C"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Briefing
                  Not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the plan of the Administrator to implement subsection (a).
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HDA78BDFDA22845FE856853D01AA1CED5"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (f)
                  Nonapplication of noise certification requirements pending standards development
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HFB7C2478DC33420A81467C09A317734B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Notwithstanding the requirements of section 44715 of title 49, United States Code, the Administrator shall—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H960D0CF58E6C43B3B7B265E9E9BFAA2A"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        waive the determination of compliance with part 36 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, for an applicant seeking unmanned aircraft type and airworthiness certifications; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H872A27E8709247BDA25BF8661B524273"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        not deny, withhold, or delay such certifications due to the absence of a noise certification basis under such part, if the Administrator has developed appropriate noise measurement procedures for unmanned aircraft and the Administrator has received from the applicant the noise measurement results based on such procedures.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0BBAAAA7BF174CC6B92C7E2FA528C432"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Duration
                     The nonapplication of the noise certification requirements under paragraph (1) shall continue until the Administrator finalizes the noise certification requirements for unmanned aircraft in part 36 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, or another part of title 14 of such Code, as required under paragraph (3).
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H561358481F5945CDA2754B69460CF77C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Associated UAS certification standards
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HBB2C18961326455F8B24882DDB3C6449"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        Development of criteria
                        Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall develop and establish substantive criteria and standard metrics to determine whether to approve an unmanned aircraft pursuant to part 36 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H0B7592F320C843958B91C6E75F924899"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        Substantive criteria and standard metrics
                        In establishing the substantive criteria and standard metrics under subparagraph (A), the Administrator shall include criteria and metrics related to the noise impacts of an unmanned aircraft.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H8CF84F2554234E2397B99DD6980DFBAD"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        Publication
                        The Administrator shall publish in the Federal Register and post on the website of the FAA the criteria and metrics established under subparagraph (A).
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HC5B36849CB76488FBCDBF88D550EB3E2"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (g)
                  Concurrent reviews
                  If the Administrator determines that the design, construction, maintenance and operational sustainability, airworthiness approval, or operational approval of an unmanned aircraft require environmental assessments, including under the requirements of the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (42 U.S.C. 4321 et seq.), the Administrator shall, to the maximum extent practicable, conduct such reviews and analyses concurrently.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H4D49C99A233B4C7DB14FAA2A97CB282F"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (h)
                  Third-party support
                  In implementing subsection (a), the Administrator shall allow for the engagement of approved specialized third parties, as appropriate, to support an applicant’s preparation of, or the Administration’s preparation and review of, documentation relating to the requirements of the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (42 U.S.C. 4321 et seq.) to ensure streamlined timelines for complex reviews.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HE1EB1E117A7B4B8AAA096077C5D82B2E"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (i)
                  Rule of construction
                  Nothing in this section shall be construed as prohibiting, restricting, or otherwise limiting the authority of the Administrator from implementing or complying with the requirements of the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (42 U.S.C. 4321 et seq.) and any related requirements to ensure the protection of the environment and aviation safety.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H1A3E9DB86CFE452AB209BC93BDC4E1E4"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               910.
               UNMANNED AIRCRAFT SYSTEM USE IN WILDFIRE RESPONSE
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HD55A9CB68D4E4AFDB871208FA2A4FFB8"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Unmanned aircraft systems in wildfire response
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1DABB48DD442482F988678C6F97C1919"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator, in coordination with the Chief of the Forest Service, the Administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, and any other Federal entity (or a contracted unmanned aircraft system operator of a Federal entity) the Administrator considers appropriate, shall develop a plan for the use of unmanned aircraft systems by public entities in wildfire response efforts, including wildfire detection, mitigation, and suppression.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB0585D6EE520413FA3315819271186E3"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Plan contents
                     The plan developed under paragraph (1) shall include recommendations to—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H8D3571ABBB794675B33F42B705EC946F"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        identify and designate areas of public land with high potential for wildfires in which public entities may conduct unmanned aircraft system operations beyond visual line of sight as part of wildfire response efforts, including wildfire detection, mitigation, and suppression;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H12DB028F251C4449ACD84CAE979689B6"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        develop a process to facilitate the safe and efficient operation of unmanned aircraft systems beyond the visual line of sight in wildfire response efforts in areas designated under subparagraph (A), including a waiver process under section 91.113 or section 107.31 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, for public entities that use unmanned aircraft systems for aerial wildfire detection, mitigation, and suppression; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H1F016679A73E42D3950ED7C24E92B7CE"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        improve coordination between the relevant Federal agencies and public entities on the use of unmanned aircraft systems in wildfire response efforts.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB5601C21EC114ED5BFB9A61E866FAAA5"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Plan submission
                     Upon completion of the plan under paragraph (1), the Administrator shall submit such plan to, and provide a briefing for, the appropriate committees of Congress and the Committee on Science, Space, and Technology of the House of Representatives.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC594E65FE6834C728529B0256FF40541"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Publication
                     Upon submission of the plan under paragraph (1), the Administrator shall publish such plan on a publicly available website of the FAA.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H2D5C0D6731104769A73F9A584C5FE6BE"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Applicability
                  The plan developed under this section shall cover only unmanned aircraft systems that are—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF16A52C041F64FE58F3A6D68C2CC46AA"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     operated by, or on behalf of, a public entity;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC4F1DA89885D461A913CCAB2D7AE0335"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     operated in airspace covered by a wildfire-related temporary flight restriction under section 91.137 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H81D0366A46994C0DB3C357F36A368258"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     under the operational control of, or otherwise are being operationally coordinated by, an authorized aviation coordinator responsible for coordinating disaster response aircraft within the airspace covered by such temporary flight restriction.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H03CAFAF630EF4E1880C0DE5B93B7430E"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Interagency coordination
                  Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall seek to enter into the necessary agreements to provide a liaison of the Administration to the National Interagency Fire Center to facilitate the implementation of the plan developed under this section and the use of manned and unmanned aircraft in wildfire response efforts, including wildfire detection, mitigation, and suppression.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HE89E4FA3CA1043C6A466E53C67C7FCBE"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Savings clause
                  Nothing in this section shall be construed to confer upon the Administrator the authorities of the Administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency under section 611 of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act (42 U.S.C. 5196).
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H3A59A5E33A17492A8C8BDD22BEC857F2"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Definitions
                  In this section:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB97D4A7CA6A24ADF8F6E79A6998A2565"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Public entity
                     The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">public entity means—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H6BC43A823EF54FBA97F85747C17D6E7E"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        a Federal agency;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HFFF1A663549F46B9976FB1E294D07262"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        a State government;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H6BF7C77556D446A9AAADB4A626B5F8DA"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        a local government;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H6F83517EB82E498D851A5811736787E9"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        a Tribal Government; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H66653D45074447038F20697E68C89F29"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (E)
                        a territorial government.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H9E7C9705145C4F2AA03BC9502E85C636"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Public land
                     The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">public land has the meaning given such term in section 205 of the Sikes Act (16 U.S.C. 670k).
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H639AF63B63BE4FFEADA8E1EE109AF04E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Wildfire
                     The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">wildfire has the meaning given that term in section 2 of the Emergency Wildfire Suppression Act (42 U.S.C. 1856m).
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H7D15E044D64045E99B05CB98EA893F0C"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               911.
               PILOT PROGRAM FOR UAS INSPECTIONS OF FAA INFRASTRUCTURE
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H78196D9628A340E2B7F8A19F7DAFD7A6"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall initiate a pilot program to supplement inspection and oversight activities of the Department of Transportation with unmanned aircraft systems to increase employee safety, enhance data collection, increase the accuracy of inspections, reduce costs, and for other purposes the Secretary considers to be appropriate.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H5F942F87248D4D6FAE4779CE6AF223A0"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Ground-based aviation infrastructure
                  In participating in the program under subsection (a), the Administrator shall evaluate the use of unmanned aircraft systems to inspect ground-based aviation infrastructure that may require visual inspection in hard-to-reach areas, including—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HCA13FA2E84714107B3995232DBC16BA9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     navigational aids;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC796AFB7378D4193AA3B2E6C3D816F3F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     air traffic control towers;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF82B5D841CB24BB69A3B4E5ECF77A0CF"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     radar facilities;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB7AFF5926B9143358701653162EAE5B1"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     communication facilities; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H6C21D7846FB548BCAB08A4E4F618ECE9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     other air traffic control facilities.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H46772C7BF051455A8313B6DBA27D4AE2"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Coordination
                  In carrying out subsection (b), the Administrator shall consult with the labor union certified under section 7111 of title 5, United States Code, to represent personnel responsible for the inspection of the ground-based aviation infrastructure.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H2A7780F2751E46689951D30F284D76AF"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Briefing
                  Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, and annually thereafter until the termination of the pilot program under this section, the Secretary shall provide to the appropriate committees of Congress a briefing on the status and results of the pilot program established under subsection (a), including—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H85E28A8B28C24B758FB40D08A64774A2"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     cost savings;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3F7CE753CB8744548A8A4AC5737A8627"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     a description of how unmanned aircraft systems were used to supplement existing inspection, data collection, or oversight activities of Department employees, including the number of operations and types of activities performed;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA41C3F771F964C24B20CAA1C626244E0"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     efficiency or safety improvements, if any, associated with the use of unmanned aircraft systems to supplement conventional inspection, data collection, or oversight activities;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H7A928FF874BB470F8C0755A5CAEF9C88"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     the fleet of unmanned aircraft systems maintained by the Department for the program, or an overview of the services used as part of the pilot program; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB92C16B0249E4A84828208A27B23B806"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     recommendations for improving the use or efficacy of unmanned aircraft systems to supplement the Department’s inspection, data collection, or oversight activities.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HD830A96325EA42ECB5B9369EE891E715"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Sunset and incorporation into standard practice
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HEC1EB66222F34A898D002AF9A6CE8769"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Sunset
                     The pilot program established under subsection (a) and the briefing requirement under subsection (d) shall terminate on the date that is 4 years after the date of enactment of this Act.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H54028B0AD1EE49D1A5F4EE4139A42CB6"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Incorporation into standard practice
                     Upon termination of the pilot program under this section, the Secretary shall assess the results and determine whether to permanently incorporate the use of unmanned aircraft systems into the regular inspection, data collection, and oversight activities of the Department.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H9D612D90EA58442892627062B3CDEA5E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Report to Congress
                     Not later than 9 months after the termination of the pilot program under paragraph (1), the Secretary shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the final results of the pilot program and the actions taken by the Administrator under paragraph (2).
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H8C7EC97D9BF74C30A3191D1E0A3CAD32"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               912.
               DRONE INFRASTRUCTURE INSPECTION GRANT PROGRAM
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H39500A9821454AA5B41D0A5E3EB6FA31"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Authority
                  Not later than 270 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall establish an unmanned aircraft system infrastructure inspection grant program to provide grants to governmental entities to facilitate the use of small unmanned aircraft systems to support more efficient inspection, operation, construction, maintenance, and repair of an element of critical infrastructure to improve worker safety related to projects.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HB7A1095AC4334BC58D6D0AD1267B11F5"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Use of grant amounts
                  A governmental entity may use a grant provided under this section to—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF757B32570EC4A239210771050327DB2"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     purchase or lease small unmanned aircraft systems;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H88E8E9CC2145443D86736F21280F8806"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     support the operational capabilities of small unmanned aircraft systems used by the governmental entity;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HBE7577D07EB346F98C1819092FE61DB2"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     contract for services performed using a small unmanned aircraft system in circumstances in which the governmental entity does not have the resources or expertise to safely carry out or assist in carrying out the activities described under subsection (a); and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA88B0C0A5951428397A78A97E71CF4B0"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     support the program management capability of the governmental entity to use or contract the use of a small unmanned aircraft system, as described in paragraph (3).
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H6DE2ACBA99BB486DAB0A7F52F48E5AA4"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Application
                  To be eligible to receive a grant under this section, a governmental entity shall submit to the Secretary an application at such time, in such form, and containing such information as the Secretary may require, including an assurance that the governmental entity or any contractor of the governmental entity, will comply with relevant Federal regulations.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H7DB917356B1445E5A0BF7DCDCEBF30D6"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Selection of applicants
                  In selecting an application for a grant under this section, the Secretary shall prioritize applications that propose to—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H03002EBE06BF44F8B81D5B437E9A3D8B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     carry out a project in a variety of communities, including urban, suburban, rural, Tribal, or any other type of community; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HEB2F285DC8D745E49DE5BA6BF9894EC6"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     address a safety risk in the inspection, operation, construction, maintenance, or repair of an element of critical infrastructure.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H98F1A047C74A4DDA9D97FBE36BC73017"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Rule of construction
                  Nothing in this section shall be construed to interfere with an agreement between a governmental entity and a labor union, including the requirements of section 5333(b) of title 49, United States Code.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H1CCDAD06A81D43CD980C0ACD8FADDF22"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (f)
                  Report to Congress
                  Not later than 2 years after the first grant is provided under this section, the Secretary shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report that evaluates the program carried out under this section that includes—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HDD7C720127CA47A294F5CB363A69904F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     a description of the number of grants provided under this section;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3D4F78BCB7484DACAB8D44D941E61F25"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the amount of each grant provided under this section;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB3FB612D2564416FB4D135573684AD48"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     the activities carried out with a grant provided under this section; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HEA0F9DC7D62F47F7A959FABDF2CA6B3F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     the effectiveness of such activities in meeting the objectives described in subsection (a).
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HF34E923C7327405DA7A0C5DF1B9AAB50"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (g)
                  Funding
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE13B330036264937A25ECFBC1ADDA922"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Federal share
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE58E9FB0812F4563B52C343E4CEC820D"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        In general
                        Except as provided in subparagraph (B), the Federal share of the cost of a project carried out using a grant provided under this section shall not exceed 50 percent of the total project cost.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H712C461A8A1A4ADBAFC51FAEF30BF892"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        Waiver
                        The Secretary may increase the Federal share under subparagraph (A) to up to 75 percent for a project carried out using a grant provided under this section by a governmental entity if such entity—
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HA291B82553F448DA9DDCDED7514CD582"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (i)
                           submits a written application to the Secretary requesting an increase in the Federal share; and
                        
                        <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H200C827172E849278B0F015ECDA0C8AF"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (ii)
                           demonstrates that the additional assistance is necessary to facilitate the acceptance and full use of a grant under this section, such as alleviating economic hardship, meeting additional workforce needs, or any other uses that the Secretary determines to be appropriate.
                        
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H66AC92B8DFD14F4E96CB4B4276E8778F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Authorization of appropriations
                     Out of amounts authorized to be appropriated under section 106(k) of title 49, United States Code, the following amounts are authorized to carry out this section:
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HB9E8783529D24215AB77A32BD9EECB10"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        $12,000,000 for fiscal year 2025.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HAD9AFA7CF1224470A87AD7BBB5689AAA"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        $12,000,000 for fiscal year 2026.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H2B775DE482A445438B3B605FDDCDA6D4"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        $12,000,000 for fiscal year 2027. 
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H1D376D8A74CB4EB2998BE91B8D5370CC"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        $12,000,000 for fiscal year 2028.
                     
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H41414855C0C7480FB06F2E5806F7AFF5"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (h)
                  Definitions
                  In this section:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF4736004DD60485E805B2F68AD3A25B7"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Critical infrastructure
                     The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">critical infrastructure has the meaning given such term in subsection (e) of the Critical Infrastructures Protection Act of 2001 (42 U.S.C. 5195c(e)).
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE5F8F960E05D4EEAB8A39FA1D14780FA"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Element of critical infrastructure
                     The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">element of critical infrastructure means a critical infrastructure facility or asset, including public bridges, tunnels, roads, highways, dams, electric grid, water infrastructure, communication systems, pipelines, or other related facilities or assets, as determined by the Secretary.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HEB3BD9767DB34B08BAEBBE3E130BC567"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Governmental entity
                     The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">governmental entity means—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H8F4C4E875DCC426A8F4A956FDBC7F7BE"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        a State, the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, a territory of the United States, or a political subdivision thereof;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H93976AB4558A4D8CB0FA6FDDB9BE7ADA"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        a unit of local government;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H0621CBFA03514153AD9D34F5DE9E1F1E"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        a Tribal government;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H14F8EAF9567C4FEB9EE0523E50989AC9"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        a metropolitan planning organization; or
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H31E0975E1DE84D10A61BC8709F28BD91"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (E)
                        a consortia of more than 1 of the entities described in subparagraphs (A) through (D).
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H810517639B544954A9EAAB2BC7FBA06B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Project
                     The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">project means a project for the inspection, operation, construction, maintenance, or repair of an element of critical infrastructure, including mitigating environmental hazards to such infrastructure.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H1B54069B7D434C8CA5E7EA90E5B00C18"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               913.
               DRONE EDUCATION AND WORKFORCE TRAINING GRANT PROGRAM
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HC3E1E08F06554B1CAE095D9609DF709D"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Authority
                  Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Transportation shall establish a drone education and training grant program to make grants to educational institutions for workforce training for small unmanned aircraft systems.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H743E7E33B5934BCF91656CB4CA20163D"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Use of grant amounts
                  Amounts from a grant under this section shall be used in furtherance of activities authorized under section 631 and 632 of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 (49 U.S.C. 40101 note).
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H245AC32A372F49D6BCACA4B37D43BB3D"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Eligibility
                  To be eligible to receive a grant under this section, an educational institution shall submit an application to the Secretary at such time, in such form, and containing such information as the Secretary may require.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H9EF309D917834A74935183D366E3ED85"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Authorization of appropriations
                  Out of amounts authorized to be appropriated under section 106(k) of title 49, United States Code, the Secretary shall make available to carry out this section $5,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2025 through 2028.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HA3CD3033C7EA4C32B65997DE08299CD6"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Educational institution defined
                  In this section, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">educational institution means an institution of higher education (as such term is defined in section 101 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1001)) that participates in a program authorized under sections 631 and 632 of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 (49 U.S.C. 40101 note).
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H0F98A815E9CE4843B4D89A9E356AB4C0"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               914.
               DRONE WORKFORCE TRAINING PROGRAM STUDY
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H9222A4D00518473993ED80A769B66C1A"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall initiate a study of the effectiveness of the Unmanned Aircraft Systems Collegiate Training Initiative established under section 632 of the FAA Reauthorization Act 2018 (49 U.S.C. 40101 note).
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HF5544F3EB176443EBA24E3B2C787D7DE"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Report
                  Upon completion of the study under subsection (a), the Comptroller General shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report describing—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HCC81581FA2C743BEA789C8ED764CA0AF"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     the findings of such study; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HEEC0C79642FB4777A11EA1DE454EEFEA"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     any recommendations to improve the Unmanned Aircraft Systems Collegiate Training Initiative.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H1817954AD5CB49C392C9ABA15CC7494D"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               915.
               TERMINATION OF ADVANCED AVIATION ADVISORY COMMITTEE
               The Secretary may not renew the charter of the Advanced Aviation Advisory Committee (chartered by the Secretary on June 10, 2022).
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H6E2EBE59A44F48C6A0F9BD7A29D62E58"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               916.
               UNMANNED AND AUTONOMOUS FLIGHT ADVISORY COMMITTEE
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HF8FDCEE2BAA4487AA2971E782F871156"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 1 year after the termination of the Advanced Aviation Advisory Committee pursuant to section 915, the Administrator shall establish an Unmanned and Autonomous Flight Advisory Committee (in this section referred to as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Advisory Committee).
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H4563616DA8804AE3BC92F48C42FB5447"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Duties
                  The Advisory Committee shall provide the Administrator advice on policy- and technical-level issues related to unmanned and autonomous aviation operations and activities, including, at a minimum, the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H49A8F2736CDF4BF19D050A49288C85B9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     The safe integration of unmanned aircraft systems and autonomous flight operations into the national airspace system, including feedback on—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H2DFBEED6C8A44A33B089DB3B3CE886F9"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        the certification and operational standards of highly automated aircraft, unmanned aircraft, and associated elements of such aircraft;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H11A0EDEB34A04ABBA9496C7B95E08FAA"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        coordination of procedures for operations in controlled and uncontrolled airspace; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H3572D1A2F4FF4907BCDA298CC5FBB6D3"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        communication protocols.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE8E29C76D3DD460AB08F091558FEE0E7"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     The use cases of unmanned aircraft systems, including evaluating and assessing the potential benefits of using unmanned aircraft systems.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3B34678D075842949B6C50C0E473329A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     The development of processes and methodologies to address safety concerns related to the operation of unmanned aircraft systems, including risk assessments and mitigation strategies.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD982970F973B4D7DAFCD0BA0084F4EF3"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Unmanned aircraft system training, education, and workforce development programs, including evaluating aeronautical knowledge gaps in the unmanned aircraft system workforce, assessing the workforce needs of unmanned aircraft system operations, and establishing a strong pipeline to ensure a robust unmanned aircraft system workforce.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB71DC67EFC204FCFA9A83C4E47975EC3"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     The analysis of unmanned aircraft system data and trends.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H11DA6DD67AE445B0A81479EC8EE6247E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     Unmanned aircraft system infrastructure, including the use of existing aviation infrastructure and the development of necessary infrastructure.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H49EBF16D620B48249900E1FD85786923"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Membership
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD6ED1A24094F4AB08EB9472DEF72F3D3"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     The Advisory Committee shall be composed of not more than 12 members.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H2DDFC626696147E481F681EB0862A1B6"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Representatives
                     The Advisory Committee shall include at least 1 representative of each of the following:
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HFE755C5C1D424E49A36337658CFE29E9"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        Commercial operators of unmanned aircraft systems.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H11266A47A44142EFA9CA18A4DBF723E1"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        Unmanned aircraft system manufacturers.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE28AFFF00A5346EBA7422F894C2FEC49"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        Counter-UAS manufacturers.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H04E5E8D81BC74C36A1FC47F648B5CEF2"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        FAA-approved unmanned aircraft system service suppliers.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H77F4951886994259A5071A064D02A812"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (E)
                        Unmanned aircraft system test ranges under section 44803 of title 49, United States Code.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H7ECACE7D4A1446E88276164DA243BD25"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (F)
                        An unmanned aircraft system physical infrastructure network provider.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H437256077CC54E7489387648483EB4C3"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (G)
                        Community advocates.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H2297ED1C6F5E49E9BB1B02C2304524EB"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (H)
                        Certified labor organizations representing commercial airline pilots, air traffic control specialists employed by the Administration, certified aircraft maintenance technicians, certified aircraft dispatchers, or aviation safety inspectors.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HB422BCB551774F538EB4B3F12EDF3E19"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (I)
                        Academia or a relevant research organization.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HFF22AEBDAE22430E8DF91FC5AF90F469"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Observers
                     The Administrator may invite appropriate representatives of other Federal agencies to observe or provide input on the work of the Advisory Committee, but shall not allow such representatives to participate in any decision-making of the Advisory Committee.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H6B4A1C4BACBB4FD4916EA1052B844653"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Reporting
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H04F701721E7248AFAEBFF9A3E44FE1DE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     The Advisory Committee shall submit to the Administrator an annual report of the activities, findings, and recommendations of the Committee.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H2141BA9B234F46CD863128E580B95910"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Congressional reporting
                     The Administrator shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress the reports required under paragraph (1).
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H7E4AC494D57944568F3CF2EE467D74B9"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Prohibition
                  The Administrator may not task the Advisory Committee established under this section with a review or the development of recommendations relating to operations conducted under part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H3E7F28E08D70411D9A57A69B938BA3FF"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               917.
               NEXTGEN ADVISORY COMMITTEE MEMBERSHIP EXPANSION
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H4C68B037B95A49AEA52E55BFC983D6E8"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall take such actions as may be necessary to expand the membership of the NextGen Advisory Committee (chartered by the Secretary on June 15, 2022) to include 1 representative from the unmanned aircraft system industry and 1 representative from the powered-lift industry.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H84A72FB82FF84354A3B86820F5B482D4"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Qualifications
                  The representatives required under subsection (a) shall have the following qualifications, as applicable:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE69EE2F6712C4BD7B713213FC90959DD"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Demonstrated expertise in the design, manufacturing, or operation of unmanned aircraft systems and powered-lift aircraft.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H04C7B75570CE4096877D6CB213D94DA2"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Demonstrated experience in the development or implementation of unmanned aircraft system and powered-lift aircraft policies and procedures.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1C79F5E5E2EB4647AC18452D7E6CAC62"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Demonstrated commitment to advancing the safe integration of unmanned aircraft systems and powered-lift aircraft into the national airspace system.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H1150B07A412E466A876E898F67637069"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               918.
               INTERAGENCY COORDINATION
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H6AF358F4A13A4B0ABFB1C7076475EA2C"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Sense of Congress
                  It is the sense of Congress that—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H7EC6D610ECC644F78F7F7FEDDA6DE6DC"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     the purpose of the joint Department of Defense-Federal Aviation Administration executive committee (in this section referred to as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                                quote-display-start="auto"
                                quote-type="text">Executive Committee) on conflict and dispute resolution as described in section 1036(b) of the Duncan Hunter National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2009 (Public Law 110–417) is to resolve disputes on the matters of policy and procedures between the Department of Defense and the Federal Aviation Administration relating to airspace, aircraft certifications, aircrew training, and other issues, including the access of unmanned aerial systems of the Department of Defense to the national airspace system;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF9293B716DCB49AD945391AF409AE876"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     by mutual agreement of Executive Committee leadership, operating with the best of intentions, the current scope of activities and membership of the Executive Committee has exceeded the original intent of, and tasking to, the Executive Committee; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H70C0DD442B454C959F93019DF5FAD801"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     the expansion described in paragraph (2) has resulted in an imbalance in the oversight of certain Federal entities in matters concerning civil aviation safety and security. 
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H75A570A8DB3548848E2940647080AA0C"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Charter
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H623A5D9D541945B39CB8A6C59E8F6562"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Charter revision
                     Not later than 45 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall seek to revise the charter of the Executive Committee to reflect the scope, objectives, membership, and activities described in section 1036(b) of the Duncan Hunter National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2009 (Public Law 110–417) in order to achieve the increasing, and ultimately routine, access of unmanned aircraft systems of the Department of Defense into the national airspace system.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3067B94DB77D4D9EA72ECC48507505E7"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Sunset
                     Not earlier than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall seek to sunset the activities of the Executive Committee by joint agreement of the Administrator and the Secretary of Defense.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H6C2A8D83DD2E4E19BA5A634B57446506"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               919.
               REVIEW OF REGULATIONS TO ENABLE UNESCORTED UAS OPERATIONS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HF974BC03FDA6432C9C4F86BFF87D8656"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall, in coordination with the Secretary of Defense, conduct a review of the requirements necessary to permit unmanned aircraft systems (excluding small unmanned aircraft systems) operated by a Federal agency or armed forces (as such term is defined in section 101 of title 10, United States Code) to be operated in the national airspace system, including outside of restricted airspace, without being escorted by a manned aircraft.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H986D70E2DA8B4C0696266EB94778516C"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Report
                  Not later than 2 years after the completion of the review under subsection (a), the Administrator shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report on the results of the review, including any recommended regulatory and statutory changes to enable the operations described under subsection (a).
