                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H9AA303B531D54394B0FF07C327ECDC96"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        other issues identified by the Secretary, the Administrator, the Secretary of Energy, or the advisory committee established under paragraph (7) that must be addressed in order to enable the safe and efficient use of hydrogen in civil aviation.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HAE030A857C834C4AA0B3701D5BB87C31"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (7)
                     Establish an advisory committee composed of representatives of NASA, the aerospace industry, aviation suppliers, hydrogen producers, airlines, airport sponsors, fixed base operators, and other stakeholders to advise the Secretary, the Administrator, and the Secretary of Energy on the activities carried out under this subsection.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H16A1AEFD949B474B878E3F7492C6AEBF"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  International leadership
                  The Secretary, the Administrator, and the Secretary of Energy, in the appropriate international forums, shall take actions that—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1E5C3868D7BF40EB913B24656F93AD4C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     demonstrate global leadership in carrying out the activities required by subsections (a) and (b);
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC7B0066F46854F56B6CCA6C1312BD4FB"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     consider the needs of the aerospace industry, aviation suppliers, hydrogen producers, airlines, airport sponsors, fixed base operators, and other stakeholders identified under subsection (b);
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8088BC29A40B4DF6954EC0ABE0679F1F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     consider the needs of fuel cell manufacturers; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HBBA1645DB9C94EACA6AE37DFC42AAD65"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     seek to advance the competitiveness of the United States in the safe use of hydrogen in civil aviation.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H581A9476FBB14D8CA0CAF3221A697D48"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (f)
                  Report to Congress
                  Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary, acting through the Administrator and jointly with the Secretary of Energy, shall submit to the covered committees of Congress and the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives a report detailing—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H7BDE48F5189C4B3DBC475177BCD8B4CB"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     the actions of the Secretary, the Administrator, and the Secretary of Energy to exercise leadership in conducting research relating to the safe and efficient use of hydrogen in civil aviation;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3097B84D6ABE43FB9887C85A8E0CDE44"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the planned, proposed, and anticipated actions to update or modify existing policies related to the safe and efficient use of hydrogen in civil aviation, based on the results of the research and development carried out under this section, including such actions identified as a result of consultation with, and feedback from, the aerospace industry, aviation suppliers, hydrogen producers, airlines, airport sponsors, fixed base operators, academia and other stakeholders identified under subsection (b); and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1FF5F896C08C42C48E279EC3B7CF5234"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     a proposed timeline for any such actions pursuant to paragraph (2).
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H8429EAD7A3A345F68FDA91DA30BAAB12"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               1020.
               AVIATION FUEL SYSTEMS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HDB66E4036B0D49CFAD3373BD00FD3BD3"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Coordination
                  The Secretary, in coordination with the stakeholders identified in subsection (b), shall review, plan, and make recommendations with respect to coordination and implementation issues relating to aircraft powered by new aviation fuels or fuel systems, including at a minimum, the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HDF8FD133F1F641109E8B2DCBFE4EB020"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Research and technical assistance related to the development, certification, operation, and maintenance of aircraft powered by new aviation fuels and fuel systems, along with refueling and charging infrastructure and associated technologies critical to their deployment.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1833142B2D004547BFAFD4DFE104509D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Data sharing with respect to the installation, maintenance, and utilization of charging and refueling infrastructure at airports.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF4982918F2AF4739AAC5681A4E5634C9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Development and deployment of training and certification programs for the development, construction, and maintenance of aircraft, related fuel systems, and charging and refueling infrastructure.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H19F055EDCDB64526B50F48436AC4540E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Any other issues that the Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Energy, shall deem of interest related to the validation and certification of new fuels for use or fuel systems in aircraft.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H1ED0FA5FE1A64E13ABA8651130F4B9BB"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Consultation
                  The Secretary shall consult with—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H6EFE8AA1DB3846B69447CCC103FB918A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     the Department of Energy;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA31E060E9AA84C1E8A3C3C68485CA87C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     NASA;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD0A156A8D3A042D4A81CEA0FC97199EC"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     the Department of the Air Force; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF4E1BDBEC00C4037BE45FE9243C1E829"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     other Federal agencies, as determined by the Secretary.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HC777FB8C255044A19124150B2447DCB9"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Prohibition on duplication
                  The Secretary shall ensure that activities conducted under this section do not duplicate other Federal programs or efforts.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HAFE38A71256F46AC897B7F97376B1DC5"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Savings clause
                  Nothing in this section shall be construed as granting the Environmental Protection Agency additional authority to establish alternative fuel emissions standards.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H9FFE8A615FFA48E9AF1E52852DA455D6"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Briefing
                  Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall provide to the covered committees of Congress a briefing on the results of the review of coordination efforts conducted under this section.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H5F295FE91943455C8EDC6ADE4BD6D2DF"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               1021.
               AIR TRAFFIC SURVEILLANCE OVER UNITED STATES CONTROLLED OCEANIC AIRSPACE AND OTHER REMOTE LOCATIONS
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HC914F60C772F43F681BD7111B96932B1"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Persistent aviation surveillance over oceans and remote locations
                  Subject to the availability of appropriations, the Administrator, in consultation with the Administrator of NASA and other relevant Federal agencies, shall carry out research, development, demonstration, and testing to enable civil aviation surveillance over oceans and other remote locations to improve safety.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H1DE4ED1DBDA24B3E98FA5D191C781055"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Report
                  Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall submit to the covered committees of Congress a report on the activities carried out under this section.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HAAE7D652E10B4BB4B5D4928D88F7D18D"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Rule of construction
                  Nothing in this section shall be construed to duplicate existing efforts conducted by the Administrator, in coordination with other Federal agencies.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H15097E0ED07843F1B2BC3F84DCDE2401"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               1022.
               AVIATION WEATHER TECHNOLOGY REVIEW
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H3C648A17C842403AAD425FF60FE4C47C"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Review
                  The Administrator, in consultation with the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, shall conduct a review of current and planned research, modeling, and technology capabilities that have the potential to—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3AFDE5E2D5544AAEA881B25568480719"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     more accurately detect and predict weather impacts to aviation;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HCD09804493DE4486ADF3C56C0365BD0F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     inform how advanced predictive models can enhance aviation operations; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H5B0D4AE7536C404CA778867AC599D1E5"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     increase national airspace system safety and efficiency.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HD397F75B3B6B4504BFF9FF9C2ADDF575"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Consideration
                  The review required under subsection (a) shall include consideration of the unique impacts of weather on unmanned aircraft systems (as defined in section 44801 of title 49, United States Code) and advanced air mobility operations.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H494574BD6519435CB4F59BDB90B80123"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Report
                  Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall submit to the covered committees of Congress a report containing the results of the review conducted under subsection (a).
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HD34B11063A084B3B85DD002312787BA3"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Rule of construction
                  Nothing in this section shall be construed to duplicate existing efforts conducted by the Administrator, in consultation with the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H30B037B572BA40F88877F718FE28CE4B"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               1023.
               AIR TRAFFIC SURFACE OPERATIONS SAFETY
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H3CDF3DE058C4404895917515E2B9A678"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Research
                  Subject to the availability of appropriations, the Administrator, in consultation with the Administrator of NASA and other appropriate Federal agencies, shall continue to carry out research and development activities relating to technologies and operations to enhance air traffic surface operations safety.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H46A7EF2949AE48AF826E0C62AAF7518E"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Requirements
                  In carrying out the research and development under subsection (a) shall examine the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0D30C1C7E6E94153A312A377E8E40F54"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Methods and technologies to enhance the safety and efficiency of air traffic control operations related to air traffic surface operations.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H313D4623547847CE99F6703BF585B90B"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Emerging technologies installed in aircraft cockpits to enhance ground situational awareness, including enhancements to the operational performance of runway traffic alerting and runway landing safety technologies.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA68967986CF3439B821881E070D9E8DE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Safety enhancements and adjustments to air traffic surface operations to account for and enable safe operations of advanced aviation technology.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H2405191EE5754DA0AD5E806DC2D59E7A"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Report
                  Not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall submit to the covered committees of Congress a report on the research and development activities carried out under this section, including regarding the transition into operational use of such activities.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H7ED374E4041E474387FF34648AD054DC"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               1024.
               TECHNOLOGY REVIEW OF ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE AND MACHINE LEARNING TECHNOLOGIES
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HED4615C9023F42C58CD1A0AF0796AA76"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Review
                  The Administrator shall conduct a review of current and planned artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies to improve airport efficiency and safety.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H26D3703EB3744F7C8C8ECBCE032854C3"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Considerations
                  In conducting the review required under subsection (a), the Administrator may consider—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3A3D970701EF4D4680913484C91852B0"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     identifying best practices and lessons learned from both domestic and international artificial intelligence and machine learning technology applications to improve airport operations; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3F9D8DA51D564AFB97CFCD3E263A1EA8"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     coordinating with other relevant Federal agencies to identify China’s domestic application of artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies relating to airport operations.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H0DC937E28A5B4A33B3FB1ED88F5537CF"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Summaries
                  The review conducted under subsection (a) shall include examination of the application of artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies to the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB4A9A0920F2449F4B3A5AF54C2139788"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Jet bridges.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H40FDB9DF89A24430828FDF2BA6AA6807"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Airport service vehicles on airport movement areas.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA61B66B2D90749A4B047967ADB06EB9D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Aircraft taxi.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H52FBB0390E7542BAB7E849F34BC0737F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     Air traffic control operations.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H47CE435258F34ACE984258FDE683E279"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     Any other areas the Administrator determines necessary to help improve airport efficiency and safety.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H67657E05F91A47E4B4FCB954FDA3662E"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Report
                  Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall submit to the covered committees of Congress a report containing the results of the review conducted under subsection (a).
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H9B81C3BA45614965B2F5566CA72AC70C"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               1025.
               RESEARCH PLAN FOR COMMERCIAL SUPERSONIC RESEARCH
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H90FD39A244244FDC901DD9FA1AF85263"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator, in consultation with the Administrator of NASA and industry, shall provide to the covered committees of Congress a briefing on any plans to build on existing research and development activities and identify any further research and development needed to inform the development of Federal and international policies, regulations, standards, and recommended practices relating to the certification and safe and efficient operation of civil supersonic aircraft and supersonic overland flight.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HF426F1CB20FB4007BF81882EFEB14251"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Rule of construction
                  Nothing in this section shall be construed to duplicate existing research and development efforts conducted by the Administrator, in consultation with the Administrator of NASA.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H924EF102D42A47EC88CF0EFB26A37862"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Supersonic defined
                  In this section, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">supersonic means flights operating at speeds in excess of Mach 1 but less than Mach 5. 
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HF32998FA3A154776895666992A043E39"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               1026.
               ELECTROMAGNETIC SPECTRUM RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H0CFD5F31B89B4E12A07396A82F17E2B5"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  The Administrator, in consultation with the National Telecommunications and Information Administration and the Federal Communications Commission, shall conduct research, engineering, and development related to the effective and efficient use and management of radio frequency spectrum in the civil aviation domain, including for aircraft, unmanned aircraft systems, and advanced air mobility.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HE57E64F530DC425680D385B648AE016B"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Contents
                  The research, engineering, and development conducted under subsection (a) shall, at a minimum, address the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H7802A9E2C28942EBBD907FFF9A4F9866"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     How reallocation or repurposing of radio frequency spectrum adjacent to spectrum allocated for communication, navigation, and surveillance may impact the safety of civil aviation.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H41B86AB8DFBC4834AF3103C063C2E6F5"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     The effectiveness of measures to identify risks, protect, and mitigate against spectrum interference in frequency bands used in civil aviation operations to ensure public safety.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HDBE235E07A074E449547BDFC35F20147"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     The identification of any emerging civil aviation systems and their anticipated spectrum requirements.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF46BE8F9E3594E5ABA6B01B1DB31E0CE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     The implications of paragraphs (1) through (3) on existing civil aviation systems that use radio frequency spectrum, including on the operational specifications of such systems, as it relates to existing and to future radio frequency spectrum requirements for civil aviation.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H8D864BBE99FD4E5A9B2D337DAF65CCE5"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Report
                  Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall submit to the covered committees of Congress a report containing the results of the research, engineering, and development conducted under subsection (a).
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H28D3883857C0495ABDC7B70C5D273AEE"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               1027.
               RESEARCH PLAN ON THE REMOTE TOWER PROGRAM
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H922D9A349D374CE49824AED726875AF4"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall submit to the covered committees of Congress a comprehensive plan for research, development, testing, and evaluation needed to further mature remote tower technologies and systems and related requirements and provide a strategic roadmap to support deployment of such technologies.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H1C098F67591E4ED998804E63A79A186D"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Considerations
                  In developing the plan under subsection (a), the Administrator shall consider—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H14F0B763B10F4B7ABCFD8045A5D5EFF2"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     how remote tower systems could enhance certain air traffic services, including providing additional air traffic support to existing air traffic control tower operations and providing air traffic support at airports without a manned air traffic control tower;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H9C68C17D7BAC48C19AB8BF5D3D40E83E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the validation and certification timeline and structure of the FAA;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB3A251B2A2504C9EA6F84EA727FDC874"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     existing remote tower technologies to the extent possible to inform technology maturation and improvements;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H16A9F056146147F88AA6BC6C8E66A97D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     new and developing remote tower technologies and the extent to which remote tower systems enable the introduction of advanced technological capabilities; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3E560CFE93B04E12A70503EB1F638CF1"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     collaborating with the exclusive bargaining representative of air traffic controllers of the FAA certified under section 7111 of title 5, United States Code.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H318FFC8305CD47CA9892A6B68BB20966"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Savings clause
                  Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit or otherwise delay testing, validating, certifying, or deploying remote tower technologies conducted under section 47124 title 49, United States Code.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HFE134C67415640189C642F62A6AB33C3"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               1028.
               AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL TRAINING
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H938C796F6B4D4252B161547FAA835D25"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Research
                  Subject to the availability of appropriations, the Administrator shall carry out a research program to evaluate opportunities to modernize, enhance, and streamline on-the-job training and training time for individuals seeking to become certified professional controllers of the FAA, as required by the Administrator.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HD33CE5DDDC974F2F91D6613845A702BC"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Requirements
                  In carrying out the research program under subsection (a), the Administrator shall—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H443741A7E9774A5F9D4B6CA4F7303F6A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     assess the benefits of deploying and using advanced technologies, such as artificial intelligence, machine learning, adaptive computer-based simulation, virtual reality, or augmented reality, or any other technology determined appropriate by the Administrator, to enhance air traffic controller knowledge retention and controller performance, strengthen safety, and improve the effectiveness of training time; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HFF8A5B78C61F4329B2C1CBFC28FE1C63"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     include collaboration with labor organizations, including the exclusive bargaining representative of air traffic controllers of the FAA certified under section 7111 of title 5, United States Code, and other stakeholders.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H49079F4413B549CDA923F785737684BD"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Report
                  Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall submit to the covered committees of Congress a report on the findings of the research under subsection (a).
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HE5BA45BEE59F42DE84D46F3C27871773"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Rule of construction
                  Nothing in this section shall be construed to delay the installation of tower simulation systems by the Administrator at FAA air traffic facilities across the national airspace system.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H7BB26E908DBA41599CCD67220DD711C3"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               1029.
               REPORT ON AVIATION CYBERSECURITY DIRECTIVES
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HC092509F2D8C42DF807AB788F8791BD5"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall submit to the covered committees of Congress a report on the status of the implementation by the Administrator of the framework developed under section 2111 of the FAA Extension, Safety, and Security Act of 2016 (Public Law 114–190; 49 U.S.C. 44903 note).
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H31146BA547254379A2FEB6CF3590ADD3"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Contents
                  The report, at a minimum, shall include the following:
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HEA2BC7BD99924669BE23719ABEFC51E8"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     A description of the progress of the Administrator in developing, implementing, and updating such framework.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HAC19AFAD3F6C4458A68C14863BE7B48E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     An overview of completed research and development projects to date and a description of remaining research and development activities prioritized for the most needed improvements, with target dates, to safeguard the national airspace system.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H00199EA0A76A43DA9C1878B19C4E8C4D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     An explanation for any delays or challenges in so implementing such section.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HF474EA776D2740F191E12F9424A6F0B3"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               1030.
               TURBULENCE RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HB6334CF1C8EB43CBABC5299E772ABF8B"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Subject to the availability of appropriations, the Administrator, in collaboration with the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, and in consultation with the Administrator of NASA, shall carry out applied research and development to—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD06A08D70A984FEC896495F1AEBAE559"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     enhance the monitoring and understanding of severe turbulence, including clear-air turbulence; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HCA347C25F8D9402EA8848AC5FEE97D8C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     inform the development of measures to mitigate safety impacts on crew and the flying public that may result from severe turbulence.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HF2F123E2250440FF95544E95B397CF4D"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Research and development activities
                  In carrying out the research and development under subsection (a), the Administrator shall—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H15D64F47E25D4635AF137622A181886C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     establish processes and procedures for comprehensive and systematic data collection, through both instrumentation and pilot reporting, of severe turbulence, including clear-air turbulence;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3A2F49BA1C5345EEBBC59092A5190356"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     establish measures for storing and managing such data collection;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H5BC68254E1C2405AACE0BDE14EA444EF"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     support measures for monitoring and characterizing incidents of severe turbulence;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HD344D3263A114040AA8793C1EA6EB117"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     consider relevant existing research and development from other entities, including Federal departments and agencies, academia, and the private sector; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE3866CA846AB448C903B93BEAE54E103"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     carry out research and development—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HE7EB69102C9646779AEEC22E5CDE0E27"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        to understand the impacts of relevant factors on the nature of turbulence, including severe turbulence and clear-air turbulence;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H96EB60FB12F048DE963CD5DA474303F4"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        to enhance turbulence forecasts for flight planning and execution, seasonal predictions for schedule and route-planning, and long-term projections of severe turbulence, including clear-air turbulence; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HCE6150E90E7C4BF4A87FBCBD4872540D"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        on other subject matters areas related to severe turbulence, as determined by the Administrator; and
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H13732384276B471E9FDAEF85AB2CE7C9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     support the effective transition of the results of research and development to operations, in cases in which such transition is appropriate.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HE2B9DA067412466798FE5A2A5A340261"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Duplicative research and development activities
                  The Administrator shall ensure that research and development activities under this section do not duplicate other Federal programs relating to turbulence.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H32AF386320054EC2879F3EA937D5B1AA"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Turbulence data
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC8BC24176AD04F4FBF8E6ACD98560ABE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Commercial providers
                     In carrying out the research and development under subsection (a) and the activities described in subsection (b), the Administrator may enter into agreements with commercial providers for the following:
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H06A041D3C54E482D9ED3BE185A91CB0A"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        The purchase of turbulence data.
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HBE6DC644F57941FB9DF30B8E54E6FC8C"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        The placement on aircraft of instruments relevant to understanding and monitoring turbulence.
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF400E98183E1438ABC29DF6615865784"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Data access
                     The Administrator shall make the data collected under subsection (b) widely available and accessible to the scientific research, user, and stakeholder communities, including the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, to the greatest extent practicable and in accordance with FAA data management policies.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HBB863B13AA1B45B3B8AE3F91F6FC07D0"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Report on turbulence research
                  Not later than 15 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator, in collaboration with the Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, shall submit to the covered committees of Congress a report that—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H09DA9041D6C541EEAE12B59073BF4FDD"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     details the activities conducted under this section, including how the requirements of subsection (b) have contributed to the goals described in paragraphs (1) and (2) of subsection (a);
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB2D601791FDF411087C8973F213E76F5"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     assesses the current state of scientific understanding of the causes, occurrence rates, and past and projected future trends in occurrence rates of severe turbulence, including clear-air turbulence;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8C5CB6168D5A428E8901F642138A679D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     describes the processes and procedures for collecting, storing, and managing, data in pursuant to subsection (b);
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC3A615EBB793484AB6E6085D94E002D1"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     assesses—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H88FB1D51F0B74641B87760131BAE16EC"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        the use of commercial providers pursuant to subsection (d)(1); and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H6BBB46BC6B7643EFA178774BFCD5572B"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        the need for any future Federal Government collection or procurement of data and instruments related to turbulence, including an assessment of costs;
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3F39A96B55B8428CA9CFEF4BBDBB8CDE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     describes how such data will be made available to the scientific research, user, and stakeholder communities; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4FAC04F0504B49278E1734816EA007E4"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     identifies future research and development needed to inform the development of measures to predict and mitigate the safety impacts that may result from severe turbulence, including clear-air turbulence.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H977C7DF4935B46D6BF3230C45929C5E2"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               1031.
               RULE OF CONSTRUCTION REGARDING COLLABORATIONS
               Nothing in this title may be construed as modifying or limiting existing collaborations, or limiting potential engagement on future collaborations, between the Administrator, stakeholders, and labor organizations, including the exclusive bargaining representative of air traffic controllers certified under section 7111 of title 5, United States Code, pertaining to FAA research, engineering, development, demonstration, and testing activities.
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H73D45D165B5F417087A07A4643B2400B"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               1032.
               LIMITATION
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H8438CFA270474B6C986DF47EDE2EB739"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Prohibited activities
                  None of the funds authorized in this title may be used to conduct research, develop, design, plan, promulgate, implement, or execute a policy, program, order, or contract of any kind with the Chinese Communist Party or any entity that is domiciled in China or under the influence of China unless such activities are specifically authorized by a law enacted after the date of enactment of this Act.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H75775F1CA9AF4CEDB8D87A742DE7DF57"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Exemption
                  The Administrator is exempt from the prohibitions under subsection (a) if the prohibited activities are executed for the purposes of testing, research, evaluating, analyzing, or training related to—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC565B6E3ACD54F73AC9C7F19CA02E48D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     counter-unmanned aircraft detection and mitigation systems, including activities conducted—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HAC8E7757183C44619EB9E0EA681C5BE0"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        under the Center of Excellence for Unmanned Aircraft Systems of the FAA; or
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H2E01D50F055947A9884ACC604CDC1BD9"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        by the test ranges designated under section 44803 of title 49, United States Code;
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H6E9BB3CA69EF4827A3DA32487ED76934"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     the safe, secure, or efficient operation of the national airspace system or maintenance of public safety;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HEFFF7F06B27249B9B9AEBCBFFB0737E2"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     the safe integration of advanced aviation technologies into the national airspace system, including activities carried out by the Center of Excellence for Unmanned Aircraft Systems of the FAA;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3104DFF4CB9B4BF9B9E47CD62D7034B7"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     in coordination with other relevant Federal agencies, determining security threats of unmanned aircraft systems; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H734AD24369974FFAB50A820D71D795AC"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     intelligence, electronic warfare, and information warfare operations.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HECBC1B3953E1448E8E926C59AC144C69"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Waivers
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC6F3DCA335424427AE1BE07A99FE2B50"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Public interest determination
                     The Administrator may waive any prohibitions under subsection (a) on a case-by-case basis if the Administrator determines that activities described in subsection (a) are in the public interest.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE3EE1DAD21AB46B895395AECF502EA52"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Notification
                     If the Administrator provides a waiver under paragraph (1), the Administrator shall notify the covered committees of Congress in writing not later than 15 days after exercising such waiver.
                  
               
            
         
         <subtitle id="H9F3122BCB3EC4EB089EFF8C81D98ECBF"
                    qb-display-quote="yes"
                    style="OLC">
            B
            Unmanned Aircraft Systems and Advanced Air Mobility
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H89DDC3CD052347CBB89F80BE6922F720"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               1041.
               DEFINITIONS
               In this subtitle:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HCF7A66BCAB604B4CA7BEDABE62B0F7DF"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Advanced air mobility
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">advanced air mobility means a transportation system that is comprised of urban air mobility and regional air mobility using manned or unmanned aircraft. 
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HC46A4598F5424BB6A2694B8B5C00E82B"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Interagency working group
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">interagency working group means the advanced air mobility and unmanned aircraft systems interagency working group of the National Science and Technology Council established under section 1042.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HDB8EC07AE26C488697599E83E994C522"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  Labor organization
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">labor organization has the meaning given the term in section 2(5) of the National Labor Relations Act (29 U.S.C. 152(5)), except that such term shall also include—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H467B6F4C15F8415187DA23A26B9F9E40"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     any organization composed of labor organizations, such as a labor union federation or a State or municipal labor body; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HBC3D0881BAA24216BF7AC949C9979CC3"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     any organization which would be included in the definition for such term under such section 2(5) but for the fact that the organization represents—
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H069532C52D27472FB33C8552DA806E5A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (i)
                        individuals employed by the United States, any wholly owned Government corporation, any Federal Reserve Bank, or any State or political subdivision thereof;
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HB0C375004EFC4C5CAB1CA34E808106A7"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (ii)
                        individuals employed by persons subject to the Railway Labor Act (45 U.S.C. 151 et seq.); or
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0BD290B04CE74664A9CAF405B18AE6F1"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (iii)
                        individuals employed as agricultural laborers.
                     
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HBC74DECDF8FF4BA0BDCEA90E346810BA"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  National laboratory
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">National Laboratory has the meaning given such term in section 2 of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 (42 U.S.C. 15801).
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H83F0DE87BA8A4576BA4F250569A29B46"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (5)
                  Technical standard
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">technical standard has the meaning given such term in section 12(d)(5) of the National Technology Transfer and Advancement Act of 1995 (15 U.S.C. 272 note).
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H253516DCF70344CE998031057B3620EE"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (6)
                  Unmanned aircraft system
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">unmanned aircraft system has the meaning given such term in section 44801 of title 49, United States Code.
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H21358BE792D94335A0C8597F94CEEFFC"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               1042.
               INTERAGENCY WORKING GROUP
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H52CF7D3824D346F09ADA2DDD615BBC4B"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Designation
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0B342E05680D49A0AD7B8BBDF8219323"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     The National Science and Technology Council shall establish or designate an interagency working group on advanced air mobility and unmanned aircraft systems to coordinate Federal research, development, deployment, testing, and education activities to enable advanced air mobility and unmanned aircraft systems.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0A509BFA4A1A421E86EB143EFA7B0C3A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Membership
                     The interagency working group shall be comprised of senior representatives from NASA, the Department of Transportation, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the National Science Foundation, the National Institute of Standards and Technology, Department of Homeland Security, and such other Federal agencies as appropriate.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HFCB6DD57CC6D4EB7A9D8D1AE7987C011"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Duties
                  The interagency working group shall—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HEE85B440C9E345029084BD578B77C98F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     develop a strategic research plan to guide Federal research to enable advanced air mobility and unmanned aircraft systems and oversee implementation of the plan;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HCCA1F65BC0E84B84A7663BBB7662CD9E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     oversee the development of—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H8B7024BAF927420B860DE8B1DDB2153B"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        an assessment of the current state of United States competitiveness and leadership in advanced air mobility and unmanned aircraft systems, including the scope and scale of United States investments in relevant research and development; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H49360BA5FEF94A149D99C21AB4E34E06"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        strategies to strengthen and secure the domestic supply chain for advanced air mobility systems and unmanned aircraft systems;
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H0993F09C61764E66A41F814BB7105AA6"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     facilitate communication and outreach opportunities with academia, industry, professional societies, State, local, Tribal, and Federal governments, and other stakeholders;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE3BC3ECAD2914E9AABCFAF7BCAA4AE91"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     facilitate partnerships to leverage knowledge and resources from industry, State, local, Tribal, and Federal governments, National Laboratories, unmanned aircraft systems test range (as defined in section 44801 of title 49, United States Code), academic institutions, and others;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE9D91FFC6F004BB1B129919657503398"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     coordinate with the advanced air mobility working group established under section 2 of the Advanced Air Mobility Coordination and Leadership Act (Public Law 117–203) and heads of other Federal departments and agencies to avoid duplication of research and other activities to ensure that the activities carried out by the interagency working group are complementary to those being undertaken by other interagency efforts; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H664719FB9996493095988A1A5A29D66F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     coordinate with the National Security Council and other authorized agency coordinating bodies on the assessment of risks affecting the existing Federal unmanned aircraft systems fleet and outlining potential steps to mitigate such risks.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HD9A7EFE299694C6D8A1B28D2E1CD099B"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Report to Congress
                  Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, and every 2 years thereafter until December 31, 2028, the interagency working group shall transmit to the covered committees of Congress a report that includes a summary of federally funded advanced air mobility and unmanned aircraft systems research, development, deployment, and testing activities, including the budget for each of the activities described in this paragraph.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H4FB578075DCF44EAAFC9E6AC90D51BDC"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Rule of construction
                  The interagency working group shall not be construed to conflict with or duplicate the work of the interagency working group established under the advanced air mobility working group established by the Advanced Air Mobility Coordination and Leadership Act (Public Law 117–203).
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HFC97F5EA64CB4181BF298AA31808DBF0"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               1043.
               STRATEGIC RESEARCH PLAN
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HC1162530760241229A724D46AB12A05C"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the interagency working group shall develop and periodically update, as appropriate, a strategic plan for Federal research, development, deployment, and testing of advanced air mobility systems and unmanned aircraft systems.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HE88BB908E7B246A7B447078E6B838BB4"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Considerations
                  In developing the plan required under subsection (a), the interagency working group shall consider and use—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1E4E269B245B454187E6E32EE64AD22C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     information, reports, and studies on advanced air mobility and unmanned aircraft systems that have identified research, development, deployment, and testing needed;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H4DF879913284444FBEFAAF91B7EB4CD6"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     information set forth in the national aviation research plan developed under section 44501(c) of title 49, United States Code; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H1EA0D62C37624733BC138EF37CEA02A2"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     recommendations made by the National Academies in the review of the plan under subsection (d).
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H0AE2075D7AE84007977F44A6D4187E82"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Contents of the plan
                  In developing the plan required under subsection (a), the interagency working group shall—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE6ECE17077C74AF98366F4262CDF7325"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     determine and prioritize areas of advanced air mobility and unmanned aircraft systems research, development, demonstration, and testing requiring Federal Government leadership and investment;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8DDDA57342774BD49812C5C233DA812C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     establish, for the 10-year period beginning in the calendar year the plan is submitted, the goals and priorities for Federal research, development, and testing which will—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HECF0B95CEB0A4933BFAEAC10E56FE621"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        support the development of advanced air mobility technologies and the development of an advanced air mobility research, innovation, and manufacturing ecosystem;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H19FEF479AEAB42178A640D26D335DAF2"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        take into account sustained, consistent, and coordinated support for advanced air mobility and unmanned aircraft systems research, development, and demonstration, including through grants, cooperative agreements, testbeds, and testing facilities;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H998BC938DAE347CE9C9D0610962CAD12"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (C)
                        apply lessons learned from unmanned aircraft systems research, development, demonstration, and testing to advanced air mobility systems;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H67FC22F5F4FD425E9C764995EAE48622"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (D)
                        inform the development of voluntary consensus technical standards and best practices for the development and use of advanced air mobility and unmanned aircraft systems;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H72B5F5F8A819461587AD212BCC3C412E"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (E)
                        support education and training activities at all levels to prepare the United States workforce to use and interact with advanced air mobility systems and unmanned aircraft systems;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H2871CA1FF7854AB38AD5B3209EFBE127"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (F)
                        support partnerships to leverage knowledge and resources from industry, State, local, Tribal, and Federal governments, the National Laboratories, Center of Excellence for Unmanned Aircraft Systems Research of the FAA, unmanned aircraft systems test ranges (as defined in section 44801 of title 49, United States Code), academic institutions, labor organizations, and others to advance research activities;
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HC4800E91C7124D9A83251A993CC7C5FB"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (G)
                        leverage existing Federal investments; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HC366B6907BAF4AD0B3D49CC0F81F37E1"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (H)
                        promote hardware interoperability and open-source systems;
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3D4DA376F4054AC4A862F4AD472D05A2"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     support research and other activities on the impacts of advanced air mobility and unmanned aircraft systems on national security, safety, economic, legal, workforce, and other appropriate societal issues;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HA829080DE02E48B9A3F4FD2C13E6EB43"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     reduce barriers to transferring research findings, capabilities, and new technologies related to advanced air mobility and unmanned aircraft systems into operation for the benefit of society and United States competitiveness;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H154B1ABB1FF14A7798390BE865F59299"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     in consultation with the Council of Economic Advisers, measure and track the contributions of unmanned aircraft systems and advanced air mobility to United States economic growth and other societal indicators; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC7FFC283A9534675ABDC84F14D72D5C7"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     identify relevant research and development programs and make recommendations for the coordination of relevant activities of the Federal agencies and set forth the role of each Federal agency in implementing the plan.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H73AC43C350C142FD805C6297B7420EDC"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  National academies of sciences, engineering, and medicine evaluation
                  The Administrator shall seek to enter into an agreement with the National Academies to review the plan every 5 years.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H8DB2EB3D80C1433D8B65E2117AB13CBF"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Public participation
                  In developing the plan under subsection (a), the interagency working group shall consult with representatives of stakeholder groups, which may include academia, research institutions, and State, industry, and labor organizations. Not later than 90 days before the plan, or any revision thereof, is submitted to Congress, the plan shall be published in the Federal Register for a public comment period of not less than 60 days.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H7FB274A432DD4AD9B602649DEA9BEFA8"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (f)
                  Reports to Congress on the strategic research plan
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC3805E6EAD654494A572066AB9E8BB76"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Progress report
                     Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the interagency working group described in section 1042 of this Act shall transmit to the covered committees of Congress a report that describes the progress in developing the plan required under this section.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF4E44A9CB8E4442F9232C41D23C7A9CD"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
