                     Initial report
                     Not later than 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the interagency working group shall transmit to the covered committees of Congress the strategic research plan developed under this section.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H9CA7AF0715E54FFDA458259F529EEBF6"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Biennial report
                     Not later than 1 year after the transmission of the initial report under paragraph (2) and every 2 years thereafter until December 31, 2033, the interagency working group shall transmit to the covered committees of Congress a report that includes an analysis of the progress made towards achieving the goals and priorities for the strategic research plan.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="H4250A254F9964F678D8372B5D1C81633"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               1044.
               FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINISTRATION UNMANNED AIRCRAFT SYSTEM AND ADVANCED AIR MOBILITY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HDE650BB088AB4943904368F79783D56C"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  Consistent with the research plan in section 1043, the Administrator, in coordination with the Administrator of NASA and other Federal agencies, shall carry out and support research, development, testing, and demonstration activities and technology transfer, and activities to facilitate the transition of such technologies into application to enable advanced air mobility and unmanned aircraft systems and to facilitate the safe integration of advanced air mobility and unmanned aircraft systems into the national airspace system, in areas including—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H8023ADE53191421288BB0A8F0489935A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     beyond visual-line-of-sight operations;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H672F8C2ACE964A65907C0D27E77375F0"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     command and control link technologies;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H865ECBCC6EE044A28D16E62AAE74E3F9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     development and integration of unmanned aircraft system traffic management into the national airspace system;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HBC6F8C3082F941E0ABE83394CA4583A9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     noise and other societal and environmental impacts;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H5258D012C4A4468AAD20AB7188FA8E85"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     informing the development of an industry consensus vehicle-to-vehicle standard;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H9D8B40A8388D4B3588B3CEDFB5E12380"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     safety, including collisions between advanced air mobility and unmanned aircraft systems of various sizes, traveling at various speeds, and various other crewed aircraft or various parts of other crewed aircraft of various sizes and traveling at various speeds; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HEB9EC431DCB8484A8541356B213AFF5F"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (7)
                     detect-and-avoid capabilities.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H6F648D5C9D1B4859B508FC2050535E5D"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Duplicative research and development activities
                  The Administrator shall ensure that research and development and other activities conducted under this section do not duplicate other Federal activities related to the integration of unmanned aviation systems or advanced air mobility.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HEAB655D22E674A9B866C48C00027CDE3"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Lessons learned
                  The Administrator shall apply lessons learned from unmanned aircraft systems research, development, demonstration, and testing to advanced air mobility systems.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HDAC1615D3522458CA5405D744511C23B"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (d)
                  Research on approaches to evaluating risk
                  The Administrator shall conduct research on approaches to evaluating risk in emerging vehicles, technologies, and operations for unmanned aircraft systems and advanced air mobility systems. Such research shall include—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H5F91EE6731664EF687BD54B70A07000A"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     defining quantitative metrics, including metrics that may support the Administrator in making determinations, and research to inform the development of requirements, as practicable, for the operations of certain unmanned aircraft systems, as described under section 44807 of title 49, United States Code;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H2D4044ECE9864D4C968D5545393B3D84"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     developing risk-based processes and criteria to inform the development of regulations and certification of complex operations, to include autonomous beyond-visual-line-of-sight operations, of unmanned aircraft systems of various sizes and weights, and advanced air mobility systems; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H74ECA49D39CB4919A888BD0C47A5815E"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     considering the utility of performance standards to make determinations under section 44807 of title 49, United States Code.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HA326AC5F3F6E448FB9E4BE2478977212"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (e)
                  Report
                  Not later than 9 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall submit to the covered committees of Congress a report on the actions taken by the Administrator to implement provisions under this section that includes—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H66A464461FF9429480BCD11EA6FCBDBD"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     a summary of the costs and results of research under subsection (a)(6);
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HBD3D2679DFD947B08A8F8E0A5DA4FF29"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     a description of plans for and progress toward the implementation of research and development under subsection (d);
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H35866A8C687D456C940795847D3CA8D7"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     a description of the progress of the FAA in using research and development to inform FAA certification guidance and regulations of—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HF20CAD5EC5DC412D9C1A44B5283AA6C9"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (A)
                        large unmanned aircraft systems, including those weighing more than 55 pounds; and
                     
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H7C22E0C169D84335B33F889DE3AB41C0"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (B)
                        extended autonomous and remotely piloted operations beyond visual line of sight in controlled and uncontrolled airspace; and
                     
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H3A98E8F57CA94089BEECA2F00BF82121"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     a current plan for full operational capability of unmanned aircraft systems traffic management, as described in section 376 the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 (49 U.S.C. 44802 note).
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H69AE59029BEE4491BD79C793BC7B74A1"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (f)
                  Parallel efforts
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H844A0D1594EF4ABFBA41A3EA505E6745"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     In general
                     Research and development activities under this section may be conducted concurrently with the deployment of technologies outlined in (a) and in carrying out the this title and title IX.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H14724572621948F99A0374A235E2D8A8"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     Rule of construction
                     Nothing in this section shall be construed to delay appropriate actions to deploy the technologies outlined in subsection (a), including the deployment of beyond visual-line-of-sight operations of unmanned aircraft systems, or delay the Administrator in carrying out this title and title IX, or limit FAA use of existing risk methodologies to make determinations pursuant to section 44807 of title 49, United States Code, prior to completion of relevant research and development activities.
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HDF8F1124059C4373B343E1F86854AD03"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     Practices and regulations
                     The Administrator shall, to the maximum extent practicable, use the results of research and development activities conducted under this section to inform decisions on whether and how to maintain or update existing regulations and practices, or whether to establish new practices or regulations.
                  
               
            
            <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                      id="HCC007B20950049FB8203761F8A3B0B25"
                      qb-display-quote="yes"
                      section-type="subsequent-section">
               1045.
               PARTNERSHIPS FOR RESEARCH, DEVELOPMENT, DEMONSTRATION, AND TESTING
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="H3BADD275E08C46E0B8F1984A7237871D"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  Study
                  The Administrator shall seek to enter into an arrangement with the National Academy of Public Administration to examine research, development, demonstration, and testing partnerships of the FAA to advance unmanned aircraft systems and advanced air mobility and to facilitate the safe integration of unmanned aircraft systems into the national airspace system.
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HEFD0FC484A654E9A83EC4D17296C8960"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (b)
                  Considerations
                  The Administrator shall ensure that the entity carrying out the study in subsection (a) shall—
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H935977FF495F4585ABD380A1A85C7059"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     identify existing FAA partnerships with external entities, including academia and Centers of Excellence, industry, and nonprofit organizations, and the types of such partnership arrangements;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HC219B7A36F034B2C90F6F48C211F2DB9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (2)
                     examine the partnerships in paragraph (1), including the scope and areas of research, development, demonstration, and testing carried out, and associated arrangements for performing research and development activities;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF3D8DC92A68F4B409757F30799A96D02"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (3)
                     review the extent to which the FAA uses the results and outcomes of each partnership to advance the research and development in unmanned aircraft systems;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H7D8FC8AE522D4C31894DEC2EF414E782"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (4)
                     identify additional research and development areas, if any, that may benefit from partnership arrangements, and whether such research and development would require new partnerships;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H2FA0B4148276462EA34BB7BC896AB0C7"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (5)
                     identify any duplication of ongoing or planned research, development, demonstration, or testing activities;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H47FE5802F8BF484B920B8365D5FEF4EF"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (6)
                     identify effective and appropriate means for publication and dissemination of the results and sharing with the public, commercial, and research communities related data from such research, development, demonstration, and testing conducted under such partnerships;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H58FC9948B63745E7B5D9A7555B78C67D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (7)
                     identify effective mechanisms, either new or already existing, to facilitate coordination, evaluation, and information-sharing among and between such partnerships;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H7E6640B16B0043898B55F85F72658AC7"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (8)
                     identify effective and appropriate means for facilitating technology transfer activities within such partnerships;
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF61DAAFFA8554290BAAB9B7E788D7FDE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (9)
                     identify the extent to which such partnerships broaden participation from groups historically underrepresented in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics, including computer science and cybersecurity, and include participation by industry, workforce, and labor organizations; and
                  
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HBE6FF6FEB936465F90170AC0552217BE"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (10)
                     review options for funding models best suited for such partnerships, which may include cost-sharing and public-private partnership models with industry.
                  
               
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HF4B6F14A82C54D0AB4AB6E91FFAD27DB"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (c)
                  Transmittal
                  Not later than 12 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator shall transmit to the covered committees of Congress the study described in subsection (a).
               
            
         
      
      <title id="H48C17C50DBAA413EB09C9CE786D97EDF"
              qb-display-quote="yes"
              style="OLC">

         MISCELLANEOUS
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"

            TECHNICAL CORRECTIONS
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"

                              display-quotes="yes"

            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"

            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"

            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"

               Section 40110(c)(4) of title 49, United States Code, is amended by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"

            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HDB5DC69FB9B94CD4B9B0F7B66AF7C957"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (f)
               General procurement authority
               Section 40110(d)(3) of title 49, United States Code, is further amended—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HA9E5E1B7F2A54C76800D1DF40D4DD5E1"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  in subparagraph (B) by inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">, as in effect on October 9, 1996 after <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">Policy Act; 
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H8529AB3249D045AE9DB08C2BDFE240A5"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  in subparagraph (C) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">division B of subtitle I of title 41; and 
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HF178084EB9B548D6B76A2542448D4041"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  in subparagraph (D) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">section 27(e)(3)(A)(iv) of the Office of Federal Procurement Policy Act and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">section 2105(c)(1)(D) of title 41.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H9C15EC233EC441D5A661CB03E3E9329C"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (g)
               Government-Financed air transportation
               Section 40118(g)(1) of title 49, United States Code, is amended by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">detection and reporting of potential human trafficking (as described in paragraphs (9) and (10) and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">detection and reporting of potential severe forms of trafficking in persons and sex trafficking (as such terms are defined in paragraphs (11) and (12).
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HEFC01224F320451089B6D7B8F7E01E34"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (h)
               FAA authority To conduct criminal history record checks
               Section 40130(a)(1)(A) of title 49, United States Code, is amended by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">(42 U.S.C. 14616) and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">(34 U.S.C. 40316).

         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HBA879110B4724A20956D6C9538D9F614"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            1102.
            TRANSPORTATION OF ORGANS
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H3B424D4645B042A3AE310B80B6B14A2F"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               Not later than 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary, in consultation with the Administrator, shall convene a working group (in this section referred to as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">working group) to assist in developing best practices for transportation of an organ in the cabin of an aircraft operating under part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, and to identify regulations that hinder such transportation, if applicable.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H58F8732B48B644059DAB2CA035FB1E6D"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Composition
               The working group shall be comprised of representatives from the following:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H942DA47B171249CEAA9D40B5F8536C0D"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Air carriers operating under part 121 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HEAD9F65C4606416CBD6906ADC5AEA69B"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Organ procurement organizations.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H906F05477ACE4DB6A230B7ECF14276D5"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  Organ transplant hospitals.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H4D6812D486C049EEA9CD697D8EA147CF"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  Flight attendants.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H90F2A6D24D7243DEB86BAF637880258D"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (5)
                  Other relevant Federal agencies involved in organ transportation or air travel.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HE329A524D0C14991BCA07BD5D7C3B6A3"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Considerations
               In establishing the best practices described in subsection (a), the working group shall consider—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H99874CE4121049F6BA9AA4C1D55CF220"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  a safe, standardized process for acceptance, handling, management, and transportation of an organ in the cabin of such aircraft; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HFAEFE845451348F69836EAEC97CCA7F9"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  protocols to ensure the safe and timely transport of an organ in the cabin of such aircraft, including through connecting flights.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H2717578D135F48F1BC9DE4B448C0F6E3"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (d)
               Recommendations
               Not later than 1 year after the convening of the working group, such working group shall submit to the Secretary a report containing recommendations for the best practices described in subsection (a).
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HD813397AF5A143F68FC4106A673CF679"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (e)
               Definition of organ
               In this section, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">organ—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HE7E458AB869B41589C4A1B6390FB845B"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  has the meaning given such term in section 121.2 of title 42, Code of Federal Regulations; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HCB7201D29C98426B9304F0D3962E70AA"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  includes—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H049C8ACF822249B285397634E3AA7A35"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     organ-related tissue;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HA55C3A2DAB5A440684ECC506F41BBECE"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     bone marrow; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H116A4E0F1D9A401DAF5347184F349FDB"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     human cells, tissues, or cellular or tissue-based products (as such term is defined in section 1271.3(d) of title 21, Code of Federal Regulations). 
                  
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H30FDC1A7E40D48EAA2ED29C694929D42"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            1103.
            ACCEPTANCE OF DIGITAL DRIVER’S LICENSE AND IDENTIFICATION CARDS
            The Administrator shall take such actions as may be necessary to accept, in any instance where an individual is required to submit government-issued identification to the Administrator, a digital or mobile driver's license or identification card issued to such individual by a State.
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H4BD7DE258C484E5D8CE70AD03DB1A41E"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            1104.
            QUASQUICENTENNIAL OF AVIATION
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HC295BA09443841548B39A4CD0416F6BB"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Findings
               Congress finds the following:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HEF62981891A947AE9623A1AD6291460F"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  December 17, 2028, is the 125th anniversary of the first successful manned, free, controlled, and sustained flight by an aircraft.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H14940A11A13F494CA88E8FA7DAE3A412"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  The first flight by Orville and Wilbur Wright in Kitty Hawk, North Carolina, is a defining moment in the history of the United States and the world.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HE3C45D634B8A445FA110FF06BB174101"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  The Wright brothers’ achievement is a testament to their ingenuity, perseverance, and commitment to innovation, which has inspired generations of aviators and scientists alike.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H679A0C23307B44DEB19BE46BD25C46D0"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  The advent of aviation and the air transportation industry has fundamentally transformed the United States and the world for the better.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H37C256BE19B949C6B75AD3D64B91D914"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (5)
                  The 125th anniversary of the Wright brothers’ first flight is worthy of recognition and celebration to honor their legacy and to inspire a new generation of Americans as aviation reaches an inflection point of innovation and change.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H5A04847735094B488E8D86A8EBF7413F"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Sense of Congress
               It is the sense of Congress that the Secretary, the Administrator, and the heads of other appropriate Federal agencies should facilitate and participate in local, national, and international observances and activities that commemorate and celebrate the 125th anniversary of powered flight.
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HDA7F3485C5A74DC6AA02B1BE45B8DFC7"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            1105.
            LIMITATIONS FOR CERTAIN CARGO AIRCRAFT
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H35BD9953E39B4C699EBD75A42E0285A7"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               The standards adopted by the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency in part 1030 of title 40, Code of Federal Regulations, and the requirements in part 38 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, that were finalized by the Administrator of the FAA under the final rule titled <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">Airplane Fuel Efficiency Certification, and published on February 16, 2024 (89 Fed. Reg. 12634) in part 38 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, shall not apply to any covered airplane before the date that is 5 years after January 1, 2028.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H07B2F29041C047C7A80623BE1A909D06"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Operational limitation
               The Administrator shall limit to domestic use or international operations, consistent with relevant international agreements and standards, the operation of any covered airplane that—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H949DDBAA568643188D4AD7B071EA7D2F"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  does not meet the standards and requirements described in subsection (a); and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HC05DD5067CD34A11B354C9F7CDDB29C1"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  received an original certificate of airworthiness issued by the Administrator on or after January 1, 2028.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HEE35915934194EA5ADDC472DC186613B"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Definitions
               In this section:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H20CA4CF1C20346F1B1812A4AAFB9305E"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Covered airplane
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">covered airplane means an airplane that—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H74BB058A61644F98B143BBAEC3D1D94E"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     is a subsonic jet that is a purpose-built freighter;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H65F15D8448AF4B20AAAB4D9ED1AADCA2"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     has a maximum takeoff mass greater than 180,000 kilograms but not greater than 240,000 kilograms; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H31BF3F7C9DE24CE19FE853E87726E665"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     has a type design certificated prior to January 1, 2023.
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HD464E0E3D7504B04ADE5D70EFD92D39F"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Purpose-built freighter
                  The term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">purpose-built freighter means any airplane that—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HC467106A6C384B44BB58054260AE05D3"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     was configured to carry cargo rather than passengers prior to receiving an original certificate of airworthiness; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H4B5820969A3E43ADA99C2BD53A164BD7"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     is configured to carry cargo rather than passengers.
                  
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H4C4644A5F91E4CAEAAD7A2BC466CEB6B"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            1106.
            PROHIBITION ON MANDATES
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H548475DCC8E744B989102B7927C109C6"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Prohibition on mandates
               The Administrator may not require any contractor to mandate that employees of such contractor obtain a COVID–19 vaccine or enforce any condition regarding the COVID–19 vaccination status of employees of a contractor.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H4DDD11A72B0C486A93499E254E6FBCEC"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Prohibition on implementation
               The Administrator may not implement or enforce any requirement that—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H39E73386E00A41EAA70724543B9E9DA8"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  employees of air carriers be vaccinated against COVID–19;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H2E3C889FB34A476E8D1CF833D5BF19B0"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  employees of the FAA be vaccinated against COVID–19; or
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HFCDA49A2255F42E3989F4AFBF1C45F0A"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  passengers of air carriers be vaccinated against COVID–19 or wear a mask as a result of a COVID–19 related public health measure.
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HF3EB55EEF81B4871ADE7CC5B13A0E73C"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            1107.
            COVID–19 VACCINATION STATUS
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H2CFDE5C96F524F988933EA124ED655E6"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               
                  Chapter 417 of title 49, United States Code, is further amended by adding at the end the following:
               <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                              display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              display-quotes="yes"
                              id="HE17BA618D81B4CD59D3E5E023FCA50EB"
                              style="OLC">
                  <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HD391A7458A664123B6AB1A7579AC140E"
                            qb-display-quote="yes"
                            section-type="subsequent-section">
                     41729.
                     COVID–19 VACCINATION STATUS
                     <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                  id="H777DBFECC6C34AC8B797148485ECD8E7"
                                  qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (a)
                        In general
                        An air carrier (as such term is defined in section 40102) may not deny service to any individual solely based on the vaccination status of the individual with respect to COVID–19.
                     
                     <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                  id="HE32331BF36214CA5A1FA2DE2EA183E1C"
                                  qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (b)
                        Rule of construction
                        Nothing in this section shall be construed to apply to the regulation of intrastate travel, transportation, or movement, including the intrastate transportation of passengers.
                     
                  
                  .
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HFDD7278A1F7A4B778E0238D71F0ED5E3"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Clerical amendment
               The analysis for chapter 417 of title 49, United States Code, is further amended by inserting after the item relating to section 41728 the following:
               <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                              display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              display-quotes="yes"
                              id="HDC91A180DA394C399AAA13182021F790"
                              style="OLC">
                  
                     41729. COVID–19 vaccination status.
                  
                  .
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HB76F156CF0C34E4DBC1C58A298C5F2AD"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Rule of construction
               Nothing in this section, or the amendment made by this section, shall be construed to permit or otherwise authorize an executive agency to enact or otherwise impose a COVID–19 vaccine mandate. 
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H23F20FB493EA4C22803642BCC6FA081B"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            1108.
            RULEMAKING RELATED TO OPERATING HIGH-SPEED FLIGHTS IN HIGH ALTITUDE CLASS E AIRSPACE
            Not later than 2 years after the date on which the Administrator identifies the minimum altitude pursuant to section 1011, the Administrator shall publish in the Federal Register a notice of proposed rulemaking to amend sections 91.817 and 91.818 of title 14, Code of Federal Regulations, and such other regulations as appropriate, to permit flight operations with speeds above Mach 1 at or above the minimum altitude identified under section 1011 without specific authorization, provided that such flight operations—
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                        id="H3E70573C1AF3462997C4FCB093BD0CB0"
                        qb-display-quote="yes">
               (1)
               show compliance with airworthiness requirements;
            
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                        id="HD6B24EA154394482B4E2B4AA9D1E1109"
                        qb-display-quote="yes">
               (2)
               do not produce appreciable sonic boom overpressures that reach the surface under prevailing atmospheric conditions; 
            
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                        id="H681C6C6B4C9648E7AB2E218C3AC25A01"
                        qb-display-quote="yes">
               (3)
               have ordinary instrument flight rules clearances necessary to operate in controlled airspace; and
            
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                        id="H092A93D371C54CB2A560E4C06D4F5F10"
                        qb-display-quote="yes">
               (4)
               comply with applicable environmental requirements.
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H68C0E316FA7544B688B743C78DF80C19"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            1109.
            FAA LEADERSHIP IN HYDROGEN AVIATION
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H99CE8CAE5DA0430AB3AC51D5CDDA5B4D"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               The Administrator shall exercise leadership in the development of Federal regulations, standards, best practices, and guidance relating to the safe and efficient certification of the use of hydrogen in civil aviation, including the certification of hydrogen-powered commercial aircraft.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HDEFE3B88CCEB400CADE955DAD5F22FCB"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Exercise of leadership
               In carrying out subsection (a), the Administrator shall—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H6E3C9A5347C84C42B55F1A5ED718006B"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  develop a viable path for the certification of the safe use of hydrogen in civil aviation, including hydrogen-powered aircraft, that considers existing frameworks, modifying an existing framework, or developing new standards, best practices, or guidance to complement the existing frameworks, as appropriate;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="HA87DFAB3A97042CBA65B98975A57A34B"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  review certification regulations, guidance, and other requirements of the FAA to identify ways to safely and efficiently certify hydrogen-powered commercial aircraft;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H78F0B4245DB74E51A2EC85C1DF624759"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  consider the needs of the aerospace industry, aviation suppliers, hydrogen producers, airlines, airport sponsors, fixed base operators, and other stakeholders when developing regulations and standards that enable the safe certification and deployment of the use of hydrogen in civil aviation, including hydrogen-powered commercial aircraft, in the national airspace system; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H78E9925113E1482E978AEEFC05ACCABB"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  obtain the input of the aerospace industry, aviation suppliers, hydrogen producers, airlines, airport sponsors, fixed base operators, academia, research institutions, and other stakeholders regarding—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HD8B4255002814AFAB515DFAFBAAE612C"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     an appropriate regulatory framework and timeline for permitting the safe and efficient use of hydrogen in civil aviation, including the deployment and operation of hydrogen-powered commercial aircraft in the United States, which may include updating or modifying existing regulations;
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H7D1C0B441D484AC29B9A78B7C9306B68"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     how to accelerate the resolution of issues related to data, standards development, and related regulations necessary to facilitate the safe and efficient certification of the use of hydrogen in civil aviation, including hydrogen-powered commercial aircraft; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H2C4557BC80D44979A52C2DCE2CB1779B"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (C)
                     other issues identified and determined appropriate by the Administrator or the advisory committee established under section 1019(d)(7) to be addressed to enable the safe and efficient use of hydrogen in civil aviation, including the deployment and operation of hydrogen-powered commercial aircraft.
                  
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H6F8C525BFC3B4F918516864D1D651EF7"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            1110.
            ADVANCING GLOBAL LEADERSHIP ON CIVIL SUPERSONIC AIRCRAFT
            Section 181 of the FAA Reauthorization Act of 2018 (49 U.S.C. 40101 note) is amended—
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                        id="H4953B96C04CF48B29E2B0F03B1E26ED0"
                        qb-display-quote="yes">
               (1)
               in subsection (a) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">regulations, and standards and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">regulations, standards, and recommended practices; and
            
            <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                        id="H94FCDF15833647169BD627C7FA78B526"
                        qb-display-quote="yes">
               (2)
               by adding at the end the following new subsection:
               <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                              display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              display-quotes="yes"
                              id="H43465EA96ABD4F5781F1F5037473C784"
                              style="OLC">
                  <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                               id="HA0C67E56386445ABAA5AF1E9444B99BB"
                               qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (g)
                     Additional reports
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HAC011EF6A08B43898BD2C21A8BD3C2B7"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (1)
                        Initial progress report
                        Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this subsection, the Administrator shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report describing—
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="HF895FB608CCD41B898DB8E1AD1CC2EC4"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (A)
                           the progress of the actions described in subsection (d)(1);
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H341FF9E24F804C2F8BA4388632081675"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (B)
                           any planned, proposed, or anticipated action to update or modify existing policies and regulations related to civil supersonic aircraft, including such actions identified as a result of stakeholder consultation and feedback (such as landing and takeoff noise); and
                        
                        <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                       id="H1D3A9D4EE7634B48B7F2E6DDCAB9A109"
                                       qb-display-quote="yes">
                           (C)
                           any other information determined appropriate by the Administrator.
                        
                     
                     <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H5D6E61B0C84A45FEAB52DC39511B1FAD"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (2)
                        Subsequent report
                        Not later than 2 years after the date on which the Administrator submits the initial progress report under paragraph (1), the Administrator shall update the report described in paragraph (1) and submit to the appropriate committees of Congress such report.
                     
                  
                  .
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HC6D8B2C1C14F48CF87F4DD9F1AE49E38"

            1111.
            LEARNING PERIOD
            Section 50905(c)(9) of title 51, United States Code, is amended by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                       quote-display-start="auto"

         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H7DD37C6D106748D89E071BC7B7142B26"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            1112.
            COUNTER-UAS AUTHORITIES
            Section 210G(i) of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 (6 U.S.C. 124n(i)) is amended by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                       quote-display-start="auto"
                       quote-type="text">May 11, 2024 and inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                       quote-display-start="auto"
                       quote-type="text">October 1, 2024.
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H4B669613999446F7933CFB64DA52A7B2"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            1113.
            STUDY ON AIR CARGO OPERATIONS
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H5D91099304234602B7E80FA4081794B6"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Comptroller General shall initiate a study on the economic sustainability of air cargo operations.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HCCD6BD9A54EB40588362A726B3052342"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Contents
               In conducting the study required under subsection (a), the Comptroller General shall address the following:
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H7B081FE045AC455A845744EC951B0F38"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  Airport and cargo development strategies, including the pursuit of new air carriers and plans for physical expansion.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H6F35A1B2256A4259BFB8228813C6D1C7"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Key historical statistics for passenger, cargo volumes, including freight, express, and mail cargo, and operations, including statistics distinguishing between passenger and freight operations.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H2E6B9390562A49A5B5D81A560D292642"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  A description of air cargo facilities, including the age and condition of such facilities and the square footage and configuration of the landside and airside infrastructure of such facilities, and cargo buildings.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H93F9477637704D72958A7BCFDFF19002"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (4)
                  The projected square footage deficit of the cargo facilities and infrastructure described in paragraph (3).
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H7D1143E1731845B89E1F878773B4C3FB"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (5)
                  The projected requirements and square footage deficit for air cargo support facilities.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H426CA3C266BC46378F94D56E1115B39C"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (6)
                  The general physical and operating issues and constraints associated with air cargo operations.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H611B5D64DFCA476E8FFD160A4560144E"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (7)
                  A description of delays in truck bays associated with the infrastructure and critical landside issues, including truck maneuvering and queuing and parking for employees and customers.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H424893EE4DD74A68A5B6C9E083E56D35"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (8)
                  The estimated cost of developing new cargo facilities and infrastructure, including the identification of percentages for development with a return on investment and without a return on investment.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H70304FA7F88A44B6A9E12195CC3E00DE"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (9)
                  The projected leasing costs to tenants per square foot with and without Federal funding of the non-return on investment allocation.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H05CDA12264594C5A8B580C5B8297AC67"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (10)
                  A description of customs and general staffing issues associated with air cargo operations and the impacts of such issues on service.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H0F2BD0130B8F4E148A2D361E3504FC87"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (11)
                  An assessment of the impact, cost, and estimated cost savings of using modern comprehensive communications and technology systems in air cargo operations.
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H55D20C14621545CC84B43989BDCAAB7B"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (12)
                  A description of the impact of Federal regulations and local enforcement of interdiction and facilitation policies on throughput.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H25B9EB9ED21D4A5185885AB8669BF6C0"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Report
               The Comptroller General shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress the results of the study carried out under this section.
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H2A9FE265F58F4F2B85E18F5C698778B2"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            1114.
            WING-IN-GROUND-EFFECT CRAFT
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H11F5BCF5F29540C7A93C61BEF542038E"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Memorandum of understanding
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H9A0C541528094F999FF97EA1E1548E4D"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  In general
                  Not later than 24 months after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator and the Commandant of the Coast Guard shall execute a memorandum of understanding governing the specific roles, authorities, delineations of responsibilities, resources, and commitments of the FAA and the Coast Guard, respectively, pertaining to wing-in-ground-effect craft that are—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H2CD986B20CBE4A369182CBDB3C0E3436"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     only capable of operating either in water or in ground effect over water; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H494B88D8077049A9AB3165820260733A"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     operated exclusively over waters subject to the jurisdiction of the United States.
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H32716BA7C43E4C15AA40DB40C8F3BBDF"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Contents
                  The memorandum of understanding described in paragraph (1) shall—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HACFBA49A991B4F9FB422B1247F081CAD"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     cover, at a minimum, the processes of the FAA and the Coast Guard will follow to promote communications, efficiency, and nonduplication of effort in carrying out such memorandum of understanding; and
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HC429B292332947A7805DE365DE9DEBCD"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     provide procedures for, at a minimum—
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HBFB69C6D0716442B87645C64270D3F2D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (i)
                        the approval of wing-in-ground-effect craft designs;
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HF01458745BB24B0FAF89FA20020E461D"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (ii)
                        the operation of wing-in-ground-effect craft, including training and certification of persons responsible for operating such craft;
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HAA919E637D2C44CDA6D5DD75E061D6B5"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (iii)
                        pilotage of wing-in-ground-effect craft;
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HBE1819FD7BCD4B72B8BF490871D6352C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (iv)
                        the inspection, including pre-delivery and service, of wing-in-ground-effect craft; and
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HE3A5570400E944618EC701858CA4F20C"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (v)
                        the maintenance of wing-in-ground-effect craft.
                     
                  
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H3741E24522AE4FC490B63AA6DD65DC81"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Status briefing
               Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Administrator and the Commandant shall brief the appropriate committees of Congress on the status of the memorandum of understanding described in subsection (a) as well as provide any recommendations for legislative action to improve efficacy or efficiency of wing-in-ground-effect craft governance.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HAFED0E23380842A897319A3000297B05"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Wing-in-ground-effect craft defined
               In this section, the term <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">wing-in-ground-effect craft means a craft that is capable of operating completely above the surface of the water on a dynamic air cushion created by aerodynamic lift due to the ground effect between the craft and the surface of the water.
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HCBD3F30B81AB4F7091EA9703F0D0F739"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            1115.
            CERTIFICATES OF AUTHORIZATION OR WAIVER
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H1C87B90B6C6541078D3F8749AF382F97"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               Required coordination
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H8D4D3FEBFA61485495B6449B71350F84"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  In general
                  On an annual basis, the Administrator shall convene a meeting with representatives of FAA-approved air shows, the general aviation community, stadiums and other large outdoor events and venues or organizations that run such events, the Department of Homeland Security, and the Department of Justice—
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="H566EF8D10A9E4AEBA17E45F1ACE450F5"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (A)
                     to identify scheduling conflicts between FAA-approved air shows and large outdoor events and venues where—
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H672A4BFB99D24E2FB7608190DD8B2484"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (i)
                        flight restrictions will be imposed pursuant to section 521 of division F of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2004 (49 U.S.C. 40103 note); or
                     
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H5E93AD6607F54C71AA3D8C9FA48970F9"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (ii)
                        any other restriction will be imposed pursuant to FAA Flight Data Center Notice to Airmen 4/3621 (or any successor notice to airmen); and
                     
                  
                  <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 id="HD265054E265048BBA41E6F9A5DB74A38"
                                 qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (B)
                     in instances where a scheduling conflict between events is identified or is found to be likely to occur, develop appropriate operational and communication procedures to ensure for the safety and security of both events.
                  
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H6BCABD462133428593EFC730FAEF0585"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  Scheduling conflict
                  If the Administrator or any other stakeholder party to the required annual coordination required in paragraph (1) identifies a scheduling conflict outside of the annual meeting at any point prior to the scheduling conflict, the Administrator shall work with impacted stakeholders to develop appropriate operational and communication procedures to ensure for the safety and security of both events.
               
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H237352BF8CA94A3091ED121B9EEFE47A"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Operational purposes
               Section 521(a)(2)(B) of division F of the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2004 (49 U.S.C. 40103 note) is amended—
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H2082567A81D741F8A0ADD3548ECDCF24"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (1)
                  in clause (ii) by inserting <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">(or attendees approved by) after <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">guests of;
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H29C36C84BC8748FABA376DC3F6B3A9FB"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (2)
                  in clause (iv) by striking <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                             quote-display-start="auto"
                             quote-type="text">and at the end; and
               
               <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           id="H10E4F8504B744960B7AA91960AD78F8A"
                           qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (3)
                  by adding at the end the following: 
                  <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                                 display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                 display-quotes="yes"
                                 id="H3AD6490D72BF4F41B37FEBDDE6E067EB"
                                 style="OLC">
                     <clause display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="H26B5BC35C4054475B51ADB0545CF3194"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                        (vi)
                        to permit the safe operation of an aircraft that is operated by an airshow performer in connection with an airshow, provided such aircraft is not permitted to operate directly over the stadium (or adjacent parking facilities) during the sporting event; and
                     
                     .
                  
               
            
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HE4F4B3A81E614126BFFAC2E55AEED8CD"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            1116.
            DESIGNATION OF ADDITIONAL PORT OF ENTRY FOR THE IMPORTATION AND EXPORTATION OF WILDLIFE AND WILDLIFE PRODUCTS BY THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H1D4A3C42CBE6450EBE59C45B03F36177"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (a)
               In general
               Subject to the availability of funding and in accordance with subsection (b), the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service shall designate 1 additional port as a <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                          quote-display-start="auto"
                          quote-type="text">port of entry designated for the importation and exportation of wildlife and wildlife products under section 14.12 of title 50, Code of Federal Regulations.
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="HDEC6B01EF27842AF93B3C1193FC36290"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (b)
               Criteria for selecting additional designated port
               The Director shall select the additional port to be designated pursuant to subsection (a) from among the United States airports that handled more than 8,000,000,000 pounds of cargo during 2022, as reported by the Federal Aviation Administration Air Carrier Activity Information System, and based upon the analysis submitted to Congress by the Director pursuant to the Wildlife Trafficking reporting directive under title I of Senate Report 114–281. 
            
            <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                         id="H3062988A7EEA49A88251A1D80A8AEBD9"
                         qb-display-quote="yes">
               (c)
               Authority to accept donations
               The Director may accept donations from private entities and, notwithstanding section 3302 of title 31, United States Code, may use those donations to fund the designation of the additional port pursuant to subsection (a).
            
         
      
      <title id="H18A823DBA62D4A7BACB8589AB7024F68"
              qb-display-quote="yes"
              style="OLC">
         XII
         NATIONAL TRANSPORTATION SAFETY BOARD
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="HEA496368B0624CEB8CF0624E87FB1B9F"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            1201.
            SHORT TITLE
            This title may be cited as the <quote quote-display-end="auto"
                       quote-display-start="auto"
                       quote-type="text">National Transportation Safety Board Amendments Act of 2024.
         
         <section display-inline="no-display-inline"
                   id="H7C8693A2E4B34375998F3A28AA065366"
                   qb-display-quote="yes"
                   section-type="subsequent-section">
            1202.
            AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS
            Section 1118(a) of title 49, United States Code, is amended to read as follows: 
            <quoted-block display-end-quotes="yes"
                           display-inline="no-display-inline"
                           display-quotes="yes"
                           id="H4F7B724F370A45548A2B637AC87BAC89"
                           style="OLC">
               <subsection display-inline="no-display-inline"
                            id="HA4738106F05143B789E2CA0D9D18DEB5"
                            qb-display-quote="yes">
                  (a)
                  In general
                  <paragraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                              id="HED6C6003E4B942DC9E4A68F6BCD06630"
                              qb-display-quote="yes">
                     (1)
                     Authorizations
                     There is authorized to be appropriated for purposes of this chapter—
                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="H08861BC9F5274D77B527EB81B919A8AF"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">

                                    id="H85063FE7F72A4399B112661A39EF942B"
                                    qb-display-quote="yes">

                     <subparagraph display-inline="no-display-inline"
                                    id="HA18085FF4CE248198F8AE795B5A666F5"

                              qb-display-quote="yes">
